webTitle: French view on tabloids, yobs and hopeless refs

fields.headline: French view on tabloids, yobs and hopeless refs
fields.trailText: His Excellency Daniel Bernard knows who are the real French ambassadors are in this country: footballers.
fields.body:
The French ambassador in London, His Excellency Daniel Bernard, owns a Chelsea shirt with the name and number 'Bernard 99' on the back. It was a gift last year from one of his friends from Stamford Bridge, Frank Leboeuf, and he is fond of it, although he is far too tactful to claim any bias to Chelsea, being obliged to follow the fortunes of the ever-increasing legion of Frenchmen making waves all over Britain. These days, with enough French players here to form two complete teams plus subs, there is a lot for him to watch over.

Bernard makes it his business to forge close contacts with the men who, to English eyes, represent France in a way that he never could. He calls footballers, with their huge star status and profile, the new ambassadors. He remembers how Betty Boothroyd, receiving President Chirac at the House of Commons, expressed how glad she was to meet the second most famous Frenchman in Britain. And who, he responded, was the first?

Eric Cantona.

Bernard is still amazed by the fact this enigma of a player managed to inspire thousands of Englishmen at Old Trafford to sing La Marseillaise. Cantona is a key figure in trying to unravel the contradictory attitude the English have towards French footballers, who are at once adored and admired, hounded and harangued.

'There are mixed feelings towards the French,' agrees Bernard. 'On the one hand people are attracted by the exotic and the Mediterranean style of football, which has brought something spectacular to English football. On the other they are a bit annoyed that the Nordic tradition has not yet found the solution to overcome it.

'I appreciate also that young English players might have their progress stopped by the presence of imported stars - although it must be said it is not only the French who come here - and there may be some resentment against that. In the long run it might not be good for English football.

'The fact French footballers are successful here makes them admired and liked but also triggers jealousy. That is a human reaction. It is not helped by the tabloid newspapers, who take a particular delight in adapting the clichés and preconceived ideas they have of France. Either they are musketeers or they are scoundrels.

'Where does it come from? The first one was Cantona, who had a very contrasting image - the God and the villain - but he was an outstanding player. Cantona showed to the football society here that there are other ways of playing football. Then came Ginola, who was not only a quality player but also a sexy star who could attract the attention of the ladies. Then a whole series of French players came. I can only rejoice to see so many French players in England because most of them give a really positive image of France. I am in contact with most of them because they have so much weight on public opinion. Besides,' he adds, 'they are very nice guys.'

He is proud to note that it is not just the major attractions who are working here; other professionals are making also an impression, like West Ham's Marc Keller and the Newcastle pair Didier Domi and Alain Goma. Although uprooting to make a living and a life in a foreign country is always challenging, with culture clashes to overcome, he says that all the players he has spoken to are welcomed with kindness in their English neighbourhoods. 'Although some, when they are on the pitch, don't receive the same welcome as others,' he adds.

As a football aficionado (his attache's attempts to feed him some information before this interview were rejected as unnecessary) Bernard understands that the topic of the moment is Patrick Vieira. He reels off statistics comparing his saintly disciplinary record for France compared to the Premiership.

'I saw the game and the red cards,' he says. 'First of all football has become such an enormous business that people must be very careful it remains a game within strict limits of courtesy or fair play. Referees, and their decisions, must be respected. Secondly Vieira is a very nice guy. I know him well. He is awfully talented, charming, strong like an ox, and in a position where he has to do a difficult job. A midfielder does not win the ball with only caresses. Paul Ince and Roy Keane are not angels either, they do not do it with flowers. Three, he is a hot-tempered guy and he must work on his tendency to boil up like this. Four, one wonders if, having acquired this image, he is not a target of some provocation by other players or particular care by referees.'

Perhaps, I venture, the ambassador could help by teaching Vieira some diplomatic skills. Bernard smiles to himself. 'I don't think you can recover the ball with diplomacy.'

webTitle: Don't blame refs for red card rage

fields.headline: Don't blame refs for red card rage
fields.standfirst: This red rage is farcical. Stop slagging refs when it's players who are at fault, says Gordon Strachan
fields.trailText: This red rage is farcical. Stop slagging refs when it's players who are at fault.
fields.body:
If any proof was needed about English football being capable of doing strange things to people, it is surely the fact that even a foreign manager with the laid-back, urbane image of Arsène Wenger has got caught up in the intensity of it.

The Football Association's action last week in charging Wenger with misconduct - over an alleged push on the fourth official in the dressing room tunnel after Arsenal's defeat at Sunderland last Saturday - is something nobody can have envisaged when he came to England three years ago. No less disconcerting, in view of the way Wenger has been perceived, is that his Arsenal players have been shown 31 red cards over this period.

English football is very competitive and has always been noted for its propensity to get overheated. Passion is important and I would hate to see it disappear from our game.

Even so, after a remarkable high-octane start to the season with eight red cards inside a week, including three in the Arsenal-Liverpool match in which Patrick Vieira was sent off for the second time in three days - and managers publicly lambasting the referees - there can be no doubt that it is at boiling point.

It is difficult to avoid the impression that, unless something is done to bring the temperature down, the game at the top level is going to explode. One calming effect would be for everybody concerned to show greater honesty.

For managers, that means not trying to publicly defend players who have been guilty of bad challenges and attempting to shift all the blame for bookings and sendings-off on to referees. Managers, while urging players to perform in a determined manner, must take on greater responsibility to help ensure that it is not taken to the extreme.

While referees cannot expect to avoid criticism - and I have hardly been a shrinking violet in this department in the past - we have reached the point where the criticism has become farcical.

All managers are quick to draw attention to instances of opposing players stepping out of line on the field, but we all tend to have a blind spot when it comes to recognising and owning up to cases of our own players doing so.

One reason is that being seen to support our players is an essential part of the job of getting the best out of them. This particularly applies to the star players, who generally wield greater power than ever before. A number of them needed to be handled more carefully than their counterparts during my own playing career. In some cases, just one managerial word out of place is enough for them to down tools - a situation that few clubs can truly afford. So there is a tendency for managers to treat them with kid gloves.

I am not suggesting this applies to Arsène Wenger at Arsenal - the manner in which he does his job is none of my business anyway. But when it comes to managers publicly backing members of their teams who are sent off, Wenger is seen as being among those at the top of the list.

The subject has again been brought into sharp focus by the recent complaints by Chelsea's Frank Leboeuf that his manager, Gianluca Vialli, did not defend him over his red card for stamping on Harry Kewell in last season's match against Leeds.

For me, Leboeuf's attitude was strange to say the least. I cannot see how any manager could have defended him for that without making himself look a fool.

It has been the same story with me concerning the Coventry players who have recently been sent off. David Burrows, John Aloisi and David Thompson all deserved to be shown the red card; and it is refreshing to me that all have been honest enough with themselves to acknowledge it.

David was sent off twice last season for catching an opponent in the face with his hand. He had run the risk of that happening for some time because he had picked up the Paul Gascoigne habit of throwing his arms out to hold off an opponent when running with the ball. We kept saying to him: 'Keep your arms down - if you don't you'll run into problems with referees.'

When it happened, I did not have a go at David publicly. But nor did I say: 'Oh, he was unlucky - the other player's face got in the way of his fist.'

In some ways, though, the present so-called 'red rage' nature of Premiership matches does give a slightly misleading picture.

While I have seen some dodgy challenges, I would say that this aspect of the English game is nothing like as bad as it was in the Sixties and Seventies. And in terms of blatant physical intimidation, the players most likely to be on the receiving end, the ones known to have a short fuse, get more protection than ever from referees.

One change - and it is something I have been reminded of through the view that Vieira is deliberately provoked by opponents - is that teams can no longer get away with using a 'rota' system to commit early fouls on such players.

At one time, a defender was rarely booked for his first foul on a player and it was not unusual for that player to be clogged by three different men without the referee taking action against any of them.

My own experience of how it worked came in a match for Aberdeen against Airdrie, when someone kicked me on the ankle in the first 10 minutes, inflicting a wound that needed six stitches. The offender immediately looked at the referee and reminded him: 'First one, ref.'

'OK then,' the official replied. 'But don't do it again.' If that had happened today, the player would have been booked straight away.

I also have to make the point, however, that intimidatory tactics - provided they are within the laws - are an important part of the game. I have lost count of the number of players who tried to provoke me into doing something rash during my career, and was not averse to indulging in this myself.

You have to exploit opposition weaknesses - and if one of those weaknesses concerns a player not being able to control his emotions, I see nothing wrong with the general principle of trying to exploit it.

I must also point out that it is inevitable that there should be highly-charged physical confrontations at this stage of the season, when the adrenalin levels of the players are probably at their highest. All teams like to think they give 100 per cent commitment throughout the season, but it seems to me that immediately after the recharging of batteries in the summer, there is always a danger of that commitment being allowed to run out of control in the opening weeks.

At Coventry experienced the problems of this high-octane factor in last Saturday's home defeat by Middlesbrough. We badly wanted to get off to a good start and some of our players allowed their frustration to get the better of them. One was Thompson, who was sent off for an impetuous tackle; others included John Eustace, whom we substituted because he seemed in danger of attracting the same fate.

I was pleased that we showed so much passion, but as I said to the players: 'We don't want you to show it by losing your rag and doing something silly - that's no good to us. We want you to show it by running faster and jumping higher. You have got to stay focused.'

I like to think that this will happen not just at Coventry, but at all the other teams who have been involved in refereeing aggro during this crazy start to the season.

But before that can happen, we all have to start being more honest.

fields.headline: Inter deserve to fail
fields.trailText: Supporters of Inter Milan are in a state of shock following their Champions League defeat to Helsingborg, but the club's problem lies right at the top: il presidente.
fields.body:
When the Inter Milan party arrived in the port of Helsingborg earlier this month, they were surprised to discover they were in Sweden. They had thought Helsingborg was in Denmark. Perhaps confused by this, they lost the match, a Champions League qualifier, by 1-0. In the return in the San Siro on Wednesday, the Swedes kept Inter scoreless for 89 minutes. Then, inevitably, Inter were given a penalty. This, everyone understood, would take them into the Champions League.

'Will you take it?' Luigi di Biagio asked his Uruguayan team-mate Alvaro Recoba. Recoba did. But a Swedish keeper with the evocative name of Sven Andersson saved his shot. The match ended 0-0, and Helsingborg are in the Champions League.

The Italians, who in August turn into a sort of one-family holiday, are treating the result as a shock. In fact, there was nothing more logical than that Inter should lose to Helsingborg. Inter regularly lose to Swedish teams, and have long since ceased to be a big club. In 20 years they have won just one Italian title, and in the history of the Champions League they have qualified only once.

This is despite spending probably more money than any other club in the world in recent years. Inter exist to give hope to the little man. The problem is their president, Massimo Moratti. The Italian club president is a phenomenon without a British equivalent: typically, a grey-haired figure in a long blue coat with an entourage of thousands who funds, rules, and virtually is his club. Men like Gianni Agnelli of Juventus, Milan's Silvio Berlusconi and Lazio's Sergio Cragnotti are fawned upon as the Queen Mother is here.

Players regularly pledge to regain form or win a game for 'il presidente'. Ronaldo, Inter's injured striker, says: 'I will remain with Moratti forever.' Nwankwo Kanu, who barely played in his time at Inter, still calls Moratti 'my Italian father'. Javier Zanetti says Moratti is 'a great gentleman' to whom he, Zanetti, owes everything. Yet Moratti has achieved almost nothing.

He was born to be president of Inter. The son of Angelo Moratti, who ran the club from 1955 to 1968, Massimo grew up watching the great Inter side that with judicious bribes to referees won two European Cups. Later Massimo inherited the family oil business, Saras, and in 1995 bought his Dad's old club for only £20 million. That's when the trouble began.

Moratti's acolytes say he buys like a fan. Rather, he buys like a Japanese teenager in a clothes shop on Milan's Via Spiga, grabbing everything with a brand name. He has signed Ronaldo, Kanu, Roberto Baggio, Christian Vieri, Clarence Seedorf, Hakan Sukur, Robbie Keane and countless others. If you have lost track of a footballer, the likelihood is that he has been forgotten in a dusty office drawer at Inter. This week's purchase was the Brazilian Vampeta, his arrival no doubt connected with two much-televised goals he scored recently against Argentina. Moratti says: 'You can never have enough skilful players.' By one estimate, he has spent almost £300 million on Inter.

He has, admittedly, had rotten luck. Ronaldo's knees and Kanu's heart suddenly revealed flaws, while even the massive Vieri, once an Australian fast bowler, got injured. Ronaldo expects to spend the autumn in Beverton, Oregon and is at least a year away from a return.

But Moratti deserves his misfortune. He has a particular penchant for big-name players whom other clubs won't touch, like Seedorf and Sukur.

Moreover, he unsettles his players by buying new ones for the same position days later, or by revealing during the season who will be released at the end. He has gone through eight managers in five years, with another tipped to replace Lippi before the Italian season starts on 1 October.

At Juventus, the Agnellis let their coach make the decisions. Moratti hires Lippi, Italy's most respected coach, lauds him as 'a man of character, a Tuscan', and then proceeds to buy cartloads of players and state publicly where they should play. So Seedorf arrived from Real Madrid in January, was apparently offered for sale last week, and was this week voted, by thousands of diehard Inter fans in a poll on the club website, best player of the Helsingborg match. Inter, apparently, have yet to pay his transfer fee.

Other presidents - Berlusconi at Inter and Cragnotti at Lazio - interfere with transfers too. But they have had a happier touch, which suggests that given enough money even the average fan can buy a winning team. It's really not that difficult.

On Wednesday a Swedish journalist asked Lippi whether the defeat was a catastrophe for Inter. 'You are a Swede?' Lippi replied. 'Well, then think of the good things for your team, and not the bad things for ours. These are our matters, and I don't see how they could interest you.'

What, indeed, of Helsingborg? Their victory has tickled the Swedish sense of humour. 'Hilarious,' says a club official, who recounts that when the team returned home from Milan at 5am on Thursday, two fans had turned out to greet them. Neither one was from Helsingborg itself, but the players were chuffed none the less. They are struggling in the Swedish league, so it was nice to beat Inter.

Neither one was from Helsingborg itself, but the players were chuffed none the less. They are struggling in the Swedish league, so it was nice to beat Inter.

fields.headline: Keegan's street cred
fields.standfirst: As the France match looms, England's manager declares his team a criticism-free zone
fields.trailText: As the France match looms, England's manager has declared his team a criticism-free zone.
fields.body:
A friendly against France was what propelled Kevin Keegan into international management, England's performance in a 2-0 defeat at Wembley being so dire that even the FA felt obliged to move swiftly to draw a line under Howard Wilkinson's caretakership. Eighteen months of non-improvement later, the now-beleaguered Keegan travels to Paris on Saturday more fearful of symmetry than of the world and European champions.

The feeling is growing that a bad result at the Stade de France could see the end of Keegan's reign. Of course it would make no sense to change the manager with only a month until important World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland, but that might not stop the newly ruthless FA seizing the opportunity presented by another lacklustre display to call a halt to Keegan's unequal struggle.

Better to act decisively, for better or worse, the argument goes, than to jeopardise World Cup qualification through misplaced loyalty. Better in that case to have acted straight after England's miserable Euro 2000, as did several more successful nations, but perhaps that would have come too close to admitting they made a mistake in the first place.

Certainly Keegan himself appears to have seen through the public votes of confidence and the supposedly solid support for him from Geoff Thompson downwards. 'I've had tremendous support from inside the FA, from Adam Crozier, David Davies and everybody, but that is not going to keep me in the job,' he said. 'The only thing that will keep me England manager to the end of my contract is results.'

At his press conference to announce his wholly unsurprising squad for France, Keegan was tense to an extent not seen since his final days at Newcastle. Gone was any pretence of enjoying the job or looking forward to the next challenge. In between sniping at individual journalists for a variety of misdemeanours including coughing, expressing pessimism and suggesting he had fallen out with Andy Cole, Keegan grimly stated he had no intention of resigning and would have to be sacked. He also claimed that although England failed at Euro 2000, the German failure was greater, and suggested the media were responsible for making the situation look graver than it actually is.

Keegan then casually announced that the 38-year-old Stuart Pearce would come straight back into contention as soon as he was match fit, so you must make up your own minds on the gravity of the situation.

It was not a media invention either when Keegan suggested Italy (three wins out of three in the group stage and within seconds of winning the final) had been slightly lucky to avoid England. 'Italy weren't playing that much better than us but they got through, that's the difference,' he said. 'We were only two minutes away from getting through to a quarter-final against Italy.'

Glenn Hoddle was fond of this sort of revisionism, though at least his side went out of the last World Cup playing well. Keegan accepts his side played badly, though appears to resent anyone saying so. 'I don't think the press should be allowed to take away the confidence of the national side all the time,' he said.

One could be facetious here, and observe that one or two England defenders are capable of doing that all by themselves, but it is probably best not to argue the point. 'The criticism we received at Euro 2000 was justified,' Keegan said. 'But I don't accept criticism from journalists who have never played the game. If Gary Lineker wants to have a go at Alan Shearer, well at least he's played in big games and he knows what goes on. I'll accept it more from professional pundits. I won't accept it from journalists who don't know what the game is all about, who sit up in the stand and see the game totally differently.'

Fair enough. Keegan is not the first football manager to feel that way and he won't be the last. But someone should have a quiet word with him to the effect that journalists aren't the only people who sit and watch and see things differently from the way managers see them. The vast majority of football spectators, whether on the terraces or at home on the sofa, have never played at international level. The journalists are merely the ones with a platform to air their opinions.

And if Keegan is going to be so dismissive of journalists' opinions, it is odd that he sets so much store by those of the general public. 'People in the street have been very supportive,' he said. 'The only pessimism around is among you people. The people I meet are right behind us, they wish me good luck and believe we can win.'

This street of Keegan's must contain the petrol station Hoddle used to pop into for fill-ups of confidence, for he always used to report the same sort of reaction. It is comforting to know that old-fashioned English politeness is still alive and well, though Keegan would be well-advised to think less of his personal popularity factor and concentrate on his team. As he says, if you get it right on the football pitch the press can't really hurt you.

To that end, Keegan has been considering playing David Beckham in central midfield (though he is more likely to stick with Paul Scholes) and switching to a back three, though all bets on England's new formation are off until the damage from this weekend's Premiership fixtures has been surveyed.

Darren Anderton could be on the right or left wing, ditto Nick Barmby, and Keegan would like to start with Steven Gerrard in midfield. Keegan has admitted that Cole is now at his peak, so if he doesn't play there will be trouble. None of these is exactly a new face, but post-Shearer, post-Euro 2000, all have a chance to make a fresh start.

'It's more or less the same squad, but there are a lot of options within it,' Keegan said. 'I probably feel the same way as Sir Alex Ferguson about bringing David Beckham inside, I just wish there were two of him so that we could still have the service from the right, but I don't feel the time is right yet to make wholesale changes.

'Everybody is talking about the new Germany, but in fact their squad against Spain contained 16 from Euro 2000. You just try to put right what went wrong, without disrupting the whole squad.

'People accuse me of not bringing any youngsters in, but they are in already. I took six players out of the under 21s [Barry, Dyer, Ferdinand, Gerrard, Heskey and Owen] and that's probably why Howard's team didn't do better in their competition. The next generation is already growing up with England, and they can only be better for the experience.'

webTitle: 'The game is simply too quick for one referee'

fields.headline: 'The game is simply too quick for one referee'
fields.trailText: Let's bring in professional referees and a new white card for technical offences.
fields.body:
'Here's an idea for a TV show, Greg. No, wait, here's the pitch. Just go with this.

'We get the top 10 referees in the country and put them in a 'safe' house. We let them out for the weekend, under escort - they'll need that these days - to take charge of Premiership games. On Monday they analyse tapes of each other's performances. On Tuesday, we get them into a private video diary room to nominate which two they want thrown out.

'From Tuesday to Thursday we spy on the insecurity, back-stabbing and ego-preening on a webcam and package the highlights nightly. Then on Friday, we get the public to vote on which ref should be kicked out of the Premiership. The 0898 revenue would be huge. Hell, one day we could even make it pay-per-voyeur. Could go out just before the 10 o'clock news, to get the crossover ratings.

'What do you mean it sounds like Big Brother, Greg? This would be public service broadcasting, for Chrissakes.'

Dontcha just love football these days in all its mad, knockabout guises, with 90 minutes of action (no, he's holding up 15 minutes of stoppage time) lasting a week?

Consistency is what we need, say the managers. So after a summer at Euro 2000 of lauding referees for common sense with cards - including the beleaguered Graham Poll, arbiter of the Arsenal v Liverpool red-rage match - Sir Alex Ferguson bemoans that yellow cards were not shown sooner in the Charity Shield. So it was Mike Riley's fault that Roy Keane stabbed his studs into Gustavo Poyet's calf, was it?

Then we have John Barnwell of the League Managers' Association praising Arsene Wenger and Gerard Houllier for their restraint and dignity in their response to Mr Poll - valid in this observer's opinion; after all we supposedly live in a freedom-of-speech country. What, though, has Mr Barnwell had to say after watching the Derby manager Jim Smith jab his finger into Dermot Gallagher's chest in midweek?

That kind of action is so much more damaging. In my experience, kids do not by and large ape the worst of professional players, except in some annoying celebrations of goals. But their misguided coaches do often think they are some kind of flash, brash Ron Knee figure. As with professionals, kids are set the wrong examples by managers who enable them to behave badly. Who fines managers two weeks' wages?

You want more consistency? Andy Gray on Sky is criticised by the England manager Kevin Keegan - a well-paid TV pundit himself, but not half so brave - for his analysis of red-card issues. This from a representative of the FA, who happily take the riches on offer from the game's favoured broadcaster.

The good thing about the last week is that it has raised many issues that need resolving about an English game ill at ease with itself, its self-image having slumped in the summer, and now bent on muscularly reasserting itself.

This quarter has always supported referees in their demanding role. They do not commit fouls after all; they are actually trying to encourage the ball-players and limit the amount of injuries which deny moaning managers the services of, and fans the pleasure of watching, the most skilful.

The time has come, however, to give referees some help. There has been some sound sense amid the hysteria this week. Glenn Hoddle suggests a third card and this column has argued before that a 'white card' for technical, non-violent offences such as shaping up to retaliate but being stopped, as happened to Patrick Vieira against Liverpool, would defuse much.

Since that match, Graham Poll has rescinded Dietmar Hamann's second yellow for some minor jostling (though he deserved a red for his 'challenge' before Vieira's dismissal) but Liverpool, then pressing for an equaliser, were reduced to nine men and conceded a second goal. How important will that be at the end of the season? A white card would have averted the injustice.

Then there is Arsene Wenger's belief in the two-referee system, also previously aired here. The game is simply too quick for one referee these days, especially at the start of a season. Privately, the Arsenal players were shocked by the fitness and condition of Steve Dunn at Sunderland eight days ago. If refs pass all the tests, players say, then the tests are not strict enough.

But they have assistants these days as well as fourth officials, say the authorities. Really? On the opening day at Nottingham Forest, a linesman - for that is what they really remain - gave the referee no help (ref struggling to keep up, lino in line), abdicating responsibility for the decision in a clear penalty for West Bromwich Albion. And where was the linesman last Monday when the corner that wasn't led to Arsenal's first goal?

These days, too, linesmen still struggle in level offside decisions, understandably given the cuteness of the timing of runs by the best strikers. Technology must come. Forget all the niggling caveats about stopping the game - it would actually increase the drama. Find ways of getting round the little problems to solve the big one.

Then fourth officials? I suppose someone has to hold up those boards for those 15 minutes of stoppage-time fame or report Arsene Wenger for the sort of tunnel dispute that used to take care of itself.

Professional referees must also come. The best will say that they don't know how much more professional they could be in their own training regimes but it would, at the least, earn them more respect from players, who, rightly or wrongly, see their week's work being undermined by a council clerk from Barnsley (er, sorry; the FA don't want referee's home towns to be listed any more, for security purposes).

This season, the FA have laudably agreed to the moving of the ball forward 10 yards if defenders do not immediately retreat. They have considerable influence on Fifa's International Board, which dictates the rules. They are well placed, given the problems of their domestic game, to extend the offer of experimentation further.

And there are smaller, shorter-term measures that might help. The PFA could, for instance, start making a Sportsman of the Year award in each division. If they won't, the Football Writers' Association certainly should, having lost sight of what our award is about in giving it to Roy Keane last season.

In the meantime, it would help if everybody relaxed a little and took responsibility for their own behaviour. Stoked by fortnight-long promotional tapes (using Dennis Wise, for goodness sake), fans champ at the bit, players emerge from fell running and meaningless friendlies like uncaged tigers. Weariness, and perspective, should creep in soon.

Remember, as they sing on a Friday night in the Big Brother household, that other tool to enliven the media dog days of August: it's only a game show.

fields.headline: Cloggers benefit
fields.trailText: The first couple of weeks of an English football season rarely fail to disappoint. Just when you think our over-hyped, over-paid and over-rated game cannot possibly spring any new surprises, you find yourself contemplating the saintly Gary McAllister being dismissed for the first time in his career on his Liverpool debut, or the monkish Arsène Wenger facing a fine for roughing up the fourth official at Sunderland.
fields.body:
The first couple of weeks of an English football season rarely fail to disappoint. Just when you think our over-hyped, over-paid and over-rated game cannot possibly spring any new surprises, you find yourself contemplating the saintly Gary McAllister being dismissed for the first time in his career on his Liverpool debut, or the monkish Arsène Wenger facing a fine for roughing up the fourth official at Sunderland.

One could add Patrick Vieira's tearfully melodramatic threat to leave if people don't stop picking on him, except we have seen this sort of behaviour before. Not just from Vieira, but from Emmanuel Petit, Eric Cantona and a few others who found it difficult to keep their emotions under control. What Vieira has to accept is that opposing managers will always try to exploit such a weakness in a key player, usually by sending out someone much less talented to try to get up his nose.

To justify his handsome wages, Vieira simply has to rise above it and behave like a professional. So does Wenger, who, instead of seeking refuge in Sky TV replays and Andy Gray's absurd self-importance, has a duty to acknowledge that his player lost his temper twice within three days. Winding up temperamental players is a trick as old as the game, and when it is not happening to their own star men, most managers don't see anything wrong with it.

The stakes have been raised significantly in recent years, however, by new guidelines to referees and stricter interpretation of dangerous play. This change was brought about by a desire to protect skilful players and encourage attackers, but the balance seems to be slipping back towards the cloggers and spoilers. If referees insist on sticking to the letter of the law and overlooking some fairly blatant examples of provocation, the scope is there for limited players to set out with the sole intention of getting leading players dismissed.

Vieira's sending-off at Sunderland was a case in point. The retaliation was mild, and Darren Williams did receive a caution in rather belated acknowledgment of his role as instigator, but Sunderland kept 11 men on the pitch while Arsenal went down to 10. Again, that would not have happened had Vieira kept his cool, and nor would Wenger's subsequent spot of unpleasantness, but referees who give the impression they read the game less well than the rulebook are only likely to inflame such situations.

Players are only human - referees just need to appear more so. Ask Peter Beardsley, who, judging by his brilliant deconstruction of the above controversy almost before it happened last week, is wasting his time as a Radio 5 Live summariser.

Send for the whistle and black shorts now, Peter. Your country needs you.

fields.headline: Barclays to bid for Friends
fields.standfirst: Insurer approached over £4bn deal; Bank 'wants to plug key gap';  Abbey could make rival offer
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank is understood to have made a £4 billion-plus bid approach to Friends Provident, Britain's second biggest mutual life assurer.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank is understood to have made a £4 billion-plus bid approach to Friends Provident, Britain's second biggest mutual life assurer.

The move comes hot on the heels of the bank's £5.4bn agreed takeover of the Woolwich, aimed at lifting Barclays' presence in the mortgage market.

City sources say Barclays' new Canadian chief executive, Matt Barrett, is now keen to address swiftly the last big weakness in its portfolio: life insurance and pensions. The bank is apparently also interested in Equitable Life, but has not been shortlisted for the much smaller sale of Scottish Provident.

One Barclays' source said: 'It's a twin track approach, a double-header. It doesn't take a genius to work out the hole in our strategy now.'

Friends Provident stunned the industry last May by caving in to carpetbaggers with plans to demutualise next year. Publicly, it remains committed to a stock market flotation, which is likely to value it at up to £4.5bn, with windfalls of between £500 and £3,000 for members and policyholders. A company spokesman said talk of a bid approach was 'all rumour and speculation. Our intention is to remain independent.'

But with Abbey National also understood to be interested in Friends, the City believes the insurer's chief executive Keith Satchell will find it increasingly hard to resist a serious approach. Like Woolwich boss John Stewart, Satchell is known to be highly ambitious.

Already in the last two years Friends has taken over fund manager Ivory & Sime and quoted rival London & Manchester.

'If Friends are thinking ahead, they'll go for Barclays rather than Abbey National, because Abbey's vulnerable to a bid and Barclays is not,' one banking analyst said.

A takeover would lift Barclays' share of the life insurance market by 3 per cent to 5 per cent. Friends has 2 million policyholders and manages £38bn of funds.

Barclays wants to cross-sell life and pensions products more successfully to its 16 million customers after the Woolwich deal. Barrett has appointed Stewart as deputy chief executive and wants to inject further fresh blood.

This weekend the bank declined to comment on Friends. 'We are growing the business organically, but we wouldn't rule anything out if it met our criteria,' a Barclays' spokeswoman said.

The bank has talked to several quoted insurers in recent years, but baulked at paying the prices sought. With the Woolwich deal, Barclays has avoided the fate of NatWest, which fell to Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) after its shares collapsed following a planned £10bn takeover of Legal & General last year.

'Buying a mutual means Barclays could avoid paying too much [for] goodwill,' one City source said. 'Friends or Equitable would do, but Friends is a bigger deal.'

 Iain Robertson, RBS' UK banking director, has cashed in share options worth £2.26m, more than a third of his holdings. The sale, announced just before the market closed last Friday, is likely to hit RBS shares this week.

fields.headline: On target to achieve nothing
fields.standfirst: Goals imposed by authority hinder performance rather than improving it, argues  John Seddon
fields.trailText: Goals imposed by authority hinder performance rather than improving it, argues John Seddon
fields.body:
On a recent Radio 4 Today programme a Liberal Democrat spokesman was invited to criticise the Government's use of targets for managing the public sector. At last, I thought, someone is going to point out that targets don't get us what we want.

Alas, the spokesman could only suggest that they should be used better. The fact is that targets don't help us get to where we want to be. Worse, they actually obviate the possibility by making people focus on the wrong things. In the police force, schools, health service and local authorities targets are hindering performance rather than fostering improvement.

What I had hoped the spokesman would say was that the whole idea of targets is flawed - that their use in a hierarchical system engages people's ingenuity in managing the numbers instead of improving their methods. People's attention turns to being seen to meet the targets - fulfiling the bureaucratic requirements of reporting that which they have become 'accountable' for - at the expense of achieving the organisation's purpose.

In simple terms, all this effort constitutes and causes waste - inefficiency, poor service and, worst of all, low morale.

The notion of a target is plausible. In principle, there is nothing wrong with individuals having targets that they set themselves - lose weight, run further, earn more money. But targets in a hierarchical system are imposed with authority, by people who are generally detached from the work being carried out. Targets are therefore arbitrary. They may suit a plan, but they do not start from a knowledge of capability - what the system predictably achieves and why.

What the spokesman should have said was that instead of targets people need measures that lead to questions of method - 'How can we do this better?'

World-class organisations have already learned this lesson. They reject the traditional 'cost-production' model of management, under which managers are separated from work and make decisions based entirely on budgets.

To engage people in improvement world-class organisations use measures that relate to purpose, not budget, and which are taken over time, since they know that all performance exhibits variation. Because such measures draw people's attention to what is predictably being achieved and why, the nature of their discussions turns to method. Better measures are at the heart of a better way of managing. What would Taiichi Ohno, the architect of the Toyota Production System, the exemplar of world-class manufacturing, make of, for example, the Government's approach to improving the performance of the NHS?

Ministers say that capacity needs to be increased and so are investing significant extra resources. Ohno taught that Capacity equals work plus waste. By adding more resources, the Government intends the system to 'do more work', in Ohno's for mula. But he would insist that a better way of increasing capacity is to remove waste - adding resources to a wasteful system just compounds inefficiency.

Nor are 'waste-busting' initiatives much help in a system that is managed and measured with targets. The targets are a major cause of waste, consuming people's time in artificial activity and, worse, deflecting their attention from what they ought to be doing.

Ohno's insight is that waste can only be removed when managers learn to manage the overall flow of work rather than functions within it. This comes as no surprise to the people who do the work - some health authorities have radically improved the way they respond to patients conditions by re-designing their processes to cut out multiple visits and waiting. Simply, patients get what they need more quickly.

To the surprise of traditionally-minded 'production' managers - who assume that putting experts at the point of transaction with the patient will increase costs - this results in lower costs and improved service.

Unfortunately, these initiatives will often not show up in the Government's mea sures because they are based on flow, not measures of individual functions like numbers of operations or appointments - the things being targeted. To concentrate on function always impedes flow, a paradox that managers find difficult to come to terms with.

Government promises it will pay attention to 'the customer's experience' of the health service. Patients would rather they paid attention to how well the service treats and prevents disease. Patients and staff need neither charters, visions, values nor any of the rest of 'modern' management.

I had hoped that the spokesman would point out that the people who work in public services want to focus on their purpose. Doctors and nurses want to treat patients; police want to prevent and detect crime. They need help with measures and means, not cajoling to focus on arbitrary activities through hierarchical power. And I hoped he would have strengthened his case by pointing out that when their purpose has effectively become 'serve the hierarchy' rather than 'improve the work' people get disheartened and demoralised.

The extent of this phenomenon is alarming. Talk to any one about their experience of public service and there is a pattern: of people being prevented from focusing on purpose by the requirement to concentrate on what the hierarchy has decided is important. To put it bluntly, people are dying while the health service is being distorted by targets.

Targets are capricious. While they are assumed to provide a spur to improvement, they actually make performance worse. The next time the Government's use of targets is raised we should be asking why they have not been abandoned.

fields.trailText: The Swedes are set to mount a hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange to scupper its merger with Germany's Deutsche Börse.
fields.body:
The Swedes are set to mount a hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange to scupper its merger with Germany's Deutsche Börse.

The decision to go hostile follows a bizarre day of drama last Friday when the LSE board rejected a surprise £800 million offer from OM Gruppen, the operator of Stockholm's trading floor.

This weekend, OM and its City merchant bank advisers, Lazards, are huddled in urgent meetings, planning to go over the board's head and take the offer direct to LSE shareholders. The Swedish strike comes as LSE shareholders prepare to vote next month on its controversial plans to merge with the Frankfurt exchange to form international exchanges to be known as iX - the biggest pan-European stock market.

'The reaction of the LSE board is wholly predictable,' OM Gruppen chief executive Per Larsson said. 'We are determined that the London market should have a better alternative to the flawed iX proposals.'

The German merger plans have become increasingly controversial since they were announced last May. Since then, LSE has demutualised and its members are now free to sell their shares. Among brokers' concerns are the difficulty of harmonising regulation of the two exchanges, the costs of new trading systems and being overtaken in an effective sellout to Frankfurt.

Opponents of the deal, however, are unlikely to back the Swedes' bid because it is mostly in paper. It offers £20 in OM Gruppen shares plus £7 cash against the £23.50 market price of an LSE share on Friday.

'This is a purely opportunistic approach,' Martin Wheatley, LSE's director of business development told The Observer . 'On pure business grounds it does not fly. We came away with the clear conclusion that there was nothing we could support. There is nothing in it of any substance at all.'

OM Gruppen made its surprise approach to stock exchange chairman Don Cruickshank last Thursday through Lazards chairman David Verey. A short meeting with advisers was followed by two-and-a-half hours of talks on Friday morning. LSE chief executive Gavin Casey led the London side, supported by bankers from Schroder, Salomon Smith Barney, and Merrill Lynch, and City lawyers Herbert Smith. Larsson presented the Swedish offer, with Lazards director Jonathan Dawson.

The bid, however, was rejected at a hastily convened meeting of the LSE board the same afternoon. 'It is entirely up to OM as to how they want to go forward,' Wheatley said.

OM was formed in 1998 from a merger between the Stockholm stock exchange and derivatives market. Valued at £2.6 billion, it has since proved a nimble operator and now runs 20 international exchanges.

In June, it won the deal to run UKPX, Britain's first online electricity exchange, and it already trades in shares in London.

webTitle: Work where you are the only woman

fields.headline: Work where you are the only woman
fields.trailText: Deal with peer pressure and avoid displaying signs of weakness
fields.body:
1: Expect a high degree of peer pressure. There is a lot of anecdotal evidence suggesting that men confined together are more inclined to enforce conformity of behaviour in everything from the suppression of painful emotions to drinking rituals and dress. This makes it harder for women to cope in the locker-room atmosphere of many kitchens, says chef Anthony Bourdain in his new book Kitchen Confidential : 'We considered ourselves a tribe. We had unusual customs all our own...We were truly happy... a band of brothers...'

2: Don't assume that the atmosphere will necessarily be loud and bullying, however. As in all workplaces, the tone is usually set at the top of the organisation. While many men loathed their days in the Army, many others - including the art critic Brian Sewell - liked it. 'Geoff', a gay former squaddie, says: 'People looked out for each other. I find civilian life much more selfish.'

3: Go as far as you can, however, not to break the unwritten rules. Avoid publicly highlighting a man's mistakes or failings, says Dan. 'Men are more solicitous of saving each other's face. If a woman says something like, "You got that wrong, didn't you?" that sort of communicativeness can be seen as unduly rude.' Similarly, as John Gray says in his book Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus, men are less willing than women to accept friendly advice since it can be construed as suggesting they have been making mistakes.

4: Recognise that men will generally be more competitive than women. Radio psychiatrist Professor Anthony Clare, author of Men: Masculinity in Crisis, says most depend on their work for self-esteem, and want to be seen as 'strong, competitive, full of drive and ambition... bringing home the bacon, racing up the ladder.' They will be more inclined to put work ahead of day-to-day family commitments and are more likely to cope badly with redundancy.

5: Avoid displaying signs of weakness in male environments. Even in warfare, space exploration and other extreme situations, men usually want other men to keep those potentially undermining emotions at bay. While women are more inclined to release those feelings openly, men are more likely to turn fear into anger or to translate nervous tension into humour. Telling jokes and playing pranks is a common theme of military life.

Next week: How to work in an all-female environment

webTitle: All the time in the world

fields.headline: All the time in the world
fields.standfirst: You don't have to stick to office hours to be good at your job, says  Neasa  MacErlean
fields.trailText: You don't have to stick to office hours to be good at your job, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
Wendy Perriam starts work at 6.30am, wearing an old quilted dressing gown, writing her novels by hand in a scrawl and surrounded by pictures of the Virgin Mary and others that have a particular meaning for her.

Such themes are central to her lapsed Catholic novels, the fourteenth of which, Lying , came out this summer. A full-time novelist, she is one of a growing number of people who work from home. Left to their own devices, they usually create a different working environment to the one they left behind in the office.

But their styles are completely individual. Ruth, a crime writer, worked at the other end of the day when she began writing. 'I found myself getting up at noon and working through to 4am. I had to be able to cut the world out. It just gravitated that way,' she explained.

And Val McDermid, best-selling author of Killing the Shadows and other gory crime novels, starts at her desk about 9am, but needs to play computer games and find other distractions before the creative juices start flowing a couple of hours later.

All three women graduated to writing from more conventional careers - Perriam in advertising, Ruth in teaching and McDermid in journalism. But even though all of them are immensely productive - averaging 14 books each - they would not be welcome in the traditional office.

Perriam would have to be locked in a cupboard because of her breach of the dress code; Ruth would be accused of skiving because she arrived late; and McDermid would be quickly fired for misusing company equipment and not devoting all her time to her work.

But things are going to change. Business is realising that most workers are more productive when they have some control over their own conditions. And there is also a clear link between a relaxed environment and creativity. The call of 'Eureka' came from the bath, not the desk. Coleridge dreamt the lines of Kubla Khan while asleep. And Charles Dickens did much of his writing in the family drawing room as he chatted to friends and played with his children.

New businesses are not only recognising the connection between relaxation and creativity, but they are also finding the confidence to trust their employees and relax the old-fashioned rules. Sir Richard Branson is a frontrunner. The casual dress is not just a statement about being modern, it is also about being closer to the creative process.

Margaret Briffa, an intellectual property lawyer, swept away decades of convention when she started Briffa & Co in London's Islington five years ago. Unlike traditional lawyers who tend to reduce eye contact in their office seating plans, Briffa's team of eight have arranged their desks in a circle. 'We can discuss things as they come along,' she says. 'This is very good for helping our reaction times. Having to see your boss by going through a door is a barrier.'

One of her lawyers is an afternoon and evening person and prefers to start work at lunchtime. She did have reservations about this at first, but now says: 'So long as people do the work, I'm not fussed. And we also have a lot of US business - so it's helpful that he stays later.'

The most dramatic thing she did was to encourage her lawyers to bill clients for four hours a day - rather than the six or seven which is almost uniform throughout the rest of the profession. This means that the firm's income is possibly only two-thirds of what it might have been. But Briffa is not so sure about that: 'If you are time-pressured, you cannot take a step back. Taking the stress off ourselves makes us better lawyers. Also, it leads to our getting better business. Our clients tell us things they wouldn't have if they thought they were being charged for the conversation.'

Frank Eve, a director of internet mortgage company E-loan, has been able to import some of the flexibility he had when he worked alone to the company's 50-strong team in Redhill. 'There is no monitoring of the hours people do here. If someone wanted to go at 3pm, there would be no checking. But we have found that people have actually been working longer hours here.' In fact, the directors have become anxious about the possibility of some staff working too hard - and they sometimes try to set an example by leaving early.

Before joining E-loan, Eve was running a business called Flexemortgage from his home. 'I worked very different hours, depending on what was going on and also on my mood. Flexibility allows an individual to follow their own creativity. If you give people arbitrary rules about working 9 to 5, it is very restricting for people whose most creative time is 10 at night. I was much more creative in that environment than in a traditional office.'

Getting the right balance of flexibility and creativity is crucial. Even the most devoted employees will struggle if there are no deadlines or other constraints placed upon them. You only have to look at the high correlation between creativity, flexibility and disaster in the pop world to see why business leaders might be confused. No amount of creativity would recompense them if their staff started behaving like Liam Gallagher.

People who have successfully worked alone are usually very disciplined. Eve was no stranger to 16-hour days. Ruth was able to produce a book in two weeks. Perriam puts in six hours of writing a day. McDermid says: 'You have to be even more disciplined if you work on your own.'

All beneficiaries of a new-found freedom, none of them would return to the rule-bound environment. 'It wouldn't suit me to go back to a law factory,' says Briffa. 'What killed me as a teacher was knowing what I'd be doing in May next year,' says Ruth. 'I felt shackled, trapped and tied. I hated it.' Perriam says: 'I'd have to wear make-up. You also waste a lot of energy getting there. And then there are all the distractions.'

Strangely, however, it is often employees, rather than bosses, who oppose change, says Jan Young, architect, designer and facilitator of change for architect DEGW: 'Creating these changes often means, in practice, giving up your own desk or own base. And many people are resistant to change and say they don't have time for it.'

fields.headline: Soros banks on Abbey property
fields.trailText: The billionaire financier George Soros is close to scooping Abbey National's property portfolio, including its entire branch network and head office, for £450m.
fields.body:
The billionaire financier George Soros is close to scooping Abbey National's property portfolio, including its entire branch network and head office, for £450m.

The Mapeley consortium, backed by Soros Real Estate Partners, is one of two short-listed parties to buy Abbey's property in a PFI-style deal.

Abbey will transfer its entire estate, including its Baker Street head office in central London and other main offices in Bradford, Glasgow and Milton Keynes plus its 750-branch network, to the winning bidder, who will have to oversee Abbey's HQ relocation to a huge new office near Euston Station.

The bank will then pay whoever wins the contract rent and fees for facilities management. Abbey maintains there will be no branch closures as a result.

Insiders say Soros is favourite to win the contract. If he does, it will confirm him as one of the biggest owners of UK property. Earlier this month, the Mapeley consortium, formed specifically to bid on Public Finance Initiative-style projects and which includes Jamie Ritblat's Delancey Estates, won a £2 billion contract to run 600 Inland Revenue and Customs & Excise buildings.

Soros's rival for the Abbey contract is a consortium consisting of US bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the quoted property group London & Regional. A final decision will be made next month.

Other banks - including Lloyds TSB, Barclays and Halifax - may seek to copy Abbey's outsourcing tactics. Banks need cash to fund capital-intensive internet ven tures. Other organisations, including the BBC, also want to release capital tied up in property.

Abbey, one of Britain's biggest lenders, is considering other ways to cut costs. It is now piloting a branch franchise scheme, under which branches could be handed over to local managers. If this scheme is spread to its entire network, it could remove millions of pounds from the bank's running costs

Soros, based in New York, is most famous for being the man who forced the ignominious exit of John Major's Conservative government from the European Exchange Rate mechanism in 1992. The financier made at least £1bn in the process. But Soros funds have recently suffered losses from investments in technology stocks.

webTitle: Make that holiday magic last forever

fields.headline: Make that holiday magic last forever
fields.standfirst: Settling in your personal paradise can bring divorce and money problems.  Maria Scott  offers a guide to avoiding the need to send postcards from the edge
fields.trailText: Settling in your personal paradise can bring divorce and money problems. Maria Scott offers a guide to avoiding the need to send postcards from the edge.
fields.body:
If you've just come back from a perfect holiday you may now be fantasising about living on that Mediterranean island or in that tiny village in the West Country.

This time of year is probably the ripest for thoughts of making a permanent escape to favourite holiday destinations, away from the grind and traffic, noise and pollution, demanding bosses and general ordinariness to something more satisfying. Should this be the year that you move to the South of France, buy a country post office or settle on a Greek island? Not unless you put in some serious homework first.

Moving to one's favourite holiday destination can be the beginning of a new life (see case studies) but it is not an easy option.

If you are struggling to keep your life together in a city or town, it is unlikely that such a move will improve your financial or emotional position unless you choose your destination with great care.

Oonagh Karanjia runs an agency, Crete Property Consultants, dealing in homes on the Greek Island, and has seen Britons move there with varying degrees of success. 'The ones that do best are generally those who were not looking for a dramatic change,' she says.

Greece is one of the most popular holiday playgrounds for the British and, because of the weakness of the drachma against the pound, now seems hugely attractive to British tourists as a place to settle.

Sue Averies-Kartanou has lived in Greece for 15 years. She and her Greek husband run shops in the busy resort of Nidri on the island of Lefkas. Aristotle Onassis's island of Scorpios is a stone's throw from Nidri.

These are islands of crystal clear water, pure white beaches, friendly locals and cheap alcohol and cigarettes. Not surprisingly, Sue has seen an increasing number of tourists decide to make Lefkas their home.

For many, though, the move ends disastrously. The reality is a string of poorly paid casual jobs and unless these people have left assets in Britain, it is virtually impossible for them to return because property prices will have soared.

For some, the idyll ends with drink problems, encouraged by the cheap alcohol in Greece, and broken marriages.

'I think quite a lot don't do their homework,' says Sue. 'There is no real structure for getting jobs unless you work on a casual basis.'

Why, she wonders, do people assume that they will be able to manage on a part-time income in a poor country like Greece when this would not be possible in England.

'Two hundred thousand drachmas a month (barely £400) would be considered a good living. That would be [for] people like civil servants and teachers.'

Cigarettes and alcohol are cheap, but food, clothes and cars are not necessarily much cheaper than in the UK. Parents who bring children, says Sue, will discover that Greek parents pay for extensive private lessons in order to educate their children well. But even getting a good education will not guarantee a good living. 'There are a lot of doctors driving taxis and running tourist shops.'

Greece has a state pension scheme and a health service, but Sue has private pensions and medical insurance because she wants extra protection.

Those who cannot speak the language are at a particular disadvantage, and she is often called in by newcomers to help them deal with paperwork.

She recalls one couple who rented a restaurant and did not realise they were paying rent that, by local standards, was exorbitant. It was difficult to organise supplies from wholesalers without speaking Greek.

'People who have made a success of it have researched it and have economic security,' observes Sue. 'They haven't put all their eggs in one basket.'

Retired people with UK pension income who buy homes on the island for extended stays tend to do well out of their moves, she says.

Anyone contemplating migration to the island should spend a couple of hours talking to a lawyer or a well-informed local who can give them some idea of the realities.

Oonagh agrees that people moving to their favourite holiday spot often fail to 'think it all the way through'.

'Buying in a place that you've had a good holiday in is not a good basis for buying. Go in February, the worst month of the year [for weather], and see what life is like then.'

Oonagh says that older couples may fail to appreciate that being together 24 hours a day poses a challenge to their marriage.

Those who move successfully rarely do so to escape an unsatisfactory life at home, and they 'don't have it in mind to vegetate'.

Offshore, but not all at sea

Moving abroad involves more planning than you would faced with if you simply upped sticks for a favourite UK holiday spot. Martin Mullany knows the financial challenges of moving abroad as he is an independent financial adviser who recently moved to Mauritius following an excellent holiday there.

Mullany has set up his own financial advice consultancy, Strategic Planning International. Here is his checklist for preparing such a move abroad :

 List the factors you would take into account if you were moving within the UK, including location of your planned home in relation to shops and amenities, and access to transport, medical facilities, schools, work, and friends. Ask yourself who you know there, and how you will get to know people.

 Find a way to speak to people in the area. The Corona Society helps people from the UK to prepare for a move abroad by putting them in touch with knowledgeable residents. It also organises briefings on the cultural and financial aspects of a move. A one-day briefing costs £250, a cultural briefing only is £75 and a telephone briefing £25. Tel: 0207 610 4407.

 Consider your financial situation. Will you retire or work? Can you afford to live without working? Will you need a work permit?

 Do some 'negative' planning. What if something or everything goes wrong? Make sure you can afford to return to the UK in an emergency. It is important to have an emergency fund. You might need to call on it for anything from a family death to a change in the political climate in the country you move to.

 Don't rule out the possibility that you will not be able to adjust to living permanently in a culture you enjoyed in small doses on holiday.

 Check that your will is valid where you are going. In some countries you will have to dispose of assets according to specific rules.

 Ask the Department of Social Security for a forecast of your state pension; there is a section on the forecast form, BR19, that applies to pensions paid abroad. It may be worth making voluntary National Insurance payments to protect your state pension. But be aware that in most Commonwealth countries the UK state pension is not increased when it goes up in this country.

 If you are investing and plan to continue, there is no change in the nature of the investments - but the vehicles you use will be different. You won't be able to use Isas or Tessas. Assuming you become a non-UK taxpayer, you will need an offshore account where interest is paid gross. For stock market investment you will probably want to consider offshore funds.

Take care, as the regulation of funds based outside the UK is not necessarily as rigorous as in Britain. If you have substantial assets and don't feel confident about managing them yourself, find a UK adviser with detailed knowledge of the expatriate market.

 The position with private pensions varies depending on the type of scheme.

You won't be able to continue to contribute but will be able to keep the pensions until you want to retire.

Find out how much they would produce. Would it be enough to maintain a reasonable lifestyle if you decide to remain abroad? How will you save for retirement when you move?

 A large number of UK residents who go abroad to live end up returning. Keep a property in the UK so you have a home to come back to. If you do sell, invest some of the proceeds in a rental property.

You will have to use an agent; an occupational hazard when you live miles away. You will need to pay tax on any income from the property, after expenses. You will need to complete forms to enable the agent to release rent without deduction of tax at source.

 Check what the tax position would be if you returned to the UK to live in the property. In some cases it is better to return to live in it for a time before selling, while for others it is best to sell while abroad.

In some cases it is best to sell after leaving the UK but before settling in a new country whose tax laws could affect you.

fields.bodyText: If you've just come back from a perfect holiday you may now be fantasising about living on that Mediterranean island or in that tiny village in the West Country. This time of year is probably the ripest for thoughts of making a permanent escape to favourite holiday destinations, away from the grind and traffic, noise and pollution, demanding bosses and general ordinariness to something more satisfying. Should this be the year that you move to the South of France, buy a country post office or settle on a Greek island? Not unless you put in some serious homework first. Moving to one's favourite holiday destination can be the beginning of a new life (see case studies) but it is not an easy option. If you are struggling to keep your life together in a city or town, it is unlikely that such a move will improve your financial or emotional position unless you choose your destination with great care. Oonagh Karanjia runs an agency, Crete Property Consultants, dealing in homes on the Greek Island, and has seen Britons move there with varying degrees of success. 'The ones that do best are generally those who were not looking for a dramatic change,' she says. Greece is one of the most popular holiday playgrounds for the British and, because of the weakness of the drachma against the pound, now seems hugely attractive to British tourists as a place to settle. Sue Averies-Kartanou has lived in Greece for 15 years. She and her Greek husband run shops in the busy resort of Nidri on the island of Lefkas. Aristotle Onassis's island of Scorpios is a stone's throw from Nidri. These are islands of crystal clear water, pure white beaches, friendly locals and cheap alcohol and cigarettes. Not surprisingly, Sue has seen an increasing number of tourists decide to make Lefkas their home. For many, though, the move ends disastrously. The reality is a string of poorly paid casual jobs and unless these people have left assets in Britain, it is virtually impossible for them to return because property prices will have soared. For some, the idyll ends with drink problems, encouraged by the cheap alcohol in Greece, and broken marriages. 'I think quite a lot don't do their homework,' says Sue. 'There is no real structure for getting jobs unless you work on a casual basis.' Why, she wonders, do people assume that they will be able to manage on a part-time income in a poor country like Greece when this would not be possible in England. 'Two hundred thousand drachmas a month (barely £400) would be considered a good living. That would be [for] people like civil servants and teachers.' Cigarettes and alcohol are cheap, but food, clothes and cars are not necessarily much cheaper than in the UK. Parents who bring children, says Sue, will discover that Greek parents pay for extensive private lessons in order to educate their children well. But even getting a good education will not guarantee a good living. 'There are a lot of doctors driving taxis and running tourist shops.' Greece has a state pension scheme and a health service, but Sue has private pensions and medical insurance because she wants extra protection. Those who cannot speak the language are at a particular disadvantage, and she is often called in by newcomers to help them deal with paperwork. She recalls one couple who rented a restaurant and did not realise they were paying rent that, by local standards, was exorbitant. It was difficult to organise supplies from wholesalers without speaking Greek. 'People who have made a success of it have researched it and have economic security,' observes Sue. 'They haven't put all their eggs in one basket.' Retired people with UK pension income who buy homes on the island for extended stays tend to do well out of their moves, she says. Anyone contemplating migration to the island should spend a couple of hours talking to a lawyer or a well-informed local who can give them some idea of the realities. Oonagh agrees that people moving to their favourite holiday spot often fail to 'think it all the way through'. 'Buying in a place that you've had a good holiday in is not a good basis for buying. Go in February, the worst month of the year [for weather], and see what life is like then.' Oonagh says that older couples may fail to appreciate that being together 24 hours a day poses a challenge to their marriage. Those who move successfully rarely do so to escape an unsatisfactory life at home, and they 'don't have it in mind to vegetate'. Ask yourself who you know there, and how you will get to know people.  Find a way to speak to people in the area. It also organises briefings on the cultural and financial aspects of a move. A one-day briefing costs £250, a cultural briefing only is £75 and a telephone briefing £25.
