fields.headline: Return of the natives
fields.standfirst: Rejuvenate your perennials by taking cuttings from them now, says Christopher Lloyd - and, next year, see the trusty old lags replaced by lusty youth
fields.trailText: Rejuvenate your perennials by taking cuttings from them now, says Christopher Lloyd - and, next year, see the trusty old lags replaced by lusty youth.
fields.body:
There are many perennials that we use as bedding plants. Most of them benefit from being rejuvenated by taking cuttings from them soon and using stock so raised for next year's bedding. Even if old plants would survive the winter to do another turn, young stock will be lustier, growing more vigorously and flowering over a longer period than the old lags.

Diascias are typical. Quite a range of them have proved hardy under the winter conditions lately on offer, but we'll do even better with our stock if we have renewed it. I get very bored with the numerous kinds having a sort of salmon-pink colouring - 'Salmon Supreme' tells it all - but 'Red Start' comes near to a true red and has given us a lot of pleasure.

As preferred propagation material, take young shoots that have arisen from the base of the plant. If they have flowerbuds on them, remove these. If there are no young shoots, just a lot of straggling old ones, shear the plant all over and wait for young shoots to appear. There's still plenty of growing time for this to happen.

Even if you don't intend to take cuttings, this shearing, mid-season, is a good thing to do, as it will rejuvenate the plant's appearance. Don't be tender-hearted, protesting that shearing will remove extant buds and flowers. It'll be for a good cause and pay off in the long term.

If the tip of the cutting is very soft, remove this and with a sharp blade remove the bottom leaves that would otherwise be buried. Insert your cuttings, with a dibber, quite thickly into pots containing a light, gritty compost.

Personally, I like the compost to include about one-sixth loam as a buffer against starvation, because, although the cuttings will root quickly enough, we do not disturb them until the following spring, when they are potted off individually. There are two principal reasons for this delay: the first is the saving of precious under- glass space; and the second that it is generally better to keep plants just ticking over through the dark, cold months than to encourage growth when considerable heat would be required to sustain it.

Most rooted cuttings that are just ticking over can be kept at a temperature just above freezing, or even just below. While still very soft and limp, most cuttings need to be kept close (without ventilation) and protected from direct sunlight. But as soon as they stiffen, it is wise to give a little ventilation, and then to increase it. Air circulation will discourage the onset of fungal disease, notably botrytis, which looks like a grey fur coat and is a rapid killer.

The perennial nemesias are not unlike diascias, but in a different colour range that includes blue. They are similarly treated. The mauve Nemesia denticulata (syn. 'Confetti') has a long season and makes a large plant. And 'Innocence' is a fresh, pure white.

Convolvulus sabatius (C. mauritanicus) is a charmer to have hanging over the edge of a pot or even down a retaining wall, starting from the top but working its way through the cracks. That will often survive the winter, especially if you leave its old growth by way of protection. But it is just as well to take cuttings, too. The flowers, like an open lamp-shade, are mauvy-blue, the colour strongest in the morning. And there is a worthwhile darker version.

Even though they are often hardy (the plants can last for several years), I think that bedding penstemons frequently give the best, and certainly most even, results from young stock, raised from soft tip cuttings (but remove the over-soft tip itself), taken now. This is a case where, to avoid too much water loss through excess leaf area, it may be a good idea, having made your cutting, to slice off the top half of the leaves with a single cross-cut.

One penstemon that impressed me in my garden this year is 'Chester Scarlet' - showy and as near to pure red as you'll find. This is a valuable colour in a mixed border from midsummer on, when good reds are rather scarce.

You'll probably want to propagate your own 'geraniums' (bedding pelargoniums), whether zonal, ivy-leaved or fragrant-leaved, and they are simple enough. There was an old practice, which dies hard, of allowing the cuttings to wilt for several hours before inserting them. This is not, in fact, a good idea.

Nowadays, most geranium plants bought on the market for summer bedding have been raised from seed. This needs fairly specialised conditions and seed is expensive, so cuttings are an easy solution, so long as your stock remains virus-free. With variegated kinds, you must take cuttings to retain the variegation.

I am fond of bedding verbenas, especially those with scented flowers such as 'La France' (lavender), 'Lawrence Johnston' (cherry red) and 'Loveliness' (purplish). These have a rambling habit and will cover a lot of ground. Again, take cuttings of young shoots. A pair of leaves and the shank of stem below it is enough material, as verbenas root well from internodal cuttings.

While we're on that theme, so do fuchsias and the general run of hydrangeas, both of which can be propagated now.

fields.headline: Final 10 named for book prize
fields.standfirst: New authors longlisted for Guardian award
fields.trailText: An American advertising copywriter whose chance encounter with a piano restorer in Paris spurred him to write his first book at the age of 55 heads the longlist of nominations for the Guardian First Book Award 2000.
fields.body:
An American advertising copywriter whose chance encounter with a piano restorer in Paris spurred him to write his first book at the age of 55 heads the longlist of nominations for the Guardian First Book Award 2000.

TE Carhart's The Piano Shop on the Left Bank is a partly autobiographical exploration of the history, mechanics and cultural relevance of the piano, inspired by a visit to a secluded Paris atelier where he met Luc, an enigmatic piano restorer whose musings on the individual nature of the instruments and the music they produce reawakened Carhart's love of the instrument.

By contrast Trezza Azzopardi, whose novel The Hiding Place is among the 10 contenders for the award, which is open to fiction and non-fiction writers of all nationalities, was "discovered" while attending a creative writing course at the University of East Anglia.

Azzopardi acquired an agent and a publisher after writing the first chapter of the novel, the story of the tangled life of a family of a Maltese immigrant in Cardiff's Tiger Bay, as part of the course.

Azzopardi's themes of migration, the search for identity and the exposure of a little known historical episode, in her case the fate of the Maltese diaspora, are also present in several of the other works on the list.

Zadie Smith's acclaimed and massively successful White Teeth, an account of a mixed race family in north London, is longlisted, as is Catfish and Mandala by Andrew X Pham, a Vietnamese-American.

Part travelogue, part autobiography, Pham's book recounts his return to the country his parents left as boat people in the 1970s.

There are three other non-fiction works on the list. A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius is the remarkable memoir of Dave Eggers, an American whose parents died when he was 21, leaving him to raise his eight-year-old brother.

No Logo by American journalist Naomi Klein examines the culture of protest that has grown up against the ubiquity of global brands and the power of capital, epitomised by the violent protests that greeted the World Trade Organisation summit in Seattle earlier this year.

Perhaps most interesting is Ubiquity by Mark Buchanan, a physicist who takes the chaos model and applies it to history and politics, arguing that the old sores of causality and consequence are redundant.

Three novels complete the list. House of Leaves by Mark Z Danielewski is a postmodern take on the horror genre, employing numerous typographical tricks including several typefaces, upside down text and pages with just a single word on them.

Beautiful Disguises by Rajeev Balasubramanyam is the tale of a young Indian girl infected by Audrey Hepburn fantasies and dreams of Bollywood success.

Douglas Galbraith's The Rising Sun, a historical seafaring tale of a Scottish voyage to the jungles of Panama, is perhaps the most orthodox of the debut novels.

Claire Armitstead, Guardian literary editor and chairwoman of the judging panel, which will include Kirsty Young, Prof Steve Jones, David Baddiel and Julian Barnes, hailed the breadth and ambition of the longlisted titles. "The thought on our minds as we worked through the 120 submissions was whether we would find a voice for the new millennium. In fact we found many voices."

The shortlist will be announced in October and the winner, who receives £10,000 and an advertising campaign in the Guardian, in December.

The ten

Title: The Hiding Place (Picador £14.99)
Sisters gather in the Cardiff docklands for their mother's funeral. They know they were deserted by their Maltese father, but they have only a patchy grasp of the horror of their childhood (full review, Books, Saturday Review). Author: Trezza Azzopardi Born and raised in Cardiff, Azzopardi, 39, now lives in Norwich.

Title: In Beautiful Disguises (Bloomsbury, £14.99)
Arjuna's Indian childhood, spent dreaming of becoming a film star,comes to an abrupt end when she is told she must marry. She escapes to the city. Author: Rajeev Balasubramanyam Born in Lancashire Balasubramanyam, 26, studied at Oxford and Cambridge, and won the 1999 Betty Trask Award

Title: Ubiquity (Orion, £20)
This theoretical book argues that chaos theory's sense of pattern and distortion can equally be applied to history and other disciplines. Author: Mark Buchanan A 31-year-old physicist specialising in nonlinear dynamics and chaos theory, Buchanan moved to London from America to join the staff of Nature. He now lives in Normandy.

Title: The Piano Shop on the Left Bank (Chatto & Windus £15.99)
An obsessional meditation on passion, craftsmanship and the piano sparked by one man's discovery of a little traditional piano restorer in Paris (full review, Books, Saturday Review). Author: Thad Carhart An American living in Paris, Carhart, 55, left a business career to become a writer.

Title: House of Leaves (Anchor, £13)
The discovery of a notebook left by a murdered man sets a Los Angeles tattooist off on a terrifying journey into the history of a haunted house. Author: Mark Z Danielewski The son of a film director Danielewski, 31, grew up in Utah and was educated at Harvard. He has written a number of screenplays.

Title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius (Picador £14.99)
When Eggers was in his twenties his parents died, leaving him to bring up his eight-year-old brother. His wild, inspired memoir looks at bereavement, love, ambition.
Author: Dave Eggers Eggers, a journalist, edits McSweeneys quarterly in New York.

Title: The Rising Sun (Picador, £16)
At the end of the 17th century, the Scots made a disastrous attempt to colonise the Panamanian coast. Scotland's place on the world map might have been very different, had the voyage not been foiled.
Author: Douglas Galbraith Born in Glasgow, Galbraith, 35, now lives in the south of England.

Title: No Logo (Flamingo. £14.99)
A stylishly argued indictment of post-modern capitalism, in particular the push towards oppressive global branding and the associated power structures of worldwide trade.
Author: Naomi Klein A Canadian journalist Klein, 30, writes for The Baffler, Ms and Village Voice. She has a column in the Toronto Star.

Title: Catfish and Mandala: a Vietnamese Odyssey (Flamingo £10.99)
After his sister commits suicide, Pham becomes obsessed with exploring his identity. His search takes him back to the Vietnam his parents fled in the 1970s.
Author: Andrew X Pham Pham, 33, left Vietnam for California with his parents. He lives in San Jose.

Title: White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99)
Willesden is the setting for this novel about two families, one Asian and one British-Jamaican, whose lives have been entwined since Samad Iqbal and Alfred Archibald Jones met up in the second world war.
Author: Zadie Smith Smith, 25, was shortlisted for the Orange Prize 2000.

fields.headline: The Maltese rabbit
fields.standfirst: D J Taylor  finds submerged horrors in Trezza Azzopardi's sharp debut, The Hiding Place
fields.trailText: D J Taylor finds submerged horrors in Trezza Azzopardi's sharp debut, The Hiding Place
fields.body:
The Hiding Place
Trezza Azzopardi
Picador, £14.99, 288pp
Buy it at BOL

The book-trade bush telegraph has been tapping out advance information on Trezza Azzopardi since the start of the year: a preview in the British Council anthology New Writing Nine; a dedication from the Poet Laureate; translation rights sold all over the place. This kind of pre-publication frenzy doesn't always work to an author's advantage, so it's a pleasure to report that The Hiding Place is an accomplished, if somewhat laboriously concluded, debut.

Much of the novel's appeal stems from the unfamiliarity of its subject matter. If the UK's Maltese population has hitherto occupied any sort of niche in British fiction, it has been as low-life bit-parters in Soho crime novels, gamely hurling paraffin heaters through the windows of dirty bookshops. Here, on the other hand, we have a genuine, if hugely warped, family chronicle, extending as far back as the late 1940s. That is when Frank Gauci steps off the boat in Tiger Bay, finds himself a room, a mentor (well-dressed, well-connected Joe Medora), some forged papers and, eventually, a wife and family.

Spendthrift and compulsive nag-backer that he is, Frankie's career high is co-ownership of a dive called the Moonlight Club - until he gambles it away. Family life in the Cardiff backstreets, as remembered by Dolores, the youngest of his six daughters, is similarly fraught. Mother Mary has her own way of paying the rent. Marina is shipped back to Malta as a foster-child (there are dark rumours over her real destiny) in part-payment for the gambling debts. Arsonist Fran ends up in a home, while teenage Celesta reconciles herself to marrying a middle-aged restaurateur. As a baby, Dolores is nearly incinerated in a housefire, leaving her with a deformed hand that her father thinks is the devil's mark.

In among the carefully trailed mysteries (what does Mrs Gauci get up to as the children stand sentinel? What were the exact circumstances of the fire?), symbolic moments abound. Several have to do with rabbits: Frankie zealously despatching a family pet on the morning of Celesta's wedding to procure the lucky foot; five-year-old Dolores rebuked for her "interference" after a rescued newborn litter is eaten by the mother. The historical part of the novel ends after Celesta's nuptials when Frankie, having elaborately scammed Medora and left his old mate Salvatore drowning in the dockyard mud, steps back onto the boat.

All this proceeds at a cracking pace, full of neat but unobtrusive gestures at the horrors beneath. There follows a further 50 pages set in the diminished present, in which the survivors return to attend Mary's funeral. Though the re-encounters and revelations are skilfully handled, the effect is curiously dispiriting. It is as if Azzopardi, mistrusting her readers' ability to decode the hints strewn over the preceding four-fifths of the book, now feels that she has to chalk its myriad connections up on a metaphorical blackboard. Sharply written, full of crisp little vignettes and cameos, The Hiding Place could have done without its over-extended finale.

fields.headline: Big players bid for Equitable
fields.trailText: Equitable Life, the beleaguered life insurer, has received approaches from at least 12 potential bidders and expects to have chosen a buyer by the end of December, the company said yesterday.
fields.body:
Equitable Life, the beleaguered life insurer, has received approaches from at least 12 potential bidders and expects to have chosen a buyer by the end of December, the company said yesterday.

Equitable sent out a memorandum of sale document to all the would-be buyers, who are understood to include Prudential and Abbey National, with Dutch insurer Aegon, Axa of France, South African insurer Old Mutual and GE Capital - the financial services arm of US conglomerate General Electric - thought to be among the foreign bidders.

Equitable Life, which put itself up for sale last month after losing a three-year legal battle involving pension guarantees, could be valued at £4bn to £5bn, according to analysts. This could translate into average windfalls of as much as £7,000, if the money were shared between the 450,000 members, even after the acquirer has pumped money into building up Equitable's long-term fund.

Equitable has been left with a bill of up to £1.5bn, following a Lords ruling that it had acted illegally in preventing 90,000 pension policyholders from enjoying the full benefits of guaranteed annuity rates sold in policies between 1957 and 1988. Policyholders with these guarantees will see pension payouts increased by around 25% as a result of the ruling.

Equitable will be under pressure to choose a deal that maximises potential windfalls as the approval of at least 75% of members will be required for the sale to go ahead.

However, it could decide on a buyer willing to invest most on rebuilding the long-term fund, which would cut potential payouts.

Nigel Webb, a spokesman for the company, said the memorandum of sale runs to 150 pages, not including an actuarial report and appendices, and was being sent to all those potential buyers which had signed the necessary confidentiality agreement. It was initially going out to "at least 12" interested parties, a number of which were overseas. He indicated that others may also come forward.

Assisted by adviser Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, Equitable will assemble a short list of bids in the autumn, and by the end of the year it will have identified which "is in the best interests of members". The company will then arrange an extraordinary general meeting early next year to vote on the proposal.

As well as details of the recommended bid, members will at this point be provided with information about the other bids and why they failed. The sale is expected to be completed during the second half of next year.

Founded in 1762, Equitable is Britain's oldest mutual insurer, and has £33bn under management, 600,000 policyholders and 2,000 employees.

Equitable sent out a memorandum of sale document to all the would-be buyers, who are understood to include Prudential and Abbey National, with Dutch insurer Aegon, Axa of France, South African insurer Old Mutual and GE Capital - the financial services arm of US conglomerate General Electric - thought to be among the foreign bidders. Equitable Life, which put itself up for sale last month after losing a three-year legal battle involving pension guarantees, could be valued at £4bn to £5bn, according to analysts. This could translate into average windfalls of as much as £7,000, if the money were shared between the 450,000 members, even after the acquirer has pumped money into building up Equitable's long-term fund. Equitable has been left with a bill of up to £1.5bn, following a Lords ruling that it had acted illegally in preventing 90,000 pension policyholders from enjoying the full benefits of guaranteed annuity rates sold in policies between 1957 and 1988. Policyholders with these guarantees will see pension payouts increased by around 25% as a result of the ruling. Equitable will be under pressure to choose a deal that maximises potential windfalls as the approval of at least 75% of members will be required for the sale to go ahead. However, it could decide on a buyer willing to invest most on rebuilding the long-term fund, which would cut potential payouts. Nigel Webb, a spokesman for the company, said the memorandum of sale runs to 150 pages, not including an actuarial report and appendices, and was being sent to all those potential buyers which had signed the necessary confidentiality agreement. It was initially going out to "at least 12" interested parties, a number of which were overseas. He indicated that others may also come forward. Assisted by adviser Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, Equitable will assemble a short list of bids in the autumn, and by the end of the year it will have identified which "is in the best interests of members". The company will then arrange an extraordinary general meeting early next year to vote on the proposal. As well as details of the recommended bid, members will at this point be provided with information about the other bids and why they failed. The sale is expected to be completed during the second half of next year. Founded in 1762, Equitable is Britain's oldest mutual insurer, and has £33bn under management, 600,000 policyholders and 2,000 employees.

webTitle: Why Ireland fell in love with the euro

fields.headline: Why Ireland fell in love with the euro
fields.standfirst:
As affluence and self-confidence reach new heights following centuries of depression and emigration, there is a wealth of gratitude for the EU
Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: As affluence and self-confidence reach new heights following centuries of depression and emigration, there is a wealth of gratitude for the EU.
fields.body:
They have never had it so good in Prosperous, Ireland; the European Union has delivered unprecedented wealth. Property prices have trebled in two years and four-wheel drives cruise the broad, tree-lined streets.

Prosperous is a small town in Co Kildare. Founded in 1780 and christened in an earlier era of industrial optimism, it stands above the sodden peat of the Bog of Allen. More than two centuries on, Prosperous, now a fusion of traditional Ireland and the "Celtic Tiger" economy, is finally living up to its name by absorbing the advancing tide of Dublin's commuterland.

The town's prosperity helps explain why the republic tops the poll of Europhile nations and, to some extent, why the UK records the lowest level of popular support for the EU of the 15 member states.

"Ireland is going through an economic boom now because we joined Europe in 1973," declares Anne O'Neil, a teacher at Prosperous's school. "We got social funding and put it into technical education.

"Now we have Intel and Hewlett Packard setting up factories (on the outskirts of Dublin). My son works at Intel which is recruiting from Belgium and Scotland. Prosperous is expanding as commuters move in; our school rolls have doubled in five years."

Her enthusiasm is widely shared. According to the latest Eurobarometer survey by Brussels, 75% of Irish respondents believe membership of the union is a "good thing"; 63% want to join the euro currency. The UK returns figures of 25% and 22% respectively.

But it is no longer merely a divergence of opinion. The fate of the republic's economy is fast becoming a significant political issue in Britain's debate over whether to join the euro. Eurosceptics have seized on Ireland's runaway inflation, which has recently touched 6.2%, as evidence that allowing the European central bank (ECB) to set interest rates amounts to abandoning sovereignty and prudent economic management.

The republic has by far the highest inflation rate in Europe but being a small player cannot persuade the ECB, dominated by France and Germany where inflation is 2%, to raise interest rates fast enough. Ireland's opposition Labour party has demanded the emergency recall of the Dail to push through compensatory increases in welfare spending.

The leap in the cost of living and spiralling property prices have already imposed strains on the government's social compact with the unions and triggered strikes among nurses and train drivers.

There is no doubting, however, that the Irish Republic has achieved a new level of affluence inside the EU after centuries of exclusion from foreign markets, depression and mass emigration. Depending on choice of statistical measure, Ireland may already have overtaken the UK in wealth creation per capita. The latest gross domestic product (GDP) figures show Ireland on 23,630 and the UK on 21,570.

Ireland's success is at least partially due to the influx of massive pump-priming investments from Brussels. Between 1993 and 1998 the republic received £13bn from various EU funds.

Gratitude towards the EU is all around. In Prosperous, the upgrading of a sewage works is accompanied by a large sign showing that the work is funded by the EU. Ireland has taken the EU to its heart. Motorways have roadside hoardings wreathed in the union's 15 gold stars. Even the GPO in O'Connell Street, Dublin, the hallowed scene of the 1916 Easter uprising, displays the flags of all 15 EU countries. Ireland's Europhilia extends to showing prices in Irish pounds and euros in restaurants, bars, bank statements and government wage slips. The body charged with ensuring that the switch goes smoothly is the euro changeover board of Ireland.

Ireland's euro and cent coins - with a harp on one side - are already being minted in preparation for January 1 2002. An advertising campaign will start next month. "Think euro" is likely to be the slogan. "Not the sexiest in the world," admits John Norris, a senior board official. But then there is not much persuasion to be done.

At the European commission offices in Dublin, deputy director Philip Ryan was sanguine about inflation. It will decline soon, he predicted. Some is due to oil price rises, some to Britain's reluctance to join the eurozone which has made UK goods more expensive.

"Whereas Ireland's identity was down-trodden, now it's self-confident," he said. "Ireland has lost nothing from membership of the EU and gained a hell of a lot.

"An agricultural economy when we joined, we are now the largest exporter of computer software in the world." Music - U2, the Cranberries, the Corrs - has invigorated the selling of Irish culture abroad. "Dublin firms were at one stage opening three Irish theme pubs a week around the world."

But it is not merely wealth, it is also pride in throwing off the British yoke. "When Ireland joined the EU, 80% of our trade was with the UK," Mr Ryan said. "Now it's about 27%."

Even with growth rates of above 8%, the highest in the union, Ireland is unlikely to become a net contributor to EU coffers until after 2006.

In the 1992 Maastricht referendum, those campaigning to uphold the ban on abortion and preserve Ireland's traditional neutrality were swept aside by government promises that a "yes" vote would secure £8bn in extra EU structural funds.

Will the disappearance of the Irish pound diminish the nation's character? In Carroll's Dublin gift shop, the manager, Gareth Kelly, was uneasy. "It'll be good not having to change money when in Europe," he said. "But it's bad because there's going to be no French money, no Irish money. No differences anymore."

In Prosperous there are euro-begrudgers too. "There's still potholes in the roads," said Cathal O'Connell, a late morning drinker at Dowlings' Bar. "The EU is a con job. We were all promised cheaper cars, but they are the dearest in Europe."

Prosperous was originally founded, with government grants, as a cotton mill by an ancestor of the former Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Brooke. Six years later it went bankrupt.

"Perhaps there are parallels with industrial development today. Will it collapse again?" asked Father Tom McDonnell, a local priest.

webTitle: England still searching for spin solution

fields.headline: England still searching for spin solution
fields.standfirst: Either Tufnell or Giles will fill a gap in the bowling attack for fifth Test
fields.trailText: David Hopps on England's bowling options for the Oval test.
fields.body:
There has been no crueller jibe all season than the dubbing of England's choice of spinner for next week's final Test at the Oval - and the winter tours that follow - as a donkey derby. Be that as it may, after studying the candidates intensely for a month and more, the selectors have been so uncertain where best to pin the tail that they might as well have attempted it blindfolded.

The choice for the Oval, where England seek to protect their 2-1 lead, and so beat West Indies in a series for the first time since 1969, rests between two left-arm spinners: Phil Tufnell and Ashley Giles. With the successful candidate virtually guaranteed selection for Pakistan and Sri Lanka, the debate has been prolonged.

Giles' tendinitis, which demanded injections and rest this week, has not come at a propitious time. He will turn out for Warwickshire in tomorrow's NatWest final against Gloucestershire at Lord's, which would normally allay doubts about his fitness. But England have sought to release pressure from their Oval squad by all but guaranteeing a tour place. "It is highly unlikely that any of the party won't go to Pakistan," the chairman of selectors, David Graveney, has asserted. There will be much conjecture, therefore, about whether Giles' tendons will be able to withstand hard Asian grounds.

Giles has delivered what the selectors have asked this season. Warwickshire's weakened seam bowling has allowed him longer and more rewarding spells. He has also batted high enough, averaging around 40, to have realistic claims as an England No8, which is beyond Tufnell's means. And eight is where he would be most likely to bat at the Oval, if England dared to omit one of the seven specialist batsmen who played at Headingley.

Most expect them to jettison Graeme Hick when the squad is announced tomorrow, even though his partnership with Michael Vaughan was essential to England's win. Serious consideration will also be given to the omission of Michael Atherton, with Vaughan offering an opening option. If England opt for Tufnell then leaving out Dominic Cork, in the name of bolstering the batting, is possible, although a double century for Derbyshire this week should have banished the notion.

"I've done a lot of bowling because we've missed our strike bowlers a lot this year - not just Allan Donald because of injury, but Ed Giddins on Test duty," Giles said. "Longer spells immediately up your confidence. I know that the contest between the spinners has been called a donkey derby, so it's best just to get on with the job."

Giles is not a big spinner of the ball, but he has worked with Bob Woolmer, Warwickshire's coach, on varying his position on the crease. A release from his all-too-common fate of just bowling to hold an end up has also had a positive psychological effect. A successful England A tour in Sri Lanka three years ago also emphasised his resilience in such sapping humidity.

All that does not counter the belief that Tufnell remains the best left-arm spinner in the country. While Middlesex are in a slump, Tufnell has 55 first-class wickets at 22. But nine years have passed since he took six for 25 at the Oval when the West Indies tried to launch him over the gasometer and since then he has flickered along at gas mark two. And his ability to survive the rigours of two Asian tours can hardly be taken for granted.

With the winter tours in mind, England are considering four off-spinners - the Northamptonshire pair Graeme Swann and Jason Brown, Peter Such, who cannot even be sure of a place in Essex's first XI, and Robert Croft, who after briefly being lauded this summer for a new enterprising approach, has within weeks become as much out of favour as the lemon Starburst, although at least the lemon Starburst made your mouth water. Croft should not be lightly overlooked.

Swann has had a chastening experience since an inactive South Africa tour last winter. Attention has switched to Jason Brown, 25, who has shot to prominence with 50 first-class wickets at 20s. He is unassuming, Swann is confident, and to pick either would be a huge gamble.

Chris Schofield, England contracted on the grounds of potential, should be an automatic leg-spin choice for at least one tour, and any talk of recalling Ian Salisbury, because of a successful alliance at Surrey with Saqlain Mushtaq, should be resisted.

Schofield is running back into form, according to Lancashire's wicketkeeper, Warren Hegg, although if Hegg had to pick a spinner for the Oval it would be his slow left-arm partner, Gary Keedy.

The England Wales Cricket Board (ECB) have announced that Simon Pack, International Teams Director, is to leave its employ next month after three years in the post.

England 12 (probable): Hussain (capt), Atherton, Trescothick, Thorpe, Stewart, Vaughan, Hick, White, Giles, Cork, Gough, Caddick.

fields.headline: Cronje the crooked Centurion
fields.standfirst: The report into cricket match-fixing in South Africa promises to be a protracted affair, according to Paul Weaver
fields.trailText: The report into cricket match-fixing in South Africa promises to be a protracted affair, according to Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
Judge Edwin King has claimed that Hansie Cronje's major motivation for his decision to forfeit an innings during the Centurion Test against England this year was personal gain.

The King Commission report into cricket match-fixing in South Africa will be under increased pressure to get to the bottom of the matter when it meets in five weeks' time. This follows the release yesterday of the interim report, which has made no recommendations to the International Cricket Council. No firm conclusions will be reached until the end of the inquiry in Cape Town. This could go on for weeks, even months.

However, it is clear from observations within the report that the respected judge does not believe the disgraced former Test captain has been completely honest in his lengthy testimony. "What occurred was that Cronje engineered a formula whereby what would otherwise have produced an inevitable draw in the Centurion Test was transformed into a match which would in all probability (and did) produce a positive result," King said in his report.

"Thus the decision was taken and the action pursuant thereto was influenced by the promise (and receipt) of a reward. Such other motive as there might have been is in this context secondary."

Judge King also indicated that there was a common thread running through Cronje's dealing with his team-mates during his international career when he was suggesting fixing various matches.

"Where Cronje sought to involve his team-mates in match-fixing . . . the initial approach is made jocularly. He would sound out his colleagues in a way which would enable him to say later, if the need arose, that he had only been joking."

Cronje's character could hardly descend any further, but his former international team-mates Pieter Strydom, Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams will have their fates decided on Monday when a disciplinary panel releases its findings after a hearing last weekend.

Dr Ali Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, looks increasingly likely to be frustrated in his hope of having the whole mess resolved as quickly and painlessly as possible.

The interim report was his idea earlier this year. He wanted to show the ICC that something was being done about the biggest problem the game has faced. But the issues were so complex that this report could not come out before the ICC meeting in June.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Hampshire are almost certain to be playing in the Second Division next season after losing a tense, fluctuating match to Kent by 15 runs at Canterbury. With three games remaining, Robin Smith's team are 43 points from safety.
fields.body:
Hampshire are almost certain to be playing in the Second Division next season after losing a tense, fluctuating match to Kent by 15 runs at Canterbury. With three games remaining, Robin Smith's team are 43 points from safety.

Beginning the final day needing a further 61 to win with four wickets left, Hampshire stumbled against an ailing Martin McCague. The former England bowler was hampered by an ankle injury but he produced his best figures of the season, five for 52, to relieve Kent's own relegation worries.

McCague bowled two decisive spells. With the old ball, he had Dmitri Mascarenhas caught behind and Shane Warne taken at slip by David Fulton. Then, after Martin Saggers and David Masters had failed to finish off the Hampshire innings with the new ball, he came back to dismiss Shaun Udal and Alan Mullally in three deliveries.

Derbyshire took only 20 minutes and five overs to polish off the remaining four Durham wickets yesterday morning and complete a 232-run victory. Tim Munton and Kevin Dean split the wickets, Dean completing match figures of nine for 101 to take his first-class tally for the season to 39 at an average of little more than 15 and enhance his prospects of an A tour this winter.

It was a long overdue win for Derbyshire, whose only success in 19 matches in all competitions since June had been against the Derbyshire Board XI in the NatWest Trophy. But Kent's victory has almost certainly condemned both of them and Durham to relegation, as they are 31 and 22 points adrift respectively with only two games to play.

Though the picture is becoming clearer in the First Division, promotion from the Second is still far from clear-cut. Glamorgan replaced Sussex in third place after beating them by an innings and 60 runs at Colwyn Bay.

With six second-innings wickets in hand, Sussex's task was to bat through the final day but their cause was undermined in the first over of the day when Chris Adams, to his obvious displeasure, was adjudged leg before to Alex Wharf for 68.

Robin Martin-Jenkins and Umer Rashid added 84 in 17 overs before Adrian Dale ended their resistance, taking four wickets.

Somerset 's players are hoping for an £11,000 bonus today. Vodafone will pay out if the county beat the West Indians at Taunton. Set 439 to win, the tourists lost Chris Gayle before the close, bowled second ball by Jason Kerr for a duck.

After their captain Jamie Cox chose not to enforce the follow-on despite a first-innings lead of 198, Somerset spent the afternoon consolidating against an unthreatening West Indian attack. After tea Michael Burns accelerated towards the declaration with 78 not out from 99 balls.

Nottinghamshire's all-rounder Paul Franks has been named as the Cricket Writers' Club young player of the year.

fields.headline: Lancashire frustrated by feisty DeFreitas
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 372 & 408-6 dec
Lancashire 574-5 dec
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 372 & 408-6 dec
Lancashire 574-5 dec
Match drawn
fields.body:
"Give over, Phil," pleaded a weary Lancastrian, but Phil DeFreitas had spent the previous three days being perfectly beastly to his erstwhile county and was not about to stop now.

Pruning each thorn with a casual deftness Percy Thrower might have envied, he took his match total to 220 runs for once out with a career-best unbeaten 123, the eighth century of a career that began in a blaze of belligerence, lit the odd furnace, and is now drawing to a close with a snug, warm glow.

Throw in a marathon piece of strangulation with the ball and it was this much-maligned cricketer who left the Red Rose title challenge wilting on a pitch that might conceivably deteriorate by Christmas.

Lancashire's chances of joining Surrey at the top of the table rested squarely with their in-form exponents of artful dodgery, Gary Keedy and Chris Schofield, but for all the duo's guile and persistence, only the odd ball misbehaved, and too slowly to encourage more than the odd whiff of hope.

Amid a summer polluted by indifferent surfaces and flattered bowlers however, it would be churlish to decry this one, much as the illustrious denizens of the Sky commentary box might have bemoaned the dearth of fireworks. If they are to have any beneficial effect on five-day techniques, four-day games on durable strips must surely be preferable.

Sober of mien, assured in defence, fluent on the drive, Iain Sutcliffe picked up from where he left off the previous evening only to fall shortly after reaching a worthy half-century, sweeping but not middling Keedy and locating Glen Chapple at deep midwicket. Ben Smith, too, was far from submissive before nicking a nigh-perfect leg-break from Schofield. So far, so promising.

Keedy struck again nine overs later, the last but one before lunch, terminating Darren Stevens's brief flurry in classical style: batsman bemused by one that spins the other way, then drawn forward, ball turning just enough to prevent full contact - silly mid-on over moon, victim parrot-sick, game on. All the more so when, with the arrears still uncleared, Jon Dakin's rumbustious flow was cut short as Schofield consigned the left-hander to the same fate.

Aftab Habib was now joined by DeFreitas, another astute player of spin, and jitters gradually gave way to assurance. Stoical and streetwise, they added 111 in 32 overs with nary a flicker of a chance bar a near miss by Neil Fairbrother; Habib would have been history had the throw gone an inch the other way. In toto, the pair contributed 389 to the Foxes' cause, more than half the runs off the bat.

The final session began with Leicestershire 88 in profit, hope flaring anew as Keedy finally found something other than the solid centre of Habib's bat. Neil Burns, though, held firm as DeFreitas flayed past his previous best of 113 set against Nottinghamshire 12 years ago. It was a shiny, happy Daffy who accepted the acclaim, a four and two sixes off successive balls from John Crawley a fitting release. Still feisty after all these years.

webTitle: Headingley quick fix gives junior cricket a tidal surge

fields.headline: Headingley quick fix gives junior cricket a tidal surge
fields.standfirst: Jim White on cricket's post-Headingley revival among our pre-teens
fields.trailText: Jim White on cricket's post-Headingley revival among our pre-teens.
fields.body:
If the letters page of the Daily Telegraph is any guide, diehard cricket fans are matched only by Radio 4 listeners in their resolute resistance to change.

The unending whingeing about the wonderful Headingley Test victory reveals that for them nothing is right with the modern game, and the past remains a glorious country of better technique and five-day bore-athons.

But my own highly unscientific research suggests that thanks to poor shot-making in that two-day sprint, cricket is enjoying a boom in the most important market of all: impressionable under-10s.

Down in Pembrokeshire for the long weekend, I have noticed that virtually every square inch of beach is occupied with games of cricket.

Last year there wasn't a bat or ball in sight as the children essayed their Cruyff turns and Vieira two-foot lunges. But now the sand is covered with boys bowling like Goughie, girls batting like Vaughan, and fathers demonstrating that the England selectors are indeed drawing from a very limited talent pool.

At a Whitesands Bay gift shop near St Davids the woman behind the counter said there had been a run on miniature cricket sets, several years of unwanted stock being shifted from the back room.

Suddenly it seems that cricket, from a minority pursuit played only in private schools, is becoming a shared obsession once again. And all because of one famous win. If only the cricket authorities had thought of it years ago.

fields.headline: Revolutionary plans another one-day strike
fields.standfirst: John Bracewell has coached Gloucestershire to yet another Lord's final
fields.trailText: John Bracewell has coached Gloucestershire to yet another Lord's final.
fields.body:
There is surely a revealing thesis to be written, at a radical faculty of psychology somewhere or other, on the clinically devised game of one-day cricket as practised by Gloucestershire.

They, and in particular their coach John Bracewell, have quietly revolutionised it, dispensing illogical shocks and sweeping away the cobwebs to reach an historic fourth successive Lord's final against Warwickshire in the NatWest Trophy today.

Gloucestershire are far from the best side in the country. Yet with an astute formula that takes into account everything from the quirks of the psyche and Jack Russell's cherished baked beans to individual strengths and flaws, they have outfought and frightened the life out of opponents whose sides are stacked with more illustrious names.

Bracewell, 42, the tall, lean Kiwi who patrols the outfield during a county match looking like a middle-aged venture scout in shorts he has outgrown, is eternally vibrant with new ideas, paternal common sense and striking phraseology. He talks about one of Gloucestershire's first finals under him: "Of the awe in actually being there, the excitement, the butterflies flying in unison."

One of four cricketing brothers who himself played in 41 Tests, he was known at home for his high-action off-spinners that attacked the batsmen rather than contained their scoring; for his extrovert traits and the ambitious glint that suggested one day he hoped to be the national coach.

He remains extrovert, ready with a contentious view when he thinks it is justified - just ask Worcestershire, who still feel hard done by that Gloucestershire were given a second shot at them after they played an unqualified bowler - and is probably the most articulate, intrepid, single-minded coach on the domestic circuit.

"Competitive, me? I'd rather you called me passionate. I like fighting causes, championing the underdog. I've socialist tendencies. In another age I'd probably have been a martyr or, at the turn of the previous century, a union representative. I think all coaches should be socialists, you know - they should have the interests of the team first and how all the parts make up that team. If the coach only concentrates on individuals who are statistically successful, then he'll run into trouble."

It is not usual to be given political or social treatises in the context of cricket. But then he returns to today's game: "We have players particularly equipped for the one-day game. Many of them are frustrated footballers. They throw themselves around in the field. All I've done is create the environment for learning. I take a great pride in the sharing of knowledge."

His approach encompasses diet and discipline. He discourages too much drinking. He doesn't like mickey-taking ("it's a belittling kind of humour"). He denies he is a martinet: "I get the players to set the standards - I tell them the rules are theirs not mine."

The players occasionally exchange looks as he comes up with another theory or drives them relentlessly in exercise. Mike Smith, one of the more experienced players, says: "John is intense, determined. He certainly doesn't like losing. He'll be treating any attempts at a wind-up by Bob Woolmer very seriously indeed." Chris Taylor, in his first season, says: "He has been very encouraging to me as a newcomer. The advice he gives is very much on an individual basis."

Bracewell argues that he has the bonus of an outstanding one-day captain in Mark Alleyne: "He has a natural instinct for it." But every member of the team will be studiously told what he has to do within Gloucestershire's formula. "The guys are prepared to switch and change to fit in."

Many thought Bracewell would have gone by now, back to New Zealand as their coach. It looks as though his contract will be extended at Bristol, however. "I'm still only an apprentice, making my way and making notes as I go. To be honest, I'm a bit afraid of becoming a national coach, not sure I'm quite ready."

He says he gave up playing in 1990 because he did not want to be an absentee parent. He did not want to keep on touring. Now his children are being educated in Bristol. "For the time being I'm keen to attend their school concerts and see them playing games."

Bracewell refutes any suggestion that he prefers to concentrate much of his energy and thinking on the one-day game. "My long-term aim is for Gloucestershire to win the championship - they just have to add something to their mental attitude." In the short term it is likely they will want to bat first - though 12 out of the past 13 finals have gone to the team batting last - and for Tim Hancock and Kim Barnett to race away in the style that has served them so well.

By contrast, it is hard to know what has been going through Bob Woolmer's mind. Has the homecoming to Warwickshire been as embracing and reassuring as he would have liked? He, too, is talented, fluent in conversation, with plenty of opinions. When he was previously at Edgbaston, the silverware bulged from the cabinets. Brian Lara was hitting 500 runs in an innings, Dermot Reeve was winding up opponents and motivating his players, who in turn were winning almost everything going.

Woolmer badly needs to recruit additional talent as much as he needs the psychological lift of a win today. Soon Allan Donald, capable of making an aggressively crucial Lord's exit, will be gone - and no doubt Ed Giddins, too, if as seems likely he moves back south.

There has also been some anxiety over the captaincy. Woolmer appears to wonder whether Neil Smith should be automatically assured of a place when another slow bowler, Ashley Giles, is around? Is Smith, doubtless desperate to do well today, reliable enough from down the order as a batsman in championship matches?

Warwickshire still have match-winners and players who can respond to the glamour of the occasion. They also need overdue restored status. But it does look as though Gloucestershire, those west country upstarts, are at least ahead in the mind games.

But then he returns to today's game: "We have players particularly equipped for the one-day game. Many of them are frustrated footballers. They throw themselves around in the field. All I've done is create the environment for learning. I take a great pride in the sharing of knowledge." His approach encompasses diet and discipline. He discourages too much drinking. He doesn't like mickey-taking ("it's a belittling kind of humour"). He denies he is a martinet: "I get the players to set the standards - I tell them the rules are theirs not mine." The players occasionally exchange looks as he comes up with another theory or drives them relentlessly in exercise. Mike Smith, one of the more experienced players, says: "John is intense, determined. He certainly doesn't like losing. He'll be treating any attempts at a wind-up by Bob Woolmer very seriously indeed." Chris Taylor, in his first season, says: "He has been very encouraging to me as a newcomer. The advice he gives is very much on an individual basis." Bracewell argues that he has the bonus of an outstanding one-day captain in Mark Alleyne: "He has a natural instinct for it." But every member of the team will be studiously told what he has to do within Gloucestershire's formula. "The guys are prepared to switch and change to fit in." Many thought Bracewell would have gone by now, back to New Zealand as their coach. It looks as though his contract will be extended at Bristol, however. "I'm still only an apprentice, making my way and making notes as I go. To be honest, I'm a bit afraid of becoming a national coach, not sure I'm quite ready." He says he gave up playing in 1990 because he did not want to be an absentee parent. He did not want to keep on touring. Now his children are being educated in Bristol. "For the time being I'm keen to attend their school concerts and see them playing games." Bracewell refutes any suggestion that he prefers to concentrate much of his energy and thinking on the one-day game. "My long-term aim is for Gloucestershire to win the championship - they just have to add something to their mental attitude." In the short term it is likely they will want to bat first - though 12 out of the past 13 finals have gone to the team batting last - and for Tim Hancock and Kim Barnett to race away in the style that has served them so well. By contrast, it is hard to know what has been going through Bob Woolmer's mind. Has the homecoming to Warwickshire been as embracing and reassuring as he would have liked? He, too, is talented, fluent in conversation, with plenty of opinions. When he was previously at Edgbaston, the silverware bulged from the cabinets. Brian Lara was hitting 500 runs in an innings, Dermot Reeve was winding up opponents and motivating his players, who in turn were winning almost everything going. Woolmer badly needs to recruit additional talent as much as he needs the psychological lift of a win today. Soon Allan Donald, capable of making an aggressively crucial Lord's exit, will be gone - and no doubt Ed Giddins, too, if as seems likely he moves back south. There has also been some anxiety over the captaincy. Woolmer appears to wonder whether Neil Smith should be automatically assured of a place when another slow bowler, Ashley Giles, is around? Is Smith, doubtless desperate to do well today, reliable enough from down the order as a batsman in championship matches? Warwickshire still have match-winners and players who can respond to the glamour of the occasion. They also need overdue restored status. But it does look as though Gloucestershire, those west country upstarts, are at least ahead in the mind games.

fields.headline: America orders safety checks on 767s
fields.trailText: US regulators ordered the country's airlines to check the tail elevator controls on Boeing 767 jets yesterday after checks revealed failed rivets in three planes, adding weight to claims that last October's EgyptAir crash was caused by a mechanical malfunction.
fields.body:
US regulators ordered the country's airlines to check the tail elevator controls on Boeing 767 jets yesterday after checks revealed failed rivets in three planes, adding weight to claims that last October's EgyptAir crash was caused by a mechanical malfunction.

Announcing the inspections, the federal aviation administration (FAA) said it had no evidence that faulty rivets were implicated in the crash of the EgyptAir Boeing 767, which plunged into the Atlantic, killing 217 people.

A crash investigation is under way, but US officials have said they believe the plane was brought down by a suicidal co-pilot, Gamil al-Batouti. Egypt has denied the suggestion, pointing instead to the possibility of a mechanical fault in the tail elevator assembly.

The elevators are horizontal flaps which can be moved to control the angle of the plane's nose. They are manipulated by a screw mechanism known as a bellcrank, which is kept in position by shear-rivets. If the system powering the elevators jams, the pilot can break the rivets by applying sufficient force on their controls and manually override the system.

In yesterday's advisory note the FAA said: "Failed shear rivets on two or more bellcrank assemblies could produce abnormal elevator movements and consequent reduced controllability or loss of control."

The rivets on EgyptAir's elevator system recovered from the ocean had been sheared. US officials suggested that this meant the pilot and Batouti had been pushing on the controls in opposite directions. Cairo argued that the broken rivets suggested they were defective to begin with.

Meanwhile, smoke in the passenger cabin caused an American Airlines Boeing 767 en route from London to New York to land in north-eastern Canada yesterday. The airline said the smoke was caused by an electrical problem.

webTitle: They've lost the plot and they've lost their hair

fields.headline: They've lost the plot and they've lost their hair
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: Ron the Manager passes judgement on the opening week of the Premiership.
fields.body:
Phew! What a start to the season... isn't it? Wasn't it? Vieira sent off three times in two games! How did he manage it?... The Premiership's back!... And the fixtures are piling up and... er... there's 37 weeks to go and... Surely it's about time we gave some serious consideration to a winter break?!... Mind you, at least we had some sort of gap. In the "low" countries they even had some kind of Mickey Mouse tournament on during the cricket!

But what a whirlwind whistle-stop weekend it was... wasn't it?... hmm? What a baptism of fire at the Valley for Man City! Tipped by Kevin Keegan as his outside choice for a successful season on their return to the top flight!... Oo-er!... Bet that set the alarm bells ringing at Maine Road! Well Joe may have spent "Royley" in the close season... but as little Dennis Wise says: "Pesetas don't mean prizes!"... er... And as Big Norm always says: "You can't knock down a coconut every time!"

The final whistle... and it's back on the train for the away fans... and myself!... heading up north for the following day's game at Old Trafford!... eagerly expecting to catch the match reports in the late sports extra ... the old Pink!... and one of the Sky Blues' "long-suffering" supporters tells me it's folded!... Eh?

Lad culture!... That's what's to blame!... Nowadays if you want to read about football it's the glossies!... Monthly magazines full of sex and innuendo... not like the thrill of getting hold of the old pink 'un on a Saturday evening!

Next day... on my way to Lou Macari's Fish Bar... a familiar face... it's Big Ron Atkinson!... And blow me! He's got one of those little collapsible silver scooters! He suggested a couple of beers after the game... and whoof!... he's off like a bat out of hell!

If United have brought anything back from their forays into Europe... it's baldness!... A far cry from their European Cup team of the swinging sixties... hmm?... haircuts that stood the test of time!

Remember George Best... "el Beatle"... Bobby Charlton!... er... in his pomp!

And now Ferguson's bald buy Barthez has slapped a ban on team-mates kissing his head!... About time!... Made you feel a bit queasy hmm?

The influx of foreigners may have brought a bit of "flair" to the Premiership but some things you'd rather not see on a football pitch!

Remember Stanley Matthews in his pomp?... Little shimmy wasn't it?... Drop of the shoulder... and BANG!... Pick that one out of the net! Quick handshake and back to the centre circle... done!

Why do players today have to celebrate a goal by cavor ting around... acting out little scenes?... All that kissing and cuddling?... Hmm? In my day all that stuff was confined to after the game!

After the game... on to a rather plush little place out of town... and by the time I arrive... Big Ron's on his second "Blue Lagoon!" and expounding his theory on the two Manchester teams to Ken Bates!... Traditionally your typical opening game of the season sees City... "do their pieces and come a cropper"... while United... "hit the ground running!"

But for me United aren't yet the finished article... The midfield doesn't gel!... And even if the manager's advice to "keep their hair on" falls on deaf ears... you'd think the merchandising men would blow the whistle!... Remember how sales of the Ruud Gullit wig transformed humble Chelsea's fortunes!... Er... earned me a typically robust response from Ken Bates!... Er... ho ho... Don't worry, Ken, I won't quote you on that!

Well before we knew it... time for the last train back!... And as Ken's chauffeur bore him away into the night, a bus came round the corner and I bet Big Ron a fiver I'd beat him to the station... ho ho!... He can't resist a challenge!... And within 10 minutes I was within sight of Manchester Piccadilly!... But just as I got to my feet to ring the bell... I saw a flash of silver... and thundering up on the inside!... a hulking figure looming out of the darkness... It's Big Ron on his scooter!... left leg pawing the ground furiously!... And slightly misjudging the speed at which we were travelling, I leapt from the bus, hit the ground running... came a cropper... and er... did my pieces!

As for City?... Didn't they come bouncing back midweek!... United?... A draw with Ipswich?... What a stupid game football is!... Surely its about time we gave some serious consideration to an autumn break?!

And this week's one to watch! The ever-green Paul Ince. Nickname - "The Self-styled Guv'nor"... Lean as a whippet... Barking orders!... Remember him at Upton Park?... He was barking then!... Midfield general!... Always re-positioning his privates!... BANG!... Watch that one cannon off the hoardings!

webTitle: Video panel blows the whistle on referee

fields.headline: Video panel blows the whistle on referee
fields.standfirst: Vivek Chaudhary on the roll of shame
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary on the roll of shame.
fields.body:
It has not been a good week for Graham Poll. On Monday he was savaged by the Highbury crowd as he sent off Gary McAllister, Patrick Vieira and Dietmar Hamann. On Tuesday he was pilloried by the press. The next day he admitted that he was wrong about sending Hamann off, and yesterday an FA video review panel said that he had got the McAllister decision wrong too.

The panel reduced McAllister's punishment to a yellow card and also charged Gilles Grimandi with misconduct after he was shown on television stamping on the Liverpool midfielder. As Poll runs out at Portman Road this afternoon, he could be forgiven for thinking that there is no part of English football that he has not alienated this season.

The new FA panels are made up of three officials chosen from a pool of 12 former players and managers who are sent videotapes of incidents. The panel upheld Vieira's sending-off against Sunderland on the opening day of the season and also ordered that charges of misconduct should be brought against Preston North End and Sheffield United for a mass brawl.

Although the panels' decisions can be overturned by the FA's disciplinary commission, their existence can only increase the pressure on referees, who already come in for plenty of criticism. A spokesman for the FA said: "There has always been a right to appeal. The video panels are not designed to undermine referees. The pressure on them is not coming from the FA."

Many within the game claim that the pressure on referees is self-generated. They say that too many red and yellow cards have been handed out by unreasonable referees who are unable to manage games properly. But referees insist they are doing nothing different this year and that they have been given only one new directive, borrowed from Euro 2000, where the refereeing was considered a success.

According to Philip Don, referees officer for the Premier League, it was found that when referees clamp down on offences in the first 15 to 20 minutes it leads to less retaliation from players later in the match, firmly establishes the authority of the referee and allows the game to flow more smoothly.

Two games into the new Premiership season and the men in the middle stand accused of doing exactly the opposite. The figures speak for themselves. After two matches in the Premiership last season only four red and 81 yellow cards had been shown, and four penalties and 516 free-kicks had been awarded. This season after two matches there have been eight red cards and 590 free-kicks. However, referees have shown only 72 yellow cards and given four penalties.

Don insists that when the 20 Premier League referees met at Lilleshall to discuss the forthcoming season they were told to continue as last season in the way they run their games. Don said: "Last season we went from a situation of clamping down on a number of areas to leniency, and nothing has changed as far as we are concerned. There is no new clampdown this season.

"We are still refereeing the same way as we were last season. In summing up to the referees at Lilleshall I reiterated that they should carry on as they had the previous season."

Don denies that the new directive to clamp down early on minor offences is responsible for the increase in sending-offs. "Our new directive has not led to more red cards. In fact, we told referees at Lilleshall not to caution too early, but obviously if a major offence is committed then ref erees have no option but to apply the letter of the law."

Many feel, however, given the number of red cards this season, something has changed. Players and managers blame the referees, accusing them of not understanding the game, but Don and his colleagues claim that players and managers are responsible.

Don said: "We are at the beginning of a new season and players are going out there to impress. Squads are bigger, everybody is fighting for their places and they are raring to go. Everybody's got a responsibility. Referees seem to shoulder the blame for everything these days. Managers have a responsibility to control their players and players also have a responsibility."

Don points to two games this past week as an example of how players can be held responsible for many of the problems.

On Tuesday night, at Ipswich against Manchester United, the first free-kick was awarded in the 28th minute and by the end of the match a total of 16 free-kicks had been given.

On Monday night, at the controversial Arsenal against Liverpool match, a total of 47 free-kicks were awarded.

Don said: "This has to be down to the attitude of the players. They must also share the blame. Monday night, for example, was a very difficult match. You cannot blame the referee."

What the rest of the Premiership thinks

Arsène Wenger, Arsenal manager

"I will not sit down with referees to discuss these problems. It is not my job to explain to them how to run the game. It is important there is respect on both sides but also that we don't become too friendly because then the pressure would be even greater. I feel there is respect for referees. I believe they try their best and are honest but they always have to try to improve. Some decisions have annoyed me. I feel sometimes I am part of a circus."

Roy Keane, Manchester United captain

"Everyone is under a lot of pressure, the players and the referees. To be fair to the refs, a lot of them are willing to hold up their hands after certain games and say: 'Yes, I did make a mistake.' We were criticised for having a go at Andy D'Urso last season and in cases like that, you have to realise the referee is only human and that, like us footballers, they will make mistakes. You have to hope it evens itself out over the season."

Martin Tyler,

Sky Sports senior football commentator

"Referees are having to operate with one hand tied to their cards. By bringing in mandatory decision-making Fifa has undermined the managerial skills of top referees to deal with individual incidents and matches. Each referee has his own personality and style, but a lot of that has been lost in searching for a perfect world that you will never find. You cannot make 20 people referee the same way."

Neil Lennon,

Leicester City midfielder

"This is the norm for the start of the season and, once an equilibrium is established between players, managers and referees, it will sort itself out. At the moment refs are a bit too hasty to dish out the bookings rather than having a quiet word. I thought Igor Stimac was unlucky against us at West Ham with the second booking. The ref might have said: "One more challenge and you're gone." If that had been me, I'd have been a bit aggrieved.

The Premiership players sent off so far this season are:

Charity Shield: Aug 13 Roy Keane (Man Utd) v Chelsea

Premiership: Aug 19 Patrick Vieira (Arsenal) v Sunderland, David Thompson (Coventry) v Middlesbrough Aug 21 Vieira (Arsenal) v Liverpool; Gary McAllister, Dietmar Hamann (Liverpool) Aug 23 Warren Barton (Newcastle) v Derby, Carl Tiler (Charlton) v Everton, Igor Stimac (West Ham v Leicester)

Europe: Aug 8 Olivier Dacourt, Eirik Bakke (Leeds) v 1860 Munich

fields.headline: O'Neill faces the fervour
fields.standfirst: Celtic's coach attends his first Old Firm derby tomorrow. He is unlikely to be underwhelmed
fields.trailText: Celtic's coach attends his first Old Firm derby tomorrow. He is unlikely to be underwhelmed.
fields.body:
The first Old Firm match of the season will be a teeming spectacle at Celtic Park tomorrow. In the acrid atmosphere in Glasgow on these occasions the first consideration often has nothing to do with football, and this clash is no different.

The game kicks off at 1pm, which still seems a blasphemous hour on the Sabbath in Scotland, but at least it militates against the drunken hordes turning up at the turnstiles on a tankful.

The kick-off time is a hangover from the infamous Old Firm clash at this same stadium in May last year, when the atmosphere flared as Rangers clinched the championship and the referee Hugh Dallas had blood dripping from his face. The authorities declared afterwards that to offer these clubs an evening kick-off, which allowed their supporters prolonged pre-match drinking time, was tantamount to officially inviting trouble. Like the dark days of the 1970s, the Old Firm are back on trial.

The backdrop for Martin O'Neill, in this context still a callow Celtic manager, is poignant. He has come to a club who are agonised by years of consistent failure against their great rivals. After Tommy Burns, Wim Jansen, Jozef Venglos and John Barnes, O'Neill is Celtic's fifth manager in as many years. To Celtic supporters the chapters of failure against David Murray's remorseless Rangers have become almost demeaning.

O'Neill, on the verge of being pitched into the noisiest footballing firmament of his life, was bracing himself yesterday for the 60,000 due to descend on Parkhead. After a lifetime of supporting Celtic, it will be a baptism of a sort.

"It will be my first Old Firm game in the flesh; I haven't been to one before," he said. "As a manager, for some reason, I never made it up to a game, and as a boy in Belfast my parents weren't of a mind to let me hop on a boat and come over for a weekend. So it's something for me to look forward to. I think this is probably the biggest derby game in the world, which is a testimony to the two teams."

O'Neill would be aided in his understanding of the Old Firm hothouse if he gleaned right from the start that this legendary fixture is full of contradictions. For one thing, Celtic supporters chant that their foes are "Protestant scum", and Rangers fans in turn sing a dirge about "the Fenian bastards" at the other end - all of which sounds pretty despicable. Yet these are supporters who work together, drink together and play five-a-side football together - then on match-day separate themselves as sheep from goats to scream bile at each other from opposite ends of the ground. Though only a fool underestimates bigotry, it is fact that this fixture carries a lot of empty ritual.

O'Neill will also soon learn, in the context of the Old Firm, that a fine line is drawn between disapproval and voyeurism. In Scotland it is an old media trick for sportwriters to pen lambasting pieces about the ugliness of the Old Firm atmosphere, while secretly crossing their fingers that each occasion proves as fiery and garish as ever.

When Rangers and Celtic collide and the blood-vessels are popping, it is hard to become divorced from the primitive savouring of it. "They are great occasions with great atmospheres," Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, said again last week of a spectacle which the churches condemn. Parkhead tomorrow will be no place for puritans.

Celtic have not won an opening Old Firm league fixture since 1994. Last season they lost 10 of the 12 points available in the fixture. It was seven league matches ago that they last recorded a victory over Rangers. These are all symbolic statistics pointing up the bleak times that O'Neill has inherited in Glasgow's east end.

"I'm trying to be realistic about the game," said O'Neill. "I feel we've made good progress since I came here. I honestly feel Celtic are in as good a shape as we possibly could be at the moment. But I won't be able to stop people from saying that if we lose then we've made no progress, and if we win then the title's just around the corner.

"As for the fixture, we all hope there can be reasonable behaviour both on and off the pitch. But this is a big game, as I say, one of the biggest in the world. How you actually contain all the emotional elements, I really don't know."

Celtic have injury doubts over both Tommy Johnson and Alan Stubbs, and Rangers surprisingly claimed yesterday that their German howitzer Jorg Albertz would not be fit. One player who will play is Stéphane Mahe, the Celtic player sent off in a cloud of red mist in that infamous clash two seasons ago, who claimed yesterday that Celtic have "more fighting spirit" under O'Neill. So Glasgow awaits a peaceful afternoon.

fields.headline: Leeds face dreaded return
fields.standfirst: While Arsenal and Manchester United are Ukraine-bound, David O'Leary's side will travel to Istanbul
fields.trailText: While Arsenal and Manchester United are Ukraine-bound, David O'Leary's side will travel to Istanbul.
fields.body:
The Champions League has given Manchester United and Arsenal a couple of long hops and bowled Leeds United a beamer. Sir Alex Ferguson's team will have to fly to Kiev in the first round while Arsenal go to Donetsk, but Leeds are back where they least wanted to be.

Ideally Ferguson and Arsène Wenger would have preferred not to take their teams to Ukraine but in October Leeds will return to Istanbul, where two of their supporters died after being stabbed during street violence in the Turkish capital on the eve of their Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray in April. Now they have to meet Besiktas.

Trouble flared outside Elland Road before the return match with Gala and the violent scenes in the centre of Copenhagen on the day of the final between Arsenal and the Turkish side stemmed from the earlier deaths.

The English and Turkish FAs, plus their respective security operations, will hope that most of the anger will have abated by the time David O'Leary's side visit Besiktas on October 18 but the arrests of a number of Leeds fans in Munich this week for giving Nazi salutes in a beer hall has not bred confidence that the match will be trouble-free.

After the draw, the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale said: "We will consult with everyone concerned before the matches are played and we will discuss fully whether Leeds fans can travel to Istanbul or whether Turkish fans can travel to Leeds.

"Whatever happens I am certain there will be no repeat of the tragedy of last time. It is an opportunity for everyone to prove that we can meet in a friendly, sporting rivalry and that we can rise above what happened."

Even from a purely footballing point of view Leeds could hardly have been given a more difficult first-round group. In addition to Besiktas, the English club will play Barcelona and Milan, both of whom will start favourites to go through from Group H. Although, with Barca still stunned following the departure of Luis Figo to Real Madrid and barely mollified by the arrival of Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit from Arsenal, Leeds will not be too concerned at starting in the Nou Camp stadium.

Dynamo Kiev should not present such a threat to Manchester United now that Sergei Rebrov, signed by Tottenham in May, has followed Andrei Shevchenko abroad. But the Ukrainian side will doubtless have retained a sufficient quality of passing and movement to give the English and erstwhile European champions an awkward game there in three weeks' time.

Ferguson's team begin their latest quest for Champions League success at Old Trafford with the visit of Anderlecht, whom they routed 10-0 on first entering the European Cup in 1956. The encounter will be closer this time but it is still a match United should win.

PSV Eindhoven, Manchester United's other opponents in Group G, may be a trickier proposition. Ruud van Nistelrooy, who still interests Ferguson despite a cruciate ligament injury, is unlikely to be fit in time to play against United and Luc Nilis has gone to Aston Villa, but PSV have spent £10m on Mateja Kezman, a youthful Yugoslav striker, and still have the strength and experience to cause an upset.

Arsenal's best chance of improving on what so far has been a dismal experience in the Champions League lies in the club's decision to play their home matches at Highbury instead of switching them to Wembley in order to accommodate bigger crowds.

What is lost in gate receipts may well be recouped, with interest, if Wenger's side can exploit genuine home advantage to see of Sparta Prague and Shakhtar Donetsk while avoiding defeat against Lazio, who come to Highbury in a month's time for an occasion to savour.

"Lazio must be the favourites to win the group," said Wenger yesterday. "It will be a tough battle for us, but with the experience we have gained in the Champions League, plus the fact that we will be playing at Highbury, we should be capable of going through."

Arsenal's first game takes them to Sparta Prague, who have lost their defender Petr Gabriel and striker Vratislav Lokvenc to Kaiserslautern and defender Miroslav Baranek to Cologne. Czech sides should never be underestimated but Sparta may present less of a problem for Arsenal than Shakhtar Donetsk.

According to Oleg Luzhny, Arsenal's former Dynamo Kiev defender, the Shakhtar stadium is the most intimidating ground in Ukraine. Wenger is also worried that, by the time Arsenal travel there in November, the conditions may be freezing.
