fields.headline: Scots sweating on Burley's calf
fields.trailText: Scotland's manager Craig Brown intends to give his key midfielder Craig Burley every chance to prove his fitness before their World Cup qualifying campaign gets under way in Latvia a week today.
fields.body:
Scotland's manager Craig Brown intends to give his key midfielder Craig Burley every chance to prove his fitness before their World Cup qualifying campaign gets under way in Latvia a week today.

The Derby player, who Brown named in a 23-man squad yesterday, is expected to miss today's club match at Everton due to injury. "He's in London having a specialist look at his calf," the manager said. "Burley is a key member of the squad and without him we've got to improvise either at right-back or in midfield."

Brown also gave the thumbs-up to the veteran centre-half Colin Hendry, who was also named despite being dropped by his club Coventry after their first game of the season.

"You want settled players when you make your selection but an experienced player like that will be able to shrug it off," Brown said. "It's a disappointment, obviously, that he's not going to get match practice at Coventry. But he's never let Scotland down."

Newcastle's Kevin Gallacher is likely to earn his 50th cap in Riga, which would make him only the 22nd Scot to reach that landmark. And Celtic's transfer-listed striker Mark Burchill could find himself being elevated from the Under-21s, who play in Riga on the Friday evening, if he impresses in tomorrow's Old Firm derby at Parkhead.

Scotland, who were drawn against Latvia in the 1998 World Cup qualifiers and beat them 2-0 in both matches, will be hoping for a good start as their next two fixtures are also away from Hampden Park, in San Marino and then Croatia, both in October.

Ipswich's captain Matt Holland and Watford's reserve striker Dominic Foley have been named in the Republic of Ireland squad for their World Cup qualifier against Holland in Amsterdam next Saturday.

Both impressed during the Republic's three-match unbeaten tour of the United States, though the manager Mick McCarthy has pruned his original 30-man squad down to 22 with Manchester United's Roy Keane again named as the captain.

Republic squad : A Kelly (Blackburn), Given (Newcastle, Kiely (Charlton), Carr (Tottenham), G Kelly (Leeds), Harte (Leeds), Staunton (Liverpool), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Everton), Babb (Sporting Lisbon), Roy Keane (Man Utd), Kinsella (Charlton), Finnan (Fulham), McAteer (Blackburn), Kennedy (Man City), Kilbane (Sunderland), Duff (Blackburn), Holland (Ipswich), Quinn (Sunderland), Connolly (Excelsior), Robbie Keane (Inter), Foley (Watford).

Scotland squad : Douglas (Dundee), Gould (Celtic), Sullivan (Tottenham), Boyd (Celtic), Dailly (Blackburn), Elliott (Leicester), Hendry (Coventry), Naysmith (Hearts), O'Neil (Wolfsburg), Pressley (Hearts), Weir (Everton), Burley (Derby), Cameron (Hearts), Davidson (Leicester), Ferguson (Rangers), Holt (Kilmarnock), Johnston (Rangers), Lambert (Celtic), McNamara (Celtic), Dodds (Rangers), Gallacher (Newcastle), Hutchison (Sunderland), McCann (Rangers).

webTitle: Savio shapes up as Vialli's real target

fields.headline: Savio shapes up as Vialli's real target
fields.trailText: The Chelsea manager, Gianluca Vialli, has admitted that the club have been talking to Real Madrid - but not about signing unwanted England midfielder Steve McManaman.
fields.body:
The Chelsea manager, Gianluca Vialli, has admitted that the club have been talking to Real Madrid - but not about signing unwanted England midfielder Steve McManaman.

Their interest instead lies with the £8m-rated Brazilian forward Savio, in whom Lazio have also expressed an interest.

Savio, who has an Italian passport, can play anywhere up front and may be seen as a left winger by Vialli. When asked if he had any interest in the 26-year-old, the Chelsea manager did not deny it. "We are keeping an eye on a few players and making inquiries, but that doesn't mean we would go for them."

However, Vialli dismissed reports linking him with McManaman, whom Real want to sell. "We are not interested as I think we have enough in our squad and don't need to go out and spend that sort of money. Certainly not as one report claimed for £12m and Tore Andre Flo."

Vialli also revealed that he had patched up his disagreement with Frank Leboeuf following the France defender's criticism of the manager, and added that the player the defender would be staying at Chelsea.

Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege has joined Liverpool in a deal initially worth £5.5m after a legal decision went in the defender's favour, but Boro are now demanding a further £2.5m.

"It does leave a bad taste in the mouth, I've lost a very good player," said manager Bryan Robson. "I have no problem personally with Ziege. The question I would ask is: where were Liverpool a year ago when we signed him? They had no interest then."

Ziege now joins German teammates Didi Hamann and Markus Babbel, taking Gerard Houllier's spending to more than £50m.

Ziege, who has 52 caps for Germany, and Boro have been at loggerheads over a clause in the player's contract which said the German defender could leave if a club offered more than £5m for him.

" What we get now will be on top of the £5.5m, the valuation has to be discussed with Liverpool and it will be classed as compensation. I'll be happy if we get £8m."

Portsmouth are hoping to sign former Middlesbrough striker Jaime Moreno from US Major League side DC United. Pompey inquired about the 26-year-old Bolivian striker, capped 38 times by his country, but the deal has stalled temporarily as Major League Soccer are only prepared to release him for three months, while Pompey want him for five.

Leeds United forward Harry Kewell has withdrawn from Australia's Olympic squad after an achilles tendon injury failed to respond to treatment.

Everton's Abel Xavier yesterday lost an appeal to lift his nine-month suspension from all Uefa-sanctioned games until his case is considered in October or November.

The ban was imposed following Portugal's controversial exit to France during the Euro 2000 semi-finals last June. Xavier, 27, was accused of "violently grabbing the arm of the linesman" who awarded an extra-time penalty which Zinedine Zidane went on to convert sending France to the final and Portugal into a rage.

webTitle: Football fan filmed hitting woman cleared

fields.headline: Football fan filmed hitting woman cleared
fields.standfirst: Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: A football fan who was filmed hitting a rival woman fan at a cup final match was cleared of assault yesterday.
fields.body:
A football fan who was filmed hitting a rival woman fan at a cup final match was cleared of assault yesterday.

Former nightclub doorman Jonathan Edmonds admitted punching Leicester fan Ruth Lelacheur during the 1999 Worthington Cup final against Tottenham Hotspur. She suffered from a bruised head and damaged tooth after being hit by Edmonds several times.

But the jury accepted his claim that he was acting in self-defence.

Edmonds, 32, broke down in tears in the dock when he apologised to Ms Lelacheur, 30, who had gone to the match with her partner Jim Blockley and three-year-old daughter Megan.

Edmonds, who is 6ft 5in, said: "I'm deeply sorry for what has happened, I didn't mean to do it to her."

Edmonds told the court that he had lashed out after he and three friends were set upon by Leicester fans who were unhappy that they were sitting in the Leicester end of the ground.

The jury saw CCTV footage of Edmonds falling to the ground after taking several blows to the face. He tried to get up, but was knocked to the ground several times before stumbling towards Ms Lelacheur.

Edmonds said there was no way of knowing whether she was a man or a woman as he lashed out in an attempt to get away from the Leicester fans.

He said: "People were getting very agitated and the Leicester fans started swearing a lot.

"My friend told me to stand up otherwise I was going to get hurt, so I stood up and received a blow to the face.

"I went down on the ground and tried to get up again, but I couldn't. I must have been knocked to the ground three or four times. I was being hit left, right and centre.

"Everything was a blur. I had to lash out as I had no other way of getting out of there."

Edmonds eventually left the stadium and went to a nearby pub to watch the match on television.

The prosecution claimed Edmonds and his friends had provoked the fight by standing up and shouting: "We are Tottenham. We are Tottenham."

Edmonds denied this. He said he had no idea he would be in with Leicester fans when he bought his ticket from a friend.

He said that the Leicester fans had somehow realised he and his friends were Spurs supporters, but he insisted they had done nothing which would have given them away.

He said that he would never hit a woman and was deeply disturbed by footage showing him hitting Ms Lelacheur.

Edmonds was not identified at the time of the match despite pictures of the incident appearing in several national newspapers and on television.

He decided to contact the police in March of this year after the pictures were shown on BBC's Crimewatch programme.

The jury at Harrow crown court took three hours to clear Edmonds, of Slough, Berkshire, of assault causing actual bodily harm and a separate charge of affray.

His wife Tracey broke down in tears and his friends cheered as the verdict was read out.

Mr Blockley said that his partner had been denied justice and he would try to find some way of bringing Edmonds back to court. "We were gutted by the verdict. Tony Blair talks about wanting to stamp out football violence - and there it is on cameras and yet this happens."

Press Association

Edmonds said there was no way of knowing whether she was a man or a woman as he lashed out in an attempt to get away from the Leicester fans. He said: "People were getting very agitated and the Leicester fans started swearing a lot. "My friend told me to stand up otherwise I was going to get hurt, so I stood up and received a blow to the face. "I went down on the ground and tried to get up again, but I couldn't. I must have been knocked to the ground three or four times. I was being hit left, right and centre. "Everything was a blur. I had to lash out as I had no other way of getting out of there." Edmonds eventually left the stadium and went to a nearby pub to watch the match on television. The prosecution claimed Edmonds and his friends had provoked the fight by standing up and shouting: "We are Tottenham. We are Tottenham." Edmonds denied this. He said he had no idea he would be in with Leicester fans when he bought his ticket from a friend. He said that the Leicester fans had somehow realised he and his friends were Spurs supporters, but he insisted they had done nothing which would have given them away. He said that he would never hit a woman and was deeply disturbed by footage showing him hitting Ms Lelacheur. Edmonds was not identified at the time of the match despite pictures of the incident appearing in several national newspapers and on television. He decided to contact the police in March of this year after the pictures were shown on BBC's Crimewatch programme. The jury at Harrow crown court took three hours to clear Edmonds, of Slough, Berkshire, of assault causing actual bodily harm and a separate charge of affray. His wife Tracey broke down in tears and his friends cheered as the verdict was read out. Mr Blockley said that his partner had been denied justice and he would try to find some way of bringing Edmonds back to court. "We were gutted by the verdict. Tony Blair talks about wanting to stamp out football violence - and there it is on cameras and yet this happens." Press Association

webTitle: Summit called as Leeds go back to Istanbul

fields.headline: Summit called as Leeds go back to Istanbul
fields.trailText: Leeds United got the Champions League draw they could have done without yesterday and it had nothing to do with being paired with Barcelona and Milan. Five months after two of their fans were killed in Istanbul the west Yorkshire club are now steeling themselves for a tense return to the Turkish city.
fields.body:
Leeds United got the Champions League draw they could have done without yesterday and it had nothing to do with being paired with Barcelona and Milan. Five months after two of their fans were killed in Istanbul the west Yorkshire club are now steeling themselves for a tense return to the Turkish city.

Leeds must host Besiktas on September 26 and play the return game at the 45,000-capacity Inonu stadium on October 18.

Amid the inevitable concerns about the potential for trouble, Uefa responded with unusual velocity by announcing it would convene a meeting for the clubs to raise security issues.

At least two of the Turkish youths charged in connection with the stabbing to death of two Leeds fans on the eve of their Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray are understood have Besiktas connections, and their supporters are reputed to be among the worst in Turkey. "They make Galatasaray's fans look like angels," an Istanbul-based journalist said yesterday.

Although Besiktas officials were quick to extend the hand of friendship, the football authorities are acutely aware of the rioting which took place before Arsenal's Uefa Cup final against Galatasaray in Copenhagen, and the violence involving England and Turkey fans during Euro 2000.

Leeds will wait until they have met with Uefa before deciding what security measures to take at Elland Road. They must also work out whether to organise an official club trip for the match in Istanbul or risk their fans travelling independently.

"We need to take the advice of the Football Association, the Foreign Office, the police and Besiktas themselves," said the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale. "Above all I hope this will be an opportunity for common sense to prevail."

The West Yorkshire police would back any calls from Leeds for away supporters to be banned but such a request is likely to get short shrift from Uefa and little co-operation from Besiktas. "I don't think there will be any problems," said their president Serbar Bilgili. "It is a sensitive subject but we are happy to play Leeds. Nobody wants anything bad to happen and we will try to be friends. We must forget what has happened.

"This is the chance for the clubs, the two cities and the two countries to put the past behind us and rebuild the sympathy and friendship that should exist in football."

Rangers have spoken to the Foreign Office and are seeking a meeting with Galatasaray officials to discuss security issues before their Champions League group games.

Group D: Monaco, Galatasaray, Rangers, Sturm Graz

Group F: Bayern Munich, Paris St Germain, Rosenberg, Helsingborgs FC

Group G: Manchester United, PSV Eindhoven, Dynamo Kiev, Anderlecht

Group H: Barcelona, AC Milan, Leeds, Besiktas

fields.headline: Anarchy on the cards
fields.standfirst: Emotions at boiling point as sending-off fever raises the game's temperature
fields.trailText: Emotions at boiling point as sending-off fever raises the game's temperature.
fields.body:
Less than a week into the new Premiership season and English football is giving every appearance of a boiler about to explode. But still the coals of controversy are being fed into the furnace with referees, players, managers and media all stoking away merrily.

In the space of five days eight red cards have been flourished, two of them likely to be rescinded, and two more in the direction of Patrick Vieira, the crèneme brulée of Arsenal's midfield, a player of sweet skills but ever likely to burst into flames. Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger also faces a misconduct charge following an alleged incident with the fourth official after the match at Sunderland last Saturday.

Already there is a stand-off between referees determined to crack down and managers angry at seeing their teams depleted. "Spectators pay to watch a match between 22 players," argued Harry Redknapp, the West Ham manager, after Igor Stimac was dismissed for a second bookable offence against Leicester on Wednesday.

"Some of these referees are prima donnas," declared Sir Alex Ferguson after three of his Manchester United players were cautioned for arguing with Jeff Winter at Ipswich the previous evening. Referees might feel entitled to retort that the managerial trade contains a higher density of divas than La Scala Milan and that United have more yap than Battersea dogs home.

Clearly the Premier League is in dire need of a thermostat to stop emotions boiling over and spoiling what has otherwise been a highly entertaining start to the season. Those most closely involved - referees, managers and players - need to pause and take stock of a situation which threatens to get out of hand.

It does not have to be like this. A glance at an old video tape just before the Premiership kicked off brought to light coverage of a match between Arsenal and Liverpool recorded so long ago that the result had slipped the memory. Certainly the game belonged to another age.

The football was fast and competitive but there were no rows or sendings off. There were no foreigners on show either, but the skills of John Barnes and Peter Beardsley for Liverpool and David Rocastle and Paul Merson for Arsenal brightened a dull winter's day.

What a contrast to Monday's scenes at Highbury. The referee Graham Poll, who had sent off Gary McAllister and Dietmar Hamann of Liverpool, as well as Vieira, was given a standing vilification extraordinary even by normal standards of crowd abuse.

Reporters struggled to make sense of what had been happening while on television Sky's Andy Gray appeared in danger of suffering an apoplectic fit as he insisted that Vieira should not have received a second booking because his two-foot lunge in the direction of Hamann had took the ball instead.

Gray is usually right but in this instance he got it wrong since the ugliness of Vieira's tackle was sufficient, under the laws, to warrant punishment whether or not he made contact with an opponent. That is why Poll, while admitting that he should not have booked Hamann a second time, stuck to his guns over the dismissals of both Vieira and McAllister for going in with both feet

Yet the latter's red card is likely to be annulled by the Football Association, so it now appears that Liverpool should have been allowed to keep 11 men on the field. Poll, a Fifa referee, cannot be flavour of the month with the FA while his next visit to Anfield should be interesting.

Afterwards the French managers of Arsenal and Liverpool, Wenger and Gérard Houllier respectively, vehemently disputed these sendings-off but what did they expect? Before the start of each season referees, managers and players get together to discuss things that need to be done to make the game a better spectacle. This time it was agreed that a strict line should be taken with two-foot tackles and flailing arms or elbows.

Monday's match at Highbury, therefore, could be said to represent an accepted policy put into practice. Except that Poll, who at the start did well in allowing a contest of exceptional pace to swing freely from end to end, came close to losing control because he did not act early enough to cool things down and now appears to have sent two men off in error.

That said it is very difficult to spot someone standing on an opponent's hand as Gilles Grimandi, yesterday charged with misconduct by the FA, appeared to do to McAllister. The real referees' assistants should not be the people who used to be called linesmen but the players themselves.

The cards and confusion offer a stark and depressing contrast to most of the matches seen during Euro 2000. There referees such as Italy's Pierluigi Collina used their common sense, accepted the inevitability of mistimed but otherwise innocent tackles, and kept their cards in their pockets.

The Premiership the players and the refs could probably work things out between themselves. The players should accept decision but referees must concede that not every tackle is perfectly timed. The managers, meanwhile, could best serve football by keeping quiet.

fields.headline: Jardel golden goal sinks Real
fields.standfirst:
Real Madrid 1 Raul 79pen
Galatasaray 2 Jardel 41pen,103
fields.trailText: Real Madrid 1 Raul 79pen Galatasaray 2 Jardel 41pen,103
fields.body:
Galatasaray, whose defeat of Arsenal in last season's Uefa Cup final made them the first Turkish club to claim a major European title, lifted another, albeit lesser, trophy in Monaco yesterday when they beat the European champions Real Madrid in the Super Cup final.

And it was no surpise that Jardel, their close-season signing from Porto who scored fivce goals in their first league game of the season, who scored the crucial Golden Goal, his second of the goal of the game, to secure a well-deserved victory for the Turks.

Galatasaray went ahead four minutes before half-time, in fact, when Jardel converted a penalty to give them the initiative.

But Real's Raul Gonzales, whose missed penalty against France cost Spain a place in the Euro 2000 semi-final, slammed his own penalty into the roof of the net in the 79th from the spot to level the scores after Suat Kaya appeared to handle the ball in his area to send the match into extra time.

Real opened the stronger and Luis Figo, their world- record £37m signing who was making his competitive bow in front of 20,000 fans on a hot, muggy evening, soon tested his countryman Claudio Taffarel with a low shot in the 12th minute but the goalkeeper was equal to it.

A splendid through ball from Savio then found Raul behind the defence but the striker drove high over the bar. And the Real defender Geremi soon met a Figo corner only to head straight into Taffarel's arms

It was all one-way traffic as Raul's header then missed the target in the 34th minute after another good cross by Savio, and the forward went close moments later with a chip that went over the bar.

Iker Casillas then made a fine save when he blocked Hagi's deflected shot from 20 yards and two minutes later Jardel converted a penalty awarded when Ivan Campo brought down Hakan Unsal.

Three minutes into the second half Roberto Carlos unleashed one of his trademark free kicks from 30 yards but hisTaffarel caught the ball. The Spanish league has still to start, while Galatasaray had the advantage of having several competitive matches under their belt.

But Real's lack of match fitness showed and even Figo was unable to raise his game enough to make a difference. He earned a yellow card in the second half for hacking down Hagi. But the Spanish team fought bravely late in the match and managed to turn it.

And Savio hit the post with three minutes to go as Real sought desperately to avoid extra time.

Real Madrid : Casillas; Geremi, Ivan Campo (Flavio Conceicao, 66min), Helguera, Carlos; Luis Figo, Makelele, Celades (Salgado, 99), Savio; Guti (Pedro Munitis, 53) Raul.

Galatasaray : Taffarel; Hakan Unsal, Korkmaz, Popescu, Capone (Fatih Akyel, 85); Hagi (Bulent, 71), Kaya, Belozoglu, Buruk (Hasan Sas, 80); Jardel, Umit Davala.

Referee : Gunter Benkoe (Austria).

fields.headline: Balkan poser for Leicester
fields.standfirst: The Uefa Cup draw is kind to Chelsea and Liverpool, but Leicester - and the Foreign Office - are faced with a trickier proposition
fields.trailText: The Uefa Cup draw is kind to Chelsea and Liverpool, but Leicester - and the Foreign Office - are faced with a trickier proposition.
fields.body:
The Leicester City chairman John Elsom is confident his club will not be forced to pull out of the Uefa Cup after yesterday's first-round draw pitted them against Red Star Belgrade.

Elsom and other club officials are preparing for a series of meetings with the Foreign Office and the Football Association regarding the viability of travelling to the Yugoslav capital for the second leg on September 28.

"I cannot really conceive putting ourselves into a situation where we would run the risk of withdrawing from the competition," Elsom said. "But we will be having talks with the Foreign Office and the FA as to whether we are advised to play there."

Leicester may be able to get the second leg moved away from Belgrade. No British club has been to Serbia since last year's Nato bombings, and the Foreign and Commonwealth Office continues to advise against all non-essential travel to the area.

The draw was kinder to Liverpool, who were paired with Rapid Bucharest, and Chelsea, who must play the Swiss minnows St Gallen.

The reward for Irish club Bohemians' defeat of Aberdeen is a trip to Germany where they face Kaiserslautern on September 14, with the second leg at Dublin's Tolka Park two weeks later.

Hearts also face tough German opposition in the Intertoto Cup qualifiers VfB Stuttgart while Celtic meet HJK Helsinki.

webTitle: At long last United learn it's good to listen.

fields.headline: At long last United learn it's good to listen.
fields.standfirst: Jim White on the overdue charm offensive at Old Trafford
fields.trailText: The overdue charm offensive at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Some people are never satisfied. On the website run by the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association a member recently posted a bitter moan. There had been a problem processing his season ticket, it seems, so he had written to the club to complain and the new chief executive Peter Kenyon had personally rung him to sort things out. And was the lad happy? No he wasn't. Didn't Peter Kenyon realise that as a schoolboy his time was precious? That was the gist of the lad's complaint, and he didn't need some bloke ringing him at home. I am pretty sure he wasn't being ironic.

Mind you, it is not hard to understand his cynicism. Good PR and Manchester United are not often linked in the public mind. Arrogance rather than communication has been the order of the day. Huge PR blunders have stumbled out of the club continuously. There was, for instance, the letter sent to season ticket holders stating that the increase in prices was due to the increase in Roy Keane's salary, this in the week that the annual report revealed a profit of over £20m. Then there was the statement warning fans not to travel to Rio for last season's World Club Championship, advice which hugely upset the hosts with the ignorant picture it painted of Brazil as a crime-ridden hell-hole.

But all this, the club hope, will change with the appointment of Kenyon in place of Martin Edwards. Since he took the helm he has been assiduous in trying to change the aloof, greedy image his boardroom has exuded for a decade. He has returned journalists' calls, organised open training sessions and turned up at a meeting organised by an independent fans' group in a Stretford pub. There are also rumours that he is minded to fill a new post of director of communications with one of the supporters who masterminded the successful campaign against Sky's takeover.

And this week he announced plans to set up a fans' forum, with voting overseen by the Electoral Reform Society to elect a body designed to articulate supporters' interests. It will report directly to Kenyon himself.

"It's very encouraging," says Andy Mitten, editor of the fanzine United We Stand. "United have been very aloof. Martin Edwards thought building a stadium and a team was all that was required to keep fans happy. But there is a real need to connect and address their concerns: about the atmosphere in the ground, about the way local youngsters are squeezed out by corporate pricing, about ticket distribution. Of course actions speak louder than words and there is a well founded, deep-rooted cynicism among hard-core fans caused by being wholly exploited this past decade. But this is very definitely a start."

The big question is, since United have been so successful without addressing their match-going supporters' concerns, why should they bother now? After all the fans are not going to switch allegiance and support City, are they?

Well, they might. After 10 years of being told to sit down, shut up and anyway they are not as welcome as tourists from Scandinavia, it would be no surprise if many a young Mancunian were drawn to Maine Road.

With clubs so high-geared financially, the strategy of ignoring one market while pursuing others is no longer viable.

With a hugely extended stadium having to finance hugely inflated wages, not even United can afford to ostracise a single bum that might occupy one of their 67,000 seats. The warning signals were posted when, for the first time since the Premiership started, enough tickets were left over for a game next month to be put on open sale. Kenyon may have been reading the runes.

fields.headline: Vieira signs off with style
fields.trailText: Two for Vieira as five-star Arsenal edge out Charlton in Highbury thriller.
fields.body:
Patrick Vieira twice went into the referee's notebook, both times as a goalscorer, as Arsenal won a hugely entertaining derby. Eight times as many goals as yellow cards. Perhaps we can stop talking about referees and start talking about the new football being used, which is turning the Premiership into a goal-fest. It curves, it swerves, it goes in the net.

A hectic afternoon saw four goals from French internationals and three goals conceded by English internationals. I know how I'd bet on the forthcoming friendly. Sylvain Wiltord watched from the stands and must wonder how he will get into the French and Arsenal teams.

Others were left to wonder whether Wenger might have been wiser to have spent the £13 million on a defender or a goalkeeper (John Lukic was on the bench yesterday). Wenger said afterwards that he had bought Wiltord in an attempt 'to play a game based on mobility and technique'. In attack Arsenal have these qualities in abundance, in defence less so. In midfield, they have Vieira.

Charlton started the game hesitantly, making basic errors on a glassy pitch. And Arsenal should have taken advantage. Nwankwo Kanu and Robert Pires both had a pair of chances in the opening 15 minutes but failed to take them. Even on the rare occasions Charlton attacked, Arsenal looked the more likely to score on the break.

They made spectacular amends for their profligacy. Kanu picked the ball up 35 yards out, skipped past a defender, passed the ball through to... guess who?... Vieira and, cool as you like, he did a little shimmy before chipping the ball into the net. A wonderful goal. Highbury got quite carried away with the symbolism of it. Vieira had scored before he had been booked. Before anyone had been booked.

Game over, one thought. Then, an innocuous cross by Radistan Kishishev eluded Martin Keown and Tony Adams and Andy Hunt scored from close range.

Charlton, thanks to the diligent efforts of Mark Kinsella and Claus Jensen in the centre of midfield, edged themselves back into the game. On the half-hour, they took the lead. John Robinson's hopeful cross from mid-way down the left hung in the air long enough for Hunt to shrug off a feeble challenge from Silvinho and loop a very slow header past David Seaman. It was Andy Hunt 2, Arsenal 1. And not a referee or linesman or fourth official to blame.

Perhaps Seaman must shoulder some of it. He wasn't directly responsible, but his marked unwillingness to come off his line seems to have rendered his defence suddenly very dodgy on the six-yard line. At the very end, he didn't even come for a ball three yards out.

Arsenal needed a goal early in the second half. It took less than a minute. Thierry Henry received the ball towards the edge of the Arsenal area, teed it up and casually volleyed it into the net. Back came Charlton. Kevin Lisbie ran down the left, crossed towards that six-yard line and Graham Stuart snuck in front of Adams to clip the ball into the net.

And back came Arsenal. Kanu passed the ball across to Vieira who caroomed the ball into the net from 20 yards. Two red cards, two goals. If he keeps this up he'll be very useful in short bursts.

At 3-3, there was everything to play for. The kind of pressure situation when someone might get booked. They were. The impressive Kinsella for a foul on...Vieira. A minute later, Arsenal were ahead when Henry skipped through and beat Dean Kiely from a tight angle. Seven goals, 25 minutes to go. 5-5, anyone?

Not quite but a minute from time there was another cracker. Silvinho streaming through on the left and stroking the ball into the net.

Afterwards, Alan Curbishley talked about his players feeling knackered. He took Kinsella off because he 'was so tired'. His parting words to the press were: 'We've just been beat 5-3 and you're gentle.' Eight goals and a gentle press. Arsne Wenger's 'crazy week' had come to the most surprising of ends.

webTitle: Winchester tops public school A-level league

fields.headline: Winchester tops public school A-level league
fields.standfirst:
Survey shows continued improvements
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The boys public school Winchester college yesterday reasserted its supremacy at the top of the independent schools A-level league table, achieving the best exam results of all Britain's 514 fee-paying schools.
fields.body:
The boys public school Winchester college yesterday reasserted its supremacy at the top of the independent schools A-level league table, achieving the best exam results of all Britain's 514 fee-paying schools.

This marks the successful end of the 15-year headship of James Sabben-Clare, and a challenge for his successor Nick Tate, former chief executive of the government's qualifications and curriculum authority, who starts at the Hampshire school next month.

According to the league tables, published yesterday by the Independent Schools Information Service, the 140 candidates at the £16,000-plus a year Hampshire school scored an average of 32.76 points. This uses the university A-level ratings system, which awards an A grade 10 points and an E grade two points on a sliding scale, for students taking two or more A-levels, but excluding general studies.

Last year Winchester was back in first place with a score of 34 points, having been toppled by rival Westminster the previous year.

This is the ninth consecutive year that Isis has released detailed statistics on each independent school's performance. Analysis of the results of 31,921 candidates this year shows continuing improvement, with an average university points score per candidate of 22.56, compared with 22.18 last year - an increase of 1.7%.

At the same time, 36% of schools' entries were awarded grade A - a 1.2% increase on the 34.8% last year. This increase is four times greater than the rise in A grades nationally (including the state sector) which was up by 0.3% at 17.8%.

In the state sector, according to the Guardian's own A-level analysis last week (using a slightly different measure which includes general studies), the top performing comprehensive school, Tarporley county high school, scored 28.76 and the top selective school, Colchester royal grammar school scored 33.98.

Despite the continued presence of a boys school at the top of the table, girls schools also did exceptionally well in the tables, in line with girls' out-performance over boys generally at A-level.

The North London collegiate school, in Edgware, north London, got an average points score of 30.80, closely followed by St Paul's girls' school with 30.78, and Haberdashers' Aske's school for girls with 30.02.

This year Eton college hangs on to its place in the top 20 with an average points score of 28.5. Last year it fell from fourth to 18th place in the league table with a marginally lower score of 28.4.

Prince William was one of the 262 A-level entrants this year, and gained grades A, B and C respectively in geography, history of art and biology.

Yesterday Winchester's second master, Jock Macdonald, denied that Winchester was an "academic sausage-machine". He added: "There is plenty of extra-curricular activity here and we give the boys a good balance".

One Winchester pupil got six grade As, he revealed, while a further six got five As and a B. Around 40% of pupils will take up places at Oxbridge.

Isis has produced a separate table, including the results of A-level general studies, which puts Withington Girls School, in Fallowfield, Manchester, in first place.

The Department for Education and Employment uses A-level general studies in its calculations.

But Isis believes that this distorts the overall picture, on the grounds that about half of the independent schools which it covers choose not to enter pupils for the subject.

fields.headline: Funky realism in Hackney
fields.standfirst: They may be dirt cheap studies in banality, but the latest crop of British films have excited  Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: They may be dirt cheap studies in banality, but the latest crop of British films have excited Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
It's a touchy time for new British cinema, with the Film Council kicking in and making its intentions known in no uncertain terms. As its head John Woodward put it in an interview with the French trade magazine Le Film Français, published yesterday in the Guardian, the Film Council is not interested in making low-budget "social realist art films", whatever they are.

All the more embarrassing, then, that in this year's new British cinema at Edinburgh, it is the "social realist art films" - some of them made on staggeringly low budgets - that stand out as the most exciting material on offer.

One of them is a digital production shot in Glasgow on a micro-budget (in the "low five-figures", according to the director). One Life Stand is the feature debut by May Miles Thomas, who not only wrote and directed, but also shot the film and edited it herself at home on her PC. It's an object lesson in telling a story cheaply and turning the visual rough edges to your advantage - but all that would just be production anecdote if not for the fact that this is a very fine film indeed.

Social realist art cinema? Yes, in the sense that it addresses everyday British life in all its banality and desperation, and that it has an artistic edge in Thomas's stark, melancholy compositions.

The tightly-scripted story is in a well-established kitchen-sink lineage - the Play For Today tradition that television no longer sees fit to bother with. Trise (Maureen Carr), a strapped-for-cash single mother, works on a dial-a-tarot phone line and finds herself uneasily lending a sympathetic ear to the desperate callers. Meanwhile, her narcissistic teenage son (John Kielty) fancies himself as a male model but finds himself only making headway as a rent boy. This tough, harrowing but often uncomfortably funny drama gives the slice-of-life genre a new surge of energy. The sense of enclosure, as the digital black-and-white photography explores cramped apartments, bedrooms and offices, creates an uneasy intimacy that brings the characters vibrantly alive: by the end of it we know every crease on Trise's brow.

The acting is uniformly superb, and while the film is socially engaged, it doesn't take the Ken Loach route of spelling things out for us. It's a moot point whether our film and TV industry currently has room for a hard-boiled case like Thomas - but it should.

Another realist, already established, is Paul Pawlikowski, who made the BBC docudrama Twockers. But with Last Resort, written by Rowan Joffe, he has really arrived.

Tanya (Dina Korzun), a young Russian mother, arrives in Britain with her young son and ends up consigned to a holding centre for asylum seekers - a desolate seaside resort that's like Butlins doubling as Kafka's Penal Colony, all hollowly ringing amusement arcades and fried fish that's pure batter.

The film works brilliantly on several levels - as an intimately observed character piece, as a quasi-documentary exposé on the conditions of life for asylum seekers and as an impressionistic depiction of our wretched cultural landscape, shot with an eye for poetic drabness by Ryszard Lenczewski.

Korzun is a tender, affecting presence, but the scene-stealer - playing the seedy bingo caller who befriends Tanya - is Paddy Considine, who made his mark as the shell-suited maniac in Shane Meadows's A Room For Romeo Brass, and is shaping up to be a compulsive and natural player.

A different kind of realism - funkier and lighter but still tough - comes in The Low Down. Superficially resembling the This Life school of drama, it has a gang of moderately groovy young urbanites experiencing love and other catastrophes in Hackney.

But Jamie Thraves's film, shot and edited with a jumpy exuberance that owes a lot to Jean-Luc Godard's Breathless, is something else - an ensemble portrait that brings its characters alive without the script having to join the dots for us. Heading an impressive and mainly unknown cast is Aiden Gillen, from Queer As Fuck and Mojo, who continues to be one of the most compelling new faces on the British screen - whether brooding, smirking or silently brazening out the threats of a pub drunk.

Lucia Zucchetti's editing is acutely tuned to those split seconds when characters reveal themselves through a tic or a faux pas. The Low Down is fresh and funny, and even a cute celeb cameo from TV jokers Adam and Joe fits in perfectly.

It's not just realism that's on offer from the new contenders. Let's hope the new regime has room for eccentrics like Ben Hopkins, whose second feature, The Nine Lives of Tomas Katz, is a strange, misshapen, sometimes inspired oddity. Hopkins, who made the venturesome anomaly Simon Magus, indulges himself something rotten in a sparky micro-budget apocalyptic fantasy that suggests a hellish collision between Michael Moorcock, NF Simpson and the Jon Pertwee-era Dr Who.

It is wayward and uneven, and I can't honestly say I liked it, yet there are occasional flashes of brilliance - such as the image of two security men watching thousands of video screens. At any rate, it's something of a miracle that an outsider like Hopkins is getting his visions on screen, and he is worth encouraging. If the right producer nudges him in the right direction, Hopkins's third, fourth or fifth film could well be extraordinary.

 Last Resort plays tonight at Filmhouse 1. Box 0ffice: 0131-623 8030.

webTitle: Producers are ditching sci-fi and revamping the historical epic

fields.headline: Past forward
fields.standfirst: Producers are ditching the space suits for sandals and turning  back the clock to revamp the historical epic. Why not, when special effects can make the past even more exciting than the future, says Steve Rose
fields.trailText: Producers are ditching the space suits for sandals and turning back the clock to revamp the historical epic. Why not, when special effects can make the past even more exciting than the future, says Steve Rose
fields.body:
Sci-fi blockbusters no longer bust blocks like they used to. Despite the futuristic zeitgeist us new-millennium folks are supposed to be surfing, the champion of today's box office is just as likely to be wielding a Roman broadsword as a laser gun. Historical epics are back, and they're more epic than ever. More importantly, they're easier to make than ever.

Ever since Jurassic Park, the blockbuster formula has been simple: old idea, new effects. Once the computer-generated image became an industry standard, all you needed to do was salvage a story from the sci-fi scrapheap (take your pick from dinosaurs, alien invaders, meteorites, natural disasters, killer sea creatures), slap on some "state of the art" effects, and laugh all the way to the bank. It's worked for the past decade or so, but in recent months, the formula has gone wrong as often as it has gone right. Brian de Palma's $90million space turkey Mission To Mars, for example, was a transparent attempt to feed us Kubrick's 2001 again, and no one bought it. Walter Hill's $70million shambles Supernova suffered a similar fate - aside from the novelty of zero-gravity sex scenes, it was basically Alien again. (At least Hill had the foresight to take his name off the picture, just as the studio had the foresight not to hold any preview screenings.) The forthcoming Pitch Black, while a substantial improvement in the originality stakes, still failed to set the US box office alight. And let's not go into Battlefield Earth. In fact, the most successful and imaginative sci-fi flicks of recent times have been Star Wars Episode I (call that new?), The Matrix (which, tellingly, had snappy new special effects) and Galaxy Quest, a sci-fi spoof.

Like spoilt toddlers, audiences need new toys on a regular basis, and the more prescient industry players saw the ugly spectre of sci-fi fatigue rearing its head a long way off. They realised that the way forward was not forward at all. If computer power could be used to create those tired old sci-fi futures, why not use it to re-create the real-world past? Hey presto! Titanic!

If former sci-fi diehard James Cameron could score big with a 90-year-old sinking ship, and win an armful of Oscars to boot, what else could be done? Spielberg ditched the dinos and went to war for Saving Private Ryan, and he came out with an Oscar too. French event-movie master Luc Besson tried next, but the tactic didn't quite pay off. His The Fifth Element was one of the best examples of the modern-day effects movie, despite one of the dumbest storylines ever committed to screen (goodies must stop baddies from destroying earth: they do). This year his ambition, and his faith in leading lady Milla Jovovich, got the better of him when he attempted to join the ranks of the "serious" directors with his own Gallic-flavoured historical epic, Joan Of Arc. And of course, leading this year's charge, sci-fi great Ridley Scott struck gold by going ancient for Gladiator.

Where others had only hinted, Gladiator brazenly demonstrated that full-scale historical epics were viable again - and they hadn't been for more than a decade. The historical epic of yore required a cast of thousands, enormous sets, and pedantic historical accuracy. Big bucks, in other words, which was fine in Cecil B de Mille's day but became increasingly hazardous as time went on. There was so much to get wrong, and when it did go wrong the results were catastrophic. Ask Michael Cimino, who never really recovered from his $35million flop Heaven's Gate, or Hugh Hudson, who took down Goldcrest Films with his Al Pacino-starring 80s effort, Revolution. The failure of that civil war epic prompted critic Leonard Maltin to quip, "Thanks to this megabomb, it'll be 2776 until we get another one." He was out by 776 years.

There's no better indication of the turning tide than producer-director team Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich. They gleefully rode the wave of sci-fi revamps with the chest-beating Independence Day, then they were forced to eat their slogan - "size does matter" - when their hulking entry into the big reptile market, Godzilla, came crashing to the ground (size doesn't matter, you fools, effects do).

This year they scored big again by switching to the historical formula. No doubt encouraged by the knee-jerk patriotism which made Independence Day so popular in the States, they decided to simply make it again, this time based on the real independence day. Hence the Mel Gibson-starring civil war epic, The Patriot. Like the rest of the sci-fi defectors, Devlin and Emmerich recognised that computer animation has eliminated the risks which scuppered "old-fashioned" historical epics, and the two genres have become interchangeable. So why "kick ET's butt" when you can kick a child-murdering Limey's butt (with historical justification)? Why blow up an alien spaceship when you can blow up an 18th-century battleship just as easily? Why hire 1,500 extras for a battle scene when you can just dress up 50 and fill in the rest with a computer? Costs down, profits up, audiences happy. You might even win an Oscar.

This week we're back in the Colosseum for another lavish sandal-fest, Julie Taymor's Shakespeare adaptation Titus. Although much of the production gloss is real rather than computer-rendered (the director was responsible for the stage version of The Lion King, after all), many of the same themes that made Gladiator so popular are present - power struggles and revenge tactics in ancient Rome, bloody combat with primitive weaponry, grand interiors and costumes, emperors with eye-shadow. Although its application is more subtle, computer rendering is still widely deployed: for the multi-layered dream sequences; for the plot's intermittent dismemberments (so difficult to achieve with the conventional long sleeves and false stumps); and for adding a Matrix-style, bullet-time zip to the climax.

Titus is a particularly distinguished example of how the historical epic can be resurrected (ie with some restraint and intelligence), but the studio bean-counters are currently throwing millions of dollars at a new (computer) generation of these movies. The related world of swords-and-sorcery epics is due to come into play again soon, with game cash-in Dungeons And Dragons and Peter Jackson's hugely ambitious Lord Of The Rings trilogy in production (he's apparently using the whole of New Zealand as the set). In real history, there's Michael Bay and Jerry Bruckheimer's second world war epic Pearl Harbor on the horizon, with Ben Affleck, Alec Baldwin and Kate Beckinsale among others, which already has the dubious distinction of being the most expensive movie since Titanic.

If the historical craze continues, aside from making intellectually challenged movie moguls even more money, what will be the consequences for history? Perhaps movies will distort it beyond all resemblance to factual reality - after all, that's what movies do best. People will assume that all Romans had fringes and spoke English (some with Australian accents), that the British are the sole cause of evil and injustice in the world, that slaves enjoyed being classified as property and that the second world war was won single-handedly by the Americans (who defeated the British, of course). Perhaps they'll even forget that people used to make movies about spaceships and dinosaurs. Then we can start all over again.

 Titus is out on Friday

fields.headline: Sufferin' Saffron
fields.standfirst: Former model and Mike Figgis regular Saffron Burrows can finally see her fellow actors  eye to eye - but not without banging her head on the ceiling
fields.trailText: Former model and Mike Figgis regular Saffron Burrows can finally see her fellow actors eye to eye - but not without banging her head on the ceiling
fields.body:
Saffron Burrows is fast becoming one of the busiest actresses in the UK. The 6ft-tall 26-year-old is a former model, a feminist, a political activist, and now the partner of film-maker Mike Figgis. Her third film with the tousle-haired director (it actually came between The Loss Of Sexual Innocence and Timecode) is an adaptation of the battle-of-the-sexes drama by August Strindberg, Miss Julie. Burrows's heartbreaking performance as the eponymous aristocrat is easily her best to date, and has even earned her plaudits from Dustin Hoffman.

This is one of the most intense films I have seen in a while. Was the experience of making it an intense one, too?

It was, actually, because we shot it quickly - it was a 16-day shoot - and because we shot in sequence. For me, the first two days were personally very shaky. I'd be thinking, "Christ, what am I doing? What have I taken on?" I was terrified. And then at night I'd be like, "This is daunting... and there's 98 pages more to do."

It couldn't have helped that Mike Figgis likes putting his camera right in his actors' faces.

I got slightly used to it working on The Loss Of Sexual Innocence. But I remember Peter Mullan [who plays her lover, Jean] saying, "My God, that camera is like the opposite of Ken Loach. It's not hidden in any way." Once you get into your stride, it becomes like another person in the room. It's like being in a very small theatre where there is no getting away with anything because the audience is centimetres away from you.

Were there particular aspects of Miss Julie's character that you related to?

First of all, I was completely daunted by the whole theatrical history of who had played her and who wanted to play her; Maggie Smith, Lena Olin... Then I thought about the fact that I hadn't been classically trained, and that scared me. There were so many things to worry me that I was rendered mute and couldn't move in any direction for a while. Ultimately, I just approached her as a young woman who's pretty screwed up, and I started reading Sylvia Plath and Virginia Woolf.

In between making small British films, you have had huge Hollywood success with Deep Blue Sea. How has that changed your life?

I was initially sent a rash of scientist-in-lab-coat roles. But then they saw Miss Julie and they didn't know where to place me. Other than that, and being on some lists I wasn't on a year earlier, it doesn't seem to have a made a tremendous difference. Although I do get funny people sometimes coming up to me in supermarkets in America with my picture in their pocket, which is a bit strange.

We're soon going to see you opposite Kate Winslet in Michael Apted's Enigma.

Mmm, I loved doing that.

Why?

I really enjoyed Michael Apted. He is someone I have admired since I was little, from Seven-Up and everything. And Thunderheart. He got the best performance out of Val Kilmer ever. He's a funny guy, Apted. Very warm and lovely, but he sort of reprimands you and stuff. He's like that old "I don't believe it" character Richard Wilson plays.

And how was working with Kate Winslet?

She was quite brilliant because we were working long hours and she was pretty pregnant by the end. We were in Amsterdam and she and I had to do the Charleston together. They built us a cottage to live in which I couldn't stand up in. When we got there, they had to raise the ceiling.

fields.headline: Banishment
fields.trailText:
Banished at time's end
the arm's bend poised with memory's bow
needing to shoot down this sky
and its foreign identity
with my mandarin character...
fields.body:
Banished at time's end
the arm's bend poised with memory's bow
needing to shoot down this sky
and its foreign identity
with my mandarin character

Tireless sky vast sky
vigorous sky firm and steadfast
holding unspeakable and devouring commands
which memory screams in the solitude of winter

Rejecting shame
I saw the shame that I tried to forget
harbouring mission
scattered sight
my reading stops to gaze

Memory has no need for time
one experience loathes the next

The clock whines
blaming me, blaming itself

Night's wheels grind
the past to sandgrains
and stone
with its deathless root
coils under us stubbornly
the long suppressed fervor
aroused by betrayal
at the end of exile

like an infinite omen
over this nation's domain

fields.headline: Note worthy
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard hails Stephen Booth's generous and fruitful edition of Shakespeare's sonnets
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard hails Stephen Booth's generous and fruitful edition of Shakespeare's sonnets
fields.body:
Shakespeare's Sonnets
ed Stephen Booth
(Yale NB, £12.50)

Twelve-and-a-half quid for 2,000-odd lines of poetry you most probably have already? (Whether as ancient A-level copy with significantly helpful marginalia - "NB Imagery", underlined twice; or poncy Folio Society edition with nice endpapers. Was it not Borges who wrote about the "obscenity" of deluxe editions?)

Well, this is the edition to knock most others into a cocked hat. Totalling 583 pages, it is the result of fantastically dedicated and thorough editorial work. The "NB" in "Yale NB" - a sub-division with which I was hitherto unfamiliar - stands, of course, for "nota bene", ie "note well", but it may as well stand here for "well annotated".

It was first published in 1978, but is well worth a reprint. The poems themselves take up 133 pages, and what's nice about that is the way modern-spelling versions are on the facing page of facsimiles of the 1609 Quarto, which reveal interesting spellings and punctuation: it is left up to us to decide whether they are simply quaint period details or an insight into the way the original readers of the Sonnets would have been struck. That in itself would have been enough to qualify it for the coveted PotW slot; but Booth's exegesis and notes lift the whole work into a different league.

Take his notes for Sonnet 146 ("Poor soul, the centre of my sinful earth..."). "Notes", for a start, is the wrong word. Fifteen-and-a-half pages is virtually a monograph. There is a good reason for this: not only is the Sonnet important, but the compositor made, or perhaps even did not make, a boo-boo, or "crux" as scholars prefer to call it, repeating the words "my sinful earth" at the beginning of line 2, leaving the line two syllables short.

Most modern editions just put a gap between square brackets for this, hoping we won't notice, or simply taking the wisest course; but if you want intelligent speculation as to what is missing, this is the book for you. The Sonnets are both direct and incredibly knotty; you'll want a good Empsonian like Booth to take you through all the ambiguities and echoes that would have been available to its first intended audience. Listen to one part of his notes for Sonnet 145, both lapidary in its simplicity and generous in its assessment of our abilities:

"The value of making up one's mind about a poem is not the same as the value of making up one's mind about real-life events that one's decision can influence. Nothing one says or thinks about a poem can change it. What one says about a poem can sometimes change the angle of a reader's perception of it, but one cannot stop the poem from doing all that it does or argue it into doing what it does not do. No interpretive description of a poem can nullify any of the actions the poem performs upon a reader's understanding."

Isn't that sweet? But it doesn't stop him, thank goodness, from offering us the fullest fruits of his and others' reading around the subject so that we can not only make our own minds up, but do something even more worthwhile: unmake them. He mistrusts those who think of the poems as "biographical spoor"; I loved his bracketed remark "I ignore candidates proposed by Baconians, Oxfordians, and such", and his note under the heading homosexuality : "William Shakespeare was almost certainly homosexual, bisexual, or heterosexual." Here, then, is - almost - all we can know.

webTitle: Guardian review: Mauve, Madder Red and Colour, a Social History

fields.headline: Madder shades of pale
fields.standfirst: Veronica Horwell  sees how colour captures the mood of a place and time
fields.trailText: Veronica Horwell sees how colour captures the mood of a place and time
fields.body:
Mauve
Simon Garfield
Faber, £9.99, 222pp
Buy it at BOL

Madder Red
Robert Chenciner
Curzon, £25, 325pp
Buy it at BOL

Colour, A Social History
Oliver Garnett
National Trust, £4.99, 48pp

In the easter hols of 1856, William Perkin, all of 18 and a student of the new-tech chemistry, experimented in his amateur lab at the family home in Shadwell, London. He had a sample of aniline distillate of coal tar, the gunky waste from the manufacture of gas for street-lighting from which his tutor had been synthesising organic compounds, and he hoped to transmute it into quinine, the treebark-derived anti-malarial drug essential to empire. Instead, he obtained a sludge containing five per cent of a colouring matter which, separated out for want of anything else to do with it save clog the drains, stained a silk cloth lustrous purple.

His discovery was the first true synthetic dye, mauveine; after it, dye creation became the basis of industrial chemistry, which revealed in time the molecular structures of nitro-glycerine, aspirin, sulpha drugs, petro-plastics, and even the quinine substitute mepacrine, which tinted the skin yellow as it warded off malaria. Perkins retired, moderately prosperous, at 36, by which time the chemical output of united Germany dominated the world.

That is Garfield's plot, and not much compressed from his shilling-life job in Mauve, one of those single-subject books with Longitude-inous pretensions that are this season's hot shade in publishing. It's a volume prepared to a precise formula of success, personal and national, won and forgotten; pages of toasts and menus from mauve-tie dinners honouring Perkins; interviews with "fashion experts"; plus a gramme or two of chemistry and literary references.

And all as monotone, as flat, as mauveine: Garfield seems not to be really interested in fashion, that acute social desire for the unnecessary. He reports that the printworks of mid-19th century Europe were desperate for economic, simple dyes, but he does not begin to connect with the huge truths about how much the Industrial Revolution had been activated by the coal-fuelled, steam-driven spinning and weaving of cotton, the manufacture of a fibre grown cheaply outside Europe into an unprecedented yardage of textiles at moderate prices.

Just as washable white cotton underclothes - their brilliant blanching effected by chlorine bleach, an early application of chemistry to cloth - popularised cleanliness, so dyed and printed cotton goods democratised fashion, since all but the poorest could afford to change style more frequently than ever before.

Garfield seems colour-blind, too, unable to see it as the essential signifier of the mood of place and time. He writes that mauve - named from the French for mallow flower - took off because the empress of France, Eugenie, decided that the colour, in a natural version brewed from lichen, matched her eyes. (In regal imitation, Queen Victoria wore a mauve gown.)

But lilacs, violets and pansies had been the sentimentally meaningful flowers of the 1840s, while art went through a seriously purple passage in the 1850s, with many a dollop in Pre-Raphaelite paintings: Ford Madox Brown used lavender for remembered hills and bonnet bows alike. Mauve was penitential purple domesticated, sad enough to be adopted as quarter-mourning in the subtle gradations of 19th-century grief, sober enough to be permitted for the waistcoats of gentlemen who had otherwise come over all monochrome in response to the era of urban commerce.

Not the waistcoats of gentlemen of artistic taste, of course: Garfield alludes to unhealthy aspects of the new colours, to the allergies and arsenic poisoning, but not to the refusal of aesthetic fellows, observed in a Punch illustration of 1877, to "go down to suppah with a young lady who could wear mauve twimmings in her skirt and magenta wibbons in her hair".

The all-too-visible 1860s triumph of mauve's aniline siblings (fuschsine, alizarin crimson etc) drove William Morris to empurple his arms in the indigo vat and madder pot, since, as he wrote, natural dyes "can be modified and toned without dirtying, as the foul blotches of the capitalist dyer cannot... these colours in fading remain beautiful, and never... pass into nothingness, through that stage of livid ugliness which distinguishes the commercial dyes as nuisances".

That quotation (and the sharp remark that follows it, that Morris was actually "a humbug" who discreetly printed his chintz daffodils in aniline yellow) comes from Robert Chenincer's Madder Red, a book of a very different colour. Modish publishing it is not: more a printed website linking everything the author found during decades of passion for the Caucasus, carpets, and the once financially important cultivation of scrubby, groundcreeper madders, the roots of which contain 25 natural hydroxyanthraquinone colourants.

There cannot be a fact about madder, and most other animal or vegetable dyes, not covered extensively within: the 1846 Moscow price of Dutch krap (powdered madder); Spartan battle dress dyed scarlet to hide bloodstains; recipes for garnet, terracotta and other incarnadined hues, plus the knowhow for recreating Imperial Roman Tyrian purple from murex shellfish. It needs putrefying molluscs' meat to brew up - a jar of cockles will do the trick. Natural dyeing is olfactorily organic as well, requiring rancid sesame seed oil, stale piss, sheeps' blood, crottin de mouton or dog excrement.

Chenincer is an undisciplined enthusiast, and the small, grisaille illustrations permitted by his academic publishers are frustrating - if only he had been robed in sumptuous colour by the British Museum Press, as was Jenny Balfour-Paul's comparable study Indigo, every page pooled with undilute vats of midnight sky. But Chenincer's curiosity makes the book match the vividness of the 5,000-year-old multi-ethnic technique that gave our retinas bandanna scarves, Micmac dyed porcupine quills, and the ferocious Turkey red cottons that take a generation of summer suns to fade to a fine pink.

After reading about George Field, Georgian supplier of "liquid rubiate" to J M W Turner - rude roots from Dutch marshes tinted Turner's sunsets - or the anonymous Jewish dyers of Central Asia binding bundles of silk yarn to create the cloud bands of ikat kaftans, I had to cover my eyes. They dazzled.

Chenincer's devotion and range of references give him a red surge of power, to plead for the re-establishment of organic dyes as renewable resources, for fewer but better possessions - "objects of perpetual desire" created with knowledge and understanding. "When I look at madder red, my eyes are excited before I know what I am seeing," he explains of the Pointilliste effect those 25 variant colouring agents have on every knotted tuft of a madder-dyed Turkish carpet: and he suggests subtly how industrial dyes, remixed constantly in an attempt to shift more garments and wallpaper than we really need, produce desensitised vision in every sense.

Oliver Garnett's Colour, done inexpensively for the National Trust, is not much more than a footnote in publishing and polychrome. Old-snobbish, too, citing the Earl of Craven's 11-layered yellow state chariot and Lord Berners dipping his white pigeons and poodle in ultramarine for surreality in the 1930s. But Garnett's eyes are in the right place: how permanently satisfying is the green library of Nina Cust, one of those 19th-century aesthetes called the Souls, the original Greens who preferred the natural in protest against the harsh, smart artifices of the machine age. Cust's green is the exact shade of leaf-reflections: I must ask my dad the housepainter how to mix it.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A learned analysis of the religions of the Roman Empire, plus Primitive Mythology and The Grand Canyon
fields.body:
A World Full of Gods
Keith Hopkins
(Phoenix, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Coy, awkward formats - first-person "time-traveller" epistles, stories, dramas - clutter this learned, and better yet, wise analysis of the religions of the Roman Empire: pagan, Jewish and Christian. A peculiar, offensive crew the last lot seemed, meanly confining themselves to a tripartite monotheism and denying the generosity of a Pantheon of gods. We haven't read anyone, save perhaps the late Rosemary Sutcliff, who has more persuasively imagined a way back into the alternative universe that was Rome, beyond the sex and the stinks and schisms, into an era when philosophical and moral ideas, since become commonplace, had not yet been thought through.

Primitive Mythology
Joseph Campbell
(Souvenir, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

First of the republications of Campbell's four-vol Masks of God, his religious/psychological history of mankind. Not humanity; he means man-kind, women merely begetters of inspiration - it's all "he for god only, she for god in him", with divinity and rites of passage for blokes only. Campbell's masterwork was written in the 1950s, takes Freud as gospel, uses "savage" for "primitive", and "primitive" pejoratively. (No wonder he was the college favourite of new Hollywood directors of the 1970s: all action heroes, spiritual gurus, girls only for sex or mom-dom.) Yet he has inpired passages connecting with the luminously permanent, beyond gender, beyond time.

The Grand Canyon
Ansel Adams
(Little, Brown £18.99)

The Campbell word we connect with is "numinous" - it means a commanding nod from the spirit of a place: and here are those spirits, specifically of the landscapes of the US Southwest, appearing to Adams's lens as they might not even to the most reverent eye. The New Mexican Chimayo sanctuary is a navel of the Earth; the striations on the rocks of Canyon de Chelly assert that eons afflict even geological strata, let alone piddling organic life. Adams's clouds exactly express that freed state of mind Campbell writes about at his most profound. Plus a portrait of Georgia O'Keeffe, wicked, wry and knowing against an Arizonan sky - she's beyond gender and time, too.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A devilishly sly Russian satire, plus The Lion of Boaz-Jachin And Jachin-Boaz, Big Trouble, Triomf and The Paraffin Child
fields.body:
The Clay Machine-Gun
Victor Pelevin
(Faber, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Devilishly sly satire about Russia is Pelevin's hallmark. While the rest of the country's writers wallow in old feuds, Pelevin's response is a fusion of history, pop culture and Eastern philosophy. Pyotr Voyd is having an identity crisis fuelled by Baltic tea ("a vodka and cocaine cocktail first mixed on the Aurora") and psychotropic drugs.

Is he the adjutant to Gen Chapayev, legendary civil-war hero, or a patient in Timur Timurovich's psychiatric clinic? Icons of the revolution and prime-time TV pass through a hectic plot that takes in psychotherapy and classics of Russian literature. Pelevin cannot be praised enough; he is a unique and essential writer blessed with a faultless translator.

The Lion of Boaz-Jachin and Jachin-Boaz
Russell Hoban
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

This reissue of Hoban's 1970s tale of a map-making father and son, and the mythical lion that links them, hangs by a maxim: "Everyone in the world is looking for something and by means of maps, each thing that is found is never lost again." It is one of those thoughts - at a glance profound, at second reading banal - that delight as long as you do not probe too far. With an artfully simple folk-tale style familiar from Riddley Walker and Turtle Diary, Hoban creates a mythology from ancient and modern parts. The elemental prose is livened by flashes of humour, but beware of reading too much into this childlike narrative.

Big Trouble
Dave Barry
(Piatkus £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Mr Barry has some influential friends, whose extravagant back-cover praise raises expectations. "The funniest book I've read in fifty years," gushes Elmore Leonard. "I laughed so hard I fell out of a chair," puffs Stephen King. I didn't. Big Trouble is a slapstick, gun-toting farce in which a cross-section of Miami society gets caught up in a high-school game of "Killer" and a real contract is taken out on a drunken gambler. Barry lines up the usual suspects - dopey teens, middle-aged jerks and sleazy crooks - for a pantomine Fargo with palm-trees. Yes, Big Trouble is entertaining, but its taut plot is fast-food entertainment, not epoch-making satire.

Triomf
Marlene van Niekerk
(Abacus, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

Built on the bulldozed rubble of Sophiatown, Triomf's nemesis is approaching: South Africa's first democratic election. It is everything the Benades - shrunken Pop, abused Mol, abusive uncle Treppie and epileptic Lambert - have passively opposed for 40 years. Sitting out on their stoep among the ruins of dismantled fridges, they cling to the belief that they are God's children, the white minority chosen to rule the kaffirs. Van Niekerk's chronicle of this incestuous, impoverished Afrikaans underclass is a vital and surprising novel that captures the bitter, tragi-comic end-game of South African racial politics and the betrayal of a twisted dream.

The Paraffin Child
Stephen Blanchard
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Fractured relationships and things barely said underpin this atmospheric novel. John Drean has returned to the northern seaside town of his childhood where everybody knows about, but no one speaks of, his daughter, who is missing presumed dead. Neither his sister or his father can get through to him, but one night he sees a young woman clutching a child and finds that she is a fellow pyromaniac. Blanchard creates a fragmentary picture of the snooker halls and daytime pubs that people troubled by the rhythms of ordinary life inhabit. The Paraffin Child is an uneasy yet powerful portrayal of a man whose connections to ordinary life have been severed.

fields.headline: Small press corner
fields.trailText: Known to generations as the author of the children's classic Ballet Shoes, Noel Streatfeild also wrote novels for adults.
fields.body:
Saplings
Noel Streatfeild
(Persephone Books, £10)
Buy it at BOL

Known to generations as the author of the children's classic Ballet Shoes, Noel Streatfeild also wrote novels for adults, which have not been so well cherished by posterity. One such is Saplings, which is reissued by the book club Persephone for the first time since its publication in 1945, as part of a mission by founder Nicola Beauman - an editor at Virago in its heyday - to continue the exhumation of forgotten novels that Virago began in the 1970s and 1980s.

In a fascinating afterword, psychologist Jeremy Holmes points to the extraordinarily advanced insights that Streatfeild, a spinster daughter of the manse, had into the sexual life of the family in the war years. Her subjects range from a bereft bourgeoisie, who find their idyllic summers by the sea interrupted with a rudeness that we associate more with the first than the second world war, to an urban working class who could live neither together nor apart: this particular form of family devotion died beneath the doodlebugs of the blitz.

The novel itself is flatfooted - Streatfeild had no ear for dialogue and seems to have learned her cockney from Dickens - but Holmes is right about its shafts of perceptiveness. It is a book that belongs in the archives of the Imperial History Museum, alongside the gas masks and identity tags and all those sad letters home from London's little evacuees.
