fields.headline: The detective's great tapestry
fields.standfirst: US novelist Elizabeth George tells John Cunningham why she loves England
fields.trailText: US novelist Elizabeth George tells John Cunningham why she loves England
fields.body:
It might seem wacky for a Californian writer to invent a detective who is not a private eye but a detective inspector in London's Met; to make him not sleazy and impecunious but titled and wealthy. And to write not one but several books about him in which distinctive bits of Britain's landscapes are bloodied with outlandish crimes.

Or maybe it is cool rather than wacky. Elizabeth George is the Californian in question: she's been an Anglophile since a visit here as a teenager, and she's spent 15 years researching and writing crime novels featuring DI Thomas Lynley, aka the eighth Earl of Asherton, and his sidekick, Barbara Havers, a maverick detective sergeant who is as grainy as Lynley is polished.

George's latest territorial conquest, in her new book, In Pursuit of the Proper Sinner, is the Peak District. But as well as trekking over large swathes of Derbyshire to get the topography, geography and folklore right for twin murders, she's burrowed into several boroughs of London for facts on everything from fast food (late-night consumption of) to kinky sex services (respectable businesses set up as covers for).

So who is the mysterious Ms George? In composure and conversation, she's as carefully poised as an alibi. But she's not the expatriate granddaughter of Agatha Christie or Dorothy L Sayers (she admires both) writing about England from an eyrie overlooking the Pacific. It turns out that she's a schoolteacher who became a college academic, who became a full-time author. She applies an icy discipline to producing crime books so steeped in detail you'd swear she'd lived in the UK all her life - so long as you hadn't lived here yourself.

A perverse literary enterprise, hers, creating a sort of Peter Wimsey of the Yard, when she could be updating Philip Marlowe. No way, says the self-possessed George. "The English tradition offers the great tapestry novel, where you have the emotional aspect of a detective's personal life, the circumstances of the crime, and the atmosphere of the countryside which functions as another character."

But why go to the trouble of mapping gorge and grange, tombs and tumuli, as she does for her Derbyshire backdrop? It's mostly because "visiting the setting for me suggests so many turns in the plot". But she adds: "I write the kinds of novels I like to read, where the setting is rendered with love and care." She admires Martin Cruz Smith, whose literary locations - from Havana to 19th-century Wigan - are "something I've always aspired to; not that I've come anywhere close".

That's not false modesty: George, a late starter who always felt she could write, is probably her own severest critic: she's frank about one or two of her books not being too good. But she does her homework with a relentless intensity. At the back of the new book, a list of experts are thanked for helping with her research into archery, 14th-century domestic architecture, mountain rescue, sado-masochism and lots more.

However, there's a stubbornness alongside this fascination with detail. Some British readers remain irked that the Met should have Inspector Lynley, a member of the peerage, in its ranks. George says that that is less of a problem with American readers, who don't think it incongruous that someone with a title works for his living. And she points out that at least one peer is a provincial copper.

But this cavil doesn't distract from her academic approach. The books, which used to be written in a few weeks, now take 15 months. And the research demands a couple of trips to the UK every year - she's just been sleuthing in Northumberland.

George's creative process owes much to her discovery of John Steinbeck's Journal of a Novel, which he kept while writing East of Eden. "I really liked the idea of creating a journal myself," she says.

"It's like the way I clear my throat. I write a page every day, maybe 500 words. It could be about something I'm specifically worried about in the new novel; it could be a question I want answered; it could be something that's going on in my personal life. I just use it as an exercise."

Writing the journal is always preceded by reading one day's entry from the journal she kept while working on a previous book, to remind herself that she has faced - and overcome - similar blocks and doubts before; also, she says, it helps remove the loneliness of being a writer working alone.

But before both of these exercises, there's a page or two to be read from either a classic (she recently finished Pride and Prejudice, which, she says, has ideally short chapters) or a book by a literary figure about the art of writing. It was the Steinbeck, of course, which set her on this track.

These three elements in her routine take only 30 minutes. Then she's ready to continue with the book in hand: weaving a tapestry that, some critics say, contains writing that's almost too good for a detective novel. But for George, a perfectionist, it's always worth going the extra mile for a new location, or to a thesaurus to avoid a familiar word, or to enhance the rhythm of a sentence. fields.bodyText: It might seem wacky for a Californian writer to invent a detective who is not a private eye but a detective inspector in London's Met; to make him not sleazy and impecunious but titled and wealthy. And to write not one but several books about him in which distinctive bits of Britain's landscapes are bloodied with outlandish crimes. Or maybe it is cool rather than wacky. Elizabeth George is the Californian in question: she's been an Anglophile since a visit here as a teenager, and she's spent 15 years researching and writing crime novels featuring DI Thomas Lynley, aka the eighth Earl of Asherton, and his sidekick, Barbara Havers, a maverick detective sergeant who is as grainy as Lynley is polished. George's latest territorial conquest, in her new book, In Pursuit of the Proper Sinner, is the Peak District. But as well as trekking over large swathes of Derbyshire to get the topography, geography and folklore right for twin murders, she's burrowed into several boroughs of London for facts on everything from fast food (late-night consumption of) to kinky sex services (respectable businesses set up as covers for). So who is the mysterious Ms George? In composure and conversation, she's as carefully poised as an alibi. But she's not the expatriate granddaughter of Agatha Christie or Dorothy L Sayers (she admires both) writing about England from an eyrie overlooking the Pacific. It turns out that she's a schoolteacher who became a college academic, who became a full-time author. She applies an icy discipline to producing crime books so steeped in detail you'd swear she'd lived in the UK all her life - so long as you hadn't lived here yourself. A perverse literary enterprise, hers, creating a sort of Peter Wimsey of the Yard, when she could be updating Philip Marlowe. No way, says the self-possessed George. "The English tradition offers the great tapestry novel, where you have the emotional aspect of a detective's personal life, the circumstances of the crime, and the atmosphere of the countryside which functions as another character." But why go to the trouble of mapping gorge and grange, tombs and tumuli, as she does for her Derbyshire backdrop? It's mostly because "visiting the setting for me suggests so many turns in the plot". But she adds: "I write the kinds of novels I like to read, where the setting is rendered with love and care." She admires Martin Cruz Smith, whose literary locations - from Havana to 19th-century Wigan - are "something I've always aspired to; not that I've come anywhere close". That's not false modesty: George, a late starter who always felt she could write, is probably her own severest critic: she's frank about one or two of her books not being too good. But she does her homework with a relentless intensity. At the back of the new book, a list of experts are thanked for helping with her research into archery, 14th-century domestic architecture, mountain rescue, sado-masochism and lots more. However, there's a stubbornness alongside this fascination with detail. Some British readers remain irked that the Met should have Inspector Lynley, a member of the peerage, in its ranks. George says that that is less of a problem with American readers, who don't think it incongruous that someone with a title works for his living. And she points out that at least one peer is a provincial copper. But this cavil doesn't distract from her academic approach. The books, which used to be written in a few weeks, now take 15 months. And the research demands a couple of trips to the UK every year - she's just been sleuthing in Northumberland. George's creative process owes much to her discovery of John Steinbeck's Journal of a Novel, which he kept while writing East of Eden. "I really liked the idea of creating a journal myself," she says. "It's like the way I clear my throat. I write a page every day, maybe 500 words. It could be about something I'm specifically worried about in the new novel; it could be a question I want answered; it could be something that's going on in my personal life. I just use it as an exercise." But before both of these exercises, there's a page or two to be read from either a classic (she recently finished Pride and Prejudice, which, she says, has ideally short chapters) or a book by a literary figure about the art of writing. fields.headline: Edinburgh nights
fields.trailText: Rain, sun and a vision of mud-wrestling at the Edinburgh Book Festival
fields.body:
 The first week of the Edinburgh Book Festival brought umbrellas (including a nice twirling parasol number for J K Rowling) and the air of a stormy tropical encampment to the tents in Charlotte Square Gardens. But showers didn't deter the writers, all 350 of them, from Simon Armitage to Moon Unit Zappa, nor audiences that look set to be well over last year's 70,000.

They came to hear Norman Mailer talk about the "dark, gritty business" of sex, and they came to hear Andrea Dworkin, too. She was calling for women to have their own country and, for good measure, their own army as well. What for? To defend themselves against men, of course.

 Alas the Loafer (after a glass or two in the Oxford Bar, haunt of Ian Rankin's Inspector Rebus) only dreamt of the event to top all others: a mud-wrestling contest between these two stalwarts of the gender wars. And the rumour that both had been for a kilt-fitting on Prince's Street - that, too, turned out to be a chimera.

 Mailer's slight frame and two walking sticks, one in each hand, may have given the impression that all passion was spent. He seemed like a gentle old man, his brawling and boozing days long gone. But the memories were lively. "Hugh McIlvanney? I knew him," he replied to a question about the famous Scottish boxing writer, brother of the novelist William. "He knocked me over once... a few of us were in a bar somewhere and he took a swing at me. Good shot, too. An uppercut. Knocked me down."

 If J K Rowling is the sellout (on both her events), other children's writers, such as Dick Bruna, have been getting a decent amount of attention. His lapine Miffy character, beloved of two-year-olds across the land, even made it onto the front cover of The List, Edinburgh and Glasgow's equivalent to Time Out. Miffy as the new smiley face, symbol of the E-generation?

The Loafer almost wept at such loss of innocence - until a joke about another famous children's character brought good cheer. Where's Wally? That was the cry that went up between festival organisers' walkie-talkies across the canvas village - the occasion being Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka's elusive habits.

 By now (week two) the sun was shining, gleaming on the famous mirrored Spiegeltent, as frighteningly well-read festival-goers queued to hear Philip Gourevitch discuss Africa as part of the Witness programme, for which Kate Adie was later to produce the star turn, with another sell-out. Oddly, one of the few events that didn't encourage people to part with their hard-earned to a great degree was Peter Jay - discoursing on money on the back of his dismal TV series.

 This year's festival (the event began in 1983 as a biennial and grew in popularity until in 1997 it became an annual event) will be the last run by the resourceful Faith Liddell, who goes to tour Australia with the Spiegeltent and, no doubt, assist in its fearfully complex erection and detumescence. Her successor is the no less doughty Catherine Lockerbie, erstwhile literary editor of the Scotsman.

 Doughty as she may be, Lockerbie has had to deal with Scotsman editor-in-chief Andrew Neil's clumsy interference in her pages. Wise editors know that the senior common room of the books pages is best left well alone, to its mysteries, eccentrics and brief excitements. But Neil made a speciality of laying his heavy hand on literary proceedings in the boilerhouse that passes for a books desk at the Sunday Times.

It's a tradition that his successor as editor John Witherow continued, virtually forcing out the highly capable Harry Ritchie. And now it looks like the same thing is happening at what was once Scotland's greatest paper, whose decline was the cause of much muttering under the foliage of Charlotte Square Gardens.

 Some days we all feel that information anxiety and breathless media culture is getting us down and, God knows, with the likes of Big Brother unavoidable, well we might. But every now and then the downwards plunge of all that once looked upward, the sick transit of all that once was glorious, throws up the kind of story that makes one know that the Good Lord is saving the last laugh. Such a tale happened to come the Loafer's way at Edinburgh.

Picture the scene: the staff of the battered Scotsman wait in trepidation for the arrival of their new editor-in-chief, hail he comes, the very same Andrew Neil, hero of Wapping, broad-braced dominus of late-night discussion programmes. Most of the staff have only seen him thus, or the other Neil image: baseball cap, Asian babe to hand in a famous Private Eye photograph. But they know he's a toughie, a ball-breaker even.

Brillo, as the Eye calls him, walks in. Under the scrutiny of the staff, he strides forward, pausing only to take a couple of sweets, as he thought, from a nearby bowl. Anyone else, on realising that they had just put two marbles in their mouth, would have quickly taken them out and, with a self-critical "silly me", continued as normal. But as everyone knows, Mr Neil is not normal and he kept them in his mouth. At least he didn't swallow them - a cleaner found them in the waste-paper basket the following morning.

fields.headline: Why art matters
fields.standfirst: Michael Billington  hails two eloquent defences of hand-made performance, Tainted by Experience and Theatre@Risk
fields.trailText: Michael Billington hails two eloquent defences of hand-made performance, Tainted by Experience and Theatre@Risk
fields.body:
Tainted by Experience
John Drummond
Faber, £25, 384pp
Buy it at BOL

Theatre@Risk
Michael Kustow
Methuen, £16.99,288pp
Buy it at BOL

What kind of cultural life do we want in Britain? One that is diverse, ambitious, internationalist and open to the shock of the new? Or one that is bland, populist, commodified and dominated by management and marketing? Both these books are passionate, rousing defences of the appetite for excellence in a conformist, commercialised age. Far from being snobbish or high-handed, they remind me of the truth of Matthew Arnold's dictum that "the men of culture are the true apostles of equality".

John Drummond's book is a polemical memoir charting his sometimes erratic ascent through British public life: BBC television's arts department in its golden age, the Edinburgh Festival, Controller of Radio 3 and director of the Proms. What strikes me is his genetic and environmental good luck. The son of a Scottish mariner and an Australian soprano, he inherited a quick intelligence, a restless curiosity, a phenomenal memory.

Although brought up modestly in Bournemouth before moving on to the National Service Russian course and Cambridge, Drummond was part of a generation that experienced first-hand the post-war renewal of British artistic life: the Third Programme, cheap paperback books, susidised theatre, opera and ballet. Exactly like contemporaries such as John Tusa, Jeremy Isaacs and Joan Bakewell, he brought to broadcasting and public life firm values and a wide frame of cultural reference: a stark contrast to the modern media brats who seem to know nothing outside the narrow, goldfish-bowl world of television.

Drummond was also endowed with the priceless gift of impatience: there's a hilarious moment in the book when a BBC superior apologises for saying of him in a report that "he does not suffer fools gladly". Drummond takes it as a compliment but is sternly told: "Not in the BBC it's not."

Among the many fools chastised in this book are bone-headed bureaucrats, egotistic conductors (Bernstein especially) and philistine politicians (headed by David Mellor and John Patten). But Drummond's bête noire is John Birt - for his assault on Reithian values, his reverence for overpaid consultants and his unbelievable management-speak. Asked by Drummond what he thought of BBC orchestras, Birt replied they were "a variable resource centre whose viability depends on the business plan of the Controller of Radio 3".

Behind Drummond's testiness, however, lies a horror at the vandalisation of a once-great institution and a belief that those placed in positions of power, in broadcasting and the arts, have a mission to inform. Planning a series of architectural programmes for BBC Television, Drummond hired expert presenters such as Alec Clifton-Taylor, John Summerson and Mark Girouard: today, as he wearily says, it's more likely to be Janet Street-Porter.

As director of the Edinburgh Festival, Drummond redressed the imbalance between music and drama and achieved thematic unity, as in his unsurpassed "Vienna 1900" year. And, as head of Radio 3, he constantly related the speech output to the music, though I'd question his drastic diminution of radio plays.

Some might accuse Drummond of paternalism or even - to invoke the silliest of all words - elitism. But this shows the confusion of an age in which a proper scepticism about authority leads to a distrust of all professional knowledge and skill. Drummond, as a confessed generalist, readily admits that throughout life he has learned from people who know more than he does.

What he has, as I can testify, is the ability to transmit his own enthusiasms. At one Edinburgh Festival he berated me for rigidly sticking, like all critics, to my own discipline: "Go to some concerts and opera," he advised, "and tell the Press Office I said so." I went that night to hear Simon Rattle conduct Stravinsky, Ravel and Fauré, and, though I wasn't exactly a musical innocent, I would say Drummond's exhortation changed my life: I have been haunting opera-houses and concert-halls ever since. And, at its best, what this invigorating roller-coaster of a book does, apart from settling old scores, is introduce you to composers who create new ones and remind you of the unending richness of what, with misplaced reverse snobbery, we crudely dub "high art."

Michael Kustow is cut from the same cloth as Drummond: having worked at different times for the RSC, the ICA, the National and Channel 4, he is a cultural impresario rather than a creator. His new, vital, vehemently argued book is partly an account of the hectic travails involved in bringing John Barton's epic 15-hour saga about the Trojan war, Tantalus, to theatrical fruition, and partly a highly personal apologia for theatre in an age of global capitalism, technology and cultural relativism.

Kustow's book is full of wise saws and modern instances. He reminds us of Britain's debt to the amateur tradition of university drama - "so rare in other countries". He compares The Lion King to Inigo Jones's 17th-century masques in which pageantry replaced poetry. And, although his focus is ostensibly narrower than Drummond's, he sees the arts in a wider socio-political context: he not only assails Thatcherite market-driven madness but attends an IT conference in Amsterdam, where he discovers that "play, the very soil of theatre, is being appropriated by a new breed of designers and gamesters".

What is heartening is that neither of these two books, finally, is apocalyptic. Kustow ends with a richly descriptive and highly moving account of Ariane Mnouchkine's Paris production of Drums on the Dam that embodies the mix of intoxicating theatricality and urgent actuality in which he strongly believes. And Drummond, in a postscript, pays tribute to the wealth of emerging talent in the arts that rejects the gross materialism of the past two decades.

The right is always pessimistic: the left is congenitally optimistic. And I too believe that, as human beings, we will eventually crave more than television's steady diet of consumerism and voyeurism, cinema's procession of soul-deadening movies or the transformation of the London theatre into an outer suburb of Hollywood. Taken together, these two books amount to a passionate defence of innovation, authenticity and hand-made excellence in art, and a necessary assault on a prevalent junk culture that denies us real richness of choice.

fields.headline: Library fiction
fields.trailText: We're all so obsessed with sales that we forget that the larger part of a book's life is spent going in and out of the public library.
fields.body:
We're all so obsessed with sales that we forget that the larger part of a book's life is spent going in and out of the public library. This chart from a typical middle England library would seem to back up recent claims that women are the biggest consumers of books.

Rosamund Pilcher and Maeve Binchy are predictably in top spots, but it's interesting to see that Joanne Harris is still up there with what must rate as one of the most lucrative sleepers of recent years, Chocolat. (Do we deduce, from the lacklustre performance of her follow-up book, Blackberry Wine, that our core woman reader is a chocoholic but not a boozer?).

Then it's on to the thrill-'em-and-spill-'em brigade.The only representative of so-called literary fiction is Julian Barnes. But even he could be argued to have earned his place with a theme (and title) that appeals to the romantic yearnings of library woman.

fields.headline: Times are changing
fields.standfirst: Sara Holloway  explains why British publishers regard the German industry with undisguised envy
fields.trailText: Sara Holloway explains why British publishers regard the German industry with undisguised envy
fields.body:
Earlier this summer, a group of editors from seven British houses went on a tour of German publishers organised by the Goethe institute. The story about German publishing that emerged - from wood-panelled Munich mansions overlooking leafy courtyards, from sleek Frankfurt offices with views of the city's glass highrises, and from trendily dilapidated East Berlin apartment blocks - was remarkably consistent. Some described a "transition"; some a "crisis"; but all agreed that the industry was going through great changes - similar to those gone through by British publishing in recent years.

Until the mid-1990s, there were no literary agents in Germany and no bookselling chains; the industry was relatively stable, with most editors and their authors remaining at the same houses for a lifetime. Although there had been consolidation in German publishing - three main groups now dominate: Bertelsmann, which owns UK's Transworld and Random House, Hoizbrinck, which owns MacMillan as well as six German imprints, and Springer - book sales were strong and the industry had none of the volatility of the UK scene.

Now, however, literary agencies are mushrooming - by some counts from three to more than 80 in the past five years - with the result that editors are having to take part in competitive auctions, and first novels by German authors are selling for DM120,000 rather than DM10,000. Job losses are threatened, particularly in the Holzbrinck group, which was recently analysed by the management consultants McKinsey: they have recommended reducing staff levels by 30 per cent and shrinking the list by a quarter.

Germany still has a net book agreement and smaller independent shops still predominate, but bookselling chains such as the Munich-based Hugendubel are expanding and demanding bigger discounts from publishers.

But although the industry is going through a time of soul-searching, there is also great excitement - much of it bound up with being a reunified country with a big city, Berlin, at its heart again. Part of the reason for the proliferation of agents is that there has been a renaissance of German fiction - it is now vibrant, fashionable, and in demand. German publishers used to fill half their lists with translations; now they are buying fewer books from abroad.

This new literature has moved away from the postwar focus on history and politics to express subjective experience. There is a new pleasure in telling stories, rather than analysing social structures or experimenting with form. These young authors are good at self-promotion and do endless reading tours; most of them gravitate to Berlin.

German non-fiction is less buoyant. While biography and politics were still strong, many of the editors we met (most of whom seemed to have PhDs) were frustrated by the reluctance of German writers to produce pacy factual narratives. Non-fiction has traditionally been analytical and academic in Germany, and writers feel uncomfortable throwing away the footnotes and emulating the Anglo-American tradition of good, journalistic travel, memoir and narrative history, and the popularising of science and other academic subjects.

An editor at Fischer offered an interesting historical explanation: there was no substantial German empire, he said, and no resulting "gentleman journalists" producing essays and reports on their travels. The serious German approach to non-fiction also affects the way books are reviewed and categorised. Pedantic non-fiction reviewers criticise writers such as Simon Schama for not producing proper history, for being too airy and speculative. Frank McCourt's memoir Angela's Ashes was published as fiction.

Although German publishers are pensive about some aspects of their business and its future, there is still much to envy for a British editor. There are roughly 76,000 books published yearly in the country, for a market of about 80,000 people; this contrasts with the insane 100,000 published in Britain for a market a third smaller. There are state-funded literature houses in every city, sponsoring readings and writers' retreats; there seem to be an infinite number of literary prizes (interestingly, the judging process is all done in a dignified, private manner, with none of our brouhaha, and the shortlists aren't even published); distribution is superb, and most bookshops are still independent and run by highly trained, well-paid staff.

Finally, something mentioned by every publisher we visited was the country's main TV books programme, The Literary Quartet, hosted by the grand old man of German letters, Marcel Reich-Ranicki, and its electrifying effect on book sales. More than two million people tune in every Friday night to hear his fierce disagreements with guest critics and his pithy verdicts on three new books. The books that are favoured - and the programme only considers highbrow literary fiction - sell in tens of thousands the following day. British publishers would eat their returns to have such a programme over here.

 From September, Sara Holloway will be Senior Editor at Granta Books.

webTitle: Guardian review: In the Shadow of the Liberator by Richard Gott

fields.headline: Paratrooper president
fields.standfirst: Richard Gott expounds Hugo Chavez's vision for Venezuela in his biography of the newly elected president, In the Shadow of the Liberator
fields.trailText: Richard Gott expounds Hugo Chavez's vision for Venezuela in his biography of the newly elected president, In the Shadow of the Liberator
fields.body:
In the Shadow of the Liberator: Hugo Chavez and the Transformation of Venezuela
Richard Gott
Verso, £16, 246pp
Buy it at BOL

Hugo Chavez, formerly a mutinous paratrooper, has just won an enviable 59 per cent in the Venezuelan elections, confirming him as the "king of plebiscites" - as one paper said - and as president for the next six years. The timely release of this biography speaks well of Richard Gott's wisdom on Latin America.

Simon Bolivar (1783-1830), the liberator who inspired Hugo Chavez's quest to remove the old order, once said that South American nations "must make kings whom we call presidents". He did not say "and make courtiers out of the English left". But that too came to pass.

Until economic chaos in the late 1980s revealed the depth of its corruption, Venezuela was the most robust democracy in Latin America. Between November 1998 and December 1999, Venezuelans voted five times. Now Chavez has a mandate for reform, and he must show that he is as good at governing as at sweeping away an old system. Gott ably describes Chavez's dream of a "Bolivarian" revolution - a mixture comparable with developmentist programmes of the 1960s and 1970s.

Chavez shot to Latin American notoriety on February 4, 1992, when he led a rebellion against the government of Carlos Andres Perez, then in his second term in office. The paratroop officer failed and spent two years in prison, then slowly began to build his platform for government.

Since he took office in February 1999, Chavez has proclaimed his identification with the Cuban revolution, and roused members of the dormant Opec oil-producing cartel - originally the project of a Venezuelan - to secure a three-fold increase in world oil prices.

But just when he had won a massive "Yes" vote in the December constitutional-reform referendum, tropical rains hit Caracas with awesome force. In the early hours of Thursday, December 16, 1999, huge chunks of Caracas's shanties, and some not-so-poor suburbs, were wiped out by ferocious floods coming down from the Avila mountain. Thousands of slum-dwellers were killed, and an estimated 100,000 people were made homeless.

Gott's view of Chavez, which includes an interview with him, is largely flattering. He sees Chavez as the most intriguing political figure to have emerged in Latin America since Fidel Castro. This could be a blessing for academics seeking fresh material for their theses, but it is a doubtful gift to democratic progress in South America. We would really like to see fewer Messiahs and more ordinary men and women with good economic management credentials.

The author describes the Venezuelan's vision and presents a far-reaching alternative future for Latin America. But presumably, like those before him, Chavez will eventually be screwed by his leftist friends, who will claim that his brand of revolution is not good enough. That is our fate.

Gott is thorough in his description of Chavez's efforts. He goes to Barinas, where the president was born in July 1954, and reveals his own nostalgia, which is a little patronising. "This is the provincial Latin America that I like most, only eight hours by bus from the capital, but light years away by most other measurements."

He compares the country's pre-Chavez political structure to a one-party East European system, in which two groups simply agree to take turns at the Miraflores presidential palace. And he has an entertaining chapter on the selection of "Miss Venezuela", which ignores the Caribbean nation's indigenous people and descendants of Africans, because, he is told, "Venezuelans would not feel represented by a black woman".

Gott's 1960s book, Guerrilla Movements in Latin America, is a definitive text, and he is an experienced writer on the area. But one's impression had been that his generation of British Latin Americanists, who dictated good ideas for governance from comfortable homes in England, had all retired.

It is irksome to read England's incestuous, leftist Latin American specialists deciding what is best for the hemisphere. Those men and women sang the praises of Peron, Castro, Guevara, Omar Torrijos, and Forbes Burnham. I had liked to think that Richard Gott knew better, so his infatuation with Chavez is alarming. We have yet to see if the Venezuelan leader will leave a legacy any more worth celebrating than the rest of them.

 Andrew Graham-Yooll is editor of the Buenos Aires Herald.

webTitle: Guardian review: Something New Under the Sun by John McNeill

fields.headline: A geology of morals
fields.standfirst: Chris Lavers  learns how we have changed the planet in John McNeill's Something New Under the Sun
fields.trailText: Chris Lavers learns how we have changed the planet in John McNeill's Something New Under the Sun
fields.body:
Something New Under the Sun: An Environmental History of the Twentieth Century
John McNeill
Allen Lane, £20, 436pp
Buy it at BOL

According to Douglas Adams in The Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy, the most dastardly instrument of punishment ever invented is the Total Perspective Vortex. This heinous device, a type of virtual-reality machine, plays on the fundamental inadequacies of the human psyche by delivering a precise and irrefutable mental image of a victim's entirely negligible importance in the universal scheme of things, whereupon the poor fellow invariably descends into gibbering madness.

The moral? Given the extent to which our brains have been wired by evolution to deal with the universe at minuscule spatial and temporal scales, the very last thing that a human being can afford to own is a sense of perspective.

As we enter the 21st century, however, the acquisition of a global and deep sense of temporal perspective seems to offer our last chance of managing Earth to the benefit of our fellows, our children, and all our cousins in the earthly family of life. To achieve this, we must try to understand the long history and slow workings of the planet, the timescales over which it has accommodated change in the past, and the extent to which rapid, human-induced environmental changes might currently be exceeding its ability to cope.

Only against the backdrop of history can we evaluate our actions in the present and predict the likely outcomes in the future. It is with this philosophy in mind that John McNeill embarked on his engrossing new book.

McNeill's aim is to catalogue the major 20th-century activities of our species and interpret their environmental impact within the broader contexts of human and Earth history. Some of his statistics are quite remarkable. For example, we have probably used 10 times more energy in the last century than our ancestors used in the previous millennium. McNeill will probably not appreciate this admittedly crude, back-of-an-envelope calculation being bandied around by reviewers, but it is such an extraordinary estimate that I suspect he will have to get used to it.

In the 20th century, humanity has also moved more rock and soil around the globe than wind, glaciers, mountain-building processes or volcanoes. Only water remains a more significant erosive agent, but with continued growth of the global human population, it will probably not be long before we occupy the top spot. So numerous and powerful have we become in the last 100 years that we now collectively qualify as a geological process, and among the most significant on the planet at that.

Similarly illuminating and powerful statistics are set before the reader as McNeill assesses the extent of humanity's recent influence on the Earth's atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere. The rate at which mammal species went extinct in the 20th century, for example, was about 40 times higher than "normal", while the corresponding figure for birds is nearer 1,000 times greater. Expert opinion varies, but some scientists predict a loss of between a third and a half of the world's terrestrial species in the next century or two.

On the basis of these and other worrying estimates, McNeill suggests that we may unwittingly be pushing the biosphere ever nearer to a global mass extinction. Others suspect that we may already be in the midst of one. Will the biosphere, including humans, be able to cope with escalating exploitation of the world's resources and the enormous losses of biodiversity that look set to ensue? No one has the faintest idea.

A little exhausted, the reader reaches page 267 of Something New Under the Sun expecting to encounter the index, but instead finds McNeill embarking on Part Two of his treatise, an assessment of the demographic, economic, political and social forces that led to the environmental impacts he has described.

Here he is as sure-footed as ever, relating with clarity and insight the underlying reasons for 20th-century population growth, urbanisation, migration, industrialisation, spiralling consumption and manipulation of the Earth's natural resources, and the staggering growth in economic activity that, one way or another, has led to our current somewhat precarious environmental situation.

Lest the reader conclude that this book is just another doom-laden environmental rant, it should be pointed out that McNeill's approach to his subject is dispassionate, balanced, and as objective as the source material allows. He is content to chronicle and sensibly evaluate the growth of human influence on the environment in the 20th century, and leave the reader to make up his or her own mind as to the wisdom and likely consequences of our activities.

In a field that inspires great passion in its protagonists and frequent polarisation of opinion, Something New Under the Sun is a breath of fresh air. It is also a monumental, important and timely work of interdisciplinary scholarship, written to be accessible to anyone interested in the relationship between our species and the planet that supports us.

 Chris Lavers is the author of Why Elephants Have Big Ears: Nature's Engines and the Order of Life (Gollancz).

fields.headline: Dancing to different drums
fields.standfirst: James Hopkin  takes the pulse of current literature in German
fields.trailText: James Hopkin takes the pulse of current literature in German
fields.body:
As Nobel-prize winner Gunter Grass presided over last year's Frankfurt Book Festival, Der Spiegel magazine ran a story about a new generation of writers. The accompanying picture showed each young pretender playing a tin drum. Both a tribute to Grass's enormous influence, and an ironic reminder that others are looking over his shoulder, the photograph captured the healthy, transitional state of literature in German.

Among the new arrivals are the self-appointed "pop" writers who look to America - to Pynchon, Gaddis, DeLillo, and Brett Easton Ellis. They write about themselves, the short-lived experiences of the individual, the search for identity within a diverse, ever-mutating culture. Sex, drugs, and techno are never far away.

Benjamin von Stuckrad-Barre is perhaps the leader of the group. His novel, Soloalbum (1998), uses Oasis song-titles as a structuring device in a brash novel about relationships, losing weight, and a quest to become as cool as "Pop-land" (England). The follow-up, Livealbum, is the author's diary of a reading-tour around Germany.

Travelogue-fictions are emblematic of this fast-moving group. Christan Kracht's Faserland (punning on fatherland; with Faser meaning thread) unravels a route from north to south that starts at Sylt, an island in the North Sea, and finishes in his native Switzerland, calling in at Hamburg and Heidelberg. Such frivolous tales of European displacement do not attempt to compete with the profound musings on emigration, history and memory in the work of W G Sebald, who has a studied regard for literary tradition. Kracht is more interested in a coruscating wit.

The Irvine Welsh of the movement is Rainald Goetz, author of the well-received play, Jeff Koons, and the novel, Rave. He has two pieces in Nightdrive (1995), an anthology of modern German short stories in translation, a useful if somewhat uneven introduction.

However, not all younger writers subscribe to this spirit of sensationalism. Thomas Lehr's Nabokov's Katze (Nabokov's Cat, due to be translated next year), is an elegant novel that strives for the flair of the great stylist. Similarly well-crafted is Meine nachtblaue Hosen (My Night-blue Trousers) by David Wagner, which tells the simple tale of a rural childhood.

Yet the more interesting work, in terms of content, follows a familiar theme in German-language fiction: migration. Originally from East Germany, Michael Schindhelm, in his novel Robert's Reise (Robert's Journey), looks at East Berlin and Leipzig and the "new experience" since reunification.

So significant is the number of women readers in Germany that the most influential reviews are published fortnightly in the women's magazine, Brigitte. Among the important writers, there is Judith Hermann, whose collection of short stories, Sommerhaus, Spoter, created a big impression with its clipped prose and gentle wisdom. Meanwhile, Pieke Biermann's translated crime novel, Violetta (Serpent's Tail), is set in Berlin just after reunification.

Embracing writers from Austria, Switzerland and elsewhere, literature in German has always been European in outlook. Elfriede Jelinek is one of Austria's best-known women writers and playwrights. She once declared her country "a criminal nation" for its role in Nazi war crimes, and when Haider was elected, she withdrew her plays from the theatre. Her novels include The Piano Teacher, a provocative analysis of an intense mother-daughter relationship, and Wonderful, Wonderful Times (both Serpent's Tail), a satire of provincial Austrians plagued by their war-crime culpability.

Another major Austrian novelist and playwright is Thomas Bernhard. Cutting Timber (1984) is a viciously funny satire of cultural life in Vienna. Boasting "the Viennese Virgina Woolf" and revolving around two very Woolfian scenes - a dinner party and a funeral - the book sends up affluent dilettantes in post-Imperial, post-Nazi Austria.

Perhaps the best-known Austrian author is Peter Handke, whose experimental novels such as The Left-Handed Woman (1976), a dystopian vision of suburban Austria, have established his reputation as one of the most interesting writers of his generation.

Of the Swiss writers, Robert Walser provides a spirited and unusual read. Institute Benjamenta (1909) is an allegorical novel set in a school for servants, full of odd and engaging characters, while The Walk and other Stories (1917) is a collection of 42 pieces that marvel at the joys of landscape, rambling, and eccentricity.

It's impossible to ignore some of the great novels of the last century. Of those concerned with the war and its aftermath, Heinrich Boll's The Clown (1963) unmasks the guilt in 1950s Cologne, while Erich Remarque's All Quiet on the Western Front (1929) is a perennial anti-war bestseller. Also popular is the Gunner Ash Trilogy by Hans Hellmut Kirst.

Boll's most famous book, though, is The Lost Honour of Katharina Blum (1974), a parody of the German tabloid press, and of public life in West Germany in the 1960s and 1970s.

Gunter Grass's Gdansk/ Danzig trilogy, of which The Tin Drum (1959) is the best-known volume, is a vibrant mix of magic realism, social commentary and mischief-making. The Tin Drum itself is a rhythmic 600-page history of the Polish city and its people, a paean to a lost homeland. You only have to read Salman Rushdie's Midnight's Children to see the book's influence on world literature.

There are many great modernist tomes (Mann, Musil, and Broch among them), but literature in German has also been remarkable for the short form: the story, the fragment, the poem. Berthold Brecht's Short Stories brings together typically perverse, and strangely affecting pieces written while the author was living in Bavaria, Berlin and, during 1933 and 1948, in exile. Brecht's poems are not too bad either. And if you haven't yet read Czech-born Kafka's Metamorphoses and other Stories, perhaps it's time.

Rainer Maria Rilke's poetry is available in very fine translations by Stephen Cohn, while Diaries of a Young Poet compiles the journals Rilke kept while living in Florence, Schmargendorf (Berlin), and Worpswede (near Bremen, north Germany). They offer an abundance of lucid thoughts and sensual descriptions. As the great German thinker Theodor Adorno wrote, when you have nowhere to go, writing becomes a place to live.

webTitle: Halifax delays launch of IF again but denies any crisis

fields.headline: Halifax delays launch of IF again but denies any crisis
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Intelligent Finance, Halifax's much-hyped phone and internet bank, faces new delays after its launch was postponed last month.
fields.body:
Intelligent Finance, Halifax's much-hyped phone and internet bank, faces new delays after its launch was postponed last month.

The Edinburgh-based venture last night refused to say when it would be ready and admitted that the first accounts would be for staff only.

The bank, which bought the rights to Fatboy Slim's hit Right Here, Right Now for advertising, is making further system checks this weekend though it has resolved the capacity problems which forced the first delay.

Jim Spowart, the chief executive who described IF as a revolution in financial services, said he was not dealing with a crisis. "We are very, very close to launch, believe me."

The delay, which Halifax insists is costing only a few million pounds, means IF has been denied at least two months of sales, so making it tougher to reach tight financial targets.

Mr Spowart acknowledged that the continuing delay means IF, in which Halifax is investing £120m over two years, will have to be "driven harder" when it opens.

The first delay to IF in July came days after Abbey National's launch of Cahoot was crippled by software glitches. Since then, potential problems for net banks have been highlighted by security breaches at Barclays' online bank.

Mr Spowart said yesterday that the computer systems for IF were running. But he added: "A crucial element of any bank's success is how it deals with customers and how it handles their money. This is why we have decided to run the account for our staff for a short while before opening our doors to other customers."

He declined to say when staff would be allowed to open the first accounts.

The bank will connect its five products - current and savings accounts, credit cards, mortgages and personal loans - so that savings interest can be increased or loan interest reduced according to customers' financial position.

The first delay to IF's launch followed systems tests based on 15,000 calls a day, the number of people who had already registered for accounts, perhaps attracted by free Wap (wireless application protocol) phones offered to the first customers.

webTitle: Lottery talks stalled by Camelot legal challenge

fields.headline: Lottery talks stalled by Camelot legal challenge
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's attempts to run the national lottery were stalled yesterday pending a legal challenge by Camelot, the current operator.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's attempts to run the national lottery were stalled yesterday pending a legal challenge by Camelot, the current operator.

At the high court, Mr Justice Sullivan ruled that negotiations between Sir Richard's People's Lottery and the regulator should be halted over the bank holiday weekend and not restart until Tuesday.

The court will then consider Camelot's application for a judicial review of the regulator's decision to hold talks solely with Sir Richard. On Wednesday, the national lottery commission gave the People's Lottery a month to resubmit its bid while rejecting Camelot's bid out of hand.

Sir Richard, who held "constructive" talks with the commission before the court ruling yesterday, condemned Camelot's decision to go to law. "It could delay the setting up of the People's Lottery and potentially deprive good causes of hundreds of millions of pounds," Sir Richard said.

Camelot faces a difficult 12 months before its licence runs out. The operator went to great lengths last night to insist that it had "no quarrel" with the People's Lottery consortium.

Dianne Thompson, chief executive designate of Camelot, said the decision to take legal action came after a direct plea to the lottery commission went unheeded.

Mr Justice Sullivan said the pledge by the lottery commission not to negotiate with Sir Richard over the long weekend "meets the fairness of the case".

The regulator threw out Camelot's bid after its reputation was tarnished by connections with GTech, the US company that supplies much of its software, and after it was found to have covered up problems with its software.

webTitle: Game-swap teenage pioneer feels the Napster effect

fields.headline: Game-swap teenage pioneer feels the Napster effect
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The teenage creator of a file-sharing site popular with computer gamers has shelved a search for investors in the light of the music industry's action against song-swapping service Napster.
fields.body:
The teenage creator of a file-sharing site popular with computer gamers has shelved a search for investors in the light of the music industry's action against song-swapping service Napster.

More than 500,000 users have downloaded the Swapoo software since it was first offered at the end of July by 17-year-old Jeffrey Freeman, and more than 110,000 files are now posted for exchange on his site.

Inspired by Napster's design, Swapoo can be used to exchange any type of file, from word-processing programs to video clips

Until recently, many of these were illegal copies of video games, called Rom files, used in consoles such as those made by Nintendo and Sega.

Mr Freeman, who created the system because he wanted something to put on his cv, says he was amazed by the response. It also attracted the attention of Shervin Pishvar, chief executive officer of WebOS, who recruited Mr Freeman as a programmer and now advises him on developing Swapoo as a business.

Mr Pishvar is wary, however, of the legal problems encountered by Napster and advised Mr Freeman to "cool it".

"Jeff needs to ask himself: 'If it is going to be a business, what kind of business will it be?'," Mr Pishvar said. "Initially the system was very open to file sharing of illegal files and that's one of the things I told him he doesn't want to do. I've advised him to sort out Swapoo's legal position before approaching investors."

Sega recently began hunting sites hosting illegal Roms of its games, and so far has shut down 220 of them.

Mr Freeman said he had not received legal threats from any games companies but has added rudimentary filters to bar Rom files of games from being traded through Swapoo.

"We do not condone sharing of illegal files and we have a procedure in place to ban users from the network if they use it illegally."

But rights owners are stepping up their war on file-sharing services that could be used to distribute pirated material.

This week Steve Heckler, senior vice president of Sony Pictures Entertainment, warned: "The industry will take whatever steps it needs to protect itself and protect its revenue streams It will not lose that revenue stream, no matter what."

He told the Americas Conference on Information Systems that Sony would counter file-sharing systems. "We will develop technology that transcends the individual user. We will firewall Napster at source. We will block it at your phone company, we will block it at your ISP."

webTitle: Dodge set famous wheels in motion

fields.headline: Dodge set famous wheels in motion
fields.trailText: Mercedes, a name now redolent of wealth and engineering excellence, may originally have been no more than a dodge to get round an exclusive marketing deal in France.
fields.body:
Mercedes, a name now redolent of wealth and engineering excellence, may originally have been no more than a dodge to get round an exclusive marketing deal in France. The official version is that Emil Jellinek, the Austrian consul-general in Nice, used Mercedes - his 11-year-old daughter's first name - as a pseudonym when he drove a Daimler in a race in France in 1899.

He then ordered 36 Daimlers - a quarter of the German company's annual output - on condition that he got the sole agency rights for Austro-Hungary, France and the United States and was able to sell the vehicle under the Mercedes name.

Gottlieb Daimler, a baker's son who founded the Daimler motor company in 1890, agreed to the strange deal. Jellinek paid for the vehicles with 550,000 gold marks. Less official sources, however, claim that Jellinek's decision to use the Mercedes name was to get round the exclusive rights to sell Daimlers in France held by French car company Panhard.

Jellinek wanted a car he could race, and Daimler came up with the four cylinder Phoenix 35. Only five were made. The one preserved at the company museum in Stuttgart won the Nice Mountain Race in 1902 and later spent 31 years powering a circular saw in England before being restored to its former glory.

By 1902 Mercedes had become a legally-protected trade name for vehicles made by Daimler. A year later Daimler and Jellinek set up a company, Société Mercedes, based in Paris. Five years later Jellinek owned a Mercedes coach which he used to take his family on holiday. He changed his name to Jellinek-Mercedes.

Gottlieb Daimler invented the high speed combustion engine with his chief engineer, Wilhelm Maybach, and made his first car in 1886, the same year in which Karl Benz patented the motorised tricycle regarded as the mother of all cars.

The companies they founded were ri vals for more than 30 years. They promoted their vehicles by entering them in the road races of the day. Daimler did not live to see the success of Mercedes. He died the year that Daimler cars first appeared under the Mercedes name.

During the first world war the Daimler and Benz plants were turned over to war work, including production of aero-engines.

After the war the German economy was devastated. There were more than 80 car makers. Daimler and Benz eventually merged in 1926 to form Daimler-Benz, now known as DaimlerChrysler following its £55bn merger with Chrysler in 1998. Its Mercedes-Benz unit concentrated on cars. In the mid 1930s it introduced a successful racing car known as the Silver Arrow because initially its white paintwork had to be sanded off so it could meet racing weight limits.

Fans of Mercedes' sporty cars were surprised when the company launched a rather staid-looking vehicle, the 170, in 1931. But the popularity of the car and its cheaper sister, the 170V, with their independent front and rear suspension, was a kiss of life for the company during and immediately after the second world war. About 100,000 of the 170V models were sold, outselling any previous model made by the company.

Like other big German companies, forced labour was used at many of its plants during the war. Forty years later it started making payments to those involved.

After the defeat of Germany in 1945, the Allies initially banned the country from making cars for personal use. Mercedes was reduced to making bicycle trailers at its Untertürkheim plant and pick-up trucks at its Sindelfingen factory.

After car manufacturing started again, Mercedes launched the 300SL in 1954, followed by a new roadster, the 190SL in 1955. Seat belt anchorage points, an optional extra from 1957, became standard in 1961.

Mercedes became known for its top of the range saloons and comfortable luxury sports cars.

Its distinctive logo, a three-pointed star in a circle, stemmed from a postcard which Gottlieb Daimler sent to the wife of one of his sons. On it he had marked his house with a star. "One day this star will shine down on my work," he is reported as saying. The points of the star symbolise the earth, sea and air, the three areas in which Daimler motors were found.

For a time Mercedes owners found that the badges were being ripped off their vehicles after rap musicians started a fashion craze for wearing them suspended from chains around the neck.

Mercedes has dipped in and out of motor racing for most of its history, using it as a powerful advertising medium. Its drivers won six grand prix races in 1937, four in 1938 and five in 1939. It resumed racing seven years after the second world war, winning Le Mans in 1952.

It then had a run of Formula One successes in the mid 1950s after poaching Juan Manuel Fangio, the legendary Argentine driver, from Maserati. Mercedes withdrew from works racing in 1955 after an accident killed dozens of spectators at Le Mans. It returned in 1989, eventually teaming up with McLaren in Formula One.

Mercedes' reputation took a knock when the firm ventured into the small car market for the first time in 1997 with its A-class model. Developed at a cost of over £1bn, it toppled over during a driving test in Sweden. Sales were halted while an expensive re-engineering programme was undertaken.

Mercedes also partnered the Swatch watch company in developing the tiny two-seater Smart car for city travel. Swatch dropped out of the project last year.

Mercedes, which cut its UK car prices by an average 9% this week, is now planning to to compete with the Rolls-Royce and Bentley, both now in German hands. Its new luxury car is to be called the Maybach, a tribute to the designers of the early Daimlers. Somehow it seems more appropriate than the first name of a car salesman's daughter.

Key investment Piano maker William Steinway bought Daimler's patent rights in the US 12 years before the German company made its first Mercedes

Behind the wheel Formula One racing drivers Michael Schumacher and Heinz-Harald Frentzen were trained by Mercedes-Benz in Group C sportscar racing

Chequered flag British racing driver Stirling Moss won his first grand prix in a Mercedes at Silverstone in 1955

fields.headline: New rules on monitoring of emails delayed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Net news
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has agreed to delay new rules governing the right of employers to monitor their employees' personal emails in the face of widespread criticism of the legislation by business leaders.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has agreed to delay new rules governing the right of employers to monitor their employees' personal emails in the face of widespread criticism of the legislation by business leaders.

Ministers had previously insisted that the controversial Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, which will govern all email and telephone surveillance, must be in place before the Human Rights Act comes into force on October 2.

The proposed regulations require all public authorities and private companies to get the consent of both the sender and the receiver of emails, voice mails and other messages before they conduct any monitoring, with only a handful of specific exceptions.

However, business groups have warned that these constraints on business monitoring of emails could leave firms vulnerable to legal action by employees claiming their right to privacy had been breached. This in turn could force firms to avoid such risks by banning their staff from sending any personal emails.

The existing rules for in-house company surveillance have already been successfully challenged in the European Court of Human Rights.

Ministers hope the new law will avoid a spate of similar challenges against government departments and other public sector employers under the new human rights legislation.

Although the business surveillance law has already received royal assent, the Department of Trade and Industry has agreed to extend the consultation period on the proposed surveillance rules, which had been due to end yesterday, by a further three weeks following criticism from businesss organisations.

The rules will now come into force on October 24, when an EU directive concerning email privacy also comes into force.

Yesterday the Alliance for Electronic Business (AEB), which includes the Confederation of British Industry, issued a response to the DTI's consultation paper condemning the rules as "totally impractical and indeed impossible" to comply with.

The AEB called on the government to introduce entirely new rules which would allow companies the right to blanket monitor all employees without consent, except in "specifically excluded" cases.

This proposal was condemned by the Trade Unions Congress and civil liberty campaigners as "completely unacceptable".

A spokesman for the Home Office said public sector employers, who have a direct duty to abide by the Human Rights Act, had already been advised of the risk of a human rights challenge.

fields.headline: Curious@Freeserve
fields.trailText: Is Freeserve being flirtatious again? The market has latched on to the latest speculation that Britain's biggest internet service provider is about to do an equity deal with one of the country's plethora of telecoms companies.
fields.body:
Is Freeserve being flirtatious again? The market has latched on to the latest speculation that Britain's biggest internet service provider is about to do an equity deal with one of the country's plethora of telecoms companies.

Freeserve is to offer a chunk of itself in return for access to a telco group's new asymmetric digital subscriber line, or ADSL, that will permit high speed internet access - or so the story goes.

Freeserve then would concentrate on what it knows best.

The tale is curious, as Freeserve already uses Energis as a telco partner for its net dial-up service.

A Freeserve official refused to comment on the speculation. "We do not expect any discussions with any potential parties will lead to a bid for the whole company," he said. "Of course, we talk to people all the time."

Some pundits differed, marking the shares up 2.5% to 269.5p.

webTitle: Blair goes to bat for cashmere industry

fields.headline: Blair goes to bat for cashmere industry
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will attempt to defuse a long running EU-US trade row threatening jobs in Scotland's cashmere industry when he meets Bill Clinton at the UN millennium summit next month.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Tony Blair will attempt to defuse a long running EU-US trade row threatening jobs in Scotland's cashmere industry when he meets Bill Clinton at the UN millennium summit next month.

Mr Blair wrote to Mr Clinton earlier this month repeating Britain's request that the US exempt cashmere from the hit-list of products it is threatening with 100% duties as part of its ongoing trade row with Europe over beef and bananas. Britain does not support the EU trade restrictions which attracted US ire.

Last year, the World Trade Organisation authorised the US to apply $300m (£200m) of sanctions on European goods because of EU rules banning imports of US hormone-treated beef and discriminating against Latin American bananas grown by US firms, which violate free trade agreements. Cashmere was not included on the original list of sanctioned goods, after a fierce British lobbying campaign. However, in May Congress directed Washington to changed its approach and rotate the tariffs around a wider list of goods.

US government sources said on Thursday that the new list had been drawn up and that only the request to exempt cashmere was delaying its publication. The list was supposed to have been published in June.

A Downing Street official denied that the ongoing trade row would sour meetings between the two leaders at the UN's millennium summit next month. "The relationship between Mr Blair and president Clinton is a good one," he said. "It means they can talk frankly about issues."

The British cashmere industry is centred in the borders region of Scotland and employs around 4,500 people. Demand for the luxury product by wealthy Asians was hit hard by the financial crisis two years ago, leaving the US as the main export market. Business representatives fear that sanctions could destroy the industry and the local economy.

The UK government is also concerned that pressure from powerful lobby groups in the US could convince the Clinton administration to include other British goods on the target list. Possible targets include shortbread, which is almost as significant as cashmere in revenue terms, and plastic sheeting.

fields.headline: Telecoms lift holiday mood
fields.trailText: Software and telecoms stocks helped lift the market's mood ahead of the bank holiday weekend, leaving the FTSE 100 index slightly ahead on the day, up 6.7 points at 6,563.7.
fields.body:
Software and telecoms stocks helped lift the market's mood ahead of the bank holiday weekend, leaving the FTSE 100 index slightly ahead on the day, up 6.7 points at 6,563.7.

Index heavyweights Vodafone and British Telecom were the key to keeping London in positive territory, with a statement from Vodafone on its anticipated debt levels easing worries that telecoms groups across Europe will struggle to fund the next generation of mobile licences.

Bid prices have been hit by hyperinflation since the government introduced auctions for radio spectrum.

Vodafone rose to 273p but slipped back after Wall Street opened. The closing price was 268p, up 6p. The shares have risen 6.6% since its American associate, Verizon Communications, announced plans to float its wireless unit.

British Telecom crept another 3p higher to 822p after Thursday's dramatic 3% rise.

The company had been battered earlier in the week amid fears that rating agency Standard and Poor's might cut its credit rating to BBB+ from AA+.

In the event, S&P, which evaluates whether a company is at risk of defaulting on its debts, downgraded the company to A, seemingly allowing BT to get on with its planned $10bn bond issue.

Among the pure software companies in demand, Sema rose 40p to £11.50, Logica rallied 99p to £18.70 and CMG closed at £11.62, up 40p on the day. Dealers pointed to half-year figures due next Wednesday from CMG, which are expected to be accompanied by an upbeat trading statement.

Biotech group Cambridge Antibody Technology jumped 17%, closing 512.5p higher at £37. The advance was put down to some aggressive speculative buying of US-listed rivals such as Abgenix.

Elsewhere, an investment magazine tip for online dating agency OneSaturday sent the shares 1.5p higher to 13p.

Billiton , the South African mining group which joined the London market three years ago, slipped 10.25p to 300p after it making its most aggressive move yet into copper, trumping two hostile bids from Noranda of Canada and Chile's Codelco to buy Canadian copper miner Rio Algom for $2bn in cash and debt.

Billiton conceded that the acquisition will dilute earnings during the current year, but inisted the acquisition will be profit-enhancing from the second half of 2001. Investment bank UBS Warburg said it had cut it recommendation on the stock from "buy" to "hold" and kept its price target at 320p.

Pace Micro Technology , maker and supplier of set-top boxes for digital and satellite television, dropped almost 11% to close at 696.5p after reports highlighting the threat of competition from the Far East.

BSkyB has signed a deal with Sony to supply 200,000 set-top boxes in the run-up to the Christmas holiday season. Recently, a shortage of set-top boxes supplied by Pace meant cable TV operator Telewest had to temporarily halt marketing its digital service.

Durlacher , the stockbroker turned internet investment house, perked up 4p to 68.5p. The shares are still a long way from this spring's high of 455.5p but followers detected a little bit of bargain hunting yesterday as part of a general market-wide rally in tech stocks.

Brief but frenzied speculation about a new buyer for Perpetual drove its shares to a new £43.50 high yesterday. But volume was low and by the end of the day the excitement had died away and left the shares unchanged at £43.

The fund management group, set up by Martin Arbib, hung up the "for sale" sign earlier this year but is trying to wring a high price from potential bidders.

Amvescap had been tipped to make a play but has set its sights elsewhere. Other names in the frame include the Dutch group ING, Hypovereinsbank of Germany and Unicredito from Italy.

fields.headline: At this price?  Vocalis
fields.trailText: Vocalis, a developer of speech recognition technology, was sought-after earlier this year but investors are still not recognising the company's full potential.
fields.body:
Vocalis, a developer of speech recognition technology, was sought-after earlier this year but investors are still not recognising the company's full potential.

Shares were 1,057p in February but yesterday ended at 255p. The Cambridge group is, however, seeking further funding for product development with plans for a £5m share placing at 230p apiece.

Vocalis products include SpeecHTML, which enables companies to offer phone-based website information plus access to email messages and reply and delete using voice commands.

SpeechMail, which translates emails into speech, is used by more than 70 internet service providers in Britain. Vocalis has primarily marketed this product to the consumer market and is about to target business customers. The big leap may come when mobile internet connection is taken up more readily by consumers.

Forecasts have put the potential value of the speech recognition market at £5bn by 2004. Vocalis, which was spun off from Logica in 1993, this year also struck a deal with the business-to-business arm of BT, Syncordia Solutions, to develop an application for BT's call centres.

However, analysts still argue that Vocalis is a company with technology waiting for a market.

Speech recognition has been slower to take off than forecast, even after Microsoft's Bill Gates said it would be one of the keys to success in the computer industry of the future.

Vocalis' attempts to build a market-leading position have also taken a severe toll on the company's earnings. In April the group issued a profits warning which was followed by some shrewd investors selling out of the stock.

For the financial year just completed its pre-tax loss had grown from £1.1m to £4.5m as the group doubled its research and development budget. But analysts expect the company to climb into the black by 2002. One worth shelling out for.

webTitle: Notebook: if only BT had boxed clever

fields.headline: Dumping that could turn to junking
fields.trailText: If only BT had boxed clever
fields.body:
If only BT had boxed clever

There was a vindictive hue to a formal statement from Vodafone AirTouch yesterday recording the fact that having completed the sale of Orange to France Telecom, the company will soon be paying over £11bn to the British and German governments for new generation mobile licences.

The bill will be met with proceeds from the sale of Orange - which raised £27bn, half arriving in cash - with the balance reducing group debt, which Vodafone reckons will be less than £14.5bn at the end of its half-year on September 30. What is more, Vodafone still has shares in France Telecom worth about £9bn - part-payment for Orange - and also a £1.3bn loan note from the French which will be turned into cash sooner rather than later.

In short, the real debt position is roughly equal to the City's year-end pre-tax profit estimates for Vodafone, and the group is now on "positive" credit watch by the rating agencies.

Whether this rosy picture is the result of good fortune or shrewd business judgment is open to debate. It should be remembered that Vodafone was initially goaded into bidding for Mannesmann by the Germans' acquisition of Orange, and the resultant disposal of Orange by Vodafone amounted to a back-door rights issue.

But just compare this with British Telecommunications, where a "result" yesterday amounted to the credit rating agencies avoiding a cut to BBB+, settling instead for a shave from AA to A-. But even here, BT's £30bn of debt is still not that far from the point where it loses its investment grade and becomes known as junk instead.

Swift and dramatic action to break up BT is becoming more likely by the day.

'Can do' dealers

While franchised car dealers in the UK have been whingeing about dot.com car retailers taking their business, their American counterparts have taken a far more "can do" approach.

The decision by Ford's 4,200-strong dealer network to set up its own online venture is certainly taking the battle to the enemy. It will be financially strong - not least because Ford itself will be taking a minority stake - and it will give the dealerships a continued role in the car-buying process.

Purchasing a car is still a very personal business. People want to test drive a vehicle before splashing out on what may be their most expensive purchase after their house.

Under the FordDirect.com scheme, potential Ford buyers in the US will still go to a Ford dealer for a test drive and will still take delivery of their vehicle from a Ford dealer.

But the concept, if widely imported into the UK, could undermine the position of the growing number of internet-based car dealers.

These budding businesses have already seen one of their best selling point - the ability to undercut the franchised dealers - undermined by the decline in car prices in recent months.

It is now harder for them to buy vehicles at cheaper prices overseas and pass on the lower costs to their customers. But they still have the advantage of being able to offer new and secondhand vehicles made by different manufacturers on the same site.

The crucial problem for the internet dealer is that customers want to try before buying. There will still have to be showrooms; and customers will still pay for them, directly or indirectly.

The likely winners will be the large dealer groups who can afford to develop their own websites, possibly linked into various manufacturers' sites, while retaining their existing operations.

US schism

Alan Greenspan may be relaxed about the prospects for the high-flying American economy, choosing to leave rates on hold earlier this week. But for once the country's big banks do not appear to share his confidence.

In a survey of loan officers at 78 institutions published by the Federal Reserve yesterday, more than one-third said they had "somewhat" tightened business loan requirements in the last three months.

"A sizable majority pointed to a less favourable or more uncertain economic outlook as an important reason," the Federal Reserve said.

In the last survey taken in May, only a quarter of the respondents said they had tightened requirements in the previous three months.

Increasing concern about loans going bad hardly squares with Mr Greenspan's fairytale reading of the economy, a story he repeated yesterday at the annual gathering of the world's top central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

There are still no signs, Mr Greenspan said, that the high rates of productivity - which have boosted growth and held down inflation - were tapering off. The markets must hope that he, rather than the loan officers, has called it right.

fields.headline: Billiton buys into Canadian copper
fields.trailText: Billiton, the UK-based mining group, has made its first foray into the copper industry with a C$1.7bn (£776m) bid for Canada's Rio Algom, trumping a hostile offer led by Noranda.
fields.body:
Billiton, the UK-based mining group, has made its first foray into the copper industry with a C$1.7bn (£776m) bid for Canada's Rio Algom, trumping a hostile offer led by Noranda.

The Rio Algom board unanimously agreed to the Billiton offer of C$27 per share, a premium of nearly 50% on its Monday closing price and 10% more than the Noranda offer.

The deal gives the former South African company some coveted copper assets in both south and north America, and advances its strategy of diversifying out of its base metals portfolio.

Rio Algom shares soared in Toronto yesterday, up C$2.05 to C$28.30. But in London, Billiton's shares fared less well, falling 5% after the news amid market concerns that it had overpaid for Rio Algom and might have left itself stretched to make other acquisitions.

One analyst said the price tag was 55 times the company's prospective earnings.

"We are not particularly impressed," the analyst said, adding that Rio Algom shares were worth only C$19 each if valued by discounting cashflows. Billiton finished the day at 300p, down 10.25p on the day.

Billiton chief Brian Gilbertson denied overpaying for Rio Algom and his finance director, Mick Davis, added that the deal would enhance earnings from the second half of next year - assuming a long-term copper price of 95 US cents a pound.

Rage Software, the computer games developer and publisher, is unlikely to break even this financial year after revealing that profits would be hit by the cancellation of a big contract.

Rage refused to disclose the name of the publisher for whom it was preparing the game but market speculation indicates Microsoft, which intends to move into the video games arena with its high powered X-box console next autumn. Rage is said to be developing a football game for that console.

Shares in Rage ended down 4p at 22p. Rage said the cancellation of the contract would leave it with ownership of the game which it will now develop for several gaming platforms. It said the effect on its balance sheet would be the loss of potential revenues of £700,000 this year and a further £1m next year.

The Liverpool company explained the deal was cancelled because of a change in the buyer's commissioning policy.

Analysts said the average cost of developing a game was between £1m and £2m, of which a buyer bore some of the costs, particularly marketing. Rage is expected to have to bear most of that development cost.

In April, Rage announced it would change its strategy to retain most of its games rather than selling them to third parties.

It said it would concentrate on being a publisher as the importance of having content for on-line gaming sites grows.

Paul Finnegan, chief executive of Rage, said of the cancelled deal: "This is just a little hump in the road. All the rights come back to Rage and we can now put this across three to five platforms which over the longer term will benefit us. But in the short term it will hit us."

Beeson Gregory analyst Julian Morse said Rage was not an attractive investment at present. It had not had strong commercial success with its games.

"There's a level of 16p which it is not going to go below at which it would be very attractive to a potential buyer."

Rage is releasing its Wild Wild Racing game for the Sony PlayStation 2 console next month. It has also worked with the makers of Dreamcast consoles.
