webTitle: Swedes bid for London stock exchange

fields.headline: Swedes bid for exchange
fields.standfirst: Unsolicited approach for London market dismissed as attempt to wreck iX merger
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange last night rejected an unsolicited bid from a Swedish rival aiming to scupper its controversial merger with Deutsche Börse to form iX.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange last night rejected an unsolicited bid from a Swedish rival aiming to scupper its controversial merger with Deutsche Börse to form iX.

The London exchange told its shareholders that the offer from OM Gruppen of Stockholm was "derisory" and a "spoiling tactic" ahead of the crucial vote next month on the proposed Anglo-German tie-up.

The timing of this latest twist to events determining the future of the 200-year-old London exchange served to inflict maximum damage on the exchange. It has racked by controversy since announcing its intention to merge with the Frankfurt market earlier this year.

Don Cruickshank, embattled chairman of the London exchange, said: "We urge our shareholders and our customers not be to distracted by this approach which amounts to no more than a competitive spoiling tactic."

The move will heap pressure on the London exchange, which already faces a tough battle in trying to win support from 75% of its shareholders for the vote on September 14. Many of London's smaller stockbroking firms have been outraged by the merger plan, anxious that the business of trading in smaller company shares and hi-tech stocks will be lost to rivals in Frankfurt.

It emerged last night that the surprise intervention by OM, which owns the Swedish stock exchange but which has already branched out into futures and options trading in London, was received on Thursday.

A series of meetings between the London exchange, OM and investment banking advisers took place late yesterday. However, no agreement could be reached.

The London exchange, which recently demutualised to allow trading in its own shares for the first time, said the offer from OM valued the exchange at £27 per share, in a mixture of cash and paper. The last traded price in the London exchange's shares, which are dealt through the offices of brokers Cazenove, was £23.50.

Mr Cruickshank said: "For our shareholders, the offer value is derisory. For our customers, the proposal fails to provide the benefits which will arise from achieving critical mass in European securities."

The idea behind the merger of the German and London exchanges is to create a pan-European market for share trading. The introduction of the euro means that investors across Europe are increasingly expected to buy shares outside their domestic borders. New technology, particularly the internet, means that traditional exchanges are facing increasing competition from new bourses.

OM has been taking a leading role in some of the new trading ventures which have been set up, including Jiway, an online stock market in which it has a 60% stake.

While the London exchange experiences difficulty in winning backing from its shareholders, a survey by AFX news agency established that its German partner is also on a bumpy path.

Of all the leading shareholders in the German exchange, only Deutsche Bank has been prepared to declare unequivocal support for the merger. The bank's chairman, Rolf Breuer, is also chairman of the German exchange.

fields.headline: Ulcer fight nears close
fields.trailText: Healthcare group Smith & Nephew is close to winning a four-year battle to get marketing approval for a highly unusual dressing for foot ulcers made from discarded babies' foreskins.
fields.body:
Healthcare group Smith & Nephew is close to winning a four-year battle to get marketing approval for a highly unusual dressing for foot ulcers made from discarded babies' foreskins.

The company yesterday announced that it had reapplied in the US for permission to sell the product, Dermagraft, after encouraging results from a recent set of clinical trials.

Dermagraft is used to treat foot ulcers suffered by diabetics - who tend to have poor blood circulation to the extremities of their limbs and whose wounds therefore take much longer to heal.

Smith & Nephew grafts foreskins removed in circumcision operations on to these ulcers, creating a new layer of natural skin which grows into place. Clinical trials showed that wounds healed rapidly in 30% of cases using Dermagraft, against a rate of 18% using traditional dressings.

A spokesman said: "Foreskins contain young, healthy tissue, containing lots of growth cells. They are a very good source of material."

When it was developed in the early 1990s, Dermagraft was seen as a potentially huge product - an estimated 400,000 patients in the United States alone have difficult to heal ulcers.

Originally, estimates of future sales were as high as $500m (£340m). However, these forecasts have been reduced sharply because of delays, which have allowed competitors to launch alternative natural dressings.

webTitle: Hague warned to 'up the energy' by senior Tory

fields.headline: Hague warned to 'up the energy'
fields.standfirst:
Senior Tory tells leader to develop more coherent policies and regain initiative from Labour
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague came under fire yesterday from a senior Tory backbencher for failing to develop principled policies and for a lacklustre performance over the summer that has played into the hands of the government.
fields.body:
William Hague came under fire yesterday from a senior Tory backbencher for failing to develop principled policies and for a lacklustre performance over the summer that has played into the hands of the government.

In a sign of the growing unease among Tory MPs over the party's poor showing in opinion polls, David Davis, the chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said that Mr Hague had lost the impetus that he had built up in the spring.

"There is plenty to attack [the government on] but they are getting away with it because there has been no attack," Mr Davis, a former minister, said. "It is a matter of energy level and drive as much as anything else."

The criticism of Mr Hague from a respected Tory backbencher will anger the party leadership, which is growing increasingly alarmed by the fall in its support in recent polls. The latest Mori poll, in the Times on Thursday, showed that Tory support had slumped to 29%, with Labour soaring ahead to 51%. Other polls also confirm that Labour has seen off the brief challenge from the Tories in the spring and early summer when government support dipped.

Mr Davis said the Tories had thrown away the campaigning opportunities in possibly the last summer before the general election, and contrasted it to Labour's summer offensive in 1996. Asked on the BBC's The World at One what had gone wrong, Mr Davis said: "I do not honestly know the answer to that. What I hope is that they are going to come back all guns blazing in September and start to create problems for the government."

His remarks show how Mr Hague's fortunes have plummeted since the spring when he unsettled the government by seizing on populist issues such as the jailed Norfolk farmer Tony Martin and asylum seekers.

However, the Tories started to falter in July when Mr Hague abandoned flagship policies, such as his "tax guarantee", and the government regained the initiative with Gordon Brown's spending review.

Mr Davis, MP for Haltemprice and Howden, said that Mr Hague's initial enthusiasm for high-profile guarantees, and his failure to replace his discarded pledges with coherent policies, were a mistake. He said the party would only win round voters with "credible and principled" policies.

"If we up the energy level, go on the attack more and make sure that what we go for is credible and principled and consistent, then we have a chance to put this awful government out of place," he said.

Mr Davis's remarks were dismissed by John Redwood, the Tories' "spin buster". "I don't think it's a fair criticism of William Hague," he said. "The mood for the Conservatives is a lot better now than it was in 1996-97 and the mood against this government is very strong."

Mr Redwood said he did not believe the polls because the Tories had performed well in this year's local elections and last year's European elections. "We have got a few polls which I think are completely meaningless," he said.

Mr Davis's criticism of the Tory leadership delighted Labour, whose spinners recalled their success during the last summer before the 1997 election when they forced John Major's government onto the defensive.

This summer the Tories have struggled to set the agenda and have been mainly reactive, often to little effect. This week the Tories criticised the government over the lottery when the ruling on Camelot was made by an independent statutory body.

fields.headline: Twins must have fatal surgery
fields.standfirst: Judges rules for twins operation
fields.trailText: Surgeons were yesterday given the go-ahead to separate Siamese twin girls against the wishes of their parents and though the operation is bound to cause the death of the weaker child.
fields.body:
Surgeons were yesterday given the go-ahead to separate Siamese twin girls against the wishes of their parents and though the operation is bound to cause the death of the weaker child.

In the first case of its kind in Britain, a high court judge decided it was right that the 12-hour operation be carried out despite the parents' wish that nature should take its course.

The parents were brought to England for the birth from a "remote" community in an unidentified European country which lacked sophisticated medical facilities.

Jodie and Mary - false names used by the judge to preserve their anonymity - were born joined at the lower abdomen on August 8 at St Mary's hospital in Manchester.

Doctors believe that if the twins are separated Jodie will have a good chance of a normal life while Mary, who relies on her twin for her blood supply, will die. Without an operation, it is thought both girls would perish within six months because of the extra strain being imposed on Jodie's heart and lungs.

Though the parents believed that morally the operation should not take place, Central Manchester healthcare trust appealed to the court for permission to go ahead with the procedure.

Jodie is described in the court ruling as a "bright and alert baby, sparkling, sucking on her dummy, moving her arms as babies do...very much a with-it sort of baby." If separated, doctors believe she would be able to walk unaided, probably attend school and have children.

Mary's state, however, is "pitiable". Her face is deformed and she has no effective heart or lung function and she probably has brain damage. Her sister is effectively her life support machine. When lightly touched or stroked, her face contorts and, when pinched, she reacts but cannot cry out in pain because she does not have the lungs. As Jodie moved, tried to crawl or turned over in her sleep, there was the "horrendous scenario" of Mary being dragged around behind her".

Mr Justice Johnson, giving his ruling in public after a two-day private hearing, said: "For Jodie, separation means the expectation of a normal life; for Mary it means death. Little wonder that the parents are overwhelmed by the circumstances that confront them.

"Instead of the joy and the longed-for happiness of children, they are faced with a decision from which any parent would shrink. They love, love dearly, both their children but they love them equally and simply cannot bring themselves to choose life for one at this frightful cost to the other."

The parent's background further complicated the quandary. The customs of their community meant that the religious couple believed they were being punished for previous sins and it was "unthinkable" that the twins could be taken home.

During the hearing, the father broke down as he tried to give evidence but the judge quoted at length from the parents' emotional written testimony. The parents expressed concern that if Jodie was left seriously disabled, they would not be able to look after her properly in their country because of their lack of money and the poor standard of health care. They argued that they might have to leave her in England - a move which would break their hearts.

Mr Justice Johnson said he had "attached great weight" to the wishes of the parents but he added that the interests of a child were "paramount".

He also emphasised that the court would never authorise a step to "actively" terminate a life, even to relieve misery. However, it is lawful for treatment to be withdrawn, even if this leads to death.

The judge said: "I conclude that the few months of Mary's life, if not separated from her twin, would not simply be worth nothing to her, they would be hurtful. To prolong Mary's life...would...be very seriously to her disadvantage."

Giving clearance for the operation, he said he based his decision on the twins' case on the view that what will cause Mary's death is the "interruption or withdrawal" of the blood supply from Jodie, comparing this to a doctor withholding food or drink.

The parents and the Official Solicitor, acting on behalf of Mary, are understood to be preparing to appeal against the decision next week. Siamese twins develop when a fertilised egg which is set to divide into identical twins fails to split. The result is that two embryos are joined together. The phenomenon occurs once in 50,000 to 100,000 births.

Great Ormond Street children's hospital, London, is one of the centres which has had success separating Siamese twins. Since 1984, 16 sets have been treated there. Twelve children, including four sets of twins, survive.

There have been some high-profile cases. Aiofe and Niamh McDonnell were born in June 1997 sharing a liver. They were separated in a seven-hour operation and are living a healthy life in Ireland.

'We have faith in God to decide our daughters' fate'

This is an extract from the written testimony of the twins' parents to the high court. The name of the parents' home country is replaced with (in our community).

"We cannot begin to accept or contemplate that one of our children should die to enable the other one to survive. That is not God's will. Everyone has the right to life so why should we kill one of our daughters to enable the other one to survive. That is not what we want and that is what we have told the doctors treating Jodie and Mary. In addition, we are also told that if Jodie survives, and that is not known at all, then she is going to be left with serious disabilities. The life we have (in our remote community) with very few, if any, facilities would make it extremely difficult not only for us to cope with a disabled child but for that disabled child to have any sort of life.

There is a small hospital but they do not have the staff or facilities to cope with someone with serious ongoing disabilities ... We know our babies are in a very poor condition, we know that the doctors are trying to do their very best for each of them. We have very strong feelings that neither of our children should receive any medical treatment.

We certainly do not want separation surgery to go ahead as we know and have been told very clearly that it will result in the death of our daughter Mary. We cannot possibly agree to any surgery being undertaken that will kill one of our daughters. We have faith in God and we are quite happy for God's will to decide what happens to our two young daughters. In addition, we cannot see how we can possibly cope either financially or personally with a child who will have serious disabilities.

We know there is no guarantee of survival but she is the stronger of the two twins and if she should survive any surgery then we have to be realistic and look at what we as parents can offer to our daughter and what care and facilities are available to her in our homeland. They are virtually nil...This has meant we have also had to give very careful consideration to leaving Jodie in England should she survive to be looked after by other people. We do not know if other people would be willing to look after such a seriously disabled child but we do know that this is something that, if we had any other choice, we would not give it consideration.

We do not know if it is possible or feasible for her to be fostered by another family so we can have an involvement in her upkeeping or whether she would have to be adopted and we would have no contact with her at all. That would break our hearts."

webTitle: Face to Faith: Hear me talking to you

fields.headline: Hear me talking to you
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: According to many, the Anglican church is in crisis. According to some, it is in terminal decline. Many of the some are Catholics, and some of them are reacting with neighbourly concern.
fields.body:
According to many, the Anglican church is in crisis. According to some, it is in terminal decline. Many of the some are Catholics, and some of them are reacting with neighbourly concern. Others among them are reacting with glee. But gleeful Catholics could start by putting their own house in order; if their Anglican neighbours are having a bit of a domestic, dry rot is silently eroding their own floorboards.

The current Anglican crisis is one of authority, or rather a perceived lack of unifying authority. As numbers decline, the prospect is of a broad church broadening to ruin, with the centre failing to hold. Contradictory beliefs about legitimate ministry and core Christian ethics threaten to fragment province, diocese and parish.

You can pick your own catalyst for this disunity, from a menu which offers the decision to ordain women priests, any refusal to declare homosexual activity sinful, and creeping secular liberalism, as espoused by Bishops Spong, Holloway, Jenkins - or whoever your preferred demon happens to be.

Whatever the contributory factors, symptoms of disunity abound. Perhaps the most glaring is the consecration in Singapore in February of two bishops bound for a ministry to American conservatives. This was done over the heads of both the Archbishop of Canterbury and the US church leadership.

Such developments have led to some Catholics claiming (more in joy than in sorrow) that ecumenism is now indefinitely postponed; they mean dead, but are not allowed to say so. The argument is that a unified choir cannot rehearse with sundry visitors who each brandish a different hymn sheet.

As a Catholic myself, I am more troubled by my church's current note of superiority than I believe Anglicans should be by their own discordant notes. In many sectors of the Catholic church, the present stand on Catholic- Anglican dialogue is, "We will continue to proclaim its critical importance while doing nothing to promote it and much to damage it."

Take the decision of Vincent Nicols, the new Catholic Archbishop of Birmingham, that St Augustine's, the joint Catholic-Anglican school in Oxford, should be replaced by a Catholic school - despite the fact that the school has already been teaching RE according to the approved Catholic syllabus. In setting out his reasons, he acknowledges that the school is "a significant ecumenical initiative and its closure would be a serious countersign." But what else can he do, given that his view of his ministry is that "as a bishop, my first duty is to seek the furtherance of the Catholic faith and religion"

Might not his first duty be to help people come to Christ together? If all his fellow Catholic bishops agree with him as to their first duty, ecumenical dialogue is finished because, from the Catholic side, it is merely a smokescreen for expansionism.

Meanwhile, an article by an Oxfordshire parish priest, which recently appeared in the Catholic press, argued that young Catholics share far more common ground with free Evangelicals than with Anglicans. Which implies that Catholics have more affinity with a church which does not have bishops, priests, or focal eucharist than with one that does.

At a stroke, decades of Catholic-Anglican dialogue are swept aside. At the international level, the implication is that the Pope would have been better employed kissing airport tarmac elsewhere, when he was visiting Archbishop Runcie. At the civic level, we can infer that, here in Liverpool, the cordial dialogue between Bishop Jones and Archbishop Kelly is wasted words.

Yet, with an annual decline in mass attendance of 50,000 or so, the Catholic church within these shores is losing adherents every bit as fast as the Anglican. But for opposite reasons. While the Anglican malaise is division threat- ening explosion, the Catholic malaise is uniformity threatening implosion.

This uniformity resembles unity, while eroding it. Its deadening assumption is that unity requires unanimity. Contrary views are either stifled (liberation theology) or tacitly tolerated, while officially outlawed (contraception). This method fosters oppression and hypocrisy above dialogue, for which - between clergy and laity - there is no structural forum.

In its own terms, this position makes sense. Dialogue implies diversity. There is no space for it internally within congealed uniformity. And there is no need for it externally when you believe you monopolise truth. If the Catholic church lays itself open to occasional mockery, it is not because nuns ride mopeds and watch wrestling, but because sectors within it sometimes adopt this forbidding view of its essence.

Those who do should look up for a second, and glance across the water. There, they will see a quiet human miracle. It is the miracle of entrenched enemies listening and talking to each other. If Derry and Londonderry dare dialogue, surely Westminster and Canterbury can as well?

 Chris Hardwick is a freelance writer

webTitle: Anger as BT raises call box fees

fields.headline: Anger as BT raises call box fees
fields.trailText: British Telecom was under fire last night after announcing that it is to double the minimum price of a call from a phone box to 20p and increase the cost of local calls.
fields.body:
British Telecom was under fire last night after announcing that it is to double the minimum price of a call from a phone box to 20p and increase the cost of local calls.

The company, which made a profit of £2.9bn last year, said it was being forced to increase fees because the growing use of mobile phones was making its phone boxes less viable.

But campaigners for the poor and elderly warned that the move would marginalise thousands of people who do not have access to a phone at home or a mobile.

Under the new charges, to come into force on October 3, the 10p minimum fee which has been in force since 1984 will be scrapped in favour of a 20p basic charge.

There will be a single charge of 11p a minute for both national and local calls made from boxes, replacing the current two-tier system under which local calls cost 9p a minute and national ones 14p.

BT will also start charging for 192 directory inquiries and 153 international inquiries from payphones, which are currently free. Here the price will depend on the time spent speaking to the operator.

A spokesman for the Low Pay Unit said: "This seems to us to be another example of the marginalisation of certain groups. How can people feel part of society when they are denied access to services others have?"

Age Concern also expressed its fears about the changes, pointing out that almost one in 10 single pensioners do not have a phone of their own.

BT has an obligation under the Telecommunications Act 1984 to provide a system of pay phones at an affordable rate. Since privatisation it has increased the number of public phone boxes from 76,000 to more than 140,000. More than 95% of people are thought to have access to their own phone.

The industry watchdog Oftel has powers to ensure that sufficient phone boxes are provided, but under the 1984 act can take no action on pricing. However, it is to launch a wide-reaching inquiry into phone boxes next year and if it believes that BT is overcharging, it can request the Department of Trade and Industry to take action.

BT claims that the present price of local payphone calls does not even cover its costs - but refuses to provide the figures to back this up.

Malcolm Newing, director of BT Payphones, said: "There is increasing competition, particularly from pre-pay mobile phones, and we need to safeguard the future of the payphone service."

He said the new fee would help BT to keep under-used payphones in rural areas.

Disabled callers who are registered for the 195 free directory inquiries service will not be affected by the changes.

webTitle: Letters: Government's lack of control over arms trade

fields.headline: Call to arms
fields.trailText: "The defeat of Mr Cook and Mr Byers is... to be lamented" (Leaders, August 23). What an understatement!
fields.body:
"The defeat of Mr Cook and Mr Byers is... to be lamented" (Leaders, August 23). What an understatement! Far from just being lamented, it makes our government a laughing stock over control of arms' sales. The year before Labour came into office the man who was later appointed Labour's foreign secretary made a statement making absolutely clear the opposition's views on the Scott report on the arms trade. For three years the government has prevaricated and now it is sliding out of any commitment to implement the recommendations of the Scott report. Such behaviour, especially on the arms trade issue, is a matter that concerns many Labour supporters and is a serious vote loser.
Lady Moser
London

fields.headline: Unsmiling eye on Ireland
fields.trailText: John O'Mahoney's devastating critique of Ireland in 2000 (A tiger by the tail, Guardian Review, August 19) reminded me of why I and thousands of twentysomethings like me, left that country during the early 80s, vowing never to return; funerals and weddings excepted.
fields.body:
John O'Mahoney's devastating critique of Ireland in 2000 (A tiger by the tail, Guardian Review, August 19) reminded me of why I and thousands of twentysomethings like me, left that country during the early 80s, vowing never to return; funerals and weddings excepted. There was the continued feting of a macho drinking culture and it's devastating legacy on families; the crass xenophobia and intolerance (at school I was routinely taught to hate the English, Jews and gays); the breathtaking, casual sexual violence perpetrated against women and children. It's not surprising that even given its renowned wide-open spaces, it was a suffocating environment to grow up in.

I'm very saddened but not surprised that the same fault lines and hypocrisies that disfigured Irish society then remain unaddressed. Short-term affluence has surely papered over the cracks, but as John O'Mahoney pointed out, an over-dependence on fickle foreign investment, coupled with a ridiculous Disney-like Oirish identity projected to the world is neither progressive nor realistic.

As an expatriate of almost 20 years I perceive the image of Ireland abroad to be peculiarly ambiguous. For all its desire to be seen as a modern European state, it remains as self-obsessed, defensive, and parochial as ever; a culture under siege. I for one, with an Asian partner, couldn't consider returning to such a place. As England has had to painfully readjust to a new reality, Ireland too, must let go of the past and trust itself and its people to make the right choices for the future.
Name and address supplied

fields.trailText: Today's Travel photo feature (on Bombay people enjoying a splash in the monsoon waterfalls and torrents at hill resorts) went to press before the news pages, which report a flood tragedy on the other side of the country, near Hyderabad. We regret the unintentional combination.
fields.body:
Today's Travel photo feature (on Bombay people enjoying a splash in the monsoon waterfalls and torrents at hill resorts) went to press before the news pages, which report a flood tragedy on the other side of the country, near Hyderabad. We regret the unintentional combination.

A misprint appeared in a letter on submarine casualties yesterday, page 19. The right version is that in May 1943, 41 U-boats were sunk in the Atlantic, 32 with all hands.

A panel in Media Guardian's insert on the Edinburgh International Television Festival, page 5, August 21, aimed to decipher acronyms. Unfortunately, almost none of them qualified. Collins decrees: "A pronounceable name made up of a series of initial letters or parts of words".

The Soil Association's spokesman quoted on page 4 yesterday is Henry Haddaway, not Hathaway.

A rock music item, page 19, G2, August 23, said that Cedar Walton played piano with John Coltrane on the album Giant Steps. In fact, Walton's takes were not issued until years later. The pianists on the original album were Tommy Flanagan and Wynton Kelly.

A Health article, G2, page 10, August 23, said swimming helped reduce "high blood pressure and hypertension". They mean the same thing.

In a piece about a Northern Ireland jail (August 24, early editions, page 2) the ninth word in this sentence should have been 'not': "The prison authorities are adamant that they will introduce the policies that resulted in the Maze being run by inmates."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Donatoni and opera
fields.trailText: I read Ivan Hewett's obituary of Franco Donatoni (August 22) with interest, but there are a few points that ask to be expanded upon.
fields.body:
I read Ivan Hewett's obituary of Franco Donatoni (August 22) with interest, but there are a few points that ask to be expanded upon. It is not strictly true that Donatoni wrote no operas. Apart from the music theatre piece Atem, a collage (it is true), there is the extraordinary one-acter Alfred Alfred, set in a Melbourne hospital and featuring the composer himself lying (mute) in bed while doctors and nurses sing the main roles.

The work composed after his silence in the mid-70s was Ash - the sprightly Spiri came later and proved to be one of Donatoni's most life-affirming works. It is strange that Ivan Hewett implies that the purported absence of operas in his output signifies a narrowness of vision, any more than the presence of operas within a composer's oeuvre signifies breadth.

Apart from the music itself, which numbers Boulez, Berio and Xenakis among its admirers and combines intellectual toughness, inventiveness and glamour, Donatoni's enormous legacy as a teacher has had immense influence on many generations of young composers from all over the world, including a number of British composers (Malcolm Singer, Michael Zev Gordon, Richard Causton and myself) who took sustenance from his intellectual rigour, professionalism and charisma. Perhaps his last orchestral work, Prom, might find its way the Royal Albert Hall one of these days?
Robert Keeley
King's College, London robert.keeley@kcl.ac.uk

fields.headline: Race issue
fields.trailText: I would like to clarify the impression that may have been given by the headline of my article (Straw's race policies are racist, August 25).
fields.body:
I would like to clarify the impression that may have been given by the headline of my article (Straw's race policies are racist, August 25).

I do not believe, and did not say, that the home secretary's race policies are racist - they aim for many of the right targets and are much more positive than previous governments' policies. But they would benefit from more dialogue with ethnic minority communities and international bodies.

On asylum, however, the government has failed to combat racist rhetoric effectively and some of its policies will lead to the social exclusion of minority groups. Unless these two policy areas are joined up, this risks undermining positive moves on race.
Anne Owers
Director, Justice

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: North Pembrokeshire
fields.body:
North Pembrokeshire

The Preseli hills provide us with a range of habitats. In a summer like this the boggy areas are particularly cheerful. On the lower slopes they are flanked by gorse bushes. The common gorse is now in fruit, seeds popping in the sun. The western gorse is a more delicate plant with a softer green colouring and flowers which, combined with heather, give a yellow-purple thrill often heightened by the addition of clear blue scabious.

Once in among the bog land you usually find yourself alone - even over public holidays. Here you find the sundews unfurling their single flower stems with a clutch of small pale blooms. It is the leaves you first notice because their green is fringed with sticky Indian red hairs longing to close over any insects that land on top of them. Thus they supplement their diet, which is rendered nutrient deficient by the acid bog surroundings. Watching this process is both fascinating and something else. Best move on to deeper bog where the bog myrtle rewards you with a haunting scent, especially in strong sunlight.

The plants we came to are kept low by sheep grazing (is this why Welsh lamb is so good?) but retain their own curiosity: usually the female plants are on one plant, the male on another, but they can change sex from year to year, or move to having both sexes on the same plant, or become hermaphrodites.

Flying over this scented delight were male Keeled Skimmers, dragonflies whose powder blue bodies add another colour to the ever changing moor. The females are brown and spend more time lying low. But a real rarity tugged us away from this pleasant spot. There is one area where bog orchids are known to appear with their typical elusiveness. One year there they are, another year where are they? They are small: 3-12 cms. Only their light green colouring allows you to distinguish them from the upright heath stems. Strong knees and a strong lens are required to see the tiny yellow flowers.

webTitle: Letters: Responses to Julie Burchill on Madonna

fields.headline: Madonna of the Groucho
fields.trailText: Re Julie Burchill's attack on Madonna (Enough! G2, August 24): might I suggest that "wrapping one's ankles behind one's head" has kept the icon's body and soul together long enough for her to have an amazing grip on contemporary culture.
fields.body:
Re Julie Burchill's attack on Madonna (Enough! G2, August 24): might I suggest that "wrapping one's ankles behind one's head" has kept the icon's body and soul together long enough for her to have an amazing grip on contemporary culture. This is more than I can say for a bloated and bitter has-been journalist. Might I suggest to Madonna that she take her detached placenta and ram it inside Burchill's gerbil cheeks. Maybe this would avert her from constant public displays of embarrassing and outmoded opinion on the modern woman.
Darren Mapals
Oxford

 So Julie Burchill thinks all slim women over 35 are desperate and neurotic? I think we can figure out why...
Elizabeth Kay
Worcester Park, Surrey

 Julie Burchill is correct about the inexplicable success of the egregious Madonna. But Madonna has always been crap, a fact which has nothing to do with her age. Rock and pop has been around since the 50s and it is no longer the sole province of "young people", nor should it be.
Glyn Powell
London

 Julie Burchill could have made better use of Jane Austen by not only quoting her correctly ("That will do extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough.") but also finishing the quotation: "Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit."
Rosie Bell
Edinburgh

 "Most talentless people disappear quite quickly: very few hang on decade after decade; when they do it feels like they are taking the piss." Quite.
Dr Richard A'Brook
Carnoustie, Angus

 Pot, kettle, black... ?
Mike Waldie
Romford, Essex

 Julie Burchill accuses Madonna of a bankruptcy of ideas. This from a women who has used the same Guy Ritchie put-down three times in the last month.
Bruce Barnard
Helston, Cornwall

 Julie Burchill must be as tired of typing her Guy Ritchie joke as I am of reading it.
Paul Bowen
London

Darren Mapals Oxford  So Julie Burchill thinks all slim women over 35 are desperate and neurotic? I think we can figure out why... webTitle: Leader: How we did at GCSE

fields.headline: How we did at GCSE
fields.trailText: "French people speak French better than English people this year." I am happy to offer this headline to you for use as appropriate should you ever run out of headlines like "Grammar schools scoop GCSE laurels" (August 25).
fields.body:
"French people speak French better than English people this year." I am happy to offer this headline to you for use as appropriate should you ever run out of headlines like "Grammar schools scoop GCSE laurels" (August 25). The report's subsequent bolt from the blue that "Selective grammar schools continue to produce the best GCSE results" must also have rocked the readership. Here's another headline for use next year: "The selective system's secondary moderns, protected by Blair and Blunkett, continue to produce the worst GCSE results."
Christopher Bray
Lincoln

 I thought I was reading the Daily Mail. Was it a PR piece for Theresa May and grammar school headteachers? The big story, from the limited information available so far, is how extraordinarily well some comprehensives are doing. If you'd told me in 1994, when 11 comprehensives scored 79% or more good GCSEs, that 52 would do so in 2000, I would have said "in your dreams", yet they've done it. Similarly the number scoring 90% or more has gone from three to 16 in four years. You even talk of the 93% from the London Oratory as failing to "scrape" in.

Yes, I know some comprehensives aren't comprehensive - but none of them are remotely close to 100% selective grammar schools in their intake. These achievements are very real. That even the Guardian allows raw grammar school performance rates to eclipse them is a disgrace.
Martin Frey
Ashford, Kent

 The DfEE earlier this year released figures showing the top 25% of students at comprehensives get better results than grammar schools on all measures. Also research by Professor David Jesson of York University shows that "the impact of grammar schools appears to depress the overall level of performance in LEAs where they exist in substantial numbers". If your reporters do not know this, they should not be writing about education.
Malcolm Horne
Buckinghamshire Parents for Comprehensive Education

 Would it not be more informative if you were to "name and shame" those grammar schools that do achieve 100% A-C grades - for them, an extremely modest target?
Tony Fraser
Braintree, Essex

 You write that "there was an improvement of more than 10% in the top two grades, from 62% last year to 72.7%". The actual rise was, of course, 17.25%. You would have failed GCSE maths.
Roger Perry
Wighill, N Yorks

 I would be interested to see somebody refer to the tremendous achievements of the thousands of adults who every year enter for GCSEs through FE colleges - many of whom are gaining an exam qualification for the first time in their lives. An analysis of the results by age would be very interesting. It seems bizarre that in these days of lifelong learning, these results are totally ignored.
Rachel Smith
Stockport

 If Anthony Grayling's rhetoric (The mark of the male, August 24) is what passes for philosophy at Birkbeck College then we must worry about standards in higher education. He states "honest educators will tell you standards are lower" and justifies his assertion with "there is no question about it: they are far lower". About an E, I think. Maybe those who pontificate about teaching should actually try to do the job in today's schools.
Nick Lacey
Shipley, W Yorks

 One might also have hoped that AC Grayling would understand that education and examinations have very little to do with each other.
Philip Negus
Pontypool

fields.headline: Knights and horses
fields.trailText: Julian Borger (Comment, August 25) could have mentioned that the courageous Serbian journalist, Miroslav Filipovic, has corroborated the extent of Serbian killing in Kosovo in articles based on interviews with Serbian army officers and an unpublished Yugoslav army report.
fields.body:
Julian Borger (Comment, August 25) could have mentioned that the courageous Serbian journalist, Miroslav Filipovic, has corroborated the extent of Serbian killing in Kosovo in articles based on interviews with Serbian army officers and an unpublished Yugoslav army report. For publishing his work through the London-based Institute of War and Peace Reporting, Filipovic has been tried for "espionage" and condemned to seven years imprisonment.
Prof Martin Shaw
University of Sussex
m.shaw@sussex.ac.uk

 Am I to infer from Austin Mitchell's letter in praise of the US (August 25) that we should now institute indiscriminate legal murder, arm our school children, teach them creationism and assume that "democracy" is a synonym for rapaciously unbridled capitalism? That would be so New Labour.
Prof Michael Rosenthal
University of Warwick

 If Cambridge University does get its hands on the Newton manuscripts, let's hope they're not bare hands as in your photograph (August 24).
Prof Charles Stirling
Department of chemistry University of Sheffield

 Your leader (August 24) bemoaning the poor recognition of Britain's scientists remarked that at least Frank Whittle was knighted. You neglected to mention that the heroic Michael Faraday was doubly distinguished for refusing that bauble.
Simon Gardner
Leighton Buzzard, Beds

 The "last horse butcher" in Britain did not close in 1938 (Where horse is harnessed a la carte, August 25). My mother bought horsemeat during WW2 at Bert Slack's, off Prince's Street in Stockport. I used to enjoy it but my Dad, being an Australian and reared with horses, couldn't bring himself to eat it.
Stanley Graham
Barnoldswick, Lancs

webTitle: On the fifth day it was time off

fields.headline: On the fifth day it was time off
fields.standfirst: As flexible working practices gain in popularity, and many of us daydream about this week's Bank Holiday Monday being added on to every weekend, Sandra Deeble asks: Is working a permanent four-day week really just wishful thinking?
fields.trailText: Sandra Deeble asks: Is working a permanent four-day week really just wishful thinking?
fields.body:
When everyone pitches up at work on Tuesday after the Bank Holiday weekend, how many of us will wish that every weekend could be a three-day jamboree. How different life would feel. Less stressful, more balanced and more fun!

The thing is, even for people who love their jobs - working long hours because their work is fulfilling and stimulating - the drawn-out time spent at work leaves less and less opportunity for developing other parts of their lives.

Indeed, for large swaths of the population, by the time we hit Thursday evening, we may well have clocked up 40 hours at work - 2.5 hours over the suggested maximum week put forward in the Working Time Directive. So, why not down tools on Thursday and just call it a day? Indeed, could the four-day week really happen?

"You can do it as soon as you have an excuse," says Paul Edwards, chairman of the Henley Centre. "If you have a baby you can do it, or if you're someone very important, like Gerry Robinson."

But what if you don't have an excuse? Supposing you just want to combine your job with another interest? Wouldn't you be labelled a shirker? And as for developing your career - wouldn't working fewer hours mean waving goodbye to any future promotions? There'll always be someone else willing to steal a march on you by putting in the hours. And anyway, how would you convince your boss that a shorter week could work in the first place?

"The four-day week often comes through length of service," says Elaine Howe, one of the founders of Working Options, a consultancy specialising in part-time professional recruitment. "Often, you can keep the bulk of your responsibilities. And certain professions lend themselves to project-type work. But client-facing work makes it more difficult. Clients expect you to be there," she says.

"There are so many jobs on the other side of the consumer power equation - working in McDonald's or in a call centre - where it doesn't work," confirms Paul Edwards. "There's a lot of 'I wish' about it," he says.

Rachel Boothroyd, a City lawyer, agrees: "Everyone would like to do it. Yet you'd end up doing five days' work in four."

Is that such a bad thing? If you knew that every week was a short one, wouldn't it make you use your time much more efficiently?

"If we were sensible, we would parcel up our working hours differently," admits Paul Edwards.

"It's something we're still battling with," says Angela Ishmael, Head of Dignity at Work, at the Industrial Society. "There's still this whole culture of proving your worth just by being there."

It has become such a hot topic that some organisations have set up programmes to look at how the four-day week could work.

At Andersen Consulting, Naomi Maxwell Macdonald works four days a week and has been running the Balanced Workforce Programme for almost a year. "We're looking at a number of things that we can do for people in relation to flexibility. We're trying to move to a situation where work is valued on outcomes rather than on hours done."

Clare Fuller is a director at the communications consultancy Bamber Forsyth, working for clients including the Gatwick Express, Kiss 100FM, Emap and Unilever. "I started doing four days a week eight and a half years ago - it was prompted by becoming a mother.

"I was working for another company in the same industry and it was at a time when business was doing well and there was a shortage of people with my kind of skills. I think that encouraged them to be flexible.

"I think you can be better natured and more relaxed if you're only doing four days. Friday is the one day where I can actually decide what I do with my time. But although my contract is four days a week, if something big comes up that needs me, then I'll do it.

"I think it's very important for clients to feel that you're available so I don't go out of my way to tell them that I'm not there on Fridays. It's easier when you're fairly senior in an organisation because you have more flexibility about arranging meetings. But if large numbers of people wanted to work four days a week in our business it would be a real problem but actually nobody else has asked to do it.

"The week does feel different although recently I have been sucked into more and more working on Fridays. I feel I'm at an interesting crossroads. I remember saying to myself 18 months ago that I would never work five days a week again because this balance is better for me.

"But sometimes when there's a lot of stuff that needs doing it's very difficult to push off on Thursday evening and leave everyone else to cope with it.

"The programme is designed to encourage people to pursue their interests so that they feel happy when they're at work."

If the four-day week were to take off, one could imagine a time when the "fifth day" becomes a time currency as common as the gap year. "What do you do on your fifth day?" people will ask each other at parties.

Forget the evening classes that are always so difficult to get to - on the fifth day the colleges of further education will be choc-a-block - unless everyone will be forced to take to their beds after the unprecedented rigours of the more intensive Monday-to-Thursday routine.

Or will it be Tuesday to Friday? Perhaps some people would rather have their Fifth Day on Monday, thus avoiding the bleakness that so often falls on a Sunday around the time of Antiques Roadshow.

Yet how will it work? When calls come in for you on your fifth day, will your colleagues be primed to say: "She's away from her desk" as they reach for another phone to call you at home or on your mobile phone?

The new way of working could come back to haunt you with the guilt associated with the fraudulent sickie.

So will the four-day week ever become a reality?

"Yes, definitely. Within the next 10 to 15 years," says Angela Ishmael confidently. "I've seen it work really effectively in small organisations and I've seen it work in the public sector. But at the moment, managers don't have the kind of skills to deal with it.

"Yet while it can produce tangible business benefits it's still a difficult concept for people to get their heads around."

Alex Datnow: Now I can fit in my painting

Alex Datnow works at the social marketing consultancy Good Business and is involved with running Reach for the Sky - a nationwide project which aims to inspire Britain's teenagers to explore their talents and passions - with client Sky Television. She is about to start a four-day week and her fifth day will be spent doing an art course.

"I remember thinking about six months ago: If I could do anything, what would I really want to do? I was really enjoying my job but I felt - and probably have done since I was about 17 - that although I'm not a Picasso, I really enjoy art. I love painting and sculpture but I've never really given it the time or energy that it needs.

"I thought that the ideal set-up would be to do four days at Good Business and then to have a day where I could do some art. At weekends, there's just not enough time. I'm currently doing the Reach for the Sky project which will run until the end of August and it will be running again next year. I went to one of the directors here about two months ago and he was incredibly supportive. Really positive.

"We've talked about why I want to do it, and about the impact it will have on my work. I'll be earning less, although the directors have recognised the work I've put into projects over the last year and they've actually given me a bonus in recognition of that, so I feel really valued.

"It is going to have an impact. Largely, I think it will be positive. I don't think it will have to affect the work and relationships with clients. If I'm not there, it may mean others will be stepping in and doing things. I don't know what the adjustment will be. If anything, I'll feel more motivated and fresher when I'm there."

James Kennedy: Don't call me, I'll be writing

James Kennedy is business development manager at BSkyB and manages the Reach for the Sky project and Skyscape at The Dome. He has just renegotiated his contract and is about to start working four days a week. On his fifth day, he is planning to pursue his interest in film directing and writing.

"I will be encouraging people not to contact me on Fridays. And my boss actually only works four days. I'm in a sleep pattern during the week to get up at a certain time and I'm converting a bedroom into a study and getting rid of my TV. My main objective is to become a film director. I'm also trying to write a book: it's a Lord of the Rings-style book in the form of one long poem. But, hopefully, my next job will be directing a film.

"When I was working in advertising I went out to Australia and some of the inspiration there was that my flatmates had two jobs: three days and two days but it didn't impact on promotions. Australia seems to be leading the way in the whole freelancing area. In the UK, the media industry's attitudes have changed. People treat you according to your merit and whether you do a great job. If you're good at your work, people won't see you as a slacker.

"And if you've got different interests, it can work in your favour. But I think some industries are still very regimented. I think it's going to take time."

fields.headline: Simon Cole
fields.standfirst: Chief executive of UBC Media, which has just floated on AIM
fields.trailText:
When did you first become a manager?
In 1987 at Piccadilly radio in Manchester. I was 26 and too young for the responsibility.
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?
In 1987 at Piccadilly radio in Manchester. I was 26 and too young for the responsibility.

What has been your best moment in management?
To see 80% of our staff buy into the company at flotation to add to free shares they had already been given.

What was your greatest mistake?
Doing things I wasn't ready for and letting an ambitious heart rule a reflective head.

Which deal would you most like to have done?
The one Ralph Bernard of GWR Group did to own the national digital radio multiplex. He was unopposed in the bid for what is one of radio's most valuable pieces of real estate.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?
Not taking initiative and fear of failure.

Does your organisation have a "glass ceiling"?
Since we went public I have realised that the answer to this is "no" if you have the courage to think big.

What management wisdom is most over-rated?
Everything that comes with a pretty chart and an acronym.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?
The ability of large organisations to adapt and change at the speed consumers and technology will demand.

What one lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?
Delegate and give responsibility to your staff.

Which management guru do you believe in?
I belive in companies: Tesco for customer service and ability to adapt, Microsoft for vision, Virgin for cheek.

Who is your management hero?
I prefer "mentor". I tend to admire the best bits of those I have come into contact with: Richard Eyre at Pearson for his dedication to team-building, Ralph Bernard at GWR for vision, Richard Park at Capital Radio for judging the consumer mood.

Who is your favourite politician?
That's an oxymoron.

What phrase or saying do you most over-use?
Any transatlantic slang.

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?
Sunsets.

What annoys you most?
Being in a queue of any sort.

How do you relax?
Running and gardening.

What was your last cultural experience?
Peter Grimes at Glyndebourne.

What is your favourite city?
Manchester, but Cheltenham would be my favourite "town" and Santa Monica in California my "world city".

Do you have a favourite website?
It changes every week - this week it was a cool site by web design team Mook.

What is your greatest regret?
My greatest regret is always when pressure of work makes you selfish and insensitive - it happens too often.
fields.bodyText: When did you first become a manager? In 1987 at Piccadilly radio in Manchester. I was 26 and too young for the responsibility. What has been your best moment in management? To see 80% of our staff buy into the company at flotation to add to free shares they had already been given. What was your greatest mistake? Doing things I wasn't ready for and letting an ambitious heart rule a reflective head. Which deal would you most like to have done? The one Ralph Bernard of GWR Group did to own the national digital radio multiplex. He was unopposed in the bid for what is one of radio's most valuable pieces of real estate. webTitle: How France did the business on the field

fields.headline: How France did the business on the field
fields.standfirst: Are victories on the football pitch reflected in national economic performance? The French deliver an emphatic 'oui'. Peter Gaskell reports
fields.trailText: Are victories on the football pitch reflected in national economic performance? The French deliver an emphatic 'oui'. Peter Gaskell reports
fields.body:
Do national sporting triumphs lift a country's mood and give its economy a boost? French central bank governor Jean-Claude Trichet said the Euro 2000 victory would "help the economy, as it did two years ago".

The recent outstanding performances of the French national soccer team, however, do seem attributable to the effect of reorganising the sport according to management principles.

Does this mean then that all England need to do to win is simply ask the French how they did it? We shall get the latest reading on the two nations when they meet at the Stade de France next Saturday.

The French can point proudly to their fondness for logic and structure as key factors contributing to the country's footballing triumphs. Philippe Tournon, of the French Football Federation (FFF), says: "Forty years ago, French football was very technical, very polished, symbolised by players like Raymond Kopa. In the 1958 World Cup in Sweden the national team did quite well, finishing third, but then little else happened for about 20 years.

"Critics said the players might be skilful and intelligent, but they were not athletic enough. It was realised that being a footballer is a profession, and players needed proper training. This led the FFF to make the key appointment in 1970 of Georges Boulogne as chief training adviser to the national technical staff, the Direction Technique Nationale (DTN). He understood the blend of skill and physical endurance that players needed, and sowed the seeds for future success."

A National Football Institute was set up at Vichy - and later moved closer to Paris. Youth national selection and training structures were set up, with coaches charged with training and choosing the various junior national teams (schoolboys, under-18, and under-21). Professional clubs began setting up their own nurseries of young players. The best were selected for national training courses.

Today just under 500 young players undergo training at the seven FFF federal training centres staffed by coaches from among the 150 highly qualified technical instructors. Current French internationals Thierry Henry, Nicolas Anelka and David Trézéguetall rose to prominence by this route.

The Boulogne methods brought their first results in 1982 when France reached the World Cup semi-finals in Spain, losing on penalties to Germany after leading 3-1. Often referred to as the Michel Platini generation, this team went on to its first major triumph, winning the Euro competition in France in 1986.

"One element was still missing, though," says the FFF's Tournon from his office in the Federation's Avenue d'Léna headquarters. "Our players still lacked the killer instinct: that ability to get ahead in a game and to stay there. They had learned this during the 90s, while playing in the English, Italian and Spanish leagues. Our players have been psychologically toughened there, and the 1998-2000 team would not have surrendered a 3-1 lead - even against the Germans!"

It was France's football mercenaries who provided the backbone of the World Cup-winning side of 1998, trained and picked by Aimé Jacquet, an officially qualified coach who joined the DTN in the 1992/93 season to work with national selector Gérard Houllier (now manager of Liverpool). Jacquet had managed (coached) several clubs. The Federation's management committee put him in sole charge of the national team in 1993.

Jacquet once gave this definition of his job: "I am a reducer of uncertainties." The definition is certainly one with which many business leaders would happily concur. Jacquet's greatest achievement was to instill in the players the conviction that the team was all-important. When the mercurial Eric Cantona would not accept a set number 9 role in the team, he was not picked for the Euro 96 squad that reached the semi-finals in England.

The Jacquet approach has been adopted by his successor Roger Lemerre, 60, who was a professional footballer from 1961 until 1975. His most important responsibility was as coach/selector for France's national military XI. As a selector Lemerre now has a slightly superior record to his mentor Jacquet. For Euro 2000, the French technical staff at Clairefontaine developed a computer-based "match-reader" system which produced a morning-after analysis of the game.

This analytical approach, plus the incredible self-belief of the players, stood them in good stead through the anxious half-hour when Italy led in the final, bringing the French to a last-gasp equalising goal 45 seconds from time. The golden goal winner was then inevitable.

 Peter Gaskell is former head of press relations at the OECD

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: Kicking your heels in an immigration holding-pen can powerfully focus the mind. A few weeks back I flew into Detroit to work with a giant, would-be global car company.
fields.body:
Kicking your heels in an immigration holding-pen can powerfully focus the mind. A few weeks back I flew into Detroit to work with a giant, would-be global car company.

As my turn came to speak to the grim-looking immigration officer, he grilled me on who I was working for, how much I was being paid - and whether there weren't American experts who could do the job?

I answered the first, told him the second was none of his business and, on the third point, noted that Europe now has something of a competitive advantage in stakeholder engagement processes.

He decided I needed a lesson in local power politics. Happily, my luck held: once in the pen, a charming official sped me through the process and wished me God-speed. But the process turned up the amps on a thought-process that had been buzzing around my brain as we crossed the Atlantic.

Ahead of the next day's stakeholder process, which I was co-facilitating, I had been reading two recent books on globalisation: Thomas Friedman's The Lexus and the Olive Tree (HarperCollins, £8.99) and A Future Perfect by John Micklethwait and Adrian Wooldridge (Heinemann, £20.00). The combination was mind-altering - and should be required reading in anyone's immigration service.

One message I had already absorbed from Friedman was that the inevitable backlash to globalisation won't come just from the downtrodden. "Like all revolutions," he says, "Globalisation involves a shift in power from one group to another. In most countries it involves a power shift from the state and its bureaucrats to the private sector and entrepreneurs.

"As this happens, all those who derived their status from positions in the bureaucracy, or from their ties to it, or from their position in a highly regulated and protected economic system, can become losers - if they can't make the transition to the Fast World."

It's hard to imagine even the surliest immigration officers being out of work any time soon, particularly in the US, where the country's southern boundaries are under growing pressure from would-be immigrants. But my small contretemps in Detroit further sensitised me to a key theme of the Micklethwait and Wooldridge book: the importance of borders.

These, they say, "are arbitrary abstractions, economic impediments, and surprisingly ineradicable". It's a paradox that globalisation will force us to think about our borders - economic, social and environmental - as never before.

But what most worries these two is the risk that the whole process may still fall flat on its face. They suspect that "globalisation's psychic energy - the uncertainty that it creates which forces companies, governments, and people to perform better - may have a natural stall point, a moment when people can take no more".

Last year's "Battle of Seattle", which shook the World Trade Organization to its roots, was an early warning that the Fast World may be dangerously near some sort of stall point.

Whatever immigration officers may believe, countries championing globalisation must lean over backwards to open up their own markets.

As Friedman concludes: "For globalisation to be sustainable America must be at its best - today, tomorrow, all the time."

Do Americans, do we, realise just how big a challenge this is going to be?

 John Elkington is chairman of strategy consultants SustainAbility (web-site: www.sustainability.co.uk) and author of Cannibals With Forks: The Triple Bottom Line of 21st Century Business (Capstone, £12.99).

fields.headline: Loopholes left in leasehold
fields.standfirst: An attempt to curb the landlord's power has not gone far enough, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: An attempt to curb the landlord's power has not gone far enough, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.body:
This week flat owners around the country sighed with relief as the government signalled an end to the reign of nightmare landlords with the publication of its proposals for residential leasehold reform.

The long-awaited draft Commonhold-Leasehold Reform Bill is light at the end of the tunnel for nearly 2m flat and house leaseholders in England and Wales, many held to ransom by unscrupulous freeholders charging sky-high maintenance charges. But critics say the proposals to increase leaseholders' rights and introduce a new form of flat ownership, called commonhold, don't go far enough.

In the consultation document, the government proposes a new right for leaseholders to take over the management of their building without having to prove landlords' shortcomings and without paying them compensation.

The move does not replace existing leaseholders' rights to buy the freehold, but is an alternative for those dissatisfied with the management of the building and either don't want, or can't afford, to fork out for the freehold.

Leaseholders who do want to force the landlord to sell them the freehold, a process known as collective enfranchisement, will find it easier under the proposals, which aim to simplify how freeholders are compensated.

Leaseholders will have a greater say on the vexed question of service charges. Other improvements include changes to accounting procedures to discourage fraud.

Campaigners were hoping ministers would get rid of leasehold for good. However, the draft bill stops short of removing the status. Instead, it introduces a new form of tenure, commonhold, where flat owners have an interest in their flat or "unit" and an interest in a commonhold association which owns the shared parts, such as hallways.

Flat owners will be able to convert to commonhold, but only if all interested parties, including the freeholder, agree. Applicants must satisfy HM Land Registry that consent was given freely.

The fact that newly built properties will not automatically be registered as commonhold proves the government has ducked the issue, says Ken Murray of the Coalition for the Abolition of Residential Leasehold (Carl). Instead, owners of new flats will have to go through the same process as others to convert to commonhold.

Mr Murray says Carl is also angry that the government is sticking with the device known as the marriage value, the term for the compensation made to the freeholder if he or she is forced to sell to the leaseholders.

Disputes over the marriage value have slowed down attempts at collective enfranchisement in the past. Some flat owners have given up when unwilling freeholders have used the process to stall the sale.

The marriage value is the amount the leasehold and freehold would be worth if they were sold together on the open market. The draft bill proposes that the marriage value is split half-and-half between leaseholders and landlord. Mr Murray wanted to see it abolished altogether.

About 200,000 leaseholders in England have a local authority or housing association as their freeholder. Many bought flats from their landlord under the right-to-buy initiative of the 80s. Since then a growing number have changed hands.

According to the government, about a third of the group are second owners who bought their ex-council flat on the open market. Buildings that started life as council housing, such as architect Erno Goldfinger's Trellick Tower in Hammersmith, London are now inhabited by a mix of council and private owners.

But many, particularly the system-built estates of the 60s, are expensive to maintain. And leaseholders are often unhappy with the service they receive from their landlord, particularly when it comes to charges for maintaining the building and common parts. For their part, many social landlords are unwilling freeholders, uncomfortable with the role - they were forced to sell properties to former tenants by law.

The government has decided that leaseholders with social landlords need the same protection as those in the private sector. Announcing the publication of the draft Bill, housing minister Nick Raynsford said all leaseholders have a right to be consulted about the works they'll be expected to pay for and an opportunity to challenge works or costs they consider unreasonable.

Leaseholders already have the right to be consulted about major works. The government proposes extending this right to include improvements to the property. Leaseholders will also be able to challenge the reasonableness of the work or its cost at a Leasehold Valuation Tribunal. Leaseholders who fall out with freeholders or suspect they are being ripped off can turn to Lease, an independent agency that provides free legal advice to leaseholders, landlords and others.

Residential leasehold reform is a slow process. The government says it now wants to test proposals out. Interested parties have the chance to comment on the proposals and draft bill before October.

But Mr Murray says Carl will take this opportunity to try and persuade ministers to remove leasehold status from the statute books altogether.

webTitle: Matches of the day on the box

fields.headline: Matches of the day on the box
fields.standfirst: A forthcoming Christie's sale of offbeat collectibles could prove illuminating, reports Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: A forthcoming Christie's sale of offbeat collectibles could prove illuminating, reports Stewart Dalby
fields.body:
The International Match Safe Association sounds as if it could be anything from a body to look at the control of football hooliganism to a secret society aimed at aligning codes for security vaults around the world.

In fact it is a group of people, mostly Americans, who collect matchboxes. Or rather, they are collectors of Vesta cases, the Victorian prototype of the matchbox, which are known as match safes in the US.

In September the association is holding its annual meeting in London, the first time it has done so. There will be about 100 delegates. Ever alive to a good marketing opportunity, Christie's, South Kensington is holding a dedicated sale of Vesta cases.

Vesta cases grew out of the tradition of snuffboxes or enamel patch boxes, which became popular from the 18th-century onwards. Ornate enamel boxes were made by applying one or more layers of a vitreous substance, usually on a base of copper.

The Vesta box came in during the 19th-century after the discovery of the match. It was a great breakthrough because it obviated the need to keep a constant fire in the hearth to provide a flame.

Several countries lay claim to have invented the match, but the strongest case has been made for John Walker of Stockton-on-Tees in the UK. His experiments in 1826 led to the first friction match. Its tip was a composite of potassium chloride and sulphur antimony, which struck when placed between rough surfaces like sandpaper.

The matches were sold in batches of 100 for a shilling, with an extra two pence being for the tin box container. This was very important because these early matches could easily ignite accidentally if not stored carefully. They were also a health hazard to match workers, giving rise to the degeneration of facial and bone tissue.

To avoid Victorian gentlemen catching alight in the street, the safety match was developed. This involved the separation of chemicals between match head and the sandpaper used for striking.

But the attraction of having a decorative case in which to hold the matches remained and grew stronger throughout the late 19th-century and into the 20th-century. These early Vesta cases were at first relatively simple affairs. But as time went on, they became more sophisticated enamelled cases on a silver or sometimes gold base.

The highlights of the Christie's auction are a colourful scene depicting the Changing of the Guard outside Buckingham Palace gates. This is a silver Sampson Mordan and is estimated to fetch £800 to £1,200. A silver HMV Vesta case of Nipper the dog standing beside a gramophone is expected to realise £500 to £600. A third Vesta is shaped as a gun. The matches are placed in the barrel while the top also acts as a cigar cutter (estimated at £600 to £800).

But these are estimates; the point about Vestas is that they are becoming increasingly rare. Jeff Lovell, the specialist at Christie's, says: "We started stand-alone sales two years ago because some collections came our way. This sale, which has 144 lots, is the last of the collections plus other bits and pieces."

There are many different scenes on Vestas, from hunting pictures to sentry boxes to birds and country vistas. Prices start at £200, but they could reach thousands.

For more details: Christie's South Kensington, tel: 020-7581-7611

fields.headline: Passing her final test
fields.standfirst: Donna Symmonds finds that her work as a lawyer stands her in good stead as the world's first woman cricket commentator. Michael Edmands talked to her
fields.trailText: For many of us, the sound of Test Match Special on Radio 4 signals the beginning of summer, bringing memories of the Hampshire burr of John Arlott and the chocolate cakes and wit of Brian Johnston, alas no longer with us.
fields.body:
For many of us, the sound of Test Match Special on Radio 4 signals the beginning of summer, bringing memories of the Hampshire burr of John Arlott and the chocolate cakes and wit of Brian Johnston, alas no longer with us.

But what's this as we tune in for our daily fix? The sweet voice of a young woman, a Caribbean one at that. And she's good. Donna Symmonds, for it is she, is very good. Will the old fogies believe it? Only a year after the barriers on women becoming members of the MCC came down comes a breakthrough in the commentary box.

This feisty young lawyer from Barbados has made herself comfortable in a role she could scarcely have foreseen growing up in Bridgetown. Ms Symmonds went to an all-girls secondary school and was, she says, "sporty". She also admits she was lippy. "My nickname at school was Fidel. I was outspoken on any subject, in fact every thing." Her father Algernon, at one time a High Commissioner for Barbados in London, fostered a love of cricket in his daughter and did a bit of commentating himself.

Her aunt suggested she go to her alma mater, Reading University in England, to read science. Ms Symmonds says: "I hated everything about it. I didn't like the food, I didn't like the weather and I was terribly homesick - so I went home. I had wonderful parents and I travelled extensively. Hence, I've got an open mind."

Then came the turnaround. A friend at Reading told her: "You talk a lot. Why don't you try to become a lawyer?"

"In those years," she says, "I went to a lot of cricket and tennis matches, but I didn't neglect my studies. Cricket was in my blood. My father's friends included Sir Frank Worrel; Sir Gary Sobers and Clive Lloyd were regular visitors."

In l985 she was accepted to the bar at the Council of Legal Education, Chancery Lane, London. The daughter of a Bridgetown partner in a legal firm introduced Ms Symmonds to her father and she was taken into his chambers. Two years later she was ready to open her own firm and currently defends clients on a range of crimes.

Her big break into sports came almost by accident. Another childhood friend, Sharon Jones, who was a producer on the local sports station, needed a tennis commentator badly. At very short notice she turned to her friend Donna and begged her to help her out of a tight spot. "I was hesitant," Ms Symmonds admits, "But although tennis is the hardest commentary to do, the $100 she offered convinced me."

Her successful debut brought overtures from the Caribbean Broadcasting Corporation to persuade her to try her hand at cricket. "I had enjoyed myself, so I said 'why not?' I wound up doing Test cricket in the West Indies," she says. There was a mixed reaction from listeners. "Back in the West Indies," she says, "Some people were saying 'this can't be right' when they heard my voice. Some of them thought I was reading from cue cards. Only 20% of listeners supported me but that has now risen to 85-90%. It has moved from 'she doesn't know cricket' to 'okay she knows cricket but'..."

Then the Beeb came knocking. In 1998 the Test Match Special team was covering the Tests in the Caribbean. Jonathan Agnew and Vic Marks were sitting in on local radio between stints, got to know Donna and suggested she try out for Test Match Special (TMS).

She was hired by long-time TMS producer Peter Baxter. He didn't have to blow any trumpets because he recognized she was good and she had plenty of experience.

Her cricketing background is reflected in her impressive commentary style. She insists she is not a summariser. She doesn't struggle to interpret the intricacies of the game. She is calm, seeing parallels between standing up before a judge and talking into a microphone.

"In both instances you are forced to think on your feet. You try to maintain a lawyer's objectivity," she says. "With the new technology, I am able to combine both careers. I can juggle cricket, tennis and the law. Email allows me to be in constant and instant contact with my law office. I have now created a partnership back home that allows the best of both worlds."

So here's what you do. When the Test Match is on television next weekend, turn down the sound, put on the good old wireless and listen to the sounds of summer with a Bajan lilt.
