fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: • Bristol & West is going back to basics with its new flexible mortgage. This scraps drawdowns, chequebook links and cash machine card, leaving a simple deal which allows lump sum or regular overpayments as well as underpayments.
fields.body:
 Bristol & West is going back to basics with its new flexible mortgage. This scraps drawdowns, chequebook links and cash machine card, leaving a simple deal which allows lump sum or regular overpayments as well as underpayments.

The first six months have a 2.75% discount on the standard 7.74%.

 Portman Building Society is now offering its 14-day turnaround Rapid Remortgage facility across its entire range. There are no legal or valuation fees.

 UCB Home Loans, the Nationwide arm which specialises in non-status lending, has a new Buy2Let mortgage which does not require confirmation of income.

The tracker loan charges 1.99% above bank base rate, which is discounted by 1% in the first three years to give a 6.99% starting rate.

For more details telephone 0845 9501 500.

 Halifax has launched an online interactive household insurance service on its halifax.co.uk website featuring a no claims discount and a 5% discount on the bank's normal premium.

 Coca-Cola imbibers could win up to £25,000 in university fees and living expenses in a new online auction. The prize on cokeauction.co.uk will go to the family or organisation which bids the most ring pulls and labels from special drink packs.

 Credit is getting cheaper for trade union members. The TUC is launching its Members First card with Bank of Scotland next month. The interest rate is 15.9% for those who sometimes pay off their borrowings and 12.9% for those who never clear debts.

But only members of those unions which sign up with the TUC can apply.

 Online broker comdirect.co. uk has a new low cost Isa route for Footsie index fans. It is offering fee-free lump sum or savings scheme purchases of "iShares", the new stock exchange traded tracker funds. These pay tax free dividends in an Isa.

The only outgoings are the 0.35% annual iShare fee and comdirect's yearly £25 account charge. The exit charge is £14.50 for any sum over £5,000.

 Friendly society Tunbridge Wells has a new guide to childrens' savings which sets out both the advantages and the drawbacks of everything from Premium Bonds to investment trusts. There are even "against" points for its own tax free savings product. The guide, aimed especially at new parents, is free. Phone 0500 800830.

 Average life insurance premiums have been cut by 20% but policyholders are not being told, claims new internet site life4less.co.uk. It offers a £10 M &S voucher if it cannot improve on a quote.

webTitle: Group sex husband guilty of blackmail

fields.headline: Group sex husband guilty of blackmail
fields.standfirst: Butcher faces jail over video threat to estranged wife
fields.trailText: When her marriage ended, Samantha Stone destroyed her copy of a video of her enjoying group sex. Her estranged husband kept his copy, and yesterday Julian St Quinton, 33, a butcher from Easington, East Yorkshire, was found guilty of blackmail with menaces.
fields.body:
When her marriage ended, Samantha Stone destroyed her copy of a video of her enjoying group sex. Her estranged husband kept his copy, and yesterday Julian St Quinton, 33, a butcher from Easington, East Yorkshire, was found guilty of blackmail with menaces.

Details of the couple's sex life unfolded at Hull crown court. They had enjoyed group sex on at least eight occasions with a couple met through a contact magazine. Once, they were joined by another man. She also posed with a woman for pictures that her husband sent to the readers' wives section of Escort magazine.

After the verdict, Judge Tom Cracknell said blackmail usually meant jail; he adjourned sentence to a later date.

St Quinton denied the charge and told the court that he kept the video, a seven-hour compilation, to remind him of "an enjoyable time in his life", but the jurors found he had used it to make Ms Stone, 26, give up her claim to half of their £100,000 home.

In an acrimonious divorce, he threatened to send the tape to her parents, Linda and Trevor Stone, and to the colleagues of her father, millionaire owner of a timber firm.

At one point in the five-day trial St Quinton alleged Linda Stone had been keen on him and had performed a sex act on him in her kitchen - a claim that her daughter dismissed.

Ms Stone, a secretary from Roos near Hull, said her husband phoned her threatening to release the video. She went to police after an anonymous call from a woman who said: "Get your solicitors to back off. I know what he's got. I have seen the video."

She wept as she told the court she now viewed the group sex with revulsion, although at the time she had agreed; when she drank a lot of alcohol, she lost her inhibitions. "He never held a gun to my head. I knew what I was doing. I did it to keep him happy. I craved love from him, but he didn't show me any."

They had met when she was 16. Within two years of getting married in 1993 he suggested they have group sex, which he often filmed. They separated in 1997, and she later moved in with another man.

St Quinton admitted showing the video to two girlfriends and to his brothers, but his defence lawyer described him as a fool and braggart who had showed off the video only to regain a status he thought he had lost when his wife left him. He was visibly shaken at the jury's verdict.

In a statement outside court, Mr and Mrs Stone said they were delighted with the verdict: "Our love for each other has never been stronger, and we utterly refute [sic] Julian St Quinton's allegations."

Residents of Easington, a hamlet with three pubs and a 12th century church, were shocked to hear what had been going on. One said: "It's difficult to believe. That said, we're out on a limb here and there's not much to do, so perhaps that explains it."

webTitle: Rights for babies on fatherless status

fields.headline: Rights for babies on fatherless status
fields.trailText: New rights are to be given to babies conceived after their father's death to prevent a repeat of the Diane Blood case.
fields.body:
New rights are to be given to babies conceived after their father's death to prevent a repeat of the Diane Blood case.

Mrs Blood had to go abroad to obtain fertility treatment using her dead husband Stephen's sperm. In 1998 she gave birth to a son, Liam, but was unable to register her husband's name on the birth certificate because he was not alive at the time of conception.

The 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act states that when a child is conceived posthumously it is legally fatherless and should be registered as such. But after the birth of Liam Blood, a government review was set up headed by Sheila McLean, professor of law and ethics in medicine at Glasgow University, to examine the issue of posthumous conceptions.

Mrs Blood, from Worksop, Nottinghamshire, said yesterday that she was pleased by the government's proposals to change the act. "It is very important for these children and their mothers because it means that the biological facts will be recorded as they truly are," she said. "Until now mothers have effectively had to lie when asked whether they knew the father of their child."

If the proposals become law, Mrs Blood will now be allowed retroactive permission to re-register her son's birth and put her husband's name on the birth certificate.

But she was disappointed that the government had refused to make legal the use of sperm or eggs taken from a spouse without their consent.

Mrs Blood was unable to seek consent to remove sperm from her husband Stephen in 1994 because he was in a coma after becoming ill with meningitis.

After a long legal battle, she convinced the appeal court that she should be allowed to receive fertility treatment in Belgium using her husband's sperm.

The number of posthumous conceptions has increased in Britain in recent years, putting pressure on ministers to change the law or offer more guidance. At least six such babies were born last year.

However, the government has refused to extend inheritance or succession rights to the children and will insist that the father's name is followed by the word deceased.

Marian Jordan, from Stourbridge, West Midlands, has been campaigning to register her late husband as the father of her son Daniel ever since the child's birth last October. Her husband, David, was diagnosed with cancer three years ago and some of his sperm was frozen before he died.

She said it was one of the last things she could do for her husband to have his name on his son's birth certificate.

Announcing the changes, Yvette Cooper, the minister for public health, said: "These proposals will build on an existing law to form a sensible and balanced framework governing what will always be difficult and emotional circumstances. The government rarely proposes that legislation should be retrospective, but in the unusual case where families are unable to put the father's name on the birth certificate where his sperm has been used after death, this is exactly the right thing to do. These children should have the right to have their father's name registered on their birth certificate."

The government will leave unchanged the common law provisions which require a person's consent before his or her gametes (sperm or eggs) are removed, under most circumstances. When a person is incapacitated and unable to give their consent but they are likely to recover and their fertility is likely to be affected, then gametes may be removed in their best interests.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Migrants saved in Channel
fields.body:
Migrants saved in Channel

Five men suspected of trying to enter Britain illegally in a rubber dinghy were rescued by a tug yesterday in the English Channel. The men, believed to be East European, were spotted in the mid-Channel shipping lane - the busiest commercial route in the world - by a ferry, a coastguard officer said. The five were taken to Dover.

M&S made to cover up

Marks & Spencer has been forced to replace the blouses in its new staff uniform for female staff after failing to notice they were see-through. The uniform was being introduced to go with the store chain's image revamp, after the previous navy and green shirts were deemed too frumpy.

Computer bugs' £1 trillion bite

Computer viruses such as the love bug have cost businesses worldwide 40,000 years in lost productivity since the beginning of the year alone, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers report for US magazine Information Week. The survey across 30 countries claims the cost so far this year has reached more than £1 trillion.

Cyclist's full stop at lights

Law abiding cyclist Colin Masters, 16, waited at red traffic lights for almost 40 minutes when they refused to turn green as he rode home from Northampton town centre. "It was lucky I was not going to get my exam results, I think the tension would have been too much to bear," he said.

webTitle: UDA buries second loyalist feud victim

fields.headline: UDA buries second loyalist feud victim
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A leading loyalist shot dead in the feud between rival gangs in Belfast was given a full paramilitary funeral yesterday, with more than 1,000 members of the Ulster Defence Association and Ulster Freedom Fighters following his flag- draped coffin through the Shankill area of the city.
fields.body:
A leading loyalist shot dead in the feud between rival gangs in Belfast was given a full paramilitary funeral yesterday, with more than 1,000 members of the Ulster Defence Association and Ulster Freedom Fighters following his flag- draped coffin through the Shankill area of the city.

Jackie Coulter, a prominent member of the UDA and close associate of the convicted terrorist Johnny Adair, was shot in the head as he sat in a Land Rover Discovery by a lone gunman from the rival Ulster Volunteer Force on Monday.

His was the second funeral in north Belfast in two days: Bobby Mahood, who was killed in the same attack as Coulter, was buried yesterday, while Sam Rocket, 22, a man with links to the UVF who was shot dead in retaliation on Wednesday night, will be laid to rest today.

Coulter's wife Agnes, son Jackie and daughters Tracey, Natalie and Amy walked behind the coffin as it made its way to the spot outside a bookmakers on the Crumlin Road where the UDA man was killed. Weeping, they embraced the coffin before standing beside a tree adorned with bouquets of flowers to watch the massed ranks of the six battalions of the UDA-UFF march past.

A green flatbed truck bedecked with flowers, its number plates covered with masking tape, led the cortege, while two teenagers in white shirts and black ties carried red and black UFF and red, white and blue UDA floral tributes beside the coffin.

The police were out in force, as they have been every day since the bloody feud between the loyalist factions began. Grey RUC Land Rovers sat at every street corner while an army helicopter and spotter plane buzzed overhead.

When the cortege turned into Northumberland Street the coffin was put into a hearse and driven down the Shankill Road and across the city to Roselawn Cemetery where Coulter was buried.

Earlier, at a 20-minute service inside Coulter's detached house relayed to the crowd outside by loudspeaker, Pastor Tom Gamble of the Belfast city mission led the tributes to the UDA man. "The sun is shining outside but our hearts are sad and their darkness within; it seems to be all around us," he said. "But we will rise above this day and soon the dark clouds will disappear and soon the light will be around us. At this moment there are no smiles but soon there will be again."

The different loyalist battalions, dressed almost to a man in dark suits, white shirts and black ties, filled the street outside, as marshals with black arm bands and walkie-talkies kept photographers well back.

Among the mourners was John White, spokesman for the Ulster Democratic party, the political wing of the UDA-UFF. Also present was Gina Adair, the wife of the UFF leader who was returned to prison on Tuesday night for breaching the terms of the licence that allowed him early release from prison.

Celine Dion's The Power of Love and A Million Love Songs by Take That blasted out of the loudspeakers before the service, which ended with the playing of Joe Cocker and Jennifer Warnes' Up Where We Belong. After a delay while one of the grieving family received medical attention, the coffin was carried from the house while a lone bugler played the Last Post.

Tensions remain high, with fears of more bloodletting over the weekend. Neither side appears to be any closer to agreeing to mediation in the feud.

fields.headline: Saddam building missiles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: The German intelligence service took the highly unusual step yesterday of confirming a report that it had found a secret missile-production facility in Iraq.
fields.body:
The German intelligence service took the highly unusual step yesterday of confirming a report that it had found a secret missile-production facility in Iraq.

The tabloid daily, Bild Zeitung, had placed the plant 25 miles south-west of Baghdad in the "al-Mamoun" factory.

The report was the latest of several based on western intelligence assessments suggesting that the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, has rebuilt his missile-production capability far more swiftly than expected. After British and American war planes struck at 12 military factories in 1998, the allies claimed to have set back Iraq's missile programme by several years.

But last month the New York Times reported that Baghdad had resumed building and flight-testing ballistic missiles. American officials said US spy satellites and aircraft monitoring the "no-fly" zones over northern and southern Iraq had detected seven test flights in the 12 months to the end of June.

Iraq described the article as an attempt to divert attention from the issue of sanctions imposed after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait. But it did not deny the report.

Bild said that about 250 technicians were working at the al-Mamoun plant, producing a solid-fuel, short-range weapon called the Ababil-100. A spokeswoman for the Bundesnachrichtendienst, the German federal intelligence service, said: "We can confirm that the report is substantially correct."

The paper said the Ababil-100 had a range of less than 150 kilometres (about 90 miles), and thus did not breach UN restrictions imposed on Iraq after the Gulf war in 1991. Iraq is known to be keen to enhance its air-defence systems to strike at British and US pilots enforcing the UN's no-fly zones.

But German and other western security experts have expressed concern that building and testing short-range missiles could herald a move towards establishing a longer-range capability.

Bild also reported that Germany's secret service had unearthed evidence that President Saddam's scientists were working on plans for weapons that could travel up to 3,000 kilometres (1,865 miles), which would allow Baghdad to hit targets in western Europe.

Anthony Zinni, the US commander in the Gulf, sounded a similar warning last month, when he told the New York Times that short-range missile technology was "transferable to longer-range missiles".

webTitle: Mugabe adds 509 farms to seizure list

fields.headline: Mugabe adds 509 farms to seizure list
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government designated another 509 mostly white-owned farms for seizure yesterday as part of its fast track programme to redistribute land to poor black farmers.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government designated another 509 mostly white-owned farms for seizure yesterday as part of its fast track programme to redistribute land to poor black farmers.

Its plan to take over up to 65% of the country's commercial farms before the rainy season begins in November is likely to damage the already battered economy.

So far about 1,500 farms have been earmarked for confiscation. In the next few weeks the government is expected to designate a total of 3,000 farms. More than 200 have already been seized under the land acquisition law enacted by decree earlier this year.

President Robert Mugabe's cash-strapped government does not have the funds to redevelop properties for small-scale farming, so thousands of black families will be dropped on the land and left to cultivate it as best they can.

The accelerated resettlement programme has also been criticised because of the politically partisan way in which it is being carried out. Officials of the government party, Zanu-PF, have chosen the farms to be seized and are allocating them on the basis of loyalty to the party. Many have been won by picking lots out of a hat.

Agriculture now in disarray, for the commercial banks have refused to lend to white farmers because of the unrest. This will halt most agricultural production before the evictions actually take place.

"Some of our most productive farms, that are the envy of the rest of Africa, will become peasant plots farmed on a subsistence basis," John Robertson, a Harare economist, said.

At least 1,000 Zimbabwean white farmers have inquired about migration to Zambia but financial problems are ruling out a mass exodus: only 40 have gone since April. Uganda and Mozambique have also invited Zimbabwean farmers to migrate.

webTitle: Megawati takes the reins in Indonesia

fields.headline: Megawati takes the reins in Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, announced yesterday the long awaited transfer of many duties to his deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri, as part of a drive to improve his administration's much maligned image and performance.
fields.body:
The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, announced yesterday the long awaited transfer of many duties to his deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri, as part of a drive to improve his administration's much maligned image and performance.

Ms Megawati's acceptance of the additional responsibilities quashed mounting speculation that she had fallen out with Mr Wahid and was about to resign. But analysts and the financial markets remain sceptical about how effective she and a new, slimmed-down, cabinet will be in solving Indonesia's deepening social and economic crises.

In a decree signed on Wednesday but made pubic only yesterday, Mr Wahid, 60, gave Ms Megawati, 54, authority to set cabinet agendas and chair the weekly meetings, review ministers' performance and appoint senior bureaucrats, police and military officers. She will also liaise between government agencies and take charge of disseminating policy to the public.

"In order to increase the effectiveness of the government, it is necessary to task the vice-president to help the president in his duty, especially in technical day-to-day [matters]," said the decree, which runs until the end of Mr Wahid's term in 2004.

Mr Wahid, who is almost blind, has had two strokes and has diabetes, decided to transfer duties to Ms Megawati after his handling of the government since taking office last October was roundly criticised by a special parliamentary session earlier this month.

He has said that he will now concentrate on foreign policy, national unity and humanitarian affairs.

The decree left many questions unanswered because much of it was vague. Furthermore all major decisions will still require Mr Wahid's approval as he did not cede any formal power to his deputy.

Ms Megawati is expected to work closely with the two coordinating ministers for politics and the economy that Mr Wahid appointed to the cabinet, which was cut from 35 ministers to 26.

The new team is being dubbed All the President's Men because Indonesia's two largest political parties, Ms Megawati's Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP) and the former ruling Golkar party, have surprisingly been virtually excluded.

Ms Megawati was so angry at the PDIP not being given any key portfolios that she boycotted the announcement of the new team.

Sutjipto, deputy head of PDIP, which has a near fanatical following among much of Indonesia's masses, said Ms Megawati then seriously considered quitting before deciding that "the desolation of this republic will be unimaginable if I resigned".

News of that decision buoyed Jakarta's bearish financial markets but no one is expecting a significant rally in the coming weeks until Ms Megawati, who has no formal managerial experience, and the cabinet prove themselves.

For the past three days, Indonesia's outspoken legislators and media have largely rubbished the new team, saying that the ministers are unlikely to prove any better than their predecessors.

Criticism has focused on the facts that many ministers have retained jobs when wholesale change was expected and that several of the newcomers are considered unworthy of being ministers.

Singled out is the new finance minister, Prijadi Praptosuhardjo, a banker and close confidant of Mr Wahid who recently failed a "fit-and-proper" test when the president nominated him to be chairman of one of the country's largest state banks.

webTitle: Young Russian to head Glyndebourne opera

fields.headline: New baton
fields.standfirst: Young Russian to head Glyndebourne opera
fields.trailText: A 28-year-old Russian wunderkind has been chosen as musical director of Glyndebourne opera.
fields.body:
A 28-year-old Russian wunderkind has been chosen as musical director of Glyndebourne opera.

Conductor Vladimir Jurowski will take over from Andrew Davis next January, and possibly make the opera house in the Sussex countryside once again a platform for contemporary composers.

Though Jurowski caused a stir in Edinburgh last year with a new production of Hansel and Gretel by the Welsh National Opera, the choice surprised observers. It had been expected that Glyndebourne, run by Gus Christie, son of Sir George who rebuilt the house four years ago, would look to more experienced hands. Glyndebourne's reputation has never been as high, gathering acclaim with a mix of revivals from the classic repertoire and daring commissions, particularly those from young people.

Nicholas Snowman, the opera house's general director, said he had had his eye on Jurowski, son of the celebrated conductor Michail Jurowski, since he took over almost two years ago.

"When I first saw him in Hansel and Gretel I was really impressed. And then I saw him do the Golden Cockerel at Covent Garden. I began to think very seriously about him indeed."

Jurowski will make his debut in two years' time conducting Britten's Albert Herring, in a revival of Sir Peter Paul's famous 1985 production. Jurowski was appointed chief conductor of the Sibelius orchestra in Berlin at 21, before making his mark as the kapellmeister at the Komische Oper in the city.

webTitle: Welsh Tories balk at clerk's salary

fields.headline: Welsh Tories balk at clerk's salary
fields.trailText: The job does not have a high profile. Nor is it one that normally excites much interest or controversy. But attempts to fill the soon-to-be-vacant post of clerk to the Welsh national assembly have drawn barbed criticism.
fields.body:
The job does not have a high profile. Nor is it one that normally excites much interest or controversy. But attempts to fill the soon-to-be-vacant post of clerk to the Welsh national assembly have drawn barbed criticism.

It is not so much the decision to find a replacement for senior civil servant John Lloyd that has upset the critics as the disclosure that whoever fills the role will pocket a six-figure sum for doing so.

Applicants for what is being described as "a unique UK civil service appointment" are being tempted with a salary of up to £127,000 - considerably more than the £69,000 that goes to members of the assembly cabinet and opposition party leaders in Cardiff Bay.

Officially, the post is being advertised at "circa £100,000" - only slightly less than the salary to which first secretary Rhodri Morgan is entitled. One Conservative assembly member said the salary being offered was "obscene".

As clerk, the successful candidate will be directly responsible to the assembly's presiding officer, Dafydd Elis-Thomas, for the provision of a wide range of independent services, including the assembly's library, information and translation services.

Bilingual advertisements published in Welsh newspapers this week have emphasised that whoever fills the post will need to have integrity as well as top drawer personal, negotiating and persuading skills.

Other qualifications required include direct experience of parliamentary processes, a thorough understanding of constitutional matters, high sensitivity to political issues, and the ability to provide leadership to a complex organisation "working within an environment of constant change".

Assembly officials are perplexed that attempts to find such a paragon to replace Mr Lloyd on his retirement should have caused surprise, citing the clerk's responsibility for a £20m budget and a staff of 200.

"It is not as if he will be doing the filing and making the tea," said an assembly spokesman yesterday.

"Basically the clerk runs the show."

But the Conservatives remain unimpressed by such arguments. Nigel Evans, the party's spokesman for Wales, claimed that teachers, farmers and nurses would be dumbfounded by the amount on offer.

David Davies, Conservative whip in the assembly, was more forthright. "It's obscene. I can't understand how they can justify that sort of salary for what he does. It's just like the cost of the new building and the cost of translators. Everything connected with the Welsh assembly costs lots of money and delivers little or nothing."

Former Welsh Office minister, Rod Richards, anxious to escape the assembly and rebuild his political career by finding a safe Westminster seat in England, was a little less scathing.

"It's cost neutral," he insisted. "This is not a new page in wasting government money because it is already happening."

webTitle: Millions head out for music festival season

fields.headline: Britons tune up for a bank holiday party
fields.trailText: Britain was preparing itself for the grand finale to the outdoor music festival season this bank holiday weekend as millions of people headed for concert venues across the country to dance away the final days of their summer break.
fields.body:
Britain was preparing itself for the grand finale to the outdoor music festival season this bank holiday weekend as millions of people headed for concert venues across the country to dance away the final days of their summer break.

The AA yesterday estimated some 15m car journeys would be made over the long weekend as music fans make for the Notting Hill carnival in west London, the Reading festival in Berkshire, Creamfields dance music event near Liverpool, and the Chelmsford Spectacular in Essex.

Tomorrow and on Monday, 1m people a day are expected to squeeze on to the three-mile Notting Hill carnival route that snakes around the streets of the west London district. Steel and soca bands will provide the musical accompaniment as 40,000 masqueraders parade through the biggest street party in Europe.

Radio 1 rap DJ Tim Westwood, who missed out on last year's carnival after he was shot in a drive-by shooting in south London, will be making a comeback.

The run-up to this year's carnival has not been entirely free from racism.

The Metropolitan police said it was investigating a series of menacing letters sent to organisers.

A spokesman said: "The community safety unit at Notting Hill is investigating a number of malicious communications sent to various addresses in the London area regarding the Notting Hill carnival."

He added that there would be no change in policing tactics and there would be just 8,000 officers at the event.

A spokeswoman for the carnival said: "We have got quite a lot of malicious mail over the years and we always treat it seriously. The latest letter arrived a couple of weeks ago and we handed it straight to the police."

However, the carnival will see its first police-sponsored float, featuring around 120 dancers and two 7ft cutout meercats which will be highlighting the Met's neighbourhood watch schemes.

Meanwhile, the meteorological office recommended that those at Reading rock festival should brace themselves for a downpour today.

"It will be rather cloudy with heavy showers or thundery storms across much of Britain on Saturday," a spokesman said. "But Sunday and Monday should be fine and dry with increasing amounts of sunshine and only a 10% chance of showers."

But yesterday afternoon 70,000 rock fans had already pitched their tents and were enjoying temperatures of 27°C.

The rock festival is being held in tandem with a twin event in Leedsay at Leeds over the weekend.

Around 40,000 people are also expected at Liverpool's old airfield today for the Creamfields dance music festival.

In Chelmsford, the three-day Spectacular 2000 festival begins with pop band Steps as tonight's headline act in Hylands Park.

Tomorrow evening the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra will give a proms concert in the park, and Monday will be a 1960s and 1970s nostalgia evening.

Further north, comedian Billy Connolly will today be hosting a highland games event at his Candacraig estate in Aberdeenshire. American comedian Robin Williams is expected to be among the celebrity guests.

fields.headline: Out of the shadows
fields.standfirst: Nigeria gets Clinton's blessing
fields.trailText: President Clinton's visit to Nigeria today is a sign of how far the country has travelled in the last two years.
fields.body:
President Clinton's visit to Nigeria today is a sign of how far the country has travelled in the last two years. When Mr Clinton toured Africa in 1998, he avoided Nigeria because it was still under the kind of military leadership that had destabilised the country over the previous three decades. Since 1998, the country has moved from a military government to democracy under president Olusegun Obasanjo, initially a military leader but elected as a civilian leader last year. There is much still amiss in Nigeria, with high levels of corruption and notoriety as a regional centre for drug trafficking. The return of democracy too has been turbulent, with parliamentarians regularly criticising Mr Obasanjo over lack of vigour in fighting corruption. But it is a sign of the growing strength of democracy within Nigeria that its parliamentarians can feel free enough to engage the leadership in such a way.

The main importance of the new Nigeria for Mr Clinton is regional security. Mr Obasanjo is spending much time abroad: too much, say some of his critics, who would like to see him concentrate on the many domestic problems, such as the spiralling religious tensions in the north. But he has succeeded in making Nigeria the main regional power in central Africa, playing a role as a peace-keeper in the civil wars in Sierra Leone and the Congo and as an intermediary with Liberia's meddlesome president, Charles Taylor. Mr Obasanjo was praised by the British government yesterday for his efforts in trying to secure the release of the Channel Four crew held in Liberia.

His influence is being felt further afield. He has emerged as one of the leaders of the developing world. He was in London this week helping to reshape the Group of 77. This organisation has grown to represent 133 developing countries, from an unwieldy, amorphous body into a streamlined body that will demand attention at the international forums dominated by the industrialised West. Its main targets are the World Trade Organisation and the IMF.

Mr Obasanjo is well on the way to providing the kind of role which we became used to Nelson Mandela playing in Africa. While nowhere near having the moral authority of Mr Mandela, he has lifted Nigeria from being one of the pariah states of the world to a regional power and one of the leading lights of the developing world. It is in recognition of this leap that Mr Clinton is in Nigeria today.

fields.headline: Battle for survival
fields.standfirst: Pillboxes to get legal protection
fields.trailText: Pillboxes, once the first line of defence against invasion but now the site for adolescent trysts, are to be given statutory protection.
fields.body:
Pillboxes, once the first line of defence against invasion but now the site for adolescent trysts, are to be given statutory protection.

Sixty years after the Battle of Britain, intended as the prelude to a German invasion, a review by English Heritage of the distinctive concrete fortifications dotted along the English coastline and of other wartime remains has recommended a representative number for listing and scheduling.

The review embraced installations as diverse as anti-aircraft emplacements, coastal batteries, anti-tank obstacles, airfields, temporary camps, and bombing decoys. "These are the only material remains of the greatest historical event of the 20th century, the second world war," said John Schofield, head of the review.

"There is growing public concern at the vulnerability of wartime remains, often temporary in fabric, potent in their associations, and today widely neglected."

Many had been lost to coast erosion, development and quarrying. "Less than 50% have survived and the great majority of what remains is in a poor state. There are perhaps 2,000 pillboxes that are well-preserved with interior fixtures and fittings intact."

The six-year project enlisted 500 volunteers to survey sites, submit plans and maps, and collect evidence from those who built and manned them. English Heritage will collate this and submit a case for statutory protection.

fields.headline: Land of the rising sushi
fields.standfirst: Meet the new threat to cheese sandwiches
fields.trailText: Britain's eight-year-olds can tell you all about it: a sudden craze, originating in Japan, which comes complete with a mysterious terminology. The country's primary schools are full of talk of elusive poliwrath and scyther Pokemon cards, but an older generation has become obsessed with sushi.
fields.body:
Britain's eight-year-olds can tell you all about it: a sudden craze, originating in Japan, which comes complete with a mysterious terminology. The country's primary schools are full of talk of elusive poliwrath and scyther Pokemon cards, but an older generation has become obsessed with sushi. Or so say the supermarkets, keen to get us to swap easy-to-afford egg and cress rolls for pricey boxes of tekka maki and tuna nigiri. Sainsbury's, which already sells more sushi than cheese sandwiches, opened a new front in the lunchtime war yesterday when it unveiled an automated sushi bar at a store in west London. Rivals Tesco say they sell £7m-worth a year. And do not dismiss this as another soft southern fad - Sainsbury's Tottenham Court Road store sells more of the rice rolls than any other, but its nearest rival is in Glasgow.

So what's the attraction? It can hardly be fashion: Hoxton's trendy types have long since moved on to raw juice and soup, while sushi has become so main stream it is on sale in the Millennium Dome. Expect William Hague to appeal soon to Middle England by claiming to have eaten 14 salmon nigiri a day in his youth. Sushi makes a handy deskside snack, but hardly packs the punch of the old-style pub lunch. A typical helping contains around 1,400 kilojoules, half that of a coronation chicken sandwich. Maybe that's the appeal to a diet-conscious nation, together with the fact that, whether the filling is vegetarian or fishy, it all tastes much the same. Added to this is the pleasant, communal way in which sushi can be eaten. "The family that rolls sushi together stays together," runs an old Japanese saying, making it the first fast food to support family values.

Can the fad last? Supermarkets have plans to move us on to bento boxes and sashimi salads, while Americans are being introduced to frozen ongiri rice balls which can be warmed in a microwave. It may happen here too, but for now we are in the golden age of the sushi baron.

fields.headline: 100,000 homeless as rains flood India
fields.trailText: Hyderabad had no answer when the savage monsoon rained down. A family of 30 climbed to a rooftop and prayed for hours for rescue. Air force helicopters tried to drop food parcels but they missed their targets and the aid was washed away.
fields.body:
Hyderabad had no answer when the savage monsoon rained down. A family of 30 climbed to a rooftop and prayed for hours for rescue. Air force helicopters tried to drop food parcels but they missed their targets and the aid was washed away.

The Musi river, which divides the old town from the new, flooded its banks and ran like an open sewer through the city's narrow streets.

In the past four days more than 125 people have died in Hyderabad and across the rest of Andhra Pradesh state; 100,000 are now homeless.

"Children were crying for food. It shows how frightening the situation is," the state's chief minister, Chandrababu Naidu, said.

"The depression formed very suddenly and we were not warned about the amount of rainfall it was going to bring. Even if we had got the correct information, it would not be possible for anybody to face this sort of a situation on a notice of a few hours."

Six people were killed in the city when a building collapsed, another girl died when she was struck by lightning.

Many more are missing in the worst floods for 40 years, and more rain is forecast for the next few days.

Some were luckier: three Indian Air Force helicopters managed to rescue 150 people stranded on rooftops.

"Several people have no access to safe drinking water. The danger of diseases spreading will increase as we begin the difficult job of clearing livestock carcasses and debris," Mr Naidu said.

Elsewhere in Andhra Pradesh heavy rain brought down electricity and telephone lines and blocked the main road from Madras to Calcutta.

In the town of Nandyal, about 120 miles south of Hyderabad, one of the worst hit areas, helicopters rescued 53 people from the roof of a bus which had been swept into a river, and one plucked 15 others from a tree.

Less than three months ago millions of Indians were suffering from one of the worst droughts in the country's history: fields turned to dust, wells ran dry and villagers prayed for rain.

Now the rains have come and brought more suffering. Half a year's average rainfall poured down on Hyderabad in one day this week.

Since the monsoon began in June, sweeping south from Assam in the north-east, more than 400 have died and 5m have been affected in India. More have suffered in Bangladesh, Bhutan and Nepal.

With the rain has come disease. In Assam, which ranks as one of the world's wettest regions, at least 38 people, many sheltering in refugee camps, have died in the past fortnight from gastroenteritis. Stagnant pools of flood water are quickly breeding mosquitoes, which carry malaria.

Farmers had just planted their rice seedlings, but now more than 200,000 hectares (495,000 acres) of crops have been damaged. Many people have complained of the slow pace of medical aid and are struggling to find clean drinking water.

The price of firewood, needed to boil water clean, has soared in local shops. Some are using improvised filters of sand and rocks.

"For the past three weeks no government doctors have visited us and we are left to survive on our own. Many people in my village are suffering from high fever and dysentery," said Binoy Chandra Rabha, a villager in Chayyagaon, close to Guwahati, 70 miles south of the border with Bhutan.

The International Federation of the Red Cross has appealed for $3.5m (£2.4m) to help India's flood victims. "There are certain things that can be done," its local spokesman, Patrick Fuller, said.

"But it is very hard to hold back the elements."

fields.headline: Abulfaz Elchibey
fields.standfirst: Azerbaijani independence leader undermined by clan rivalries and ethnic strife
fields.trailText: Abulfaz Elchibey, who has died of prostate cancer in Ankara at the age of 62, led the first movement for democratic reform and independence in Soviet Azerbaijan. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, he became the newly independent country's president.
fields.body:
Abulfaz Elchibey, who has died of prostate cancer in Ankara at the age of 62, led the first movement for democratic reform and independence in Soviet Azerbaijan. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, he became the newly independent country's president.

An Arab philologist by training and a university professor, he was part of the generation of former dissidents who rose to supreme power in all three Caucasian republics, Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan. But he lacked the skills and contacts to maintain his grip when the old authoritarian nomenklatura worked their way back.

Elchibey was head of the Azerbaijani Popular Front when, in an almost forgotten episode, Mikhail Gorbachev launched what turned out to be the bloodiest action of his six years in the Kremlin. In January 1990, the Popular Front mounted a series of mass street protests against the ruling Azerbaijani Communist party. With barricades springing up all over Baku, the Kremlin sent in tanks to crush a rebellion, leaving more than 130 people dead.

A much smaller action by pro-Soviet hardliners against nationalists in Lithuania a year later - not supported by Gorbachev - received more sympathy and publicity in the west. Partly it was because the Baltic republics were European. But the lack of interest was also prompted by the fact that, a week before the Soviet tanks were sent into Baku, scores of Armenians in the city were murdered in a pogrom of killing, looting, and burning. Thousands fled to Armenia in terror.

The KGB was rumoured to have been behind the murders, but, in the chaos of the time, no investigation was possible. Thousands of Azerbaijani refugees from the disputed territory of Nagorno- Karabkah had recently settled in shacks on the outskirts of Baku, and it was easy to fan hatred and revenge. Whoever lit the match, it was the Popular Front's foreign image that suffered from the killings of Armenians, and the crackdown aroused no international protest.

When the republic held its first presidential elections, a month after proclaiming independence in August 1991, Elchibey came second to a pro-Communist doctor, Ayaz Mutalibov. Nine months later, the Popular Front made a new stab at power, and, after armed clashes in the streets of Baku, Mutalibov fled the presidential palace. Elchibey was elected president in June 1992.

The republic's unexpected independence set off a struggle among local elites for control of its rich oil resources. Old regional and clan rivalries re-emerged. A further cause of tension was the proxy war with Armenia over Nagorno-Karabakh. Armed by the powerful diaspora, Armenian forces gradually seized control and drove out the rest of the Azeri population, in an ethnic conflict that left 15,000 dead. Azerbaijan's defeat opened the way for new challenges to Elchibey. He found himself unable to motivate the security forces' support when Surat Huseinov, a millionaire businessman from Azerbaijan's second city of Gyandzha, marched on the capital.

Elchibey fled to his native region of Nakichevan, calling on the old Brezhnev-era communist boss, Geidar Aliyev, to take over temporarily in his stead. This was political suicide; Aliyev bought Huseinov off with the offer of the prime ministership and organised new elections - which he easily won. The move was justified as preventing civil war.

Elchibey remained in internal exile. He was allowed back to Baku in 1997, and, as chairman of the new movement for electoral reform, was regaining some popularity when he was taken ill. A secular moderniser and advocate of reviving Azerbaijan's links with Turkey, during his time as president he had changed the alphabet from Cyrillic and obtained the closure of all Russian bases.

Born at Keleki, in Nakichevan, he studied Arabic and became a university teacher. He was arrested in January 1975 as an Azeri nationalist, and served 18 months in a labour camp. On release, he worked for the Azerbaijani Academy of Sciences before founding the Popular Front in 1989.

He leaves a wife and two children.

 Abulfaz Elchibey, politician, born June 7 1938; died August 22 2000

fields.headline: William Maxwell and Emily Maxwell
fields.standfirst: He was a brilliant editor and writer, she a talented painter; within their ambiance, creativity flowered
fields.trailText: The American writer and editor, William Maxwell, and his wife, the painter Emily Maxwell, have died within eight days of each other. They had been married for 55 years.
fields.body:
The American writer and editor, William Maxwell, and his wife, the painter Emily Maxwell, have died within eight days of each other. They had been married for 55 years.

William Maxwell, who was 91, died of old age and that unfashionable ailment, a broken heart, and was undoubtedly more widely known than his wife, who was 78. The author of seven novels (one of which, So Long, See You Tomorrow, won the American National Book Award), three short-story collections, a memoir, a collection of essays and a book of fables, he was, for 40 years, fiction editor at the New Yorker magazine. In addition to editing some of the most famous writers of the late-20th century, he generously spent many hours with young, unpublished hopefuls.

Bill was born in Lincoln, Illinois; his mother died when he was 10 - of influenza in the 1918 epidemic, an event that coloured much of his writing. He graduated from the University of Illinois, earned an MA from Harvard, and returned to Illinois to teach. But he always wanted to write and, with a $200 advance for his second novel, moved to New York.

He got a small job in the art department of the New Yorker, while also acting as temporary poetry editor. When the latter post became available, Emily applied for it, and was interviewed by Bill.

Born in Portland, Oregon, Emily loved the outdoors, and spent much of her childhood riding, walking and camping with her two brothers in the Oregon hills. She chose to go to Smith College, intending to study art, but when she found the course emphasis was on art history, she turned to her second love and majored in English, writing poetry throughout her college career. She had a highly developed critical sense and, for nine years, wrote the annual year-end review of childrens' books for the New Yorker.

But painting was her particular gift and, by 1986, she had won the medal of honor of the American Women Artists. She wrote about her work: "Some day, I'd like to go back to abstraction, but, at present, objects speak to me so provocatively I feel the need to paint what I see." Her work appeared in one-woman and group exhibitions both in New York and out of town.

Even so, Emily chose to put the nurturing of Bill's talent ahead of her own, and did so by creating an ambiance in which his could flourish. He was aware of what she did for him, and often said, not only that Emily was his best editor, but also that, without her, he would not have had a writing life.

Although Bill was a writer of extraordinary sensitivity and insight, for many years his fame as fiction editor at the New Yorker seemed to overshadow his own creative reputation. Because his authors were so famous - they included John Cheever, Maeve Brennan, John Updike and Eudora Welty - critics tended to forget that he, too, was a writer.

More often than not, he became a friend, as well as an editor. There is a good record of this evolving relationship in The Happiness Of Getting It Down Right: Letters Of Frank O'Connor And William Maxwell. Sylvia Townsend Warner, many of whose stories appeared in the New Yorker, also became a close friend, and The Letters Of Sylvia Townsend Warner (1982) were edited, with a long and warm introduction, by William Maxwell. Fortunately, critical consensus is now in agreement with those who always argued that Bill was one of the American greats, a quiet and subtle writer who spoke to our deepest feelings. Recently, the Harvill Press reissued his early, out-of-print novels and short stories, and they met with enthusiastic reviews and a delighted audience.

But what was it like to be included in the magic circle which Emily, a beautiful, imaginative and always thoughtful woman, created around them? Their city apartment, and their house in the countryside of rural New York state, were oases of beauty and serenity. Their lives together almost constituted another art form.

Was it the way the light fell on the white sofa, with their beloved black cat curled in the corner, or the shelves and shelves of books? Or was it perhaps a new painting by Emily, hung in an inconspicuous place so that you came upon it unexpectedly? Or the nosegay of garden flowers by your bed? Or the special tea that only they seemed to have? No, these were just details.

I came to believe that it was the way they both looked at and treated you - as though you were the most interesting, attractive person they had ever met. They were people whose souls were in their eyes. As Bill once wrote: "As a rule, when I am being introduced to a man or woman who interests me, I am so intent on searching the eyes I don't even hear what they are saying."

To spend time with them was to feel light and fancy free. Neither suffered pretension or grandiosity gladly, and cliches made them wince. But if you were their friend, they would forgive your occasional lapses. Above all, to be with them was to feel safe, protected, accepted, respected and loved.

Shortly before he died, Bill said, with a straight face: "I never knew that dying could be so entertaining. People tell you such amazing things when they know you won't be around for long."

They are survived by two daughters, Kate and Brookie.

 William Maxwell, writer and editor, born August 16 1908; died July 31 2000

 Emily Noyes Maxwell, artist, born August 25 1921; died July 23 2000

She wrote about her work: "Some day, I'd like to go back to abstraction, but, at present, objects speak to me so provocatively I feel the need to paint what I see." Her work appeared in one-woman and group exhibitions both in New York and out of town. Even so, Emily chose to put the nurturing of Bill's talent ahead of her own, and did so by creating an ambiance in which his could flourish. He was aware of what she did for him, and often said, not only that Emily was his best editor, but also that, without her, he would not have had a writing life. Although Bill was a writer of extraordinary sensitivity and insight, for many years his fame as fiction editor at the New Yorker seemed to overshadow his own creative reputation. Because his authors were so famous - they included John Cheever, Maeve Brennan, John Updike and Eudora Welty - critics tended to forget that he, too, was a writer. More often than not, he became a friend, as well as an editor. There is a good record of this evolving relationship in The Happiness Of Getting It Down Right: Letters Of Frank O'Connor And William Maxwell. Sylvia Townsend Warner, many of whose stories appeared in the New Yorker, also became a close friend, and The Letters Of Sylvia Townsend Warner (1982) were edited, with a long and warm introduction, by William Maxwell. Fortunately, critical consensus is now in agreement with those who always argued that Bill was one of the American greats, a quiet and subtle writer who spoke to our deepest feelings. Recently, the Harvill Press reissued his early, out-of-print novels and short stories, and they met with enthusiastic reviews and a delighted audience. But what was it like to be included in the magic circle which Emily, a beautiful, imaginative and always thoughtful woman, created around them? Their city apartment, and their house in the countryside of rural New York state, were oases of beauty and serenity. Their lives together almost constituted another art form. Was it the way the light fell on the white sofa, with their beloved black cat curled in the corner, or the shelves and shelves of books? Or was it perhaps a new painting by Emily, hung in an inconspicuous place so that you came upon it unexpectedly? Or the nosegay of garden flowers by your bed? Or the special tea that only they seemed to have? No, these were just details. I came to believe that it was the way they both looked at and treated you - as though you were the most interesting, attractive person they had ever met. They were people whose souls were in their eyes. As Bill once wrote: "As a rule, when I am being introduced to a man or woman who interests me, I am so intent on searching the eyes I don't even hear what they are saying." To spend time with them was to feel light and fancy free. Neither suffered pretension or grandiosity gladly, and cliches made them wince. But if you were their friend, they would forgive your occasional lapses. Above all, to be with them was to feel safe, protected, accepted, respected and loved. Shortly before he died, Bill said, with a straight face: "I never knew that dying could be so entertaining. People tell you such amazing things when they know you won't be around for long." They are survived by two daughters, Kate and Brookie.  William Maxwell, writer and editor, born August 16 1908; died July 31 2000  Emily Noyes Maxwell, artist, born August 25 1921; died July 23 2000

fields.headline: Kray 'has only days to live'
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, has agreed to consider whether the former London gangster Reggie Kray should be freed after doctors revealed he could have "days rather than weeks to live".
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has agreed to consider whether the former London gangster Reggie Kray should be freed after doctors revealed he could have "days rather than weeks to live".

Kray, 67, serving a life sentence after being convicted of the murder of Jack "The Hat" McVitie in 1969, is being treated for cancer of the bladder in the Norfolk and Norwich hospital, Norwich.

His lawyer, Trevor Linn, yesterday wrote to Mr Straw appealing for Kray's release on compassionate grounds.

"I have now been informed by Mr Kray's treating consultant that Mr Kray has cancer of the bladder with other secondary tumours," Mr Linn said in his letter.

"The consultant's opinion is that Mr Kray 'could have days rather than weeks to live'. His condition is terminal. The cancer is inoperable and will not respond to chemotherapy."

"In the circumstances I request that you order Mr Kray's immediate release on compassionate grounds ... that will allow Mr Kray the dignity to die in peace at home."

A spokeswoman for the prison service said Mr Straw would consider the request over the weekend and was expected to make a decision early next week.

Prisoners can apply for compassionate release under section 36 of the 1991 Criminal Justice Act if they can show they have an exceptional case.

Mr Linn said Kray had served long beyond his tariff and parole review reports indicated he was no longer a risk to the public.

Mr Linn added that Roberta Kray, 41, who married Kray while he was in prison, was staying at her husband's bed side. "He is cracking jokes. He's a tough old bird," said Mr Linn. "Roberta is staying at the hospital and is with him all the time.

"But he wants to be released and if he could be told that he was free, that would give him such a lift."

If released, Kray would go to a private address with his wife, Mr Linn said. Kray was sentenced to serve not less than 30 years for the murder of McVitie, who was stabbed to death in a flat in Stoke Newington, north London.

Reggie Kray's twin Ronnie, the other half of Britain's most notorious gangster duo, received the same sentence in 1969 for two murders.

Ronnie, who died of a heart attack in 1995, was convicted of the murder of George Cornell, shot in the Blind Beggar pub in east London. He was also convicted of McVitie's murder.

webTitle: Reforms force farmers off the land

fields.headline: Reforms force farmers off the land
fields.standfirst: Thousands struggle to survive as Turkish state removes the subsidies that kept agriculture alive
fields.trailText: The rolling plains of Anatolia may well have been the place where farming began 10,000 years ago, and millions of Turks still live off the land.
fields.body:
The rolling plains of Anatolia may well have been the place where farming began 10,000 years ago, and millions of Turks still live off the land.

But a tradition that stretches back through generations is under serious threat. There are too many farmers in Turkey, and the state can no longer afford to support them.

"People are selling their land, selling their tractors," said Muzaffer Turkoglu, the provincial representative of the Turkish Chamber of Agriculture in Polatli.

"They are struggling to survive."

It is not hard to work out why. In the leading industrialised countries an average of 5% of the population work in the agricultural sector, and they are subsidised by the rest. In Turkey agriculture accounts for more than 40% of the work force, and the subsidies are crippling the economy.

So, under a strict economic reform programme agreed with the International Monetary Fund, the government has set the price of wheat much lower this year than the farming lobby demanded. Now the farmers are feeling the pinch.

Millions of people have migrated from the countryside in the last 20 years to take up residence in suburbs and shanty towns on the edge of the big cities. All the signs are that the pace of migration will increase, as new farming techniques and changing economic priorities drive many small agricultural communities out of business.

"It's inevitable that over time more people will move from the rural areas to the cities," said Haluk Kasnakoglu, an economist at the Middle East Technical University in Ankara.

"My concern is that current policies are making it happen too quickly. It could be a recipe for social unrest."

There are various pilot projects for schemes to help support farmers without keeping agricultural prices artificially high. But the state's aim is to reduce the number of people working in agriculture, and there is no painless way of doing it.

Agricultural reform is part of the country's preparations for possible membership of the European Union.

When attention focuses on Turkey's relations with the EU, issues such as human rights and democratic reform usually grab the headlines, but what happens down on the farm is equally significant in the long term.

"The common agricultural policy gets enough flak as it is," a European diplomat in Ankara said. "Just imagine what 25m Anatolian peasants could do to it."

The government agrees. Without reform, it insists, Turkish agriculture will remain ill-equipped to survive in a global economy. But small farmers in the Anatolian heartland are already feeling the chill winds of competition.

"We used to be self-sufficient," Sait Akyar said as he waited to sell his tractor-load of wheat.

"But they've annihilated our economy by importing cheap surplus crops from other countries".

It is not all bad news. Turkey has all the natural advantages it needs - good soil, a good climate and plenty of water. It could still become the breadbasket of Europe.

Economists insist that agriculture is the most backward sector of the Turkish economy, and that reform must come. But many farmers in Anatolia are facing tough times ahead, as their traditional rural lifestyle changes for ever.

webTitle: Liberia frees Channel 4 crew after apology

fields.headline: Liberia frees Channel 4 crew after apology
fields.trailText: Four Channel 4 journalists charged with espionage in Liberia were released from prison yesterday after a week of international protests and a personal apology from the men and the chairman of the television company to Liberian president Charles Taylor.
fields.body:
Four Channel 4 journalists charged with espionage in Liberia were released from prison yesterday after a week of international protests and a personal apology from the men and the chairman of the television company to Liberian president Charles Taylor.

The four men, who were making a three-part documentary, were detained last Friday and charged on Monday with helping British and US intelligence to support allegations that Liberia was assisting rebels in neighbouring Sierra Leone by diamond smuggling and gun running.

Interviewed on CNN, Mr Taylor said their release was the result of "plea bargaining" between government lawyers and defence counsel.

"We are not expelling the journalists but they are free to leave whenever they want," he said.

The journalists - British director David Barrie, Zimbabwe-born cameraman Tim Lambon, who has dual South African and British nationality, Sorious Samura from Sierra Leone, and South African soundman Gugulakhe Radebe - were expected to fly out of the capital Monrovia to Abidjan on the Ivory Coast. Under the Liberian penal code they could have faced 10 years in prison or, according to the indictment, the death penalty.

Their release was welcomed by the foreign secretary Robin Cook as "an enormous relief for the men's families".

Mr Cook said that he would be thanking President Ob-asanjo of Nigeria; Nelson Mandela; Jesse Jackson, President Clinton's envoy to Africa; and the Sierra Leone ambassador to Liberia for their efforts.

The Liberian authorities released the men's statement which read: "We, the four journalists currently held in Monrovia central prison, wish to express our unreserved apology to both his excellency the president of Liberia and the people of Liberia for any offence which our actions or statements have caused."

The letter to Mr Taylor from Channel 4 chairman Vanni Treves, which is not being released, reinforced that message.

Mr Taylor told CNN that the charges against the men stemmed from a script seized from them at the time of their arrest at their Monrovia hotel. He said the journalists appeared to have decided on their story before arriving in Liberia and to have come to the country to "fill in the blanks".

"This was not a check to the free press. We were dealing with a case of conspiracy with a clear case of libel here, which would have damaged this country.

"I am very thankful to Almighty God that they have realised that an error has been made and that Channel 4 in Britain have issued a statement of remorse, because they did something terrible here."

Mr Taylor, a former warlord in the Liberian civil war, has repeatedly denied allegations that he was colluding with his allies across the border, the rebel Revolutionary United Front which controls Sierra Leone's diamond areas. He again demanded proof yesterday, even though the evidence is far from circumstantial.

British and American officials have claimed to have information from photographs and satellite surveillance of arms being trucked across the border to the rebels as well as intelligence of meetings between rebel leaders and Mr Taylor.

It is estimated that last year Liberia, with an annual diamond production worth about $10m (£6.8m), exported stones to the value of $300m. A senior Swiss customs official confirmed two weeks ago that Liberian imports had surged from nothing in 1997 to $29.7m in the first half of this year. Last month a senior director of De Beers, the main diamond buyer, told a conference in London that 600 Liberian soldiers were guarding a rebel diamond mine.

In July, the UN security council imposed a ban on the purchase of Sierra Leone diamonds that do not have a government certificate in an effort to prevent the RUF from financing its long-running civil war, in which tens of thousands have been killed and maimed.

webTitle: Villagers warned after big cat mauls boy playing in field

fields.headline: Villagers warned after big cat mauls boy playing in field
fields.trailText: Residents of a country village are being warned to be on their guard after a schoolboy said he was attacked by a large cat-like animal.
fields.body:
Residents of a country village are being warned to be on their guard after a schoolboy said he was attacked by a large cat-like animal.

Police in Monmouthshire have called in a big cat expert to help in their hunt for the animal. The police force helicopter is also being used to scour the surrounding area with heat seeking equipment. Although there have been numerous reported sightings of big cats in rural parts of Wales and the west country, the latest incident is thought to be the first attack on a human.

Josh Hopkins, 11, told yesterday how he was playing in a field close to his home in the village of Trelleck, near Monmouth, with his older brother when he spotted what he thought was the family's cat. But it was a much bigger black cat than he had seen before.

"It turned and made a horrible hissing sound. It reared up and lashed at me with its paw, holding my cheek for a second. Then it got my head in its jaws and bit me. I was terrified and I thought it was going to kill me."

He said the animal ran off when he began screaming. But the attack left him bleeding from claw and bite wounds that required treatment at a medical centre.

Chief Inspector Nigel Russell of Gwent police said that although there had been local sightings of one or more large black cats he had not heard of anyone being attacked.

"We don't want to panic people but we are asking them to be very careful and vigilant."

Danny Nineham, a big cat expert, said he believed Josh was "extremely lucky" to be alive. He was baffled that the creature had backed off.

"They are quite capable of killing a small child even though they try to keep away from human beings."

Experts believe big cats have bred in the wild after escaping or being released by their owners following the Dangerous Animals Act in 1976.

webTitle: Big in Japan - and Britain Supermarket boom in Sushi sales

fields.headline: Big in Japan - and Britain Supermarket boom in Sushi sales
fields.trailText: First it was their camera equipment. Then it was their cars. Now their food is threatening to make inroads against home-grown competition.
fields.body:
First it was their camera equipment. Then it was their cars. Now their food is threatening to make inroads against home-grown competition.

The phenomenal growth in Japanese restaurants and noodle bars - backed up by a burgeoning takeaway trade - has helped to trigger a supermarket boom in sushi sales.

Sainsbury's yesterday opened its first in-store sushi bar - and at least three more are planned this year - to complement a big increase in its range of Japanese-style foods.

What started four years ago as a small niche product line, sold only in London and the south-east, is now available in more than 200 branches - and it is outselling cheese sandwiches.

Supermarket rival Tesco sells £7m worth of sushi a year as part of what is rapidly becoming a mass-market phenomenon as Britons' taste for both exotic and healthy fishy food, which has made the Japanese the longest-living people on earth, helps to create a new eating fashion.

The new Sainsbury's sushi bar, at the Cromwell Road branch in Kensington, includes a conveyor belt from which customers can choose a selection of sushi.

"Sales seem to show people are buying it for dinners and parties," said a spokeswoman.

Sainsbury's has gone into partnership with the restaurant and bar chain Yo! Sushi, launched in 1997 and already established in Harvey Nichols and Selfridge's.

The conveyor belt system is its trademark and its next venture, in central London's increasingly fashionable Clerkenwell area, will add a sake dispenser to the self-service beer it already provides in its other London bars. But customers will be able to see how much they have drunk on a table-top meter, and staff can operate a turn-off tap if they think anyone is over-indulging.

Yo! Sushi has also adapted another Japanese strength - robots, to act as drink trolleys.

webTitle: Suu Kyi blocked in dash to leave Burmese capital

fields.headline: Suu Kyi blocked in dash to leave Burmese capital
fields.trailText: The Burmese democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi has again defied the military junta by attempting to travel outside the capital, Rangoon.
fields.body:
The Burmese democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi has again defied the military junta by attempting to travel outside the capital, Rangoon.

She was halted by the police on Thursday in a suburb of the city after crossing the river. Her convoy of two small vehicles was moved to a side road and blocked by two trucks. It remained there overnight.

The government claimed that officials had asked her not to proceed further "for security reasons". Police and plainclothes agents were at the scene yesterday morning and an ambulance stood by.

The new confrontation comes after a year of dangerous stalemate in which official threats have been made to execute Ms Suu Kyi, or imprison her for life for "high treason".

This is the first time that the Nobel prizewinner has challenged her travel restrictions since 1998, when she was frustrated in four such efforts to leave the capital to meet supporters of her National League for Democracy party (NLD).

A spokesman for the NLD, which is regularly harassed by the authorities, said yesterday that Ms Suu Kyi was trying to meet members of the party's youth wing in Kungyangon, about 30 miles south of Rangoon.

In May this year the Burmese army newspaper the Mirror warned that Ms Suu Kyi and her followers were liable to execution or life imprisonment for committing high treason by having contact with dissidents.

Earlier, the senior army general, Than Shwe, who also serves as prime minister, threatened to "eliminate" rivals of the regime.

General Shwe told an army day parade "Whoever disturbs the stability and hinders the development of the nation must be eliminated as the common enemy."

Ms Suu Kyi's new confrontation seems to be a deliberate effort to rally support at a time when hope of an accommodation with the junta has faded completely.

She described the restraints on her travel in a recent television interview conducted secretly by the US network NBC.

"They've closed off the road to my house," she said. "There are barricades on either side of my garden. So I can't really go out without them knowing."

"And every time I go out, I'm followed by two cars and two motorbikes. They're outside now sitting and waiting for me to come out."

She has been under house arrest in Rangoon for 11 years.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Mrs Milosevic wants to be MP

The wife of President Slobodan Milosevic announced yesterday she would stand for the lower house of the Yugoslav parliament in her home town of Pozarevac in the national elections due on September 24.

It is the first time that Mirjana Markovic, 58, a senior official in her husband's Yugoslav Left party, has sought an elected post.

GI accused of killing boy, 6

A US soldier on peacekeeping duty in Kosovo has been charged with negligent homicide and dereliction of duty in connection with the fatal shooting of a six-year-old Albanian boy.

The Pentagon said yesterday that the charges against the Private Nicholas Young arose from an incident on July 10 at a school in the village of Gornja Slatina. They carry a maximum three years' detention.

LAPD sued by its own officers

The Los Angeles police department is to be sued by 41 serving and former officers who claim they were harassed or fired after reporting misconduct.

The officers filed a case on Thursday seeking compensation and an injunction prohibiting LAPD officials from retaliating against whistleblowers. Up to 500 officers could join the case if it is certified as a class action.

Five die as fires rage in Greece

Raging wildfires in Greece killed five more people yesterday as officials declared a state of emergency in the province of Arcadia.

Several major fires, fed by gale-force winds, threatened villages from the Albanian border to Arcadia in the south. Seven people have died in the past two days.

China frees US missionaries

China released three Taiwanese-born American missionaries yesterday after they were arrested with 130 members of the banned evangelical Christian Fangcheng church.

The three were detained for two days in the central province of Henan for "activities incompatible with the tourist status under which they entered China".

Kenyan bus crash kills 45

At least 45 people died when a bus travelling from Maua in eastern Kenya to Mombasa plunged off a bridge, local newspapers reported yesterday.

About 27 people survived the accident on Thursday night, but the death toll may rise to at least 50 since more people may have been trapped in the wreckage.

Policeman dies fighting the flab

A Filipino policeman died of a stroke on Thursday while jogging to trim his stomach after the chief of police ruled that the waists of the 117,000 officers in his force must measure no more than 34in (86cm).

Antonio Miralpes, 55, is the second officer to die since the diktat was issued in March.

webTitle: Turks split by plan to purge Islamists

fields.headline: Turks split by plan to purge Islamists
fields.standfirst: Unions and military at odds on 'enemies of the state' issue
fields.trailText: Trade unions in Turkey are threatening a mass campaign against a government plan to authorise the dismissal of thousands of civil servants suspected of supporting radical Islamist or Kurdish groups.
fields.body:
Trade unions in Turkey are threatening a mass campaign against a government plan to authorise the dismissal of thousands of civil servants suspected of supporting radical Islamist or Kurdish groups.

Union leaders warned yesterday that the government would have a struggle to get the bill approved when parliament returns from its summer recess.

"We will lobby every deputy in parliament and mobilise all our forces against [the measure]," said Resul Akay, of the conservative union Kamu-Sen, which has several hundred thousand members. Other unions and human rights groups have also expressed their opposition.

It could become quite a fight. The national security council, which is dominated by military leaders, said earlier this week that there was an urgent need to pass legislation as soon as possible.

The plan to get rid of what the establishment calls "enemies of the state" has already provoked a constitutional crisis.

The government tried to change the law by cabinet decree but President Ahmet Necdet Sezer twice refused to sign it.

The president, who took office in May, emphasised that his veto was not aimed at the proposal itself, but he has insisted that it must be introduced by parliamentary legislation rather than cabinet decree.

The government has responded angrily by publicly accusing Mr Sezer of exceeding his powers and hindering the fight against radical Islam.

Pressure from the military establishment seems to be the decisive factor behind the rising political temperature. The generals are reported to have criticised the president behind the scenes, and they are demanding results.

A report presented to the national security council identified 252 local governors among those who are alleged to be sympathetic to the Islamist cause.

The move to sack "suspect" civil servants is part of a continuing campaign against political Islam which was launched with military backing more than three years ago. In 1997 Turkey's first Islamist-led government was forced to resign by what local commentators called a "soft coup".

The unions are afraid that the proposed dismissals may turn into a witch-hunt.

They also argue that Turkey's reputation abroad will be badly damaged at a time when it is trying to meet a series of conditions laid down by the European Union for countries which wants to begin negotiations for membership.
