webTitle: Friends flounder in fountain of youth

fields.headline: Friends flounder in fountain of youth
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
It's about time they did something about the footage of the flatmates in the fountain during the titles of Friends (Channel 4). Their hair has changed, they've lost and put on weight (and taken it off and put it on again), got married, gained new surnames, crashed their Porsches, been lost in space, had high school reunions and undergone liver transplants (allegedly), yet there they still are in their flouncy white shirts with their voluminous hair.

Couldn't they just re-record the fountain scene? Then they'd have The One With the New Titles. (But I don't suppose they'd lower themselves to getting wet like that now without a significant pay rise). No? OK. Well, we shall just have to clap our hands three times in quick succession at that bit in the theme tune (you know: "So no one told you life was gonna be this way") and ignore Ross's frou-frou Brillo Pad 'do and Rachel's abundance of wavy locks.

Last night's episode, The One Where Phoebe Runs, was funnier than anything for a while because it concentrated on the basics of the sextet's characters. Phoebe's kookiness was set against Rachel's self-consciousness, Monica's anally-retentive nature was challenged by Chandler's rearrangement of their apartment, Joey's hopeless womanising was to the fore with his new roommate (in the form of Elle Macpherson) and Ross was plain old pathetic.

It has been said that sitcoms don't work any more because they don't use stereotypes, but the likes of Friends and Frasier show that to be untrue. These days the stereotypes are just more sophisticated than the desperate fat woman, the battleaxe wife or the dizzy tart - and a whole lot less misogynistic.

In fact, it's the women in the current crop of classic sitcoms who fare better than the men. From Frasier's Roz and Daphne to Rachel, Phoebe and Monica, the women are stronger, sassier - and often funnier - than the blokes. They are the grown-ups, while the men are juveniles. In last night's episode Ross moaned over his lovelessness, Chandler fretted about Monica and Joey was a complete dork, while the women were out expressing themselves freely. Apart from Macpherson, of course, whom you could practically see mouthing "Is that OK?" to the director when she thought she was out of shot.

When will Debs Brownlow in Coronation Street (ITV) be unmasked as Patricia Farnham from Brookside? It can only be a matter of time until local historian and bow tie-wearer Anthony removes his gaze from Rita's roots (her family tree's, that is, since looking at Rita's hair for too long can induce blindness) and exposes Debs/Patricia's double life as high-flying lawyer and denim jacket-clad hairdresser. How will Natalie react to finding out her mum is a lesbian in France? What will Max say if news reaches Brookside Close? How will Susannah cope knowing her one-time rival is a stone's throw away?

(Probable answer: by hotfooting it to Weatherfield and working her way through the blokes there.)

Of course, none of that matters for the moment, since poor little Tommy has been snatched by Doreen and "that fancy man of hers" from Vera's warm, if slightly wrinkled, bosom. I feel a rescue attempt coming on: Tyrone and Jack in balaclavas and black polo-necks, and Vera doing a Judi Dench back at HQ.

That Linda Barker is a jolly sort, even when people whose rooms she has changed didn't like the result. Changing Rooms Redecorated (BBC1) took her, Anna Ryder Leather-Trousers and Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen (who, come to think of it, may have supplied the Friends with their flouncy fountain shirts) back to the scenes of their crimes/triumphs.

The lovely Barker, who always sounds like she's going to burst into fits of uncontrollable laughter anyway, was so very smiley in the face of the harshest criticism you couldn't help but think she should become an adviser to Tony Blair.

Speaking of teeth, is it that wrong to dislike someone - who's not a vampire - for having not very nice teeth? Thought not. With that in mind, next week on Big Brother (Channel 4) vote Claire. Between those and that sarong, the girl has got to go.

Meanwhile, in Brookside (Channel 4) Mick gave Susannah a right surprise. Goodness - imagine what that would take.

fields.headline: Creatures of the night
fields.trailText: Tanya Wilson: On radio
fields.body:
Hearing that Craig David song the other day, it was brought home to me by the silky voiced one how staid my bedtime habits have become. Call it the strains of busy modern life, the pressures of work, the long-standing relationship or just old fashioned laziness, but for too long now the Wilson household has been stuck in a bedtime radio rut. A lovely rut, but a rut all the same. Late Junction plus Radio 4 at the weekends, occasionally dipping into World Service fare. Sigh.

David, on the other hand, meets a "beautiful honey" who asks him the time (that old one) on a Monday afternoon, treating her to Moët (that old one) on Tuesday, makin' lurve for the rest of the week and chillin' on Sunday.

With this in mind, and translated into my wireless world, I began a giddy week of flirtation, eyeing up, rampant promiscuity with the knobs on my trannie. It has three.

My first lovely honey came in the form of Edwina Currie on Late Night Currie (Radio 5 Live) on Sunday. This is such a perky little number, it makes Late Junction's penchant for Mongolian nose flute symphonies from the 12th century look positively pedestrian. This is mainly due to Currie's dominatrix approach to presenting. Tony Bullimore was on to talk about sailing round the world with Lenny Henry, as you do.

Maybe it's since his mid-Atlantic near-death experience, but boy can he ramble on. He also has one of those talking tics that, once you notice it, drowns out everything else he says. My mum has a friend who does this, starting every sentence with "I/She/He/They turned around and said_". You can't listen without visualising every member of her personal cast as perpetual spinning tops. Bullimore's is "you know", said like a muted Frankie Howerd, linking together some of the longest stories known to man. La Currie was going crackers, snipping, snapping, finishing his sentences and verbally bundling him out of the studio.

She interviewed a woman who has spent 40 years with chimps too. This was just as much fun, with the woman telling us about Froddo, "The biggest, strongest chimp we've even known". He knocks you over, drags you a bit and sometimes stamps on you. So that is where Edwina learned her interview technique. I had the most lurid dreams after this frothy mix, I can tell you.

Monday, wimped out back to Late Junction in shock. Emboldened by some frog music (yes, really) I spent Tuesday bedtime in the company of shock jock James Whale on Talk Sport. It all made perfect sense in the world that is Talk. Whale was calling for camps in which to deposit scumbags (asylum seekers) and grotbags (beggars) and was encouraging us to "smile" about the fate of the Kursk, as it's sinking meant one sub and lots of Russian sailors less to worry about as enemies. The Cold War hasn't defrosted on Talk.

"Russia's more dangerous now than ever," he told one caller, a woman who like me had just found Whale by accident. Her husband was away, she said, as if that's the only reason she could go wild and touch that dial. I counted my blessings and dreamed of a camp for all the Talk Sport presenters and callers. One caller stopped what he was saying to inform the nation that a topless lady was peering out of a window in Kensington. Another had written to Teletext about the Kursk. Teletext.

Wednesday brought the bizarre feast that is the Janice Long show (Radio 2). The mix is some music (Los Lobos, Sheryl Crow, kd lang), some competitions, and some gentle polemic from our Janice. Nasty Nick fever is out of control she said. "There are people in this country who have committed far worse crimes, I'm sure," she said, all sage-like.

A man called Thomas called in with the wrong answer for a quiz. Why do that? Why put him on just to humiliate him? Especially when he was clearly an ex-colleague of David Shayler's. "I can't say where I am," said Tommy, calling from his workplace. Asked if he wanted to say hello to anyone, he almost whispered: "That might reveal where I am."

Where I am now, is back in my late-night listening rut. It's staid, I know, and Craig David will never pen a song about me, but I'm sleeping much better, thanks all the same.

webTitle: A night at the round table

fields.headline: A night at the round table
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  finds why Le Roi Arthus should stay forgotten
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements finds why Le Roi Arthus should stay forgotten
fields.body:
As far as I know Ernest Chausson is the only composer to have died from falling off a bicycle (in 1899, at the age of 44). He's remembered otherwise now for a handful of works - a symphony, the beautiful Poeme for violin and orchestra, some chamber music and songs - and for being one of Claude Debussy's closest friends. Some of his later music prefigures the world of Pelléas et Mélisande.

Chausson's only opera, Le Roi Arthus, premiered in Brussels four years after his death, is virtually forgotten. The performance in Edinburgh's Festival Theatre this week seems to have been the first time it has been heard in Britain. Chausson worked on this Arthurian legend for nine years, trying to reconcile his admiration for Wagner with his own specifically French musical instincts, but he was only partially successful.

The one thing that this creditable, but by no means ideal, Edinburgh performance demonstrated is that Le Roi Arthus isn't a neglected masterpiece; it contains some wonderful moments when what Chausson was attempting to do is suddenly brought into focus, but the dramatic structure is flawed and the music uneven.

The starting point for the story is the love affair between Lancelot and Guinevere and their betrayal by the ambitious Mordred. That occupies the first of the three acts, and the rest of the opera deals with the catastrophic aftermath, not only for them - she kills herself, he dies in battle against Arthur's forces - but for the community of the Round Table. Arthur's world is destroyed, and he takes his leave in the final scene.

The parallels with Tristan und Isolde are obvious; Lancelot and Guinevere's big love duet is even interrupted by a servant. But here the hero is Arthur, while the illicit lovers make a deeply unsympathetic couple: Guinevere is a manipulative monster, and Lancelot hopelessly weak-willed, caught between his love for her and his loyalty to his king.

It's Arthur and his tragedy that brings the best music out of Chausson too. The first act is a mess. The love duet sprawls, the score is a noisy mélange of Tristan, The Ring and the melodic chromaticisms of Chausson's teacher, César Franck. But after that the musical world shifts. Parsifal becomes the reference point, and Arthur's major scenes - his despair at discovering the truth about his wife and best friend, and his encounter with Merlin, who forsees the destruction of the Round Table - have a numinous power. Though some of the earlier brashness returns in the final act, and Guinevere's death scene goes on far too long, the ending is superb, modelled on the Good Friday music from Parsifal, but rapt, ethereal and totally effective.

It's a hard work to cast nowadays - the role of Lancelot needs a tenor of heroic stature, and Guinevere has to be sung by a soprano with the power and projection of a mezzo in the middle registers. Hubert Delamboye and Francoise Pollet weren't convincing here. It was left to Simon Keenlyside as an Arthur of heroic timbre and presence, and Christopher Maltman as a grave, sonorous Merlin to provide the real frissons of the evening. Frédéric Chaslin conducted the Royal Scottish National Orchestra and the chorus of Scottish Opera with the brisk efficiency that a bit too much of the score needs.

Worth hearing, certainly. Worth seeing on stage, I'm not so sure.

He's remembered otherwise now for a handful of works - a symphony, the beautiful Poeme for violin and orchestra, some chamber music and songs - and for being one of Claude Debussy's closest friends. Some of his later music prefigures the world of Pelléas et Mélisande. Chausson's only opera, Le Roi Arthus, premiered in Brussels four years after his death, is virtually forgotten. The performance in Edinburgh's Festival Theatre this week seems to have been the first time it has been heard in Britain. Chausson worked on this Arthurian legend for nine years, trying to reconcile his admiration for Wagner with his own specifically French musical instincts, but he was only partially successful. fields.headline: How to clean
fields.trailText: When a woman's place was in the home they used to spend a lot of time scrubbing the front step, probably because they were so keen to get out of the house. This was also a deep subliminal reaction to having been carried over the threshold in the first place.
fields.body:
When a woman's place was in the home they used to spend a lot of time scrubbing the front step, probably because they were so keen to get out of the house. This was also a deep subliminal reaction to having been carried over the threshold in the first place. Attitudes to cleaning have changed now, and some people employ a cleaner. This is still only acceptable for domestic cleaning - people would be a little bit surprised if you had a weekly cleaner in to tackle your armpits.

Life is a progress from dust to dust and from ashes to ashes, but some people like to reduce travelling time by living knee deep in dust and ashes their whole life. If cleanliness is next to Godliness, then most teenagers are atheists. That's why the words 'student accommodation' have the same resonance now as the Black Hole of Calcutta used to.

Men don't clean very often, but when they do, they like to vacuum. The vacuum cleaner has an engine, therefore it must be a toy. Men like to see just how much the vacuum cleaner can suck up, and so will happily spend a couple of hours sucking the crumbs from the toaster, the curtains from the wall and the topsoil from the garden.

Cleaning the bath is one of life's great philosophical problems: it's a place where you get clean, not a place you have to clean. Men have to spend time in front of the television thinking about this problem, while women clean the bath. On the other hand, no one should be expected to deal with that great tangled clump of hair that you pull out of the plug hole, unless you need something to educate your children about the hairstyles of the 60s.

Dust can be the source of allergies, and you might feel better if you give the house a daily once-over with a feather duster. On the other hand, you might be allergic to feathers. The rule with dusting is that if you run your finger along a bookcase and it gets black, then it's time to wash your finger. If you can't find the bookcase, it's probably time for a quick dust.

Cleaning the oven is the absolute pits. There are two useful labour-saving tips here: don't cook, or else cook a lot then move house. There are various creams and sprays that claim to do the job for you. These are vicious cocktails of chemicals, and if you leave them for too long you'll come back, open the oven and be able to see straight through into the neighbour's kitchen.

fields.headline: That bathroom sinking feeling
fields.standfirst: Surreal drama, cruel comedy and glorious Bach: our critics on more highlights from the Edinburgh festival
fields.trailText: Surreal drama, cruel comedy and glorious Bach: our critics on more highlights from the Edinburgh festival
fields.byline: Elisabeth Mahoney, Tom Service, Andrew Pulver and Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
Theatre
1500 Metres Above the Level of Jack **** Edinburgh Festival Theatre
Imagine Beckett had been Argentinian, had seen a few Jeunet and Caro films and liked Delicatessen best, and had a thing about diving. Set all this in a bathroom and you have something very wonderful: Federico Leon's 1500 Metres Above the Level of Jack (Mil quinientos metros sobre el nivel de Jack), a show that puts the quirk back into quirky and then some.

The international festival director, Brian McMaster, stumbled upon a rehearsal for this production in Buenos Aires last year and snapped it up for Edinburgh on the spot. "We have nothing like it in the programme," is his reasoned explanation (and given the uneven theatre offerings this year, that's a compliment). Jack is dreamy, seductive, irresistible, like underwater swimming in proper, clear sea.

Jack, a husband, father and compulsive diver, has gone missing, maybe with another woman. His wife sits in a bath, the tap dripping all the while ("great unease for those of us with weak bladders" said a gent in the front row), her son dips in and out. He is wearing a wetsuit, she a cozzie. They watch telly, though the picture is not great. "It's got water in it," she says.

They splish and splosh and then are joined by the son's girlfriend, Lisa (she's really called Marina), and her oddball son, Enzo. He throws water biscuits at people. They both have swimming gear on under their clothes. The man in their life has also disappeared, maybe drowned himself. They all end up in the bath.

Somehow, out of this strangeness, Leon weaves a poetic, often demonically funny tale about what it means to be a father, what it means to be abandoned. The ways in which we shield ourselves from the harshness of reality are in the mix too - they each slink under the water, envelop themselves in wetsuits. It is beautifully acted by the small cast. Hold your breath, prepare yourself for strangeness as startling as a pool of icy water: jump in. (EB)  Till tomorrow. Box office: 0131-473 2000.

Comedy
The Johnny Vegas Gameshow **** Edinburgh Garden Party
When Johnny Vegas exhorts you to "'ave some fun, son," what he really means is "be afraid - be very afraid". This year, the hectoring, belligerent comic has left behind his potter's wheel and gone for a briskly tacky gameshow format. Woe betide anyone frogmarched into being a contestant: the alternative title could be Who Wants To Be A Nervous Wreck?

I would not for all the tea in China (or as it happened, all the Heineken in a supermarket trolley) have been in the shoes of hapless Charlie, who turned out to be the comedy reviewer from the Observer. He got off lightly. Worse yet to be on the receiving end of Johnny's affection, like the male contestant who was wrestled to the floor in an extended display of slobbering lachrymose tenderness.

Vegas, a rotund, boozy Pa Ubu in a crimplene safari suit, knows that terror is the unspoken key ingredient in showbiz, and makes it clear from the start, quickly identifying punters as stalkers or lesbian piano teachers. He divides the audience into two and sets the teams against each other, because "hatred breeds entertainment". Not so much Chris Tarrant, then, as Chris Tyrant. The terror only increases when Vegas exposes his blubbering, embittered vulnerability - playing secret tapes of so-called friends carping about him, or moaning about his failure to get a part in the forthcoming Lord of The Rings movie.

The momentum is touch-and-go, full blast at the start, then sagging badly. By the end, people have even started warming to Vegas, which is a worrying sign. But when he is on form, he has Theatre of Cruelty down to a tee. (JR) Classical
Late Night Bach ***** Usher Hall, Edinburgh
Andras Schiff's late-night concerts of Bach's keyboard music have become a feature of recent festivals. This year he turns his attention to the six English suites Bach compiled around 1725, though they were probably written more than a decade before. Schiff has become something of a talisman for the whole music programme at the international festival: he has been at the centre of four concerts of Schumann's chamber music over the past week.

One of the products of such a close relationship between festival and artist is that the audience has the concentration of a gathering of Schiff's closest confidants. You sense that his playing is as free from mannerism and as intimate as it would be in his own front room; and the atmosphere bristles with a keen, cerebral focus on the stark mastery of Bach's compositions and Schiff's performances.

Yet there is nothing austere about Schiff's attitude to Bach. In fact in movements like the headlong rush of the Bourées and Gigue from the first suite, he has an impish impetuosity, and for all the seriousness of the E minor fifth suite, it is his playful exaggeration of the final Gigue's vivid chromaticism which is most memorable.

From the rustic drone of the Musette in the third suite to the rigorous counterpoint of the fifth suite's Prelude, Schiff conjures Bach's expressive world to life. For an hour in the Usher Hall, Bach's music is a complete, all-encompassing musical universe. (TS)

 Final concert tonight at 10.30pm.

Cabaret
Arthur Smith sings Leonard Cohen *** Edinburgh Pleasance
Arthur Smith has long been a dangerously over-exposed figure - Loose Ends, BA's soporific in-flight comedy programme, and even a Guardian Edinburgh diary - so it comes as a surprise to be reminded that he is such a commanding performer. With his doleful, grey, rasping voice, emerging as if from the bottom of a deep well, he is a perfect candidate to perform the Leonard Cohen songbook.

He sings out of love for the man's work, and because the show's title suggested the most lugubrious afternoon you could imagine on the fringe.

It is partly a tribute to Cohen - "the greatest comedian of the 20th century" - partly a rambling philosophical discourse on boredom, addiction, depression and ducks. Smith maintains a rather lofty distance from the audience, telling his tales in a stentorian boom. He is very much a monologist rather than a stand-up, and the riffing factor in his routine is nil. But his intricately structured ramble, which, I suspect, would be even better on radio, affectingly mixes farce with a streak of melancholy.

It is only a shame that his rather heartfelt renditions of Famous Blue Raincoat and other bedsit favourites are self-consciously sabotaged by his clowning around with the guitarist. Ronnie Golden may do a virtuoso Jimi Hendrix impression, but the device of the comedy accompanist is one of the wearier institutions of the circuit.

Still, believe it or not, Smith can sing - that is, inasmuch as Leonard Cohen himself can. To paraphrase the great man, he was born this way, he had no choice, he was born with the gift of a golden voice. A Jacques Brel for the 21st century, surely, or Rod McKuen on acid? (JR)

Film
George Washington **** Cameo cinema
The title is deceptive. David Gordon Green's feature film debut is not a biography of the pre-eminent revolutionary of the US, but a sardonic, beautifully filmed fable of America's predilection for indulging in heroic ideals.

There is something of the resonance that Wes Anderson's Rushmore, summoning up the giant presidential rock carvings, got out of its title; and in its flashes of humour and its idiosyncratic protagonist, George Washington actually echoes much of Rushmore's distinctive mood. But the milieu is considerably different - a small, rusting southern town, its multi-racial population living in fragile harmony - and at George Washington's forefront are a bunch of young teens whiling away their summer at the swimming hole or running along the railway tracks.

There is a character called George, but he is no Washington: he is a 13-year-old African- American kid (Donald Holden) who has to wear a crash helmet because of a skull-plates problem. He is sweet natured, but hardly the brightest penny on the collection plate. The film's narrator is 12-year-old Nasia (Candace Evanofski), whose rambling, meditative voiceovers convey a beyond-her-years sophistication.

Scene casually follows scene: kids fight, local track workers eat their lunch, girls discuss their boyfriends. What initially appears a beguiling, but directionless, narrative is suddenly focused when, out of the blue, one of the teens is accidentally killed, and events take a macabre, stricken turn and the movie just gets weirder, and funnier.

Writer-director Green deserves considerable credit for creating an authentically impressive film at his first attempt. The effortless naturalism of his performers only reinforces the film's matter-of-fact stylishness. (AP)

 Today at Cameo 1. Box 0ffice: 0131-623 8030.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck wanders down memory lane and bumps into a few old friends.
fields.body:
Oh, the sheer joy of it! The glorious, cleansing feeling achieved when unloading 35 years of papers, certificates, letters, assorted writings, bank statements, rejection slips, diaries. The men from Westminster council's recycling unit had no inkling of the traumatic saga they were piling into their green wagon.

One letter (vintage 1969), ruthlessly consigned to the recycling bin of history like everything else, referred, among its paragraphs of maudlin prattling, to a bottle of wine labelled Red Burgundy, bought for nine shillings from Peter Dominic in Marylebone High Street. It came from Chile. Alas, there is no comment on its excellence or otherwise, but I have no doubt that it was not a patch on Cono Sur Pinot Noir 1999, also from Chile, or that this latter wine, at £3.59, is not only incomparably better value but, in real terms, far cheaper. It is also, I would dare guess, far more like a crunchy red burgundy that its distant relative that was once labelled as such.

Two incorrigibly modern aspects to this wine, however, are that, to acquire this superb 16-point (out of 20) pinot at that absurd price, you have to buy two bottles and visit a supermarket. The supermarket is Somerfield, and, until September 5, it has a 'buy one bottle, get the second at half price' offer on certain wines. I make no apologies for the fact that I am practising additional recycling, seeing as six of them, including the richly elegant Cono Sur (normal price £4.79), have appeared in this column before.

The other five recycled wines are Chilean Merlot 1999 (17 points, normally £4.49), Cabernet Sauvignon/Merlot Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, normally £3.99) from Chile, Argentine Sangiovese 1999 (17 points, normally £4.29), Chilean Semillon Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, normally £3.99) and Bright Brothers Argentine Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, normally £4.29). Buying two bottles makes the price risible.

The cheapies not seen in this column before are four in number: Argentine Tempranillo 1999 (16 points, normally £3.99) outguns rioja with the brilliance of its tannins and creamy richness; Cabernet Sauvignon Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, normally £4.49) has warmth and generosity of the fruit, tannins that are meaningful enough, and also the beauty of subtle wood touches; Argentinian First Ever Shiraz 2000 (16 points, normally £4.49) competes with anything Australian, though it is more darkly savoury; and Cono Sur Viognier 1999 (16 points, normally £4.99) offers delicious apricot fruit with a touch of apple and pineapple - this wine is in limited distribution, as not a lot of it is produced.

I appreciate that certain regular correspondents will itch to write and point out that, technically, the second bottle of each of these wines should rate higher than the first one, being the cheaper, but this refinement is beyond my patience to tolerate. However, I am not intolerant of the fact that there are people who find it undignified to shop for wine while pushing a steel trolley and who find paying the paltry sum of £3.50 for a bottle of wine beneath them. For these folk, then, there is Oddbins and Landmark Overlook Chardonnay 1998. This svelte Californian performs like a Meursault - no, no, too modest, let us say Montrachet - of a magical vintage. It exhibits beautiful wood and fruit harmony, rates 17 points and costs £14.49.

You are not required to spend this much at Oddbins in order to get a fine chardonnay, let me add. Fairview Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £5.99), for example, is the most elegant expression of its kind in the Cape for the money, with superbly poised fruit and a lingering, yoghurty finish. Casablanca Santa Isabel Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £6.99), from Chile, meanwhile, has a superb woody polish to its rich fruit, which maintains an even flow of substance and style, lingering and subtly lush, throughout its whole chic performance. Fairview 'Oom Pagel' Semillon 1999 (16.5 points, £6.99) parades utterly compelling fruit, marvellously complete and incisive, plus it has a touch of mystery that doesn't quite achieve spiciness. This is a richly engaging wine, as is the rosé from same estate - Fairview Goats do Roam Rosé 2000 (16 points, £4.99) - which is, to my palate, the tastiest rosé for less than a fiver in the land.

It is also, I would dare guess, far more like a crunchy red burgundy that its distant relative that was once labelled as such. Two incorrigibly modern aspects to this wine, however, are that, to acquire this superb 16-point (out of 20) pinot at that absurd price, you have to buy two bottles and visit a supermarket. The supermarket is Somerfield, and, until September 5, it has a 'buy one bottle, get the second at half price' offer on certain wines. I make no apologies for the fact that I am practising additional recycling, seeing as six of them, including the richly elegant Cono Sur (normal price £4.79), have appeared in this column before. The other five recycled wines are Chilean Merlot 1999 (17 points, normally £4.49), Cabernet Sauvignon/Merlot Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, normally £3.99) from Chile, Argentine Sangiovese 1999 (17 points, normally £4.29), Chilean Semillon Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, normally £3.99) and Bright Brothers Argentine Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, normally £4.29). Buying two bottles makes the price risible. The cheapies not seen in this column before are four in number: Argentine Tempranillo 1999 (16 points, normally £3.99) outguns rioja with the brilliance of its tannins and creamy richness; Cabernet Sauvignon Vina La Rosa 1999 (16.5 points, normally £4.49) has warmth and generosity of the fruit, tannins that are meaningful enough, and also the beauty of subtle wood touches; Argentinian First Ever Shiraz 2000 (16 points, normally £4.49) competes with anything Australian, though it is more darkly savoury; and Cono Sur Viognier 1999 (16 points, normally £4.99) offers delicious apricot fruit with a touch of apple and pineapple - this wine is in limited distribution, as not a lot of it is produced. I appreciate that certain regular correspondents will itch to write and point out that, technically, the second bottle of each of these wines should rate higher than the first one, being the cheaper, but this refinement is beyond my patience to tolerate. However, I am not intolerant of the fact that there are people who find it undignified to shop for wine while pushing a steel trolley and who find paying the paltry sum of £3.50 for a bottle of wine beneath them. For these folk, then, there is Oddbins and Landmark Overlook Chardonnay 1998. This svelte Californian performs like a Meursault - no, no, too modest, let us say Montrachet - of a magical vintage. It exhibits beautiful wood and fruit harmony, rates 17 points and costs £14.49. You are not required to spend this much at Oddbins in order to get a fine chardonnay, let me add. Fairview Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, £5.99), for example, is the most elegant expression of its kind in the Cape for the money, with superbly poised fruit and a lingering, yoghurty finish. Casablanca Santa Isabel Chardonnay 1998 (16.5 points, £6.99), from Chile, meanwhile, has a superb woody polish to its rich fruit, which maintains an even flow of substance and style, lingering and subtly lush, throughout its whole chic performance. Fairview 'Oom Pagel' Semillon 1999 (16.5 points, £6.99) parades utterly compelling fruit, marvellously complete and incisive, plus it has a touch of mystery that doesn't quite achieve spiciness. This is a richly engaging wine, as is the rosé from same estate - Fairview Goats do Roam Rosé 2000 (16 points, £4.99) - which is, to my palate, the tastiest rosé for less than a fiver in the land.

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Vya
fields.trailText: Vya
fields.body:
You might think that all Martinis are wet. Not so - in general, yes, the drier the better, with the merest whisper of vermouth being allowed to wet the glass. But now enter the wet Martini, courtesy of Vya, a Californian vermouth made by maverick Californian winemaker Andrew Quady, who is best known for dreaming up drinks in his hot tub. The taste is so superior, maintains Mr Q, that you should serve it one-third extra dry to two-thirds gin (I prefer a mix of 1:4) or mixed half-and-half with his sweet vermouth (a 'French Kiss'). Like most vermouths, Vya is made from a fortified base wine (in this case, colombard and orange muscat) flavoured with herbs and flowers, but it has a really citrussy taste. And the bottles are drop-dead gorgeous.

So who drinks it, apart from Andy's fellow hot-tub aficionados? Well, it's unaccountably popular with cigar smokers, according to Ranald Macdonald of the Boisdale bar, Belgravia. You can also order it from Avery's of Bristol (01275 811100) at £12.90 a bottle.

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: If I'd known you were coming...

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: If I'd known you were coming...
fields.standfirst: 'Amazed to discover that Fred is not, as I suspected, exclusively gay...'
fields.trailText: 'Amazed to discover that Fred is not, as I suspected, exclusively gay...'
fields.body:
Home alone, as son is in Amsterdam and rest of family in Gatehouse-of-Fleet. Have consumed large quantity of stone fruits and am only halfway into my first crucifying wave of intestinal cramp when doorbell rings and am confronted with Tom, erstwhile lover, now Ex-Spouse's second ex-wife's co-habitee. Cannot help reflecting that life would have been much easier in 1849 - although lack of water closets a major inconvenience.

Tom is also home alone. Elaine has fled from their decaying Georgian building site to spend a few days with her vile child, Sandy (my ex's sprog), and her parents (my ex's ex-in-laws).

"I was hoping you'd be here." Tom sprawls on the sofa looking glassy-eyed.

Wonder if this is lust or merely fatigue. Wonder if he is wondering if I still fancy him. Wonder if I do. If I'd known he was going to call, I would never have eaten all those apricots. I might even have combed my hair or applied lip gloss, thus making the mistaken leap from authentic old crone to sad old slapper.

Wonder if he still fancies me. Although I do not really fancy him any more, it would be diverting if he could hurl himself to the floor and assure me he had never ceased to long for me with a fiery throbbing in his loins.

"Any chance of a cup of tea?" He cocks an eyebrow. I find myself hoping it's the only organ that will be subjected to hydraulics. I go to the kitchen and find myself wishing he hadn't followed me.

"How are things with Elaine?" I enquire breezily, but even as he launches into a self-pitying aria of misogyny, I am already fantasising about my next trip to the loo.

"The wonderful thing about you, Dulcie, is that you're so easy-going." He smiles wistfully at me. He's got fatter and has lost quite a bit of hair. It's a terrible thing when your toy-boys start to look middle-aged. "Tell me," he goes on, "is there anyone in your life right now?"

Inform him crisply that not only am I celibate, but I intend to remain that way, and wish I had realised long ago what a self-destructive waste of time lurve is.

The doorbell rings. Years ago, Tom and I would have hesitated, torn between guilt and terror, our hearts thudding in unison. He would have whispered, "Don't answer it!" Now, I waddle mundanely to the door, glad of an interruption. Open door and behold divinely handsome man. For a split-second I am not sure where I have seen him before. Perhaps he is the fishmonger.

"Hi, Dulcie," he smiles, "sorry to disturb you, but there's a bit of a problem about my house in Umbria." Ah yes! It is Fred, whom I met at the gay barbecue.

Invite him in, and introduce him to Tom, who I assume he will fancy. Men's libidos are so much more persistent, poor loves. Or do I mean Dirty Beasts?

"Fred had offered me his house in Umbria," I explain, "but I think he's just about to have second thoughts."

"Oh no!" cries Fred, ogling Tom briefly before turning to me with an embarrassed, appealing smile. "The thing is, it looks as if I'll have to be there myself then. My Barcelona thing has fallen through, and I need to prepare for an exhibition in Perugia. But the house is quite big, and I promise that I won't get in your way." Assure him that Harriet and I will be delighted to have our party augmented by an extra person.

"Well, two extra people, actually," he says, "I hope you don't mind, but I'll have my son, Scott, with me. He's 17." Amazed to discover that Fred is not, as I suspected, exclusively gay, but has gone so far as to beget. Trip to Umbria is taking on an unexpected glamour. Begin to wish I was more liberally equipped with floaty linen togs, and plan to acquire some immediately. Longing for Toast and Ghost, like some American tourist planning a tour of British castles.

We all sit down to Earl Grey, and I cannot help observing that Tom is looking cheesed-off. While it does seem rather cheaply triumphant to feel pleased about this, I decide I will, anyway. One has to take one's pleasure where one can, these days. But Umbria? Who knows?

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Pete Wylie
fields.trailText: Pete Wylie
fields.body:
Pete Wylie, 41, was born in Liverpool. In the 70s, he formed The Crucial 3 with Julian Cope and Ian McCulloch. By 1979, Cope and McCulloch had formed Teardrop Explodes and Echo & The Bunnymen, respectively, and Wylie was lead singer of Wah!, who had a hit single with The Story Of The Blues in 1983. Wylie's career over the past decade has been chequered, however, in part due to the effects of a near-fatal accident. This year, he released a new album, Songs Of Strength And Heartbreak, and his single, Heart As Big As Liverpool, was adopted by Liverpool FC.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Ha! Don't toy with me!

What is your greatest fear?
No love.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Kenneth Williams (read the diaries!).

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Inability to reveal pain; flakiness.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Underestimating me.

What makes you depressed?
Everything.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Everything about me is embarrassing.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Elvis wallet; love; hard-on.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Opening my gob.

How did you vote in the last election?
With my heart (ie, Labour).

How will you vote in the next election?
With my head (ie, I won't).

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Consistency.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes. I love you.

What is your greatest regret?
They're all great.

How do you relax?
I often ask myself.

How often do you have sex?
All the time.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Different parents.

What would your motto be?
'If I can dream.'

What keeps you awake at night?
My dark secret.

How would you like to die?
I'll try anything once.

Do you believe in life after death?
I'm not even sure about before.

How would you like to be remembered?
Differently from the reality.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
It's okay to be gay.

fields.headline: Raising a glass to Zizou
fields.standfirst: 'In poll after poll, a majority of French voters admitted to holding 'racist ideas'. The Front National has made hatred legitimate'
fields.trailText: 'In poll after poll, a majority of French voters admitted to holding 'racist ideas'. The Front National has made hatred legitimate'.
fields.body:
Each summer L'Equipe, France's sporting daily, comes crammed with catastrophically bent axles and hamstrings as the Tour de France zips its way over col and val. Last month, the cycling news was interrupted by a momentous football story. The front page was given over to the features of a balding, no longer young-looking Arab with preternaturally grave features. One might have expected to see him standing on a dais, kitted out like Colonel Gadafy, surrounded by green and white flags; but he wore blue, and he held above him a cup. "C'EST LUI", the headline said exuberantly, explaining that Zinedine Zidane had been voted not just best sportsman, but most popular Frenchman in the nation's annual poll.

It isn't easy to elicit love, or even respect in France, and politicians rarely do. Brigitte Bardot was admired until she started telling people not to eat steak. Johnny Hallyday's epic bouts of pharmacological abuse (not his songs, one hopes) kept his flame alive. But Zizou, as he is affectionately called, is the first North African or black Frenchman to be thus honoured.

In 1998, just after the World Cup, I took a bus from the centre of Marseille to Les Tarterets, the tatty 60s cité where Zidane was born. I had been writing about the Front National and its effect on France. I was depressed by what I had seen, but Zidane's two goals had given me grounds for hope. It took more than an hour to get to there. I shook hands with his nieces, and was shown the mural in which he features. But I was made conscious of the reality of segregation in France when a crowd gathered around me, and I asked where they or their parents were from. There were Comoro Islanders, Togolese, Moroccans, Algerians, Antillais. No white French appeared to live in Les Tarterets.

I knew that 25% of Marseillais voted for the Front National. In poll after poll, a majority of voters admitted to entertaining "racist ideas" or displayed what might be termed, least uncharitably, a lack of hypocrisy in their attitudes to unwanted "foreigners" who had made their home in France. These attitudes were particularly strong among middle-aged males, petits commerçants and members of the police force. The Front had made hatred legitimate in France.

But the same polls recorded the growth of intermarriage, and with it the alteration of attitudes, among younger people. French-born Arabs and blacks were finding a new way of addressing the question of non-white French identity. In Le Havre, a social worker told me that racists were no longer the problem, or not entirely so. "We know the racists," he said. "We know who they are." The well-meaning leftish establishment was to blame, with its ideas of how everyone must integrate. It was not easy to integrate in France, particularly if you were born poor. If you were an Arab, it was next to impossible. When I asked about sport, he smiled: "The best thing would be for the whole French team to be composed of Arabs or blacks."

Were the French really "racist"? Were they any worse than their European neighbours? Half-French, I had grown up with the abstract tradition of republican rights. In France, I knew, anyone possessing a carte d'identité might be considered a citizen. But, alas, things were not so simple. It came as a shock to discover that the most ardent proponents of these rights also believed that their cherished Frenchness needed to be defended. They, too, like their Front enemies, dreaded the extinction of French culture.

You could hear rappeurs on every radio station. Sensitive films were made about the plight of beurs (young North Africans born in France), and literary festivals discussed in nuanced tones the poetics of estrangement. But the old core of Frenchness was unaffected. It seemed to me that a fear still stalked France: the idea that alien "Anglo-Saxon" notions such as multiculturalism, if pushed too far, might provoke wrath, adding to support for the racist Front. And this was why so little was allowed to change in France.

Sitting in the sun, with Zidane's image before me, I wondered whether I wasn't behind the times. There were fewer Le Pen posters, and the FN graffiti on autoroute bridges was faded. If the Paris papers were to be believed, it was no longer chic to be racist. But I was stopped short in my optimism. I knew that the FN was less attractive merely due to its squabbles; its militants were active in Provence and elsewhere. The banlieues were still toxic dumping grounds where hatred was cultivated. It would take more than one, or even 11 Zidanes to eradicate French resentment. Still, an Arab becoming most-loved Frenchman was cause for celebration, and I raised my glass to Zizou.

 The Voice Of Modern Hatred: Encounters With Europe's New Right, by Nicholas Fraser, is published by Picador. Alexander Chancellor returns next week.

fields.headline: It's showtime
fields.standfirst:
Imagine living in a show house filled with the best
a modish retailer can offer. Style overkill or
consumer heaven? Jennifer Kabat moves in to
find out.
fields.trailText:
Imagine living in a show house filled with the best
a modish retailer can offer. Style overkill or
consumer heaven? Jennifer Kabat moves in to
find out.
fields.body:
On paper, it sounds perfect: move into a show house in hip east London for a week and step into a new lifestyle. I had this fantasy of becoming a more glamorous, sexy version of myself. Here, I'd have the life, the parties and the glamour that I can't quite manage in the banal real world.

The house is on four floors, just off Old Street, all done up with sleek modern furniture. It's called Play Home - that's not "play" as in playing house, as I was doing by moving in there, but rather as in Playboy. The place is awash with black and red, all very retro. It was as if I'd stepped into Patrick Bateman's American Psycho flat circa 1986: black cotton sheets and red satin throw, plus, disconcertingly, a pair of translucent lace Agent Provocateur knicks and balcony bra lying casually on the red chaise longue.

The place was less of a home than a stage set for a fictional life - thick shag carpet, two Robin Day sofas (one that turned into a bed with the flick of a switch, giving it a very 007 gadgety feel), cocktail shakers, juicer. The study was hung with film posters from Barbarella, Bullitt and The Italian Job; and the paintings spread over each floor had a distinctly pop edge or an 80s feel. Books such as 60s Decorative Arts, Casino Design, Hip Hotels, plus various guides to poker, gambling and Denon stereos (one per floor) were all deployed to give a picture of just whose home this was - to the point of hyperbole, it seemed to me.

It took Suzanne Stankus, Play Home's stylist, the better part of two weeks to kit it all out, and by the end she had come up with a fiction for our resident. "He's a playboy with money and an international traveller," she says. "He's interested in design and won't buy just anything."

He likes quality, hence the solid oak bedroom set upstairs, though it doesn't quite seem his style. Only with the 1974 cult classic The Glass Inferno open on the bedside table, and the cufflinks, the half-empty tumblers and the red chaise lounge that looks like a leaning arm waiting to wrap around an unsuspecting date at the cinema, has he - or, rather, Stankus - customised it to his taste. "He likes books with 60s, 70s and 80s themes, and is into design, art, architecture and film," she says. "He's well-rounded and intellectual." After my week there, I am not sure that I'm his type.

Anyway, I had my mind on other things. I'd have a week in the perfect life, immaculate furniture, great stereos, and all within stumbling distance of Hoxton. But on my first night, when I was to start actually living there, I was scared of being lonely so I invited a friend and my husband to join me - so much for my idea of a swinging bachelorette/ Bond babe pad. That evening, we drank copiously - there was a well-stocked bar, but no tea bags or even a pint of milk - and ordered in Chinese. It all felt like NYC (a very good thing, since Friend and I are both ex-New Yorkers) - the sight of the tall NatWest building lit up in the distance meant we could almost pretend we were back there.

Then, early in the morning - at 5.34am, to be precise - I was really convinced that I was back in Manhattan. Trash pick-up. Just like when I lived in the Lower East Side and NY's Sanitation Department did its rounds at a criminally inhuman hour.

At a slightly more decent hour, Habitat, creators of Play Home, had scheduled a training video shoot at the house - the idea is that the house should tell the "story" of its autumn/winter collection. I wasn't involved - or invited - but the early arrival of camera crew and lighting folks didn't exactly encourage me to spread out as if I really owned the place. So, while the night before Friend, Husband and I had flopped on every sofa in the place (that is some seven couches) and lounged on the basement's black and red (natch) sheepskin rugs, I made sure to tidy up before I went to work. Also, that night I was having a dinner party - a catered dinner party (I cannot get it up to host such affairs in my real life).

People started arriving at 8pm; I'd greet them at the door with a "Welcome to my house", and after a glass of wine I actually believed it. Each floor served as a stage set for the evening. We started off in the ground-floor lounge, then graduated to the first-floor dining room and finally settled into the sex den. Well, there is no other way to describe the space, what with its red carpets, black walls, serpentine sectional sofa, card table and acres of sheepskin casually tossed about.

Now, there is obviously something a bit odd about moving into a show house and living on parade, though Play Home is more private than some: it's intended mainly for the trade and press. Taking over a real house creates a sense of voyeurism, explains Stankus, "like you're taking a sneaky look around someone's home". The difference this time is that the house will remain on show for a year instead of a couple days. That way, there's a context for the products that head of design Tom Dixon is developing, and you still get to keep up the voyeurism.

Every day, people were passing in and out of "my" doors from 9am until after 6pm. While I cannot say that this was exactly relaxing, it is in keeping with our current fad for observed living. Each decade seems to go through its homemaking fads: 50s to mid-60s, the suburbs; early 70s, communes; now, with television's Big Brother and Castaway, it's voyeurism.

Ironically, in Play Home, there wasn't a TV, which was a bit of a shame: it has the perfect couch-potato couch, complete with table for your crisps, pizza, beer, and I couldn't even try it out. But then, I was trying to go out every night.

Does Play Home have a place today? Since the late 50s, when the Ideal Home Show clocked its greatest number of visitors, the trend for show houses has died a slow death in this country. Now, show houses such as the "technology house" or the "home of the future" just seem quaint. Still, such spaces might be experiencing a revival: people actually moved into show houses at the Ideal Home Show this past year, with a radio station broadcasting reports - sounds familiar?

In other ways, too, Play Home is cutting edge, part of a new era of the seamless shopping experience, where retail and real life converge. Some New York stores are, in fact, real flats, only with everything inside for sale; Apartment even has a fictional couple "living" there. Given this, it should come as no surprise that Habitat is considering using Play Home as a store.

I was lucky: moving in for a week is a great way to try out the furniture. But, in the true spirit of voyeur-vision, I know everyone wants to know what didn't work, what went wrong. In truth, nothing. I just got homesick. After five days, I crept over to my own house and realised I missed all my familiar stuff, not to mention my cats. It can be a little demanding living in a showcase. So I moved out a day early.

Now, I'm happy to be back in SoLo (aka South London: well, you've got to try). Still, I know the sofa I want - Robin Day say my name.

The house is on four floors, just off Old Street, all done up with sleek modern furniture. It's called Play Home - that's not "play" as in playing house, as I was doing by moving in there, but rather as in Playboy. The place is awash with black and red, all very retro. fields.headline: Whose Europe is it anyway?
fields.standfirst: A new Europe is taking shape. More united, yes, but is it also increasingly xenophobic? Travelling from country to country, Linda Grant finds that the danger is less the resurgence of old-style fascism than the rise of 'modern', democratically elected, far-right parties, on the model of Jörg Haider's Freedom Party in Austria, whose aim is to turn the continent into a largely white fortress.
fields.trailText: A new Europe is taking shape. More united, yes, but is it also increasingly xenophobic? Travelling from country to country, Linda Grant finds that the danger is less the resurgence of old-style fascism than the rise of 'modern', democratically elected, far-right parties, on the model of Jörg Haider's Freedom Party in Austria, whose aim is to turn the continent into a largely white fortress.
fields.body:
It is May 9, Europe Day. Ragged, marching lines of schoolchildren enter the Klagenfurt town square waving the blue-and-gold flags of the European Union under a cloudless sky. Lining the square, Europe has set out its stalls: Euro pens; Euro hats; Euro stickers; and Roland Prinz, an executive of the Hypo Bank, in a tie decorated with samples of the new euro currency, is glowing with Euro-pride as he thrusts into people's hands postcards which, like his tie, depict the banknotes that in two years' time will replace the Austrian schilling. More and more children arrive, and the square is now filled with Euro people, who five years ago, before entry into the EU, were just Austrians living in the region of Carinthia, on the border of Italy and Slovenia.

One school has marked the event by giving each child a placard listing one of the rights enshrined in the European charter: freedom to work; freedom of religion; equality before the law, no censorship. Another has handed every pupil a home-made sign with the flag of a different country bearing the word peace in its language. Paix! Shalom! It's the opposite of a Nuremberg rally - informal, undisciplined, all the racist poison sucked out of it. Except that, according to the programme, the keynote speaker is to be Jörg Haider, governor of Carinthia and, until his resignation earlier that year, leader of the far-right Freedom Party, a man now tagged as Europe's most dangerous racist and xenophobe. (Haider, however, denies that his anti-immigration policies are xenophobic or racist.) Someone says he has decided not to turn up, after all. Where is he? In Vienna. Yet rumours persist that he might yet show, for he is, it's said, a law unto himself, who travels by helicopter and, like God, can be anywhere at short notice. And so we look up at the sky, hoping to hear a heavy drone.

Because of Haider, Austria is under EU sanctions, Israel has cut off diplomatic relations, tourism to the country has plummeted, and Austrians themselves, travelling abroad, are being greeted with a cold shoulder. Last year, on October 3, the Freedom Party (FPO) came second in the elections, throwing the country into political paralysis and sparking the largest protest demonstrations Austria has ever known. After months of agonising, in February the FPO was invited by the conservative People's Party, under the chancellorship of Wolfgang Schussel, to join a coalition, partly in fear that, if no government could be formed and fresh elections were held, the FPO would win outright with its appeal to nationalism and calls for measures to restrict the numbers of foreign workers allowed into the country.

A couple of months before the end of Europe's most catastrophically violent century, people were talking once more of a new menace coming out of Austria. Was Haider the new führer, an Austrian dictator who would provoke a world war? The comparison between Haider and Hitler is probably hysterical. Periods of history are not templates that can be imposed on each other. Austria has a population of eight million, and it took one of its foreign workers, an Israeli who runs a fast-food stand near a U-Bahn station in Vienna, to put things into perspective: "Germany in the 30s was a strong country; it had an army, an air force, a navy - things Hitler could use to get what he wanted," he said. "This place? What's Austria got? Nothing. It's a country of no consequence. It's got no military. No industry. Ski slopes - that's all."

We would be fools to believe that nazism is resurgent in Europe. Seventy years ago, totalitarianism was not imposed on the people; it was a political movement with mass and intellectual support. In his book, Dark Continent: Europe's Twentieth Century, the historian Mark Mazower describes the hostility to democracy among the thinkers and politicians of the right in the 20s who dismissed parliamentarianism as "sluggish, materialistic, unexciting and incapable of arousing the sympathy of the masses". The experiment in excitement was, of course, a disaster. Despite the endurance of a few skinheads, vandalism in Jewish cemeteries and an admiration for the racist and anti-Semite (formerly known as a historian) David Irving, there is no real taste for fascism in Europe these days. If there is anything to fear, we will find it rooted in democratically elected parties that want all the economic benefits of EU membership without the political consequences.

A new vision of a Europe is emerging. Borderless inside, it would form a largely white fortress to stand against the alien hordes of Muslims and former communists that menace it from the east, a place that pays lip-service to a tolerance of Jews while focusing on the main agenda, which is to keep immigrants out. In an opinion poll carried out by the French National Human Rights Commission earlier this year, 68% of respondents agreed with the statement: "The presence in France of people from non-European countries is disturbing."

In Denmark, Pia Kjaersgaard, leader of the ultra nationalist Danish People's Party with 18% support in opinion polls, regards Muslims as "as good a people as you or me, but it's a problem in a Christian country to have too many Muslims". According to the Organi-sation for Economic Co-Operation and Development, Denmark is one of the world's richest countries, with the least success in incorporating foreigners into the workforce. Souhail Ibrahim, a Palestinian who left the Social Democrats in January to form an immigrants' party, told a newspaper, "I don't think Austria will do half of what they're doing to foreigners in Denmark." In Belgium, the Flemish Vlaams Blok, based in its Antwerp stronghold where it attracts 15% of the vote in regional elections, calls for an immediate halt to immigration and the expulsion of unemployed immigrants who are there already. In Norway, the Progress Party, on 15%, wants to divert money spent on immigrants to pensions and health care for Norwegians. And in Britain, with no far right worth speaking of, Labour and Conservatives vie with each other to criminalise refugees and asylum seekers, driving them into detention camps.

Who will be at the helm of this new Europe? Across the other side of Klagenfurt town square, Roland Prinz formally introduces me to a smiling, courteous man with a neatly trimmed beard. He gives me his card, which is decorated with the flag of the European Union and the coat of arms of Carinthia, and identifies the bearer as Dr Johannes Maier, Landesmanndirektion, EU-Koordinationstelle: he is the civil servant who advises Haider on European affairs. Maier was delighted to speak to the Guardian, "a great newspaper" he said, in contrast to the response to previous efforts to get an interview with Haider himself.

We stood and shielded our eyes from the strong sunlight as the children paraded with their European flags. "Mr Haider is not understood in Europe," he told me. "Yes, he made mistakes in former times, but now he is trying to make policies like any other regional governor in Europe. Please remember, we are not against Europe, we are one of the weaker regions south of the Alpine line, one of the economically weakest regions of Austria and we profit from Europe - one billion schillings [£45 million] a year. But if we look at Europe as a whole, we see that we have no great politician any more, like Mitterand and Kohl, someone who sees Europe as more important than the interests of his country."

And is Haider that great man? "Mr Haider is a very intelligent politician," Maier replied. "He can speak very well and pronounce the problems of the people. He is one of the most important politicians now living."

In Haider's 1995 treatise, a book called The Freedom I Mean, he sets out his vision not just for Austria but for Europe, and so for us, too: "The concept of a 'multicultural society' has become an ideology," he writes. "Any policy of immigration must insist on assimilation and adaptation to the culture and norms of the indigenous population... Especially in education we have to defend Christian values. As more immigrants bring their children into western Europe, the indigenous population is slowly being substituted by aliens. It's hard to understand why Catholic bishops and clerics march in the streets defending a multi-cultural utopia when the threat to Christianity is so obvious...

From 1989-1992, 10,400 new jobs were created in eastern Austria and all of them were filled by cheap foreign labour. At the same time employment of Austrians declined by 1,300... For [our ruling politicians] it's more important to experiment with our youth as guinea pigs in abstract, multicultural programmes."

And finally, in a grand sign-off: "Our movement seeks to rally the friends of freedom to regenerate the old democracies and inspire the new. Our enemies are legion both in eastern Europe and the west, where the threats are more subtle and insidious. The road will not be easy, but the rewards will be worth the struggle. That is the challenge for Austria. That is the vision for Europe. That is the freedom I mean."

Does this sound familiar - particularly the invocation of some hazily defined "enemies" on to whom the reader can pin any label he chooses?

What is the Freedom Party? It can protest as much as it likes, but the records show that it is directly descended from Austrian National Socialism. In 1945, there were 500,000 registered Nazis in the country. Deprived of the vote until the 1949 election, they formed such a formidable force that neither Conservatives nor Social Democrats dared ignore them, and considerable numbers were absorbed into these two main parties.

Immediately after the election, Austria's Nazis organised their own party, the Association of Independents, which split in 1955 but re-formed itself one year later as the Freedom Party. Haider's father, Robert, had joined the Hitler Youth in 1929 and later became a member of the Austrian National Socialists, joining the FPO on its formation. His son became party secretary in Carinthia in 1976 and, supported by the party's most right wing elements, overthrew its liberal wing to become leader in 1986. The last of the liberals left the FPO in 1993. In 1994, according to the Documentation Centre for Austrian Resistance, the FPO campaigned against Austria joining the EU "using theories of worldwide conspiracies connected with barely concealed anti-semitic arguments".

The FPO's success in recent years is not necessarily because Austria's voters are covert Nazis but because of the corruption of the two main parties, the Conservatives and the Social Democrats, who have shared power continuously since the end of the war.

What alternative do Haider and the FPO offer? A few days before I arrived in Carinthia, I sat in the office of the Documentation Centre's director, Wolfgang Neugebauer, the son of a former lieutenant in the SS, who has spent much of his life documenting Austria's Nazi past. He is a spare, blond man who at school, in the 50s, had come under the influence of socialists and somehow wrenched himself away from his father's fascism.

"Haider is a right wing extremist," he said. "He is a racist and xenophobe. Not everyone in the party has the same opinions [as he does], but this is a führer party, a leader party, and he dominates it. After his retirement at the party congress, he still remains the most important politician in the party, and I'm sure that in the next elections he will be a candidate for the Federal Chancellorship. I am not afraid of some small Nazi groups in Austria. The greater danger is the coalition between a party like the FPO, with strong anti-immigrant and xenophobic policies, and a conservative party, and such developments can take place in other countries, too. Such a coalition can realise policy where small groups of extremists can't."

Would Haider's election as Chancellor be comparable to the election of Hitler in 1933? "No, I don't think so," he replied. "This is not possible in Europe in this time, but I think he will try to realise his propaganda in the field of foreign labourers and immigrants. There will be a stop to further immigration and, perhaps, the expulsion of refugees. And there will be some reduction in freedom of opinion by cutting the subsidies for newspapers."

In Vienna, I bought a copy of the Economist, because its cover story was about Europe's need for more immigrants. Because of the ageing of the baby boom generation, it stated, "Europe's working population is falling, while Europeans' aspirations to do only clean, sedentary, well-paid jobs are constantly on the rise." It described a new sort of migrant, a "labour tourist", who shuttles "resourcefully back and forth across an EU border, usually from eastern Europe into Germany and Austria, and often earns a living in the Union to support a family outside it."

Economically, foreign workers are exactly what Europe needs but, to the Economist writer, this is being hampered by Europe's failure to adjust to being a continent of immigration, such as America or Australia, instead of a continent of nation states. Europe is currently desperate for workers trained in hi-tech skills, which India is now producing in huge numbers, but would-be emigrants are reluctant to go to Germany, where they are only offered short-term contracts with no right to bring their families. America pays more, and offers them and their families citizenship.

The two men I bought the magazine from were victims of this myopia. They were immigrants from India. They had come 10 years ago on student visas to gain degrees in business studies, leaving their wives at home, and, like many non-white entrants to the country, had never been able to turn that initial entry into a work permit. One of them explained how the system operated: "You apply for a job, and the boss of the company will give you a paper for the government labour office and they should give you permission to work, but a lot of people have been living here for up to eight years and every time they go to the government office, they say no, and this is much more common for Indians and Africans than for Yugoslavs." One of the anomalies of the new borderless Europe is that its non-citizens do not share the right to work in other EU countries. The two newspaper sellers were effectively resident in Austria, but not the EU.

The only way they had found to earn a living was to work for a firm, which required them to take 100 copies a day of a newspaper called Kronen Zeitung, the country's most popular paper, similar in its appeal to our own Daily Mail. They were expected to sell 80 of these; if there was a shortfall, they had to pay for the unsold copies themselves. Being forced to sell Kronen Zeitung was a humiliation: "The paper is always against foreigners. Every day there's more propaganda, and nobody talks about it, not the Social Democrats, not the Greens. They are always writing about Africans, saying they are drug dealers." Abuse and racist attacks from neo-Nazis wasn't the main problem. One of the men showed me the apartment rental ads in Kronen Zeitung and pointed out the line in almost every one that said, "Austrians only". They saw racism as sewn into the very fabric of the country.

While we were talking, a man who was looking at Rolling Stone could no longer contain himself. "In my opinion, Kronen Zeitung is a newspaper which manipulates everything, including photos," he said. He explained that recently the paper had run a picture of an anti-Freedom Party demonstrator hitting a policeman. A week or so later, it was exposed as the juxtaposition of two separate photographs. "If you manipulate photographs and no one complains, what kind of a country is this?" he asked.

His name was Edward Boehler, he was 36, a veteran of the anti-Haider demonstrations, and he worked for an advertising agency. I asked him why people his age voted for the FPO. "These are the new yuppies who are interested in their careers and not in immigrants," he said. "They see themselves as the cool, clever people of the new century. They're not really interested in the roots of the Freedom Party. For them, it's the party that takes us very fast into the chic future. For myself, I would be very glad if in 10 or 20 years' time, Austria didn't exist any more. It's just a region. But I don't think many Austrians think this."

In Britain, we are used to thinking of the right and the far right in a particular way: little Englanders, nostalgic for Britain's long-lost greatness, insular, conservative. In Austria, the reverse is true. Boehler's description of the FPO supporters' amputation of history helped me understand a puzzling conversation I'd had the night before over a drink in the area of Vienna known as the Bermuda Triangle, a maze of streets heaving with bars and restaurants, and full of the hip young people of Vienna, indistinguishable from their counterparts in London's Camden Town or New York's East Village.

Here, I thought, I would hear the voice of young Austria, the anti-Haider forces who have led the demonstrations. So, sitting at a table outside the Casablanca bar, I asked the people at the next table, six old schoolfriends, all in their mid-20s, about Europe. They were all for it. They understood implicitly the advantage of being able to work and travel in other countries. Yet they confirmed that, politically, they were on the right and one of them, the most articulate, was an economics student who was sympathetic to the FPO.

"Haider says we must be newer," said Markus. "The FPO is not racist. If they were, do you think I would have voted for them? It's a democratic party, and here in Austria we are a democracy. I know people who went to the demonstrations and it's their democratic right - in Austria, everyone has the right to say what they want." The other five nodded in agreement. The only girl with them said, "If the FPO makes mistakes, they will not be in parliament." Once again, I understood how it was possible to build a party of the far right among people who consider themselves to be the same as their peers in other European countries, not special, or different, or secretly plotting a campaign for world domination.

But what about the FPO's Nazi past? Had they studied the legacy of fascism in school? They all insisted that they had. As for the FPO, Markus pointed out, "Most of the higher national socialists after the war went into the socialist and conservative parties. All the old Nazis were integrated without questions. It's strange, of course, but it's like in Russia with the communist party [some of whose members are now in government], and it was the same with us in 1945." When they themselves raised the question of immigrants, it was the refugees from the former Yugoslavia that concerned them.
